28E AGREEMENT
FOR THE ADMINISTRATION/MANAGEMENT
of Workforce development in Region 7
This 28E Agreement (Agreement) is made and entered into this 1st day of July, 2010, and 
ending on June 30, 2011, by and between the lowa Workforce Development (IWD) and
Hawkeye Community College (HCC). The parties agree as follows:
Section 1.
Purpose.  The purpose of this Agreement is to establish a procedure for hiring a
Regional Iowa Works Director in Region 7 and to provide for the employment and
terms of employment of the Regional lowa Works Director.
Section 1.1
Identity of the Parties: Iowa Workforce Development (IWD), which is a duly
created state department, is authorized, among other things, to provide and fund
workforce development programs. IWD's state administrative address is 1000
East Grand Avenue, Des Moines, Iowa 50319. Hawkeye Community College is 
authorized among other things, to provide and fund workforce development
programs. HCC's address is 1501 East Orange Road, Waterloo IA 50704. This
Agreement does not create any separate legal or administrative parties or
entities.
Responsibilities of Parties.
Section 2.
2.1
IWD shall provide administration/management services for HCC employees
located at the Waterloo Workforce Development Center and any satellite centers
in Region 7. These services will be provided by the Regional Iowa Works
Director, who shall be employed by IWD. The Regional lowa Works Director shall
provide all administrative/management services in accordance with all applicable
federal, state, local laws and regulations, merit system rules, and collective
bargaining agreement rules and practices. (See attachment A for complete list of
documents currently included in all Regional and PROMISE JOBS Master
Agreements.)
2.2.
Policy guidelines for Workforce Development Center operations will be jointly
agreed upon by appropriate HCC and IWD representatives and will comply with
applicable personnel and labor relations policies of both entities.
In the absence of the Regional Iowa Works Director, personnel issues involving 
2.3
IWD employees which require the involvement of IWD administration will be the
responsibility of the Division Administrator for the Workforce Development Center
Administration (WDCA) or their Designee.
2.4
HCC shall permit the Regional lowa Works Director to participate in staff
development, training, and management meetings required by IWD.
IWD shall be responsible for the payment of the Regional lowa Works Director's
2.5
salary and personnel benefits according to its existing policies. IWD shall be
solely responsible for the payment of all applicable federal and state withholding
taxes, social security taxes, workers compensation, employer's liability and
Page 1 of 11
Region 7 Regional Iowa Works Director 28e April 2010
unemployment compensation taxes. All fringe benefits provided the Regional
lowa Works Director will be in accordance with IWD policy.
2.6
Selection, evaluation and termination of the Regional Iowa Works Director will be
within the joint discretion of HCC and IWD.  HCC shall provide IWD with its
comments concerning potential candidates for the Regional lowa Works
Director's position and shall periodically provide IWD with its comments
concerning the performance of the Regional lowa Works Director in order to
assist IWD with its evaluation. IWD will notify HCC when the evaluation is being 
developed, a deadline for HCC comment submission, and a signed copy of the
completed evaluation for HCC records.
2.7
IWD shali provide staff development and training services to ensure the Regional
Iowa Works Director is knowledgeable of IWD practices, procedures, and
policies.
Reserved for future use.
2.8
The Workforce Development Center Regional lowa Works Director.
Section 3.
3.1
The Regional Iowa Works Director shall, at all times, be considered the employee
of IWD and not an employee of HCC. (See attachment B for Regional lowa Works
Director job description.)
3.2
The Regional Iowa Works Director shall consult with the WDCA Division
Administrator or their Designee and the Department of Administrative Services
(DAS) personnel officer assigned to IWD before taking any disciplinary action
against any IWD employee.  Joint review by both the Regional lowa Works Director
and the WDCA Division Administrator or their Designee will precede any
performance appraisal and related action for any IWD employee.
When notifying IWD of any annual or sick leave requests, the Regional lowa Works
3.3
Director shall also inform HCC.
3.4
The Regional Iowa Works Director shall attend all regularly scheduled meetings of
the IWD regional managers and joint administrators, as well as any other required
meeting called by the WDCA Administrator or their Designee. The Regional lowa
Works Director will inform the WDCA Administrator or their Designee of conflicts
that may prohibit attendance.
Compensation.
Section 4.
Reserved for future use.
Section 5.
Effective Date of Agreement.  This Agreement shall be effective when the
following conditions are completed:
5.1
The Agreement is signed by IWD and HCC.
5.2
The Agreement or a recordable form of this Agreement is recorded by the Polk and
Black Hawk County Recorders.
Page 2 of 11
Region 7 Regional lowa Works Director 28e April 2010
5.3
The Agreement is filed with lowa Secretary of State.
Term of Agreement.  This Agreement shall be in effect beginning July 1, 2010,
Section 6.
and ending June 30, 2011, with the option to renew for two (2) additional one-year
terms. This Agreement may be terminated at any time, by either party, for any
reason upon at least sixty (60) days written notice in advance of the specified
termination date.
Termination.  This Agreement may be terminated in any of the following
Section 7.
circumstances:
a)  At IWD or HCC discretion, without cause, after sixty (60) days written notice
to the other party by FAX with hard copy to follow by overnight delivery.
b)  As a result of default under this Agreement.
c)   As a result of the termination or reduction of funding to IWD.
d)  Due to bankruptcy, insolvency, or receivership.
Authorization.  Each party to this Agreement represents and warrants to the other
Section 8.
that (1) it has the right, power, and authority to enter into and perform its
obligations under this Agreement; and (2) it has taken all requisite action
(corporate, statutory, or otherwise) to approve execution, deliver, and performance
of this Agreement, and this Agreement constitutes a legal, valid, and binding
obligation upon itself in accordance with its terms.
The Vice President of Academic Affairs of HCC and the IWD Administrator of the
Division of Workforce Development Center Administration will be responsible for
administration of this Agreement.
Section 9.
Default.
The occurrence of any one or more of the following events shall constitute cause
9.1
for IWD or HCC to declare the other party in default of its obligations under this
Agreement:
a)  Non-performance of this Agreement.
b)  A failure of either party to make substantial and timely progress toward
performance of the Agreement.
c)   A failure of either party's work product and services to conform with any
specifications noted herein.
d)   A repeated exhibition of defects in the services delivered by either party,
causing serious disruption of use or downtime over a six month period.
e)  A breach of provisions related to intellectual property.
A failure to make payments required under this Agreement.
f) 
g) A breach of any term of this Agreement.
9.2
HCC or IWD shall not be considered to be in default under this
Agreement if its performance is delayed or made impossible by an Act of
God, floods, fires, strikes, a freight embargo or similar events; but in each
such case, the delay or impossibility must go beyond the reasonable control
and without the fault  of HCC or IWD. In event of such delay, the
scheduled date of delivery shall be extended on a day-to-day basis until
delivery of performance is possible and feasible.
Page 3 of 11
Region 7 Regional Iowa Works Director 28e April 2010
9.3
HCC shall not be liable for indirect, special, or consequential damages
resulting from a breach of this Agreement.
9.4
Notice of Default. IWD or HCC shall issue a written notice of default
providing therein a sixty (60) day period in which the other party shall have an
opportunity to cure, provided that cure is possible and feasible. If, after opportunity
to cure, the default remains, IWD or HCC may do one of the following:
a) Exercise any remedy provided by law,
b) Terminate this Agreement as set forth in Section 7 of this Agreement.
Waiver.  Except as specifically provided for in a waiver signed by duly authorized
Section 10.
representatives of IWD and HCC, failure by either party at anytime to require
performance by the other party or to claim a breach of any provision of the
Agreement shall not be construed as affecting any subsequent breach or the right 
to require performance with respect thereto or claim a breach with respect thereto.
Section 11.
Notices.  Notices under this Agreement shall be in writing and delivered to the
representative of the party to receive notice (identified below) at the address of the
party stated below:
Iowa Workforce Development

delivery of such notice:
 By personal delivery; or
(a)
(b)

(and not the date of mailing).  Failure to "receipt" shall constitute delivery; or
(c) 
By recognized overnight delivery service, such as Federal Express or UPS.
Section 12.
Indemnification.
Indemnification of IWD.  To the extent allowed by applicable constitutional and
12.1
statutory law (including without limitation lowa Code Chapter 670), HCC agrees to
indemnify and hold IWD harmless from any and all liabilities, damages,
settlements, judgments, costs and expenses, including reasonable attorney's fees
of the lowa Attorney General's office, and the costs and expenses and reasonable
attorney's fees of other counsel IWD may retain, related to or arising from:
Page 4 of 11
Region 7 Regional lowa Works Director 28e April 2010
Property damage, personal injury, death, loss costs, expense or other harm
(a)
arising out of, resulting from, relating to, or connected with, any act or
omission by HCC, its divisions, subsidiaries, employees, agents, elected or
appointed officials, officers, and directors in fulfilling this Agreement; or
Claims for infringement of patents, trademarks, trade secrets, or copyrights
(b) 
arising from this Agreement.
Provided that HCC accepts responsibility for Indemnification under this Section 12,
HCC, at its sole expense, shall be entitled to control the prosecution, defense and
settlement of, any proceeding, litigation or claim incident to any of the foregoing
with counsel of its own choosing and IWD will cooperate in connection with any
such proceeding.
12.2
Indemnification of HCC. To the extent allowed by applicable constitutional and
statutory law (including without limitation lowa Code Chapter 669), the State of
lowa shall indemnify HCC under this Agreement, and its directors, officers, elected
and appointed officials, and employees for any claim, loss, liability, damage or
expense (including reasonable attorney's fees) which may be asserted against it or 
them by a third party, by reason of any action taken or not taken by IWD in
connection with the Agreement, and which does not arise from the breach of this
Agreement, negligence, fraud, or misconduct of HCC, its employees, directors, 
officers, agents, elected or appointed officials.
Conditions. Any indemnification hereunder shall be subject to the prior
(a) 
approval of an appropriation of funds by the General Assembly and Governor
of the State of lowa and the allotment of funds by the lowa Department of
Management as may be required by law, and HCC shall furnish the State with
a detailed estimate of any expected claim, loss, liability, damage and/or
expense for the State's use in obtaining such approval and appropriation or
allotment. Indemnification is further conditioned on the following:
HCC shall promptly give the State of lowa written notice (by overnight
(i)
mail) of any expected, threatened, or actual claim, loss, liability, damage
or expenses.
(ii)
HCC and the above-mentioned indemnified, shall at all times cooperate
with the State, both in document production and personnel time.
To the extent that HCC is indemnified under this section, the State shall
(iii)
have the right to hire and direct counsel in the defense of HCC.
(iv) To the extent that HCC is indemnified under this section, the State shall,
after consultation with HCC, make all decisions regarding any claim,
threatened litigation, litigation, or settlement in connection with any claim,
loss, liability, damage or expense which may be asserted against HCC
and/or the above referenced indemnified.
(v) The indemnification provisions contained herein, in no way limits the
State from asserting a sovereign immunity defense as allowed by
Page 6 of 11
Region 7 Regional Iowa Works Director 28e April 2010
applicable state or federal law to any claim made in conformance with
this section.
Section 13.
No Indemnification.  The State of lowa shall not be responsible for action taken
by HCC, its employees, officers, elected or appointed officials, or its agents in
violation of any federal, state or municipal law or in violation of a law of a foreign 
country.  HCC shall not be responsible for action taken by the State of lowa, its
employees, officers, elected or appointed officials, or its agents in violation of any
federal, state or municipal law or in violation of a law of a foreign country.
Obligations Beyond Agreement Term. This Agreement shall remain in full force
Section 14.
and effect to the end of the specified term or until terminated or cancelled pursuant 
to this Agreement. All obligations of IWD and HCC incurred or existing under the
Agreement as of the date of expiration, termination, or cancellation will survive the 
expiration, termination, or cancellation of this Agreement.
Third Party Beneficiaries.  There are no third party beneficiaries to this
Section 15.
Agreement. This Agreement is intended only to benefit IWD and HCC.
Section 16.
Assignment and Delegation.  This Agreement may not be assigned, transferred,
or conveyed in whole or in part by either party without the prior written consent of 
the other party.
Section 17.
Choice of Law and Forum.  The terms and provisions of this Agreement shall be
construed in accordance with the laws of the State of Iowa.  Any and all litigation or
actions commenced in connection with this Agreement shall be brought in
Waterloo, lowa, in the lowa District Court for Black Hawk County. This provision
shall not be construed as waiving any immunity to suit or liability which may be
available to the State or to HCC.
Section 18.
Entire Agreement. This Agreement represents the entire agreement between the
parties and neither party is relying on any representation which may have been
made which is not included in this Agreement.
Writing Required. This Agreement may be amended or modified only in writing 
Section 19.
signed by all parties.
Section 20.
Headings or Captions.  The section headings or captions are for identification
purposes only and do not limit or construe the contents of the sections.
Not a Joint Venture.  Nothing in this Agreement shall be construed as creating or
Section 21.
constituting the relationship of a partnership, joint venture, or other association of
any kind or agent/principal relationship between the parties.  Each party shall be
deemed to be an independent contractor contracting for services and acting toward
the mutual benefits expected to be derived from this Agreement.  No party, unless
otherwise specifically provided for in this Agreement, has the authority to enter into
any contract or create any obligation or liability on behalf of, in the name of, or
binding upon another party to this Agreement.
Section 22.
Cumulative Rights. The various rights, powers, options, elections, and remedies
of either party, provided in this Agreement, shall be construed as cumulative and
Page 6 of 11
Region 7 Regional lowa Works Director 28e April 2010
no one of them is exclusive of any rights, remedies or priorities allowed either party
by law, and shall in no way affect or impair the right of either party to pursue any 
other equitable or legal remedy to which either party may be entitled as long as any
default remains in any way unremedied, unsatisfied, or undischarged.
Severability.  If a provision of this Agreement is determined by a court of
Section 23.
competent jurisdiction to be invalid or unenforceable, such determination shall not 
affect the validity of enforceability of any other part or provision of this Agreement,
unless such invalid or unenforceable provision goes to the very essence of the 
Agreement.
Time is of the Essence. Time is of the essence with respect to the performance
Section 24.
of the terms of this Agreement.
Section 25.
Binding Effect.  All the terms, provisions, and conditions of this Agreement shall
be binding upon and inure to the benefit of the parties hereto and their respective
successors, assigns and legal representatives.
Section 26.
Counterparts.  The parties agree that this Agreement has been or may be
executed in several counterparts, each of which shall be deemed an original and
all such counterparts shall together constitute one and the same instrument.
Additional Provisions.  The parties agree that if an Addendum, Rider or Exhibit is
Section 27.
attached hereto by the parties, and referred to herein, then the same shall be
deemed incorporated herein by reference.
Section 28.
Further Assurances and Corrective Instruments.  The parties agree that they
will, from time to time, execute, acknowledge and deliver, or cause to be executed,
acknowledged and delivered, such supplements hereto and such further
instruments as may reasonably be required to carry out the express intentions of
the parties, as evidenced by this Agreement.
Section 29.
Administration/Additional Property.  No separate legal or administrative entity is
necessary to carry out the arrangement contemplated by this Agreement.  It is not
contemplated that any additional real or personal properly will be acquired by
either HCC or IWD in order to carry out the objectives in this Agreement.

CHAPTER 28E LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES CONTRACT BETWEEN
CHICKASAW COUNTY AND LAWLER
This Agreement is entered into this 20 day of May
__ . 20 14,
by and between Chickasaw County, through its Board of Supervisors, and the Chickasaw
County Sheriff, (collectively County), and the City of Lawler, through its City Council,
for the law enforcement services identified hereunder.
1. STATEMENT OF AGREEMENT
1 A. The City of Lawler (hereinafter City), in lieu of providing police protection services
as required by lowa Code, hereby elects to contract with the County for the provision of
law enforcement services on behalf of the City and its residents.
1B. The County agrees to provide law enforcement services to the City, through the
County's Sheriff and Sheriff's personnel, in response to requests made by the City, its
officers, employees, and agents and upon request, call or dispatch through Sheriff's E911
personnel to any residents or persons within the City.
2. LEGAL BASIS
2A. This Agreement is authorized by the provisions of Code of Iowa, Chapter 28E. The
purpose of this agreement is to provide law enforcement services for the City and to
discharge the City's obligation to provide law enforcement services for their citizens in
accordance with Chapter 372.4(2) of the Code of Iowa as interpreted by the lowa
Supreme Court in Johnson v. Allen, 569 N.W. 2d 143 (Iowa 1997), referencing Code of
Iowa Chapter 368
3. GENERAL LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES DEFINED
3A. Law enforcement services consists of routine, irregular, random, intermittent and
unpredictable patrol in the City or "as needed" patrol and investigation and all auxiliary
and technical service now provided by the Sheriff in support of patrol and investigation.
All references to law enforcement services contained in this Agreement are references
only to services that shall be delivered under the terms of this Agreement
4. DELIVERY OF SERVICES
4A. Service area. The Sheriff shall provide law enforcement services within the
corporate limits of the City.
14 March 14 / 19-1

Todd W. Miller, Chickasaw County Sheriff, 116 N. Chestnut Avenue, New Hampton, IA
50659 641 394 3121 (24 hours)
4B. Enforcement Responsibilities. It is agreed that the law enforcement services
performed will encompass only violations made criminal under the law defined by the
Code of lowa. Ordinances established by Chickasaw County will be enforced. No
enforcement will be undertaken for violations of City Ordinances.
4C. Delivery of Service. The delivery of law enforcement services to be provided by the
Sheriff will consist of routine, irregular, random, intermittent and unpredictable patrol in
the City so as to afford the maximum possible law enforcement to the City at those times
and in those places where crime is determined by the Sheriff most likely to occur; except
that upon special request of the City to the Sheriff, specially focused law enforcement
services may be requested upon particularized and identified need.
4D. Service Management. It is understood and agreed that the law enforcement officers
providing services to the City under this Agreement are County employees, and not
employees of the City. The Sherift's Deputies are solely subject to control, supervision,
and discipline of the Sheriff and under the Sheriff's law enforcement policies and
regulations, and employment rules and policies
4E. Responsiveness. The County's Sheriff and his Deputies will answer and
appropriately respond to calls for service made requesting law enforcement services and
provide immediate response to all E911 calls in which an emergency is claimed
threatening the lives, safety, and property of residents of the City or persons in the City.
1.
City agrees "calls for service" from their community will be prioritized
based on established rational law enforcement practices and based on
availability of Sheriff's personnel working any particular duty shift.
4F. Coordination. Pursuant to Iowa Code Section 28E.6 (1) (a), this Agreement does not
establish any separate legal entity. The administrators for this Agreement are the Sheriff
and Mayor of the City, a signatory to it.
4G. Resources. In consideration for the per capita rate charges described below, the
County and Sheriff agree that the law enforcement services to be provided include the
County's provision of fully equipped patrol cars with emergency lights, sirens, and radios
and other standard electronic telemetry; of law enforcement officers and deputies
appropriately selected and employed under County civil service, appropriately trained
and certified by the Iowa Law Enforcement Academy; of uniforms and all other personal
equipment necessary for the provision of law enforcement services; and for the
telephone, E911 and radio communications services made necessary under this
Agreement.
5. LIABLITY
5A. No agreement has been reached between the County and City concerning which
party is required to defend and indemnify the other party for claim or suit arising from
law enforcement services provided under this contract. That question is expressly
reserved for decision by the courts on an appropriate occasion.
14 March 14 / 19-1
2/4
Prepared by:
Todd W. Miller, Chickasaw County Sheriff, 116 N. Chestnut Avenue, New Hampton, IA
50659 641 394 3121 (24 hours)
6. PERSONNEL
6B. Employee Payment. The City shall not be liable for the direct payment of salaries,
wages, or other compensation to the County officers or employees providing law
enforcement services to the City.
7. FEES
7A. Total sum. The City shall pay to the County an annual sum for law enforcement
services delivered during the term of this Agreement. Said payment shall be made
semiannually on or before the 15th day of October and the 15th day of April of the
contract year. Said payment shall be made to the Auditor of Chickasaw County.
7B. Payment Plan. The City payment plan is attached in Section 11 of this Agreement.
7C. Adjustment. The County may adjust the total sum in accordance with changes in
costs of providing law enforcement services. The County shall notify the City in writing.
of each adjustment. Any adjustment will be done on an annual basis.
8. TERMS
8A. This Agreement will take effect on the 1st day of July, 20 \ and shall continue
through the 30th day of June 20 \ S and this Agreement may be renegotiated within
three (3) months prior to March 15th of any year as to any terms or particulars upon
request by any party.
8B. Unless terminated or renegotiated, this Agreement shall be renewed automatically for
successive terms of one (1) year. The Agreement may be terminated by either party by
giving the other party notice of its intention to withdraw, said notice being delivered to
the other party no later than one hundred eighty (180) days prior to the renewal of the 30th
day of June.
9. SPECIAL EVENTS
9A. In the event that the City, or an organization within the City, plans a "special" or
major event in the City, it shall notify the Sheriff at least three weeks, or twenty one (21)
days prior to the event. It is the City's burden, responsibility and expense to determine
the need for extra security personnel and employ the needed security personnel to be
present at a "special" or major event. The City shall be liable for all actions of the extra
security personnel and shall hold harmless, defend and indemnify the County for all acts
of the extra security personnel so employed by the City.
1.
A "special" or major event is defined as an event whether indoors or
outdoors, that is held on public property or streets, non-profit organization
property, or non-residential private property that can reasonably be expected
to cause a public gathering that is not part of the normal course of business or
pedestrian traffic at the location.
10. FILING WITH SECRETARY OF STATE
10A. This Agreement or any amendment, modification, or notice of termination shall be
filed with the Iowa Secretary of State in a manner specified in Iowa Code Section 28E.8.
Any amendment, modification, or notice of termination of this Agreement

10B. Additionally, upon execution of this Agreement, both the County and City shall

AGREEMENT FOR LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES
THIS AGREEMENT is entered into this _ / 2_ day of Ma 1 c.h __ , 2012, by and
between Chickasaw County, hereinafter referred to as the "County," and the City of
Lawler, Iowa, hereinafter referred to as the "City."
1. STATEMENT OF AGREEMENT
The County through the office of the Chickasaw County Sheriff, agrees to provide
general Law Enforcement services to the City and the City agrees to engage the County
through its Sheriff to provide such service in accordance with and subject to the terms of
this agreement.
2. LEGAL BASIS
This Agreement is authorized by the provisions of Chapter 28E, Code of Iowa (2009).
3. GENERAL LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES
General Law Enforcement Services consist of patrol and investigation and all
auxiliary and technical services now provided by the Sheriff's Department in support of
patrol and investigation. All references to General Law Enforcement services contained
in his agreement are references only to services that shall be delivered under the terms of
this agreement.
4. DELIVERY OF SERVICES
4.1 Service Area. The Sheriff shall provide General Law Enforcement services
within the corporate limits of the City.
4.2 Enforcement Responsibilities. The Sheriff shall enforce State statutes and City
and County ordinances. The Sheriff shall not be required to assume another law
enforcement duty or function not consistent with those customarily performed by the
Sheriff under the provisions of Section 331.651-331.660 of the Code of Iowa.
. 1.6
, 1.5
4.3 No extra charges shall be made for emergency calls or special events such as the
annually held Lawler Days.
4.4 There shall be a monthly report to the City regarding the hours worked and
activity.
4.5 Quantity of Service. The quantity of law enforcement services to be provided by
the Sheriff shall be no less than 25 hours a month.
4.6 The planning, organization, scheduling, direction, and supervision of the
Sheriff's personnel and all other matters incident to the delivery of general law
enforcement services to the City shall be determined by the Sheriff. The Sheriff shall
retain exclusive authority over the activities of his personnel working for the City.
4.7 Responsiveness. The Sheriff shall give prompt consideration to all requests of
the City regarding the delivery of general law enforcement services. The Sheriff shall
make every effort to comply with these requests if they are consistent with good law
enforcement practices.
4.8 Dispute Resolution. Any conflict between the parties regarding the extent or
manner of performance of the general law enforcement services to the City shall be
resolved by the Sheriff, whose decision shall be final and conclusive.
4.9 Communications. The Sheriff shall provide all emergency and regular radio and
telephone communications in regard to public safety for the City.
5. RESOURCES
Except as otherwise stipulated, the County shall furnish all labor, equipment,
personnel, facilities and supplies required to provide general law enforcement services to
the City. The City will furnish to the Sheriff a key to the City Hall, and the use of a room
there for conferences.
6. LIABILITY
6.1 County. The County shall assume liability for, defend against, secure and hold
harmless, the City from all costs and damages for injury to person or property caused by
the County or its employees.
6.2 City. The City shall assume liability for, defend against, secure, and hold
harmless the County from all costs or damages for injury to person or property caused by
the City or its employees.
".
in
7. PERSONNEL
7.1 Employee Status. All persons employed by the Sheriff in providing general law
enforcement services to the City shall be County officers or employees, and they shall not
have any benefit, status or right of City employment.
7.2 Payment. The City shall not be liable for the direct payment of salaries, wages,
or other compensation to County officers or employees providing general law
enforcement services to the City.
8. MUNICIPAL AGENCY
The City shall, concurrent with the execution of this agreement, enact any ordinance
required to give the County officer or employee engaged in general law enforcement
services to the City an official status required for the ordinary and adequate enforcement
of such ordinances of the City as may be appropriately enforced under the terms of this
agreement.
9. FEES
9.1 Total Sum. The City shall pay to the County a total sum of $14,795.00 annually
for general law enforcement services delivered during the term of this agreement. Said
payment shall be made semiannually on or before the 15th day of October and the 15th
day of April of the contract year.
9.2 If the City does not make payment within thirty (30) days after that date due, the
County may terminate this agreement. The city shall be liable for general law
enforcement services rendered to the time of termination.
10. TERM
This agreement will take effect on the 1st day of July, 2012, and shall continue
through the 30th day of June, 2013.

AGREEMENT
BETWEEN THE CITY OF MAURICE, IOWA AND SIOUX COUNTY, IOWA
RELATING TO THE PROVISION OF LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES
THIS AGREEMENT, consisting of two (2) pages, is made between the City of
Maurice, Iowa, a municipality of the State of Iowa (hereinafter "Maurice") and Sioux
County, Iowa (hereinafter "County").
WHEREAS, Maurice wishes to contract with County for law enforcement services
within the corporate limits of Maurice; and
WHEREAS such Agreements are authorized in Iowa Code §28E;
NOW THEREFORE, Maurice and County agree as follows:
l ) County agrees, through the Sioux County Sheriff ("Sheriff") to provide law
enforcement services within the corporate limits of Maurice, including but not
limited to the following:
a) Patrol, traffic enforcement and control, response to complaints or calls,
investigations, emergency service, service of civil documents, and other tasks
typically performed by a law enforcement agency.
b) Sheriff shall be responsible for administrative duties associated with the function
of said law enforcement services.
2) County shall furnish the necessary equipment and personnel to carry out the services
provided for in this agreement.
l
3) Maurice agrees to pay County for the law enforcement services provided by Sheriff.
The payment shall be in an amount to be determined by the Sheriff and the Board of
Supervisors of Sioux County as is necessary to carry out the law enforcement
functions stated in this agreement. Such payments shall be made to the Sheriff's
Office on a quarterly basis, payable as follows: July 1, 2013; October 1, 2013;
January 1, 2014; April 1, 2014. The total amount for this contract period has been
set at: $17,702.
4) This Agreement shall be irrevocable for the duration of the contract period.
Thereafter either party may discontinue participation by providing written notice to
the other no later than May 1st of the current year.
5) This agreement shall be effective on the 1st day of July, 2013 and shall run to the 1st
day of July 2014. Thereafter, at the option of the Maurice City Council, and the
Sioux County Board of Supervisors, with the consent of the Sheriff of Sioux County,
this agreement may be renewable for successive periods not to exceed one (1) year.

28E AGREEMENT AND CONTRACT BETWEEN CITY OF FOREST CITY, IOWA,
AND THE FOREST CITY AMBULANCE SERVICE
WHEREAS, the City of Forest City, Iowa (hereinafter referred to as (“City”) whose
address for the purpose of this Agreement is 305 North Clark Street, Forest City, IA 50436 and
The Forest City Ambulance Scrvice (hereinafter referred to as “FCAS”) whose address for the
purpose of this Agreement is 635 Hwy 9, Forest City, IA 50436 has had an ongoing relationship;
and.
WHEREAS, the parties hereto wish to set down in writing their agreement their
agreement as to the future funding of The Forest City Ambulance Service and the cities
Paramedic costs and budget; and,
NOW THEREFORE, it is agreed to as follows:
Article I. Revenues.
1. The parties hereto agree that the City will continue to support and fund the
paramedic costs.
2. During the term of this contract FCAS will pay the Paramedics for the wages
incurred by the Paramedics for on call pager hours backup shifts.FCAS will
be responsible for the administration associated with the payments of wages
including but not limited to monitoring and tracking timecards, payment of all
payroll taxes and the payment of the net wages to the Paramedics.
3. In addition FCAS will pay to the City 10% of Line 19 of the Form 990 filed
with the Internal Revenue Service.
4. Any amounts due under Paragraph No. 3. of this Article will be calculated and
a check issued to the City during June of the next succeedingyear after the end
of the calendar year beginning with the calendar year 2013.
5. During the term of this agreement the parties reserve the right to review the
payments made to the Paramedics under Article I.2 and mutually agree upon
changes in the amount paid per hour to the Paramedics for the wages incurred
by the Paramedics foron call pager hours backup shiftsas contained in this
Article I. Until amended pursuant to this Article FCAS agrees to pay $2.25
per hour for regular non-weekend and non-holiday shifts and $5.00 per hour
for regular weekend and holiday shifts.
Article II. Independent Contractor.
It is expressly agreed to by the parties that this contract is one of an Independent Contract
and nothing in this contract should be construed as a Joint Venture, partnership or any other form
of business other thanthat of an Independent Contractor.
Each party shall obtain a policy of General Comprehensive Liability Insurance which is
of a type applicable to the particular entity in an amount of not less than the current amount of
liability carried by the FCAS or $1Million Dollars per person and $2Million Dollars per
occurrence, whichever is less. The insurance shall be an "occurrence" type policy and shall, to
the extent allowed, name the other party as an additional insured to the extent a claim may arise
from or in the course of any mutual endeavor or location of injury.
Article III.
Terms of Agreement.
The entities agree that this Agreement is the complete agreement of the parties and
nothing further may be utilized to explain, contradict or nullify the agreement. The parties
further agree that this document is four (4) pages and encompasses Ten (10) numbered sections.
Each party has had ample opportunity to seek independent advice with regard to its terms.  If
there are to be any changes to this Agreement, they shall be done in writing and signed by all
entities.
Article IV.
Jurisdiction Venue and attorney fees.
In the event there are any disputes that arise between the entities, all entities hereby 
consent and agree to binding arbitration. All disputes shall be decided according to the laws of
the State of Iowa and the prevailing entity shall be entitled to reasonable attorney's fees.
Article V. 
Article Headings
The article headings contained in this Agreement are for reference purposes only and
shall not affect the meaning or the interpretation thereof.
Article VI.
Execution of Documents
The parties agree to timely execute any documents necessary to carry out the terms of
this Agreement. The parties further agree that this document may be executed outside the
presence of the other party and in separate counterparts.
Article VII. Amendments
As required by Section 28E.8, Code of Iowa, this Agreement before going into effect
must be filed with the Secretary of State and recorded with the CountyRecorders of Winnebago
and Hancock Counties, Iowa
The City Clerk of Forest City shall cause this Agreement to be recorded in the offices of
the Hancock and Winnebago County Recorders and filed with the Secretary of State prior to the
effective date of this Agreement which shall be deemed effective fifteen days subsequent to the
last date of approval, below, by the governing bodies designated. An amendment is required to
add another public agency as a signatory party to this Agreement.  Any duly approved
amendments to the Agreement shall be filed with the secretary of State and recorded in the office
of the Winnebago County Recorder and the Hancock County Recorder.
Article VIII. Term of Agreement
Other than the provisions of Article I.5, this Agreement shall begin on January 1, 2014
and shall be in effect until December 31, 2018, and may only be amended by all parties by
resolutions of the governing bodies of the parties to this Agreement made prior to the first day of
January of any year during the term of this Agreement. This Agreement as amended shall renew
for successive five (5 ) year periods automatically unless written notice is given at least two (2)
months prior to the last day of this agreement or renewals thereof.
Article IX.
Termination prior to end of the Term
In the event of a catastrophic occurrence to the non-terminating party or for cause by the
non-terminating party, theterminating party may elect to withdraw or terminate this Agreement
prior to the end of any 5-year term. To terminate the terminating party shall complete a written
notice of withdrawal and delivered to all non-terminating party by hand delivery or certified mail
by the first day of February and said termination shall be effective on the following June 30, and
provided further, that said withdrawal or termination under this paragraph shall not become
effective until state law as to the 911 system is complied with, and all current and outstanding
payments for services have been made by the withdrawing party to the other party. Termination
may also be by agreement of the parties.
Article X.
Amendments.
This Agreement may only be altered or amended by a writing signed by all of the parties.
Approved by the City Council of the City of Forest City, Iowa, and The Forest City Ambulance
Service, Forest City, Iowa.

AMENDED AND RESTATED AGREEMENT
BETWEEN THE CITY OF MAURICE, IOWA AND SIOUX COUNTY, IOWA
RELATING TO THE PROVISION OF LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES
THIS AGREEMENT, consisting of three (3) pages, is made between the City of
Maurice, Iowa, a municipality of the State of Iowa (hereinafter "Maurice") and Sioux
County, Iowa (hereinafter "County").
WHEREAS, Maurice wishes to contract with County for law enforcement services
within the corporate limits of Maurice; and
WHEREAS such Agreements are authorized in Iowa Code §28E;
NOW THEREFORE, Maurice and County agree as follows:
l ) County agrees, through the Sioux County Sheriff ("Sheriff") to provide law
enforcement services within the corporate limits of Maurice, including but not
limited to the following:
a) Patrol, traffic enforcement and control, response to complaints or calls,
investigations, emergency service, service of civil documents, and other tasks
typically performed by a law enforcement agency.
b) Sheriff shall be responsible for administrative duties associated with the function
of said law enforcement services.
2) County shall furnish the necessary equipment and personnel to carry out the services
provided for in this agreement.
 1
3) Maurice agrees to pay County for the law enforcement services provided by Sheriff.
The payment shall be in an amount to be determined by the Sheriff and the Board of
Supervisors of Sioux County as is necessary to carry out the law enforcement
functions stated in this agreement. Such payments shall be made to the Sheriff's
Office on a quarterly basis, payable as follows: July 1, 2012; October 1, 2012;
January 1, 2013; April 1, 2013. The total amount for this contract period has been
set at: $17,138.
4) This Agreement shall be irrevocable for the duration of the contract period.
Thereafter either party may discontinue participation by providing written notice to
the other no later than May 16 of the current year.
5) This agreement shall be effective on the 1st day of July, 2012 and shall run to the 1st
day of July 2013. Thereafter, at the option of the Maurice City Council, and the
Sioux County Board of Supervisors, with the consent of the Sheriff of Sioux County,
this agreement may be renewable for successive periods not to exceed one (1) year.
6) Each party to this agreement is responsible for liability occurring as a result of the
acts or omissions in performing or failure to perform its obligations under this 28E
Agreement. Maurice shall protect, indemnify, defend, and hold harmless the County,
to the extent authorized by law, from and against all claims, demands, action and/or
causes of actions, judgments, settlements, or other costs, including reasonable
attorney fees which the County may incur or sustain for the acts or omissions of
Maurice, its officers, employees, agents, and assigns with respect to the obligations
of Maurice under this 28E Agreement. The County shall protect, indemnify, defend,
and hold harmless Maurice, to the extent authorized by law, from and against all
claims, demands, action and/or causes of actions, judgments, settlements, or other
costs, including reasonable attorney fees which Maurice may incur or sustain for the
acts or omissions of the County, its officers, employees, agents, and assigns with
respect to the obligations of the County under this 28E Agreement.
APPROVED by the Maurice, Iowa City Council.

28E AGREEMENT
FOR THE ADMINISTRATION/MANAGEMENT
OF WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT IN REGION 7
This 28E Agreement (Agreement) is made and entered into this 1st day of July, 2010, and
ending on June 30, 2011, by and between the lowa Workforce Development (IWD) and
Hawkeye Community College (HCC). The parties agree as follows:
Purpose.  The purpose of this Agreement is to establish a procedure for hiring a
Section 1.
Operations Director in Region 7 and to provide for the employment and terms of
employment of the Operations Director.
Identity of the Parties: Iowa Workforce Development (IWD), which is a duly
Section 1.1
created state department, is authorized, among other things, to provide and fund
workforce development programs. IWD's state administrative address is 1000
East Grand Avenue, Des Moines, Iowa 50319. HCC is authorized among other
things, to provide and fund workforce development programs. HCC's address is
1501 East Orange Road, Waterloo IA 50704. This Agreement does not create
any separate legal or administrative parties or entities.
Responsibilities of Parties.
Section 2.
2.1
HCC shall provide day-to-day operational support services for IWD employees
located at the Waterloo Workforce Development Center and any satellite centers
in Region 7. These services will be provided by the Operations Director, who
shall be employed by HCC. The Operations Director shall provide all
administrative/management services in accordance with all applicable federal,
state, local laws and regulations, merit system rules, and collective bargaining
agreement rules and practices. (See attachment A for complete list of documents
currently included in all Regional and PROMISE JOBS Master Agreements.)
2.2.
Policy guidelines for Workforce Development Center operations will be jointly
agreed upon by appropriate HCC and IWD representatives and will comply with
applicable personnel and labor relations policies of both entities.
2.3
In the absence of the Operations Director, personnel issues involving IWD
employees which require the involvement of IWD administration will be the
responsibility of the Regional Division Administrator for the Workforce
Development Center Administration (WDCA) or their Designee.
2.4
HCC shall permit the Operations Director to participate in staff development,
training, and management meetings required by IWD.
2.5
HCC shall be responsible for the payment of the Operations Director's salary and
personnel benefits according to its existing policies. HCC shall be solely
responsible for the payment of all applicable federal and state withholding taxes
and social security taxes, workers compensation, employer's liability, and
unemployment compensation taxes. All fringe benefits provided the Operations
Director will be in accordance with HCC policy.
Page 1 of 11
Region 7 Operations Director 28e April 2010
2.6
Selection, evaluation and termination of the Operations Director will be within the
joint discretion of HCC and IWD.  IWD shall provide HCC with its comments
concerning potential candidates for the Operations Director's position and shall
periodically provide HCC with its comments concerning the performance of the
Operations Director in order to assist HCC with its evaluation. HCC will notify
IWD when the evaluation is being developed, a deadline for IWD comment
submission, and a signed copy of the completed evaluation for IWD records.
2.7
IWD shall provide staff development and training services to ensure the
Operations Director is knowledgeable of IWD practices, procedures, and policies.
2.8
Reserved for future use.
Section 3.
The Workforce Development Center Operations Director.
3.1
The Operations Director shall, at all times, be considered the employee of HCC
and not an employee of IWD. (See attachment B for Operations Director job
description.)
The Operations Director shall consult with the WDCA Division Administrator or
3.2
their Designee and the Department of Administrative Services (DAS) personnel
officer assigned to IWD before taking any disciplinary action against any IWD
employee. Joint review by both the Operations Director and the WDCA Division
Administrator or their Designee will precede any performance appraisal and related
action for any IWD employee.
3.3
When notifying HCC of any annual or sick leave requests, the Operations Director
shall also inform the IWD Regional lowa Works Director or their Designee.
The Operations Director shall attend all regularly scheduled meetings of the IWD
3.4
regional managers and joint administrators, as well as any other required meeting
called by the WDCA Administrator or their Designee. The Operations Director will
inform the WDCA Administrator or their Designee of conflicts that may prohibit
attendance.
Compensation.
Section 4.
Reserved for future use.
Effective Date of Agreement. This Agreement shall be effective when the
Section 5.
following conditions are completed:
5.1
The Agreement is signed by IWD and HCC.
The Agreement or a recordable form of this Agreement is recorded by the Polk and
5.2
Black Hawk County Recorders.
5.3
The Agreement is filed with lowa Secretary of State.
 Page 2 of 11
Region 7 Operations Director 28e April 2010
Section 6.
Term of Agreement.  This Agreement shall be in effect beginning July 1, 2010,
and ending June 30, 2011, with the option to renew for two (2) additional one-year
terms. This Agreement may be terminated at any time, by either party, for any
reason upon at least sixty (60) days written notice in advance of the specified
termination date.
Section 7.
Termination.  This Agreement may be terminated in any of the following
circumstances:
a) At IWD or HCC discretion, without cause, after sixty (60) days written notice
to the other party by FAX with hard copy to follow by overnight delivery.
b) As a result of default under this Agreement.
c)  As a result of the termination or reduction of funding to IWD.
d) Due to bankruptcy, insolvency, or receivership.
Section 8.
Authorization. Each party to this Agreement represents and warrants to the other
that (1) it has the right, power, and authority to enter into and perform its
obligations under this Agreement; and (2) it has taken all requisite action
(corporate, statutory, or otherwise) to approve execution, deliver, and performance
of this Agreement, and this Agreement constitutes a legal, valid, and binding
obligation upon itself in accordance with its terms.
The Vice President of Academic Affairs of HCC and the IWD Administrator of the 
Division of Workforce Development Center Administration will be responsible for
administration of this Agreement.
Section 9.
Default.
9.1
The occurrence of any one or more of the following events shall constitute cause 
for IWD or HCC to declare the other party in default of its obligations under this
Agreement:
a) Non-performance of this Agreement.
b) A failure of either party to make substantial and timely progress toward
performance of the Agreement.
c) A failure of either party's work product and services to conform with any
specifications noted herein.
d) A repeated exhibition of defects in the services delivered by either party,
causing serious disruption of use or downtime over a six month period.
e)  A breach of provisions related to intellectual property.

28E AGREEMENT
FOR STAFF SHARING BETWEEN IOWA WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT
AND DES MOINES AREA COMMUNITY COLLEGE
This 28E Agreement (Agreement) is made and entered into this _
day of October 2015.
and ending on June 30, 2016, by and between lowa Workforce Development (IWD) and Des
Moines Area Community College (DMACC). The parties agree as follows:
Section 1.
Purpose.  The purpose of this Agreement is to provide for the employment and
terms of employment for a shared staff person between DMACC and IWD.
Section 1.1
Identity of the Parties: Iowa Workforce Development (IWD), which is a duly
created state department, is authorized, among other things, to provide and fund
workforce development programs. IWD's state administrative address is 1000
East Grand Avenue, Des Moines, Iowa 50319. Des Moines Area Community
College (DMACC) is authorized among other things, to provide and fund
workforce development programs. DMACC's address is 2006 South Ankeny
Boulevard, Ankeny IA 50023-3993. This Agreement does not create any
separate legal or administrative entities.
Section 2.
Responsibilities of Parties.
2.1
DMACC shall provide administration/management services for the Disability
Employment Initiative, Round 6. These services will be provided by the DEI
Team Lead who shall be employed by DMACC. The DEI Team Lead shall
provide all administrative/management services in accordance with all applicable
federal, state, local laws and regulations, merit system rules, and collective
bargaining agreement rules and practices. (See attachment A for complete list of
documents currently included in all Regional Master Agreements.) The project
manager will devote 100% of their time to these duties.
2.2.
Reserved for future use.
2.3
Reserved for future use.
2.4
DMACC shall permit the DEI Team Lead to participate in staff development,
training, and management meetings required by IWD.
2.5
DMACC shall be responsible for the payment of the DEI Team Lead's salary and
personnel benefits according to its existing policies. DMACC shall be solely
responsible for the payment of all applicable federal and state withholding taxes
and social security taxes. Additionally, DMACC shall carry a policy of workers
compensation, and at its sole expense, employer's liability insurance for the DEI
Team Lead to the extent and in the amounts required by law. DMACC, at its sole
expense, shall pay all unemployment compensation taxes for the DEI Team Lead
to the extent and in the amounts required by law. All fringe benefits provided the
DEI Team Lead will be in accordance with DMACC policy.
2.6
Selection, annual evaluation and termination of the DEI Team Lead will be within
the sole discretion of DMACC. IWD shall annually provide DMACC with its
IWD-DMACC 28e JDNEG 2015
Page 1 of 11
comments concerning the performance of the DEI Team Lead in order to assist
DMACC with its annual evaluation. DMACC will notify IWD when the annual
evaluation is being developed, a deadline for IWD comment submission, and a 
signed copy of the completed evaluation for IWD records. DMACC will secure
consent from the DEI Team Lead to share evaluative information.
IWD shall provide staff development and training services to ensure the DEI
2.7
Team Lead is knowledgeable of IWD practices, procedures, and policies.
2.8
IWD will pay DMACC for the services provided in this Agreement as set forth in 
Section 4.
The Workforce Development Center DEl Team Lead.
Section 3.
3.1
The DEI Team Lead shall, at all times, be considered the employee of DMACC and 
not an employee of IWD. (See attachment B for DEI Team Lead job description.) 
3.2
Reserved for future use.
3.3
When notifying DMACC of any annual or sick leave requests, the DEI Team Lead
shall also inform the Administrative Services Division Administrator or their
Designee.
The DEI Team Lead shall attend any required meeting called by the Administrative
3.4
Services Administrator or their Designee. The DEI Team Lead will inform the
Administrative Services Administrator or their Designee of conflicts that may
prohibit attendance.
Compensation.
Section 4.
IWD will pay DMACC the lesser of:
The DEI Team Lead "salary expense," or
(a)
The Workforce Program Coordinator ($67,000 annual salary) classification
(b)
plus any additional items included in the definition of salary expense below
which are not included as part of the Workforce Program Coordinator
classification.
"Salary expense" includes all regular DMACC benefits, including base salary, 
payroll taxes, unemployment insurance and worker's compensation insurance 
premiums, fringe benefits, travel, and per diem. DMACC benefits do not include 
any bonuses. Salary expense shall not exceed what is allowable under lowa Code
§ 28E.
For the purposes of this agreement, IWD will reimburse travel and per diem 
expenses at only the rate which is used by the employer of record, in this case
DMACC.
IWD will pay DMACC on a monthly basis in, arrears.  "Salary expense" shall be
that actually paid or incurred by DMACC. DMACC will provide a monthly invoice of

the DEI Team Lead's salary expense to the WDCA Division Administrator or their
Designee for approval prior to payment. IWD will provide said approval to DMACC
within 30 days of receipt.
Any percentage increase in the base salary in excess of the percentage increase
for a Workforce Program Coordinator classification shall be as agreed between
DMACC and IWD.
All out-of-state travel to be reimbursed by IWD must have prior approval by the
Administrative Services Division Administrator or their Designee, and the Director,
using the "Request for Travel Authority-Out of State Travel" form.
DMACC shall maintain books, records and documents which sufficiently and 
properly document and calculate all charges billed to IWD throughout the term of 
this Agreement for a period of at least five (5) years following the date of final
payment or completion of any required audit, whichever is later.
DMACC shall permit the Auditor of the State of lowa or any authorized
representative of the State or Department; and where federal funds are involved,

excerpt and transcribe any directly pertinent books, documents, papers, electronic
or optically stored and created records or other records of DMACC relating to

books and records.

Default.
9.1
The occurrence of any one or more of the following events shall constitute cause

b) A failure of either party to make substantial and timely progress toward
performance of the Agreement.
c) A failure of either party's work product and services to conform with any
specifications noted herein.
d) A repeated exhibition of defects in the services delivered by either party,
causing serious disruption of use or downtime over a six month period.
e) A breach of provisions related to intellectual property.
f) A failure to make payments required under section 4.
g) A breach of any term of this Agreement.
9.2
DMACC or IWD shall not be considered to be in default under this
Agreement if its performance is delayed or made impossible by an Act of God,
floods, fires, strikes, a freight embargo or similar events; but in each such case, the
delay or impossibility must go beyond the reasonable control and without the fault 
of DMACC or IWD. In event of such delay, the scheduled date of delivery
shall be extended on a day-to-day basis until delivery of performance is possible
and feasible.

b)  Terminate this Agreement as set forth in Section 7 of this Agreement.

ATTACHMENT B
JOB DESCRIPTION
BASIC FUNCTION: The DEI Project Manager will ensure grant deliverables are properly handled and
monitors post-award compliance.
QUALIFICATIONS:
 Bachelor of Arts or Bachelor of Science Degree required. Master's degree preferred.
Minimum of three years of acceptable related work experience in working with or
advocating for people with disabilities. Experience should include successful
management skills, grant writing, program planning and budgeting, government
program or grant implementation and monitoring, contracting for services, and
working with a volunteer board. Preference for previous experience in Human
Services agency-type of organization. Excellent written and oral communication skills
required.
SUPERVISORS:
President, Des Moines Area Community College
Administrator, Administrative Services Division, Iowa Workforce Development
RESPONSIBILITIES AND DUTIES:
1.
 Maintain on-going professional communications with all partners throughout the project, including
email updates, stakeholder meetings and other appropriate mediums. Create and review grant
related documentation for accuracy and compelling information. Prepare written reports to articulate
grant activities to appropriate and varied audiences. Ensure grant project objectives are easily
understandable.
2. 
 Provide on-going monitoring and coordination of grant deliverables, goals, performance measures
and budgets. Ensure timeframes, milestones and changes are appropriately documented and
communicated. Work with Administrative Services Division Administrator to ensure timely
submission of grant project reports within the specific timeframes for each project.
3.
Develop grant-related administration policies and procedures in accordance with appropriate state
and federal regulations. Coordinate with appropriate agency personnel to ensure policies are in
alignment with related programs.
4.
 Provide technical assistance to internal and external grant project partners to ensure successful
implementation of the project.
6.
Other duties as assigned

28E AGREEMENT
FOR THE ADMINISTRATION/MANAGEMENT
of Workforce development in Region 15
This 28E Agreement (Agreement) is made and entered into this 32_day of November, 2011, 
and ending on June 30, 2012, by and between the lowa Workforce Development (IWVD) and
Indian Hills Community College (IHCC).  The parties agree as follows:
Section 1.
Purpose.  The purpose of this Agreement is to establish a procedure for
employing an Operations Director in Region 15 and to provide for the
employment and terms of employment of the Operations Director.
Identity of the Parties: Iowa Workforce Development (IWD), which is a duly
Section 1.1
created state department, is authorized, among other things, to provide and fund
workforce development programs. IWD's state administrative address is 1000
East Grand Avenue, Des Moines, Iowa 50319. Indian Hills Community College is
authorized among other things, to provide and fund workforce development
programs. IHCC's address is 525 Grandview Avenue, Ottumwa, IA 52501. This
Agreement does not create any separate legal or administrative parties or
entities.
Responsibilities of Parties.
Section 2.
2.1
IWD shall provide day-to-day operational support services for IHCC employees
located at the Ottumwa Workforce Development Center and any satellite centers
in Region 15. These services will be provided by the Operations Director, who
shall be employed by IWD.  The Operations Director shall provide all
administrative/management services in accordance with all applicable federal,
state, local laws and regulations, merit system rules, and collective bargaining
agreement rules and practices. (See attachment A for complete list of documents
currently included in all Regional and PROMISE JOBS Master Agreements.)
2.2.
Policy guidelines for Workforce Development Center operations will be jointly
agreed upon by appropriate IHCC and IWD representatives and will comply with
applicable personnel and labor relations policies of both entities.
2.3
In the absence of the Operations Director, personnel issues involving IWD
employees which require the involvement of IWD administration will be the 
responsibility of the lowaWORKS Regional Director and the Division
Administrator for Workforce Development Center Administration (WDCA) or their
Designee.
2.4
IHCC shall permit the Operations Director to participate in staff development,
training, and management meetings required by IWD.
2.5
IWD shall be responsible for the payment of the Operations Director's salary and
personnel benefits according to its existing policies. IWD shall be solely
responsible for the payment of all applicable federal and state withholding taxes 
and social security taxes, workers compensation, employer's liability, and
Page 1 of 13
Region 15 Operations Director 28e IWD November 2011
unemployment compensation taxes. All fringe benefits provided the Operations
Director will be in accordance with IWD policy.
2.6
Selection, evaluation and termination of the Operations Director will be within the
joint discretion of IHCC and IWD. IHCC shall provide IWD with its comments
concerning potential candidates for the Operations Director's position and shall
periodically provide IWD with its comments concerning the performance of the 
Operations Director in order to assist IWD with its evaluation. IWD will notify
IHCC when the evaluation is being developed, a deadline for IHCC comment
submission, and a signed copy of the completed evaluation for IHCC records.
2.7
IWD shall provide staff development and training services to ensure the
Operations Director is knowledgeable of IWD practices, procedures, and policies.
2.8
IHCC will pay IWD for the services provided in this Agreement as set forth in
Section 4.
The Workforce Development Center Operations Director.
Section 3.
3.1
The Operations Director shall, at all times, be considered the employee of IWD and
not an employee of IHCC. (See attachment B for Operations Director job
description.)
3.2
The Operations Director shall consult the lowaWORKS Regional Director who will
work with the WDCA Division Administrator or their Designee and the Department
of Administrative Services (DAS) personnel officer assigned to IWD before taking
any disciplinary action against any IWD employee. Joint review by both the
Operations Director and the WDCA Division Administrator or their Designee will
precede any performance appraisal and related action for any IWD employee.
When notifying IWD of any annual or sick leave requests, the Operations Director
3.3
shall also inform the Regional lowaWORKS Director or their Designee.
The Operations Director shall attend all regularly scheduled meetings of the IWD
3.4
regional managers and joint administrators, as well as any other required meeting
called by the WDCA Administrator or their Designee. The Operations Director will
inform the lowaWORKS Regional Director and the WDCA Administrator or their
Designee of conflicts that may prohibit attendance.
Section 4.
Compensation.
IHCC will each pay IWD the lesser of:
50% of the Operation Director's "salary expense," or
(a) 
50% of the highest step of a Workforce Manager classification plus one-half of
(b)
any additional items included in the definition of salary expense below which
are not included as part of the Workforce Manager classification.
"Salary expense" includes base salary, payroll taxes, unemployment insurance and
worker's compensation insurance premiums, fringe benefits, travel, and per diem.
Page 2 of 13
Region 15 Operations Director 28e IWD November 2011
IHCC will pay IWD on a monthly basis in, arrears.  "Salary expense" shall be that
actually paid or incurred by IWD. IWD will provide a monthly invoice of the
Operations Director's salary expense to IHCC approval prior to payment. IHCC will
provide said approval to IWD within 15 days of receipt.
Any percentage increase in the base salary in excess of the percentage increase
for a Workforce Manager classification shall be as agreed between IHCC and IWD.
IWD shall maintain books, records and documents which sufficiently and properly
document and calculate all charges billed to IHCC throughout the term of this
Agreement for a period of at least five (5) years following the date of final payment
or completion of any required audit, whichever is later.
IWD shall permit the Auditor of the State of lowa or any authorized representative 
of the State or Department; and where federal funds are involved, the Comptroller
General of the United States or any other authorized representative of the United
States government; to access and examine, audit, excerpt and transcribe any
directly pertinent books, documents, papers, electronic or optically stored and
created records or other records of IWD relating to orders, invoices, or payments or
any other documentation or materials pertaining to this Agreement. IWD shall not
impose a charge for audit or examination of the books and records.
Effective Date of Agreement.  This Agreement shall be effective when the

following conditions are completed:
The Agreement is signed by IWD and IHCC.

The Agreement or a recordable form of this Agreement is recorded by the Polk and

Section 6.
Term of Agreement.  This Agreement shall be in effect beginning November 
30 , 2011, and ending June 30, 2012, with the option to renew for two (2)
additional one-year terms. This Agreement may be terminated at any time, by
either party, for any reason upon at least sixty (60) days written notice in advance
of the specified termination date.
Section 7.
Termination.  This Agreement may be terminated in any of the following
circumstances:
a)   At IWD or IHCC discretion, without cause, after sixty (60) days written
notice to the other party by FAX with hard copy to follow by overnight
delivery.
b) As a result of default under this Agreement.
c)   As a result of the termination or reduction of funding to IWD.
d)  Due to bankruptcy, insolvency, or receivership.

that (1) it has the right, power, and authority to enter into and perform its

Default.
Section 9.
The occurrence of any one or more of the foilowing events shall constitute cause
9.1
for IWD or IHCC to declare the other party in default of its obligations under this

a)   Non-performance of this Agreement.
b)   A failure of either party to make substantial and timely progress toward
performance of the Agreement.
c)   A failure of either party's work product and services to conform with any
specifications noted herein.
d)  A repeated exhibition of defects in the services delivered by either party,
causing serious disruption of use or downtime over a six month period.
e) A breach of provisions related to intellectual property.
f) A failure to make payments required under this Agreement.
g)  A breach of any term of this Agreement.
9.2
IHCC or IWD shall not be considered to be in default under this
Agreement if its performance is delayed or made impossible by an Act of
God, floods, fires, strikes, a freight embargo or similar events; but in each

and without the fault of IHCC or IWD. In event of such delay, the
scheduled date of delivery shall be extended on a day-to-day basis until
delivery of performance is possible and feasible.
IHCC shail not be liable for indirect, special, or consequential damages
9.3
resulting from a breach of this Agreement.

providing therein a sixty (60) day period in which the other party shall have an

to cure, the default remains, IWD or IHCC may do one of the following:
a) Exercise any remedy provided by law,
b)   Terminate this Agreement as set forth in Section 7 of this Agreement.

any contract or create any obligation or liability on behalf of, in the name of, or
binding upon another party to this Agreement.
Section 22.
Cumulative Rights.  The various rights, powers, options, elections, and remedies
of either party, provided in this Agreement, shall be construed as cumulative and
no one of them is exclusive of any rights, remedies or priorities allowed either party
by law, and shall in no way affect or impair the right of either party to pursue any
other equitable or legal remedy to which either party may be entitled as long as any
default remains in any way unremedied, unsatisfied, or undischarged.
Section 23.
Severability.  If a provision of this Agreement is determined by a court of
competent jurisdiction to be invalid or unenforceable, such determination shall not 
affect the validity of enforceability of any other part or provision of this Agreement,
unless such invalid or unenforceable provision goes to the very essence of the
Agreement.
Section 24.
Time is of the Essence.  Time is of the essence with respect to the performance
of the terms of this Agreement.
Binding Effect.  All the terms, provisions, and conditions of this Agreement shall
Section 25.
be binding upon and inure to the benefit of the parties hereto and their respective
successors, assigns and legal representatives.
