AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE CITY OF CARLISLE, IOWA AND
BRAVO GREATER DES MOINES, INC.
This Agreement is made and entered into on this 13th day of June, 2011, (the "Execution
Date") by and between the City of Carlisle ("Carlisle"), and Bravo Greater Des Moines,
Inc. ("Bravo") an Iowa not-for-profit corporation, pursuant to the provisions of Chapter
28E, Code of Iowa. The Agreement shall be effective with respect to Commitments
beginning July 1, 2011 (the "Effective Date").
That inasmuch as Bravo is organized for the purpose of assisting the cultural community
of Polk County and contiguous counties (the "Greater Des Moines Area") in
providing an enriched quality of life by increasing cultural awareness, advocacy, and
funding, as well as by fostering collaboration among cultural organizations.
That the City of Carlisle has as a goal the unification and coordination of monies for the
use and benefit of the cultural community and specifically the cultural organizations
eligible for funding by Bravo. The City of Carlisle is committed to the reasonable
stewardship of monies for arts and cultural purposes.
That the City of Carlisle and Bravo entered into an agreement on August 23, 2010,
effective through June 30, 2011, which agreement was filed with the Iowa Secretary of
State on December 14, 2010.
That the City of Carlisle and Bravo agree as follows:
I. DEFINITIONS
(1)
"Hotel/Motel Tax" means a tax imposed in accordance with Chapter 423A of the
Code of Iowa, 2009, or similar successor provisions.
"Hotel/Motel Tax Revenues" means the funds remitted to the City of Carlisle by
(2)
the Treasurer of the State of Iowa from the local Transient Guest Tax Fund in
accordance with provisions of Chapter 423A of the 2011 Code of Iowa, and the
rules promulgated by the Director of the Iowa Department of Revenue thereunder,
or similar successor provisions, representing the proceeds collected by the State
of Iowa from the Hotel//Motel Tax imposed by the City of Carlisle.
II. PRE-CONDITIONS TO OBLIGATIONS OF THE CITY OF CARLISLE
(1)
The parties understand and intend that the City of Carlisle obligation to make the
payments hereunder shall not constitute a legal indebtedness of the City of
Carlisle within the meaning of any applicable constitutional or statutory debt
limitation. In the event that any of the provisions of this Agreement are
determined by a court of competent jurisdiction to create, or result in the creation
of, such a legal indebtedness of the City of Carlisle, the enforcement of the
payment provisions of this Agreement shall be suspended and the Agreement
l
shall at all times be construed and applied in such a manner as will preserve
the
foregoing intent of the parties.
III. COVENANT FROM CITY OF CARLISLE
(1) The City of Carlisle does hereby agree to pay Bravo for the promotion of arts and
cultural activities in the Greater Des Moines Area for the entire term of this
Agreement and all extensions thereof, a minimum of $1,000.00 annually
after June 30, 2011 (the "Commitment") to be distributed and expended by Bravo
in the manner set forth in this Agreement and the bylaws of Bravo.
The City of Carlisle shall take all action necessary to implement disbursement of
(2)
the Commitment. Payment of the Commitment to Bravo shall be made annually.
IV. PURPOSE
The purpose of this Agreement is to facilitate and support the cultural community of the
Greater Des Moines Area in providing an enriched quality of life by increasing
cultural awareness, advocacy and funding as well as by fostering collaboration among
cultural organizations and increasing stability of Bravo in carrying out its goals for the
benefit of the Greater Des Moines Area. This Agreement is not intended to establish
a separate legal entity.
V. ACCOUNTING OF BENEFITS
(1)
Bravo shall administer the undertakings between the City of Carlisle and Bravo
as described herein, and Bravo shall acquire, hold and disburse its assets,
including the Commitment, in accordance with the purpose and terms stated
herein and the governing documents of Bravo. Upon request, Bravo shall
provide to the City of Carlisle copies of the governing documents, including
applicable bylaws and policy guidelines. The City of Carlisle hereby appoints
its City Administrator to administer this Agreement with Bravo, and Bravo
hereby appoints its President to administer this Agreement with the City of
Carlisle. Bravo shall post on its website notice of the time, location and agenda
for its board meetings and shall provide minutes of action taken via email to the
City Administrator or its designee.
(2)
The City of Carlisle and Bravo acknowledge that the communities within the
Greater Des Moines Area that make payment commitments to Bravo (Polk
County and the described communities are together the "Participating
Communities") and not-for-profit cultural organizations within such
Participating Communities may, as part of a cultural improvements capital
campaign, apply for grant funding. Bravo shall establish a separate fund to
provide matching funds to support the capital campaigns of not-for-profit
cultural organizations within such Participating Communities (the "Fund").
Bravo shall allocate a portion of the aggregate of the Commitment payments by
the City of Carlisle and contributions by other Participating Communities so
2
there is a balance of between $150,000 and $450,000 in the Fund at the
commencement of each fiscal year. In order to increase the amount of funding
available for cultural improvement campaigns, Bravo shall allocate an
additional $150,000 to the Fund each fiscal year provided that the Fund does
not exceed an end of fiscal year balance of $450,000. For a not-for-profit
cultural organization to be eligible to receive a disbursement from the Fund, the
not-for-profit cultural organization must make a presentation regarding its
capital campaign to Bravo before the not-for-profit cultural organization
approaches any of the Participating Communities for a contribution. Bravo, in
its reasonable discretion shall make determinations on Fund disbursements for
proposed cultural capital campaigns within the Participating Communities in
such manner that will enhance the competitiveness of the grant funding
applications and further the purpose of this Agreement. The City of Carlisle
and Bravo acknowledge that any matching funds provided by Bravo for a not-
for-profit cultural organization's capital campaign shall not be intended or
construed as the sole or exclusive capital funding source to be provided by
Participating Communities for such project.
(3)
Bravo shall present to the City Administrator of the City of Carlisle no later
than 30 days after Bravo's Board of Directors approves Bravo's audited
fiscal year financial statements, a full accounting of Bravo's revenues,
disbursements and operations for such year in a form reasonably acceptable
to the City ("Financial Statements"). The Financial Statements will include the
annual salaries paid to officers and employees of Bravo and a summary of the
disbursement awards made by Bravo during the fiscal year, including for cach
recipient of an award the amount awarded and a brief description of the approved
uses for the award. Upon request, Bravo shall provide the City of Carlisle with
copies of recipient funding agreements. The fiscal year of Bravo ends each June
30.
The Financial Statements shall be prepared by Bravo and certified by an
(4)
independent auditor selected by Bravo.
VI. OPERATIONS AND FINANCES
Bravo shall prepare and submit to the Carlisle City Council prior to the commencement of
each of Bravo's fiscal years a distribution plan for the Commitment payments from the
City of Carlisle and contributions by the other Participating Communities (the "Plan").
The Plan for the 2011-12 fiscal year shall be submitted to the Carlisle City Council prior
to the Effective Date. All expenditures of public funds by Bravo shall be made pursuant
to the Plan. Notwithstanding anything in this Agreement to the contrary, Bravo may, once
each fiscal year, submit a revised Plan to the Carlisle City Council and the governing
bodies of the other Participating Communities to reallocate up to ten percent (10%) of the
Commitment payments from the City of Carlisle and contributions by the other
Participating Communities for the fiscal year.
3
VII. DURATION AND TERMINATION
This Agreement shall continue in effect from the Effective Date until terminated in
(1)
accordance with the terms of this Article VII.
This Agreement may be terminated by either party as provided in this paragraph.
(2)
Any such termination may be accomplished only by delivery of notice to the
other party not later than January 1 of any given year after the year ending
December 31, 2013 and shall be effective on July 1 occurring eighteen (18)
months after the January 1 following the giving of the required notice.
(3)
In the event that another Participating Community submits notice to Bravo to
terminate its payment commitment agreement with Bravo, Bravo shall provide a
copy of such notice to the City of Carlisle. The City of Carlisle may then deliver
to Bravo notice to terminate this Agreement with an effective date that coincides
with the termination date applicable to the terminating Participating Community.
Such notice to terminate shall become invalid if the terminating Participating
Community withdraws or otherwise revokes its termination notice prior to the
effective date.
(4)
Notwithstanding paragraphs (2) or (3) above, in the event that any part of the
Commitment is disbursed or expended by Bravo in violation of the terms of this
Agreement, the City may deliver to Bravo a notice to cure or remedy such default
or breach within sixty (60) days and if such default or breach is not remedied
within such cure period, this Agreement shall promptly terminate.
This Agreement shall terminate if Chapter 423A of the Code of Iowa is either: (a)
(5)
repealed or amended to remove the authority of the City of Carlisle to collect the
Hotel/Motel Tax at a rate of at least 7% or (b) so modified that the purpose of the
Agreement can no longer be carried out. If the Agreement terminates pursuant to
the previous sentence, the termination date shall be the June 30 coinciding with
or next following the effective date of the statutory change that causes the
termination.
This Agreement shall terminate if an alternative, reliable funding source is
(5)
secured for Bravo that provides funding to Bravo, in the reasonable determination
of the Bravo board of directors, that is comparable in amount to the annual
funding streams Bravo has secured in the aggregate through 28E agreements with
the cities, counties and municipalities of the Greater Des Moines Area (for
example, if Chapter 423A of the Code of Iowa were amended to increase the
Hotel/Motel tax and to direct a portion of the increase to Bravo in an amount
comparable to the annual funding streams expected from 28E agreements already
in place). If a reliable alternative funding source is secured for Bravo, which
partially replaces the funds provided by the City of Carlisle to Bravo, the amount
4
of annual funding provided to Bravo pursuant to this Agreement shall be reduced
proportionately in such amount as the parties may reasonably determine. If the
Agreement terminates pursuant to this paragraph, the termination date shall be the
June 30 coinciding with or next following the effective date of the alternative
funding source that causes the termination.
(6)
Any notice or demand required or desired to be given hereunder shall be in
writing and deemed given when personally delivered or when deposited in the
United States mail, postage prepaid, sent certified or registered, and addressed
as follows:
If to the City of Carlisle, to:
City of Carlisle
195 North 156 Street
Carlisle, IA 50047
Attention: City Adminstrator
If to Bravo, to:

or to such other address or person as hereafter shall be designated in writing by the

VIII. AMENDMENT OF AGREEMENT
Any amendment to this Agreement shall be made in writing upon agreement of the City of
Carlisle and Bravo and after appropriate discussion and public dialogue, and such
amendment has been approved by resolution of the City of Carlisle Council.
IX. MISCELLANEOUS
This Agreement has been made and entered into solely for the benefit of the goals
(1)
and objectives of the City of Carlisle and Bravo as expressly provided herein and
is not intended to create any rights in any other person.
5
Notwithstanding anything in this Agreement to the contrary, any liabilities, debts,
(2)
or other obligations experienced by Bravo as a corporation/body or its members
shall not be the responsibility of the City of Carlisle.
While this Agreement is in effect, the City of Carlisle shall have the right to
(3)
designate one person to serve on the Board of Directors of Bravo.
It is the intention and expectation of Bravo and the City of Carlisle that no
(4)
organization that receives funding from Bravo during the term of this Agreement
will approach the City of Carlisle for additional operational funding during the
term of this Agreement. This expectation does not apply to: (1) any member of
Bravo that is owned, managed or operated by the City of Carlisle or a political
subdivision of the City; or (2) capital campaigns.
(5)
Each of the City of Carlisle and Bravo shall pay its own costs incurred to
negotiate, amend, abide by or terminate this Agreement.
After execution by the parties, this Agreement shall be filed with the Iowa
(6)
Secretary of State in an electronic format in accordance with the provisions of
Iowa Code § 28E.8.
(7)
As of the Effective Date, this Agreement is intended to replace the prior
agreements referred to in paragraph four of the preamble to this document.

CASS COUNTY AND THE CITY OF GRISWOLD
28E MUTUAL AID AGREEMENT
THIS JOINT MUTUAL AID AGREEMENT ("Agreement") is made pursuant to Chapter
28E of the Iowa Code. It shall be known as the "Cass County and the City of Griswold 28E
Joint Mutual Aid Agreement" and shall be adopted by Cass County and the City of Griswold by
resolution of this Agreement.
RECITALS
WHEREAS, the following law enforcement agencies wish to enter into a cooperative law
enforcement agreement: Cass County Sheriff's Office and City of Griswold (hereinafter referred
to as "Agency" or "Agencies");
WHEREAS, the Agencies wish to enter into this Agreement for the purpose of engaging
in mutual aid law enforcement support on a perpetual basis;
WHEREAS, the Agencies wish to perform whatever law enforcement services are
necessary as part of the 28E Joint Mutual Aid Agreement to enforce the laws of the State of
Iowa:
WHEREAS, no new or separate law enforcement entity or agency is created by the
Agreement; and
WHEREAS this is a contract for law enforcement services between the two Agencies, but
does not create unified law enforcement as provided in Iowa Code Sections 28E.21 through
28E.30.
THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED that the Agencies mutually agree as follows:
1. DURATION. The duration of this Agreement shall be four years from the starting date of
July 1, 2012 and ending June 30, 2016.
2. PURPOSE. The purpose of said Agreement is for Cass County and the Cass County
Sheriff's Office to contract with the City of Griswold and to provide law enforcement
services to the City of Griswold without creating a unified law enforcement district. The Cass
County Sheriff's office will provide 160 hours of service monthly within the City of
Griswold limits. Furthermore, the designated hours of service will include policing at the city
owned Cocklin Fish Farm north of the city. The Cass County Sheriff's office will distribute
monthly reports to the City of Griswold for hours spent policing in the city.
3. AUTHORIZATION. The Cass County Sheriff's Office shall be authorized to provide full
law enforcement aid and services to the City of Griswold for purposed of effectuating this
Agreement. For purposes of this Agreement, this shall mean the enforcement of any State of
Iowa code violations including investigation, charging, all necessary paperwork and related
Page 1 of 4
duties to law enforcement and City of Griswold code violations, both criminal and municipal.
However, the City of Griswold shall be responsible for the preparation of any City of
Griswold code violations and municipal infractions to include serving such notices in the
manner included in the City of Griswold Code of Ordinances. The Cass County Sheriff's
Office will file any charges arising from such notices. The Cass County Sheriff's Office
shall be responsible for serving any City of Griswold code violations to any citizen(s) in the
City of Griswold. The Cass County Sheriff's Office shall be responsible for any in-court
witness appearances, depositions and testimony for the officer's only for any State of lowa
code violation. The compensation in paragraph eight (8) of this Agreement shall cover any
such duties. The City of Griswold shall be financially responsible for securing and obtaining
the presence of any other witnesses for any of its city code violations.
4. ORGANIZATION. No separate legal or administrative entity is created by this Agreement.
The Cass County Sheriff's Office and the City of Griswold shall be the joint board
responsible for administering the joint or cooperative undertaking. The Joint Board shall
consist of the Cass County Sheriff and the Mayor of the City of Griswold. All personal
property shall be paid for as delineated in this agreement. No real property shall be acquired,
held or disposed of by the Agencies.
5. ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS AND ADMINSTRATION. The Agencies agree that a
vehicle will be purchased by the City of Griswold for the Cass County Sheriff's office. Said
vehicle shall be owned by the Cass County Sheriff's Department. The Agencies further
agree that property or equipment purchased by the Cass County Sherift's Office acquired or
held during this Agreement and in fulfillment thereof shall be the property of the Cass
County Sheriff's Office and shall remain the property of said Agency following the
termination of this Agreement. In the occurrence that the contract is voided between the City
of Griswold and the Cass County Sheriff's office, the vehicle will become the property of the
City of Griswold. The Sheriff's Department will be responsible for the maintenance, repair,
and upkeep of the aforementioned property, including the vehicle.
6. MEETINGS. No regular scheduled meetings are anticipated as a result of this Agreement
between the Agencies. However, should any meetings occur for the purpose of discussing
any administration of this Agreement, said meetings shall be held pursuant to Chapter 21 of
the Iowa Code and held as part of the regularly scheduled monthly City Council meetings in
the City of Griswold and in accordance with all publication requirements of this Section and
Chapter 21.
7. FINANCE & BUDGET. The City of Griswold agrees to assign $67,000.00 annually of its
budget for law enforcement to the Cass County Sheriff's Office to be used in accordance
with paragraph eight (8) of this Agreement.
8. COMPENSATION. While participating in this Agreement, the City of Griswold agrees to
pay the Cass County Sheriff's Office Sixty-Seven Thousand Dollars ($67,000.00) each fiscal
year for a period of four years with said payments made through the Cass County Auditor.
Said payments shall be used for employee wages, insurance, equipment, training, benefits,
vehicle maintenance and upkeep. Said payments shall be made in monthly installments on or
Page 2 of 4
before the first of each month. If at any time the City of Griswold requests an itemized
breakdown of any expenditures, the Cass County Sheriff shall provide same to the City of
Griswold at its request.
9. LIABILITY. Pursuant to Iowa Code Section 28E.7, nothing in this Agreement shall relieve
either public agency of any obligation or responsibility imposed upon it by law except as
provided in this section.
10. RENEWAL & TERMINATION. This Agreement shall terminate on June 30, 2016 unless
the Agencies named herein renew said agreement by said date. Either party may terminate
this contract upon 30 days written notice to the other party if the other party has failed to
perform any requirement under the terms of this agreement. If the default or failure to
perform is corrected within the 30 day notice period, the aggrieved party shall not terminate
this agreement.
11. EFFECTIVE DATE OF AGREEMENT. This Agreement shall become effective between
the governmental agencies stated herein upon the passage and execution of the governing
body of each governmental agency, which is a party to this Agreement. The Clerk or Auditor
of each member shall furnish the other member agencies copies of the resolution approving
the Agreement and authorizing execution and a signed copy of the Agreement shall be
furnished to each party to this Agreement.
12. OBLIGATIONS NOT EXCUSED. Nothing in this Agreement made pursuant to Chapter
28E shall relieve either agency of any obligation or responsibility imposed upon it by law
except any of the agreed upon responsibilities as delineated in the Agreement.
13. FILING AND RECORDING. Pursuant to Section 28E.8 of the Iowa Code, before entry into
force, this Agreement made pursuant to Chapter 28E shall be filed with the Secretary of State
of Iowa, Cass County Recorder and Clerk, City of Griswold.
IN WITNESS AND TESTIMONY WHEREOF, said Agencies have caused this
Agreement to be executed on their behalf by their duly authorized officers, and the same to be
attested by their clerks or auditor, and the corporate seal of said Municipalities to be affixed
hereto, all as of the day and year last below written.

28E AUDUBON COUNTY AND CITY OF GRAY LAW ENFORCEMENT
AGREEMENT
THIS 28E AGREEMENT is entered into this || day of April, 2014, by and between
the County of Audubon, State of Iowa, hereinafter, "County", and the City of Gray, State of
Iowa, hereinafter, "City", as local governments or subdivisions of the State of Iowa defined by
Iowa Code Chapter 28E (2013), as follows:
WHEREAS, Audubon County is a political subdivision of the State of Iowa and has a
County Sheriff, pursuant to Iowa Code Sections 331.651 through 331.750 (2013), and the City of
Gray is a city government pursuant to provisions of the Iowa Code.
WHEREAS, the City of Gray, has a statutory duty to provide police protection as a
municipal service from an incorporated city to its residents under Iowa Code Chapter 368. A
Mayor is mandated to appoint a Police Chief, except when an incorporated city has entered into
an intergovernmental agreement to provide for police protection. Iowa Code Section 372.3.
While the level and type of law enforcement is left to the determination of the Council, the City
is obliged to provide protection. State ex rel. Johnson v. Allen, 569 N.W.2d 143 (lowa 1997).
WHEREAS, Audubon County, through its Sheriff, is willing to provide law enforcement
protection for the City of Gray with some in-town presence and responding to calls for law
enforcement assistance, in exchange for monetary remuneration to offset increased costs, and the
County, through the Board of Supervisors, is willing to budget and assume attendant risks.
WHEREAS, the purpose of this agreement is to enter into a joint exercise of
governmental powers between the County and City as provided in Iowa Code Chapter 28E
(2013). This 28E Agreement provides that the County provide law enforcement services for the
City, and that the City pay the costs of the services, and supply office facilities if requested; and
WHEREAS, no separate legal or administrative entity shall exist by virtue of this
Agreement, the Audubon County Sheriff is hereby designated as the administrator responsible
for administration and fulfillment of this joint Agreement for the County, and the Mayor and
City Council of Gray, Iowa shall be responsible for fulfillment of the terms of this Agreement
herein on behalf of the City; and,
WHEREAS, the City and County hereby establish the terms of this Agreement, subject
to the laws and administrative rules of the State of Iowa and City and County Ordinances.
Page 1 of 7
IT IS THEREFORE AGREED and RESOLVED, in consideration of the mutual
covenants and agreements herein, the City of Gray and County of Audubon agree as follows:
1. Purpose. The incorporated City of Gray agrees with Audubon County, through its
Board of Supervisors, and the Audubon County Sheriff, to pay Audubon County for
police protection services provided by the Sheriff and his department for the period
designated below under this intergovernmental agreement, in compliance with the
incorporated city's duties under Iowa Code Section 372.3. This agreement does not
affect the Communications Center agreement already in place.
2. Compensation. City agrees to pay County an annual fiscal year fee of $15.00 per
capita based upon the United States Census of 2010 showing Gray with a population
of 63, a total of $945.00, due and payable in four (4) equal installments of $236.25
mailed or delivered to the office of the Audubon County Sheriff on the first day of
each quarter of that fiscal year.
3. Additional Consideration for Special Events. In the event that City allows a special
event during the term of this agreement, (e.g. town celebration, RAGBRAI), the cost
of additional law enforcement necessary to provide law enforcement coverage during
the special event as determined by the Sheriff and approved by the City, shall be
covered by the City as a reimbursement to County.
4. Duration. This agreement shall commence upon the signing and ratification by both
parties and shall end at midnight on June 30, 2017, absent early termination as set
forth below, or unless renewed upon written agreement of the parties.
Early termination may occur as follows: After the one year anniversary date of this
agreement either City or County may terminate this agreement effective at the
conclusion of the thirtieth (30th) day following delivery of a written Notice of Early
Termination to the other party.
a. To allow for staff changes, in the event City terminates the agreement under this
clause, City shall be obligated to pay County on a pro rata basis for ninety (90)
days following delivery of written notice.
b. In the event County terminates the agreement under this clause, City's payment
obligations and County's service obligations cease at midnight on the thirtieth
(30th) day following delivery of the written notice to ther party; any excess
amount previously paid by City shall be refunded to City on a pro rata basis.
Page 2 of 7
5. Duties of County Sheriff and County.
1. The Audubon County Sheriff shall:
a. Provide Law Enforcement Services including, at a minimum:
(1) periodic door-checks of downtown businesses for unlocked doors and
trespassers;
(2) random patrolling of all property owned by the City, whether inside or
outside the city limits;
(3) non-scheduled periodic street patrol with periodic employment of radar
operations to control speeding;
(4) response to law enforcement service calls on a 24/7 basis, together with
investigation as determined necessary by the Sheriff or his Designee; same
to be prioritized and adjusted by the Sheriff as need be for staff shortages
and emergencies according to the terms and policies of the Audubon
County Sheriff's Office.
(5) service of prepared notices upon request of the City Attorney or City
Clerk, but shall not include calls for compliance with city ordinances,
regulations, and other city services, including but not limited to the
following: requests for animal transportation, all animal nuisance calls,
snow removal, abandoned vehicles on private property, civil property
disputes, and failure to mow grass.
b. Advise City Clerk of any suspected nuisances observed by officers on patrol
within the City of Gray.
c. Supervise and instruct officers' on appropriate conduct and ensure attendance
of necessary law enforcement officers under his direction at related court and
administrative hearings upon the request of the County Attorney, City
Attorney or Mayor.
Set law enforcement policy, procedures, and regulations within parameters
d. i
and standards set forth by the United States Code, Iowa Code, civil service
rules, and common law adopted within Iowa for law enforcement generally.
The Sheriff shall consider reasonable requests from the city through the mayor
for law enforcement services but discretion as to investigations and charges
rests with the Sheriff, subject to regulation as permitted by law and
prosecutorial decision.
Page 3 of 7
e. Address written questions submitted by the Mayor or City Council acting as a
governmental body and meet with the City Council at least annually to discuss
law enforcement concerns.
2. County agrees to:
a. budget for law enforcement services and necessary law enforcement
equipment and vehicles to be used within the City of Gray as
determined by the Sheriff in a good faith effort to effectively enforce
the laws of the City, County, State and Federal governments, and as
needed to maintain peace and order within the City.
b. be compliant with labor and employment laws and other matters
pertaining to the use of Sheriff Department personnel in carrying out
the terms of this agreement.
c. budget for adequate training and certification for Sheriff Department
personnel who provide services under this agreement as required by
law and deemed sufficient by the Audubon County Sheriff.
6. Duties of City. The City shall:
a. timely pay quarterly sums due and reimbursement of sums advanced by County
for officers hired for special events;
b. supply and maintain an indoor space with utilities for the Sheriff to use on an as-
needed basis, if requested by the Sheriff , in conducting interviews or otherwise,
said space including at a minimum the following: table and chairs;
c. provide city information available to the Sheriff as requested in the course of any
investigation under this agreement; and
meet with the Sheriff at least once annually to review law enforcement needs.
d.
7. Access to information. Access to information by City and County shall be as
permitted by law, keeping in mind confidentiality requirements of Iowa Code Chapter 692,
mental health and juvenile court requirements, court orders, and any other requirements imposed
by law.
8. Reciprocal Hold Harmless and Indemnification Provision. County agrees to
indemnify and hold harmless any claims made for actions of the Audubon County Sherift's
Office, its deputies and employees, while providing the law enforcement services described
Page 4 of 7
herein. Audubon County shall hold the City of Gray, its officials and employees harmless from
any and all liability for acts, negligent or intentional of the County Board of Supervisors, Sheriff,
Sherift's deputies and employees thereof, arising out of the performance of this contract.
Audubon County shall defend the City, its officials and employees from any and all claims for
damages based on the negligent or intentional acts of Audubon County, Board of Supervisors
and Sheriff's Office, arising from this contract.
City agrees to indemnify and hold harmless any claims made against the County for
actions of the City, its officers and employees arising out of this contract. The City shall hold
Audubon County, the County Board of Supervisors, the Sheriff's Office and its officers and
employees harmless from any and all liability for acts of negligence or intentional acts of the
City, its officers and employees and shall defend the County, its officers and employees from
any and all claims for damages based on the negligent or intentional acts of the City, its officers
and employees, arising from its performance under this contract.
Both Audubon County and the City of Gray shall maintain liability insurance insuring
their respective interests and performance under this agreement. Each party may require proof of
insurance and certification of insurance from the other and compliance with such a request shall
not be unreasonably withheld.
9. City Non Liability. The City shall not be the employer of any personnel of the
Sherift's Office performing services hereunder and shall have no liability for payment of any
salaries, wages, or other compensation to such personnel. Audubon County shall carry worker's
compensation insurance on all employees of the County and the Sherift's Office performing
services hereunder and the City shall not be liable for compensation or indemnity to any such
employee for injury or sickness arising out of the employment. County shall hold the City
harmless from any such claim. The City shall assume no liability under this contract other than
expressly contracted for.
10. Notices. Whenever notices are required or contemplated to be given by one party to
the other, including requests for arbitration and other notifications, same shall be in writing and
either mailed by Certified Mail or personally delivered as follows:
If the notice is to the County Board of Supervisors and Sheriff's Office, same shall be
address to the Chairman of the Audubon County Board of Supervisors (naming the Chairman)
and to the Sheriff of Audubon County (naming the Sheriff) and copy thereof either personally
delivered to the Chairman or Sheriff or mailed to the Chairman or Sheriff. For purposes of
mailing, the addresses shall be as follows:

11. Entire Agreement. All parties state that they have obtained the necessary approval
and acceptance from their respective governing bodies to enter into this agreement and that the
above provisions constitute the entre and completed Agreement between the parties on this
subject matter.
12. Filing and Recordation. This Agreement shall be filed with the Secretary of State

28E AGREEMENT 
FOR STAFF SHARING BETWEEN IOWA WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT
AND HAWKEYE COMMUNITY COLLEGE
This 28E Agreement (Agreement) is made and entered into this 1st day of November, 2015,
and ending on June 30, 2015, by and between lowa Workforce Development (IWD) and
Hawkeye Community College (HCC). The parties agree as follows:
Section 1.
Purpose. The purpose of this Agreement is to provide for the employment and
terms of employment for a shared staff person between HCC and IWD.
Identity of the Parties: Iowa Workforce Development (IWD), which is a duly

Section 4.
Compensation.
This agreement shall require lowa Workforce Development (IWD) to reimburse
Hawkeye Community College (HCC) for one-fourth of the base salary and fringe
benefits of Dustin Brocka for the period November 1, 2015 to June 30, 2016.  In
addition, IWD agrees to reimburse HCC for the full cost (salaries and fringe 
benefits) of the above base pay increase temporarily given to Dustin Brocka. The
above base pay is being made in order to compensate Dustin for representing IWD
as the Grant Manager of the John Deere NDWG grant. The grand total of this
agreement shall not exceed $23,000 without mutual agreement among the two
agencies to amend this 28E agreement.  HCC shall submit a monthly bill to IWD
Financial Management, due by the 15th of the following month. The bill shall
include a breakdown of the total salary and fringe paid, the amount of base pay to
be reimbursed and the amount of above base pay to be reimbursed.

taxes, unemployment insurance and worker's compensation insurance premiums,
fringe benefits, travel, and per diem. HCC benefits do not include any bonuses.

For the purposes of this agreement, IWD will reimburse travel and per diem

Section 9.
Default.
9.1
The occurrence of any one or more of the following events shall constitute cause
for IWD or HCC to declare the other party in default of its obligations under this
Agreement:
a)  Non-performance of this Agreement.
b} A failure of either party to make substantial and timely progress toward
performance of the Agreement.
c) A failure of either party's work product and services to conform with any
specifications noted herein.
d) A repeated exhibition of defects in the services delivered by either party,
causing serious disruption of use or downtime over a six month period.
e)  A breach of provisions related to intellectual property.
f) A failure to make payments required under section 4.
g) A breach of any term of this Agreement.
HCC or IWD shall not be considered to be in default under this
9.2
Agreement if its performance is delayed or made impossible by an Act of God,
floods, fires, strikes, a freight embargo or similar events; but in each such case, the
delay or impossibility must go beyond the reasonable control and without the fault
of HCC or IWD. In event of such delay, the scheduled date of delivery
shall be extended on a day-to-day basis until delivery of performance is possible
and feasible.
9.3
HCC shall not be liable for indirect, special, or consequential damages
resulting from a breach of this Agreement.

providing therein a sixty (60) day period in which the other party shall have an

ATTACHMENT B
JOB DESCRIPTION
BASIC FUNCTION:   The John Deere National Dislocated Worker Grant Grant  Manager will ensure grant
deliverables are properly handled and monitors post-award compliance.
QUALIFICATIONS:
Bachelor of Arts or Bachelor of Science Degree preferred. Minimum of three years of
related work experience in career or workforce services. Experience should include a
combination of case management and program knowledge related to the Dislocated
Worker and TAA programs, grant writing, program planning and budgeting, grant
implementation and monitoring, contracting for services, and working with a volunteer
board. Excellent written and oral communication skills required.
SUPERVISORS:
Administrator, Administrative Services Division, lowa Workforce Development
RESPONSIBILITIES AND DUTIES:
1. Maintain on-going professional communications with all partners throughout the project, including
email updates, stakeholder meetings and other appropriate mediums. Create and review grant
related documentation for accuracy and compelling information. Prepare written reports to articulate
grant activities to appropriate and varied audiences. Ensure grant project objectives are easily
understandable.
2. Provide on-going monitoring and coordination of grant deliverables, goals, performance measures
and budgets. Ensure timeframes, milestones and changes are appropriately documented and
communicated. Work with Administrative Services Division Administrator to ensure timely
submission of grant project reports within the specific timeframes for each project.
3. Develop grant-related administration policies and procedures in accordance with appropriate state
and federal regulations. Coordinate with appropriate agency personnel to ensure policies are in
alignment with related programs.
 Provide technical assistance to internal and external grant project partners to ensure successful
4. 
implementation of the project.
5.
Other duties as assigned.

LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES CONTRACT
On this _ lith_ day of February
, 2013, the City of Collins and Story
County, Iowa, enter into the following agreement:
The Story County Sheriff's Office will provide the City of Collins, Iowa, with
1.
law enforcement services. These services will include but not be limited to:
Radar operations to control speed.
A.
Issuing violations under city ordinances (excluding animal control
B.
ordinances) upon request.
Housing inmates who have been incarcerated under a city ordinance.
C.
Service of abatement notices on request. . . . .
D ...
Periodically checking commercial buildings for unlocked doors and
E. .
more of the first in the program woul
trespassers.
F. . .
Investigation of traffic accidents and complaints.
Dispatch of city fire departments and first responders.
G.
H.
Staffing a 24 hour E911 dispatch center.
Providing a detective division to investigate crimes and conduct
I.
on-going investigations.
J.
Investigation of drug-related offenses.
K.
Supplying schools or community clubs with officers and materials
for special programs and talks upon request.
L.
Routine patrols and special patrols upon request.
Supply fully equipped patrol cars with radio, lights, siren and all
M.
related equipment, gasoline and oil, tires, and maintenance, uniforms and
all other personal equipment.
2.
In consideration for the law enforcement services above described, the City of
Collins, IA. will pay a per capita rate of $52.00 (based on the 2010 census of
495) to Story County, Iowa, which amounts to the annual sum of $25,740.00.
This shall be paid in equal quarterly installments to the Story County Sheriff on
July 1, October 1, January 1 and April 1. Any per capita increase in contract
cost for the following year shall be negotiated by December for the next fiscal
year. For the purposes of this contract, fiscal year shall be from July 1, through
June 30, of the following year.

The undersigned County of Floyd and City of Rockford do hereby agree as follows:
1. Purpose.
The purpose of this agreement is for the provision of law enforcement services by Floyd
County to the City of Rockford on the terms and conditions set forth herein.
2. Parties. The parties to this agreement are the County of Floyd (hereinafter "County") and the City of
Rockford (hereinafter "City"). Both parties are political subdivisions of the State of Iowa duly authorized by the
Code of Iowa.
3. Effective Date. This agreement shall become effective on the First (1") day of July, 2012.
4. Duration.
This agreement shall be effective for a period of time extending from the First (18) day of
July, 2012 up to and including the Thirtieth (30th) day of June, 2013.
The County agrees to provide law enforcement services to the City of Rockford
5. Service Provided.
during the duration of this agreement. The law enforcement services shall be performed by the Floyd County
Sheriff and the Sheriff's Deputies and employees.
6. Services Specifically Excluded. The County, the Sheriff, and/or the Sheriff's Deputies and
employees shall not provide any type of service relating to the regulation, control, or abatement of any animals
within the City. The County, the Sheriff, and/or the Sheriff's Deputies will not enforce any violation of the City's
ordinances. This paragraph is not intended to be a complete list of services the County will not provide, but is
intended to be an express exclusion under this agreement.
7. Consideration. In consideration for the services provided by the County, the City shall pay to the
Floyd County Sheriff an amount equal to four dollars ($4.00) per capita of the population of the City. This
amount shall be due and payable on the Effective Date of this agreement.
8. Insurance. The County will maintain liability insurance coverage for the activities of the Floyd
County Sheriff and Sheriff's Deputies and employees while providing law enforcement services to the City.
9. Indemnification. The County shall hold the City harmless and shall indemnify the City for any
claims or causes of action for damages to persons or property resulting solely from the negligent acts of the
County in providing law enforcement services to the City.
10. Amendments. This agreement shall only be amended by the consent and action of both the County
and the City.
11. Early Termination. The County may terminate this agreement at any time by passage of a Motion
by the Board of Supervisors. If terminated between the effective dates of this agreement, a proportional amount
of the Consideration paid to the County shall be returned to the City. This shall be calculated by multiplying the
percentage of time between the effective dates services are not provided to the City by the Consideration paid to
the County, with the resulting sum paid by the County to the City. The City may terminate this agreement at any
time, but shall not be entitled to any return of any portion of Consideration.
12. Continuation and Negotiation. The County, by and through the Board of Supervisors, and the City,
by and through the Mayor, shall meet on November 5, 2012. The purpose of that meeting shall be to enter into
negotiations regarding a possible extension of this agreement and/or negotiating a different agreement pertaining
to law enforcement services to the City. This paragraph is not intended to create any presumption or intent, by
either party, to extend or continue this agreement past the Effective Date of this agreement.
13. Advisory Board. This agreement shall not, under any circumstances, create a separate legal entity.
There shall be, however, an advisory board created consisting of the Floyd County Sheriff and City Mayor.  This
advisory board shall meet at the request of either party to discuss performance of this agreement. This paragraph
is intended to supersede Iowa Code 28E.6(1)(a).
14. Property. Any and all real and personal property used in performance of this agreement shall be
acquired, held, maintained, and retained by the County.

28E AGREEMENT
FOR THE ADMINISTRATION/MANAGEMENT
OF WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT IN REGION 7
This 28E Agreement (Agreement) is made and entered into this 1st day of July, 2011, and 
ending on June 30, 2012, by and between the lowa Workforce Development (IWD) and
Hawkeye Community College (HCC).  The parties agree as follows:
Section 1.
Purpose.  The purpose of this Agreement is to establish a procedure for hiring a
Operations Director in Region 7 and to provide for the employment and terms of
employment of the Operations Director.
Identity of the Parties: Iowa Workforce Development (IWD), which is a duly
Section 1.1
created state department, is authorized, among other things, to provide and fund
workforce development programs. IWD's state administrative address is 1000
East Grand Avenue, Des Moines, lowa 50319. HCC is authorized among other
things, to provide and fund workforce development programs. HCC's address is
1501 East Orange Road, Waterloo IA 50704. This Agreement does not create
any separate legal or administrative parties or entities.
Section 2.
Responsibilities of Parties.
2.1
HCC shall provide day-to-day operational support services for IWD employees
located at the Waterloo Workforce Development Center and any satellite centers
in Region 7. These services will be provided by the Operations Director, who
shall be employed by HCC. The Operations Director shall provide all
administrative/management services in accordance with all applicable federal,
state, local laws and regulations, merit system rules, and collective bargaining
agreement rules and practices. (See attachment A for complete list of documents
currently included in all Regional and PROMISE JOBS Master Agreements.)
2.2.
Policy guidelines for Workforce Development Center operations will be jointly
agreed upon by appropriate HCC and IWD representatives and will comply with
applicable personnel and labor relations policies of both entities.
2.3
In the absence of the Operations Director, personnel issues involving IWD
employees which require the involvement of IWD administration will be the
responsibility of the Regional Division Administrator for the Workforce
Development Center Administration (WDCA) or their Designee.
2.4
HCC shall permit the Operations Director to participate in staff development,
training, and management meetings required by IWD.
2.5
HCC shall be responsible for the payment of the Operations Director's salary and
personnel benefits according to its existing policies. HCC shall be solely
responsible for the payment of all applicable federal and state withholding taxes
and social security taxes, workers compensation, employer's liability, and
unemployment compensation taxes. All fringe benefits provided the Operations
Director will be in accordance with HCC policy.
Region 7 Operations Director 28e May 2011
Page 1 of 11
2.6
Selection, evaluation and termination of the Operations Director will be within the
joint discretion of HCC and IWD.  IWD shall provide HCC with its comments
concerning potential candidates for the Operations Director's position and shall
periodically provide HCC with its comments concerning the performance of the
Operations Director in order to assist HCC with its evaluation. HCC will notify
IWD when the evaluation is being developed, a deadline for IWD comment
submission, and a signed copy of the completed evaluation for IWD records.
2.7
IWD shall provide staff development and training services to ensure the
Operations Director is knowledgeable of IWD practices, procedures, and policies.
Reserved for future use.
2.8
The Workforce Development Center Operations Director.
Section 3.
3.1
The Operations Director shall, at all times, be considered the employee of HCC
and not an employee of IWD. (See attachment B for Operations Director job
description.)
The Operations Director shall consult with the WDCA Division Administrator or
3.2
their Designee and the Department of Administrative Services (DAS) personnel
officer assigned to IWD before taking any disciplinary action against any IWD
employee.  Joint review by both the Operations Director and the WDCA Division
Administrator or their Designee will precede any performance appraisal and related
action for any IWD employee.
When notifying HCC of any annual or sick leave requests, the Operations Director
3.3
shall also inform the IWD Regional lowa Works Director or their Designee.
3.4
The Operations Director shall attend all regularly scheduled meetings of the IWD
regional managers and joint administrators, as well as any other required meeting
called by the WDCA Administrator or their Designee. The Operations Director will
Inform the WDCA Administrator or their Designee of conflicts that may prohibit
attendance.
Section 4.
Compensation.
Reserved for future use.
Section 5.
Effective Date of Agreement.  This Agreement shall be effective when the
following conditions are completed:
5.1
The Agreement is signed by IWD and HCC.
The Agreement or a recordable form of this Agreement is recorded by the Polk and
5.2
Black Hawk County Recorders.
5.3
The Agreement is filed with lowa Secretary of State.

Region 7 Operations Director 28e May 2011
Section 6.
Term of Agreement. This Agreement shall be in effect beginning July 1, 2011,
and ending June 30, 2012, with the option to renew for two (2) additional one-year
terms. This Agreement may be terminated at any time, by either party, for any
reason upon at least sixty (60) days written notice in advance of the specified
termination date.
Section 7.
Termination. This Agreement may be terminated in any of the following
circumstances:
a)  At IWD or HCC discretion, without cause, after sixty (60) days written notice
to the other party by FAX with hard copy to follow by overnight delivery.
b) As a result of default under this Agreement.
c} As a result of the termination or reduction of funding to IWD.
d) Due to bankruptcy, insolvency, or receivership.
Section 8.
Authorization.  Each party to this Agreement represents and warrants to the other
that (1) it has the right, power, and authority to enter into and perform its
obligations under this Agreement; and (2) it has taken all requisite action
(corporate, statutory, or otherwise) to approve execution, deliver, and performance
of this Agreement, and this Agreement constitutes a legal, valid, and binding
obligation upon itself in accordance with its terms.
The Vice President of Academic Affairs of HCC and the IWD Administrator of the
Division of Workforce Development Center Administration will be responsible for
administration of this Agreement.
Section 9.
Default.
9.1
The occurrence of any one or more of the following events shall constitute cause
for IWD or HCC to declare the other party in default of its obligations under this
Agreement:
a)  Non-performance of this Agreement.
b)  A failure of either party to make substantial and timely progress toward
performance of the Agreement.
c) A failure of either party's work product and services to conform with any
specifications noted herein.
d) A repeated exhibition of defects in the services delivered by either party,
causing serious disruption of use or downtime over a six month period.
e} A breach of provisions related to intellectual property.
f) A failure to make payments required under this Agreement.
g) A breach of any term of this Agreement.
9.2
HCC or IWD shall not be considered to be in default under this
Agreement if its performance is delayed or made impossible by an Act of
God, floods, fires, strikes, a freight embargo or similar events; but in each
such case, the delay or impossibility must go beyond the reasonable control
and without the fault of HCC or IWD. In event of such delay, the
scheduled date of delivery shall be extended on a dav-to-day basis until
delivery of performance is possible and feasible.
9.3
HCC shall not be liable for indirect, special, or consequential damages
resulting from a breach of this Agreement.

a) Exercise any remedy provided by law,
b) Terminate this Agreement as set forth in Section 7 of this Agreement.

LAW ENFORCEMENT CONTRACT
This contract is made and entered into this 1st day of July,
2014, by and between the county of Tama, hereinafter referred to as
"County" and the City of Dysart hereinafter referred
to 
as
"Municipality".
The Municipality desires to contract for Law Enforcement
services with the County. The County is agreeable to rendering such
services on terms and conditions hereinafter set forth.
Such contracts are authorized and provided for by the provisions
of the 1997 Code of Iowa, Chapter 28E.
It is agreed as follows:
OBLIGATION OF COUNTY.
The County agrees through thee Sheriff
1.
of the County to provide police protection within the corporate limits
of
the Municipality, which services shall encompass the duties and
functions of the type customarily rendered by professional
law
enforcement officers including the enforcement of State Statutes and
Municipal Ordinances. The Sheriff's Office will attempt to provide law
enforcement coverage in the absence of the Dysart officer.
The
Sheriff's Office will provide a car and officer for all other police
assistance requested in the city of Dysart if the officers assigned to
the Dysart area are not otherwise available.
The Sheriff's Office shall make monthly reports to the Mayor which
reports shall include a summary of the enforcement activity conducted by
the Sheriff's Office within the Municipality,
summary of the criminal
activity within the Municipality, and interim reports on other matters
not considered routine criminal matters.
Either the number of hours or units (Car-patrolman) may
be
increased or decreased, with the adjustments being made for the cost of
said service by mutual agreement of the parties.
It is anticipated by the parties that emergencies may arise in the
County, which may necessitate the withdrawal of the unit or units from
the City of Dysart for the duration of the emergency.
It is agreed that the Municipality will share the service of the
Tama County Sheriff's Office with other cities in surrounding areas of
Deputies shall, where applicable, file charges under
the
county.
Municipal ordinances, but if the town has no ordinance, then the charge
will be filed under the applicable state statute. The officers will
appear to testify in those cases in which they are witnesses without
subpoenas, and the city will provide legal counsel and
requiring
prosecution of ordinances as requested by the officer.
The discipline of officers, matters
2.
CONTROL OF DEPUTY.
incident to performance of services, and control of personnel so
l
employed, shall remain in the County.
3.
24 HOUR COVERAGE.
The Municipality agrees that it shall
hold Tama County responsible for providing exclusive continuous
not
surveillance for any 24- hour period unless the threat of a crime so
dictates.
COOPERATION.
4.
To facilitate the performance of said function,
it is hereby agreed that the County shall have full cooperation and
assistance from the Municipality, its officers, agents and employees.
The Municipality agrees to the county using the car, equipment, radio
and officers equipment during the period of this agreement after which
time same shall revert back to the Municipality.  The County agrees to
accept the operating and maintenance costs of this equipment for the
period of the contract.
5. 
LIABILITIES.
(a)
The Municipality shall not be called upon to assume any
liability for the direct payment of any salaries, wages or any other
compensation to any County personnel performing services hereunder for
said 
Municipality or any liability other that provide for in the

contract.
indemnity to any County employee for injury or sickness arising out of

(b)
Tama County, its officers and employees, shall not be deemed
to assume any liability for intentional or negligent acts of said
Municipality or officers or employees thereof, and said Municipality
shall hold such County and its officers and employees harmless from and
shall defend said County and its officers and employees against any
claim for damages resulting therefrom.
The Municipality shall not be responsible for any act, injury
(c)
or damage arising out of the performance of this contract by the County
of Tama, and in any case claim is made by any third party, the County
shall defend indemnify and hold harmless the Municipality.
6 .
PAYMENT.
The Municipality agrees to pay the hourly rate of
$44.27 for all calls responded to within the city limit, subject to an
increase or decrease as the parties may mutually agree, if the services
contracted for in paragraph 1 hereof are materially changed.
It is
contemplated that this contract shall be effective July 1, 2013, and
shall run for a period of 12 months thereafter.
DURATION OF CONTRACT. At the option of the governing body of
the Municipality, with the consent of the Board of County Supervisors of
Tama County, this contract shall be renewable for successive periods not
to exceed 12 months. In the event the Municipality desires to renew
this contract for any succeeding period, the governing body of the
Municipality shall notify the Sheriff of Tama County and the Tama County
Board of Supervisors, in writing, that it wishes to renew the same,
whereupon the Board of Supervisors shall notify in writing the governing
body of the Municipality of its willingness to accept the renewal for no
more
2
than 12 additional months, or such other terms as agreed to. Otherwise,
the contract shall finally terminate at the end of such initial or
renewal period.
(a) 
Notwithstanding the provision of the paragraph set forth,
either party may terminate this contract as of the first day of any
month, upon notice in writing to the other party prior to the date of
termination.
ACCESS TO RECORDS.
8.

access to records, documents and papers to auditors representing the

NON-DISCRIMINATION.
Both parties mutually agree that if the
contract price shall exceed $10,000 then the parties assure the Iowa
Crime
Commission that an affirmation action plan
declaring
no
discrimination on the base of race, religion, creed, national origin,

REVIEW AND COMPLIANCE.
10.
The Sheriff of Tama County shall meet
monthly with a designated represented of the Municipality to review the
logs and work of the Sheriff's Department in the Municipality.
Any
complaints, requests or discretionary police matters shall be directed
to the Sheriff.
11.
DISPUTES, APPEALS AND REMEDIES.
Except as otherwise provided
in this agreement, any dispute concerning a question of fact arising
under this agreement which is not disposed of by agreement shall be
decided by the County which shall reduce such decision to writing and
furnish a copy to the Municipality. Such decisions shall be final and
conclusive unless within (30) days from the receipt therefor the
Municipality notifies the County in writing the nature and extent that
the Municipality disagrees with the decision. The cause (s) of the
disagreement shall then be submitted to a mutually agreed upon third
party arbitrator for decision. Either party, if still dissatisfied, may
then appeal the decision of the arbitrator in the procedure followed in
a court of contempt jurisdiction.
The parties agree that this agreement
shall be governed by the laws of the State of Iowa.

agents of the parties.

AGREEMENT FOR JOINT EXERCISE OF GOVERNMENTAL POWERS
PURSUANT TO IOWA CODE CHAPTER 28E
AND
ATHLETIC TRAINER SERVICES AGREEMENT
RECITALS:
Iowa Valley Community College District (the "College") is a community college which
is organized and existing under Iowa Code Chapter 260C and which provides various
educational programs. The College also provides athletic programs and opportunities for athletic
competition to its students and requires athletic training services.
McFarland Clinic, P. C. ("McFarland") is an Iowa Professional Corporation which,
among other things, provides athletic trainer services to educational institutions. In the provision
of these services, McFarland employs athletic trainers certified by the National Athletic Trainers
Association ("NATA"), Board of Certification ("Certified Athletic Trainer(s)"), physical
therapists licensed to practice physical therapy in the State of Iowa ("Physical Therapist(s)"), and
students enrolled in NATA accredited athletic trainer programs at institutions of higher education
("Student Athletic Trainer(s)").
The College has established courses regarding athletic training and McFarland employs
individuals who are qualified to serve as instructors for such courses.
lowa Code Section 28E.4 authorizes public agencies of the State of Iowa to enter into
agreements with one or more public or private agencies for joint or cooperative action.
AGREEMENT FOR JOINT EXERCISE OF GOVERNMENTAL POWERS
PURSUANT TO IOWA CODE CHAPTER 28E
NOW, THEREFORE, IT IS HEREBY AGREED by and between the lowa Valley
Community College District and McFarland Clinic, P.C., pursuant to the provisions of Iowa
Code Chapter 28E, as follows:
The purpose of this agreement is to provide athletic trainer
1.
Purpose.
instructional services to the students in the Iowa Valley Community College District.
This agreement shall be of indefinite duration and shall remain in
2.
Duration.
effect for an indefinite term or until it is terminated as herein provided in Section 9.
Governance. No separate legal or administrative entity shall be created for the
3.
governance or administration of the terms or subject matter of this agreement. This agreement
will be jointly administered by the President of the Iowa Valley Community College District and
the CEO/Medical Director of the McFarland Clinie, P.C. It is not contemplated that any real or
personal property will be acquired or held for the purpose of carrying out the terms of this
agreement.
The College shall use General Fund moneys to pay for its share of
4.
Financing.
the salary and insurance benefits of the McFarland employee who serves as the instructor for the
athletic trainer courses.
Allocation of Duties of the Parties. The duties of the College shall be: (1) to
5.
establish the job description for the position of instructor for athletic trainer courses, (2) to
participate in the interview process for the instructor for the athletic trainer courses, (3) to
establish a professional development plan for the instructor for the athletic trainer courses, (4) to
evaluate the performance of teaching duties by the instructor for the athletic trainer courses, (5)
to establish the office hours to be maintained and division meetings and events to be attended by
the instructor for the athletic trainer courses, and (6) to provide the instructor for the athletic
trainer courses with the office space and equipment which is necessary to perform his or her
duties.
The duties of McFarland shall be: (1) to employ and provide an individual who meets the
requirements of the job description established by the College and who is qualified to serve as
the instructor for the athletic trainer courses, (2) to conduct appropriate background checks
regarding the instructor for the athletic trainer courses, (3) to provide the instructor for the
athletic trainer courses for a period of ten (10) months at the Ellsworth campus of the College,
(4) to make the agreed-upon salary payments and to provide insurance benefits to the instructor
for the athletic trainer courses, and (5) to provide liability insurance for the instructor for the
athletic trainer courses.
In consideration of the services to be provided by McFarland to
6.
Payment.
School through a Certified Athletic Trainer, Physical Therapist or Student Athletic Trainer under
this Agreement, School shall pay McFarland in accordance with the Fee Schedules set forth in
Schedule 1 of this Agreement, as applicable. School shall pay McFarland for services rendered
under this Agreement on a monthly basis no later than fourteen (14) days after the date of the
invoice for services rendered..
7.
Indemnity.
To the extent permitted by law, the College and McFarland agree
to indemnify and hold each other harmless from any and all claims, causes of action, attorney
fees, costs or other expenditures occasioned by undertakings assumed by each, respectively, in
this Agreement.
8.
Amendments. This agreement may be amended by the parties at any time by the
adoption of the amendment by the Board of Trustees of the College and the Board of Directors
of McFarland.
9.
Termination. This agreement may be terminated by mutual agreement of the
College and McFarland. In the absence of mutual agreement, either the College or McFarland
may terminate this agreement effective at the end of any fiscal year (June 30) by giving sixty
(60) days written notice to the other party prior to the end of the fiscal year. Notice of
termination shall be sent be by certified mail to the Secretary of the Board of the College or the
CEO/Medical Director of McFarland at the address listed below. This Agreement shall
commence effective as of the date hereof and shall terminate one year from the date of this
Agreement, and shall be automatically renewable for successive one-year terms thereafter. Upon
termination of this Agreement, School shall pay all amounts due to McFarland pursuant to the
terms of this Agreement through the date of termination.

ATHLETIC TRAINER SERVICES AGREEMENT
The College and McFarland agree as follows:
I .
Services.
McFarland shall, through one or more Certified Athletic Trainers, Physical
Therapists or Student Athletic Trainers, as elected by School pursuant to Schedule 1
attached hereto, be the exclusive provider to School of the following athletic trainer
services:
(a)
Physical evaluation, emergency care, and physical reconditioning (excluding any
physical reconditioning required to be carried out under the orders of a physician
or physician assistant) relating to injuries and illnesses incurred by School student
athletes through sports-induced trauma, which occurs during the preparation for or
participation in a sports competition event sponsored by School ("School Athletic
Event(s)").
(b)
Attendance at School Athletic Events (including, without limitation, any practices
for sports competition events) for purposes of rendering the services described in
paragraph 1(a) above in accordance with a schedule determined in advance by the
parties in writing; provided, however, that in the event McFarland is not able to
provide a Certified Athletic Trainer, Physical Therapist, or Student Athletic
Trainer, as applicable, for a School Athletic Event, it shall, when reasonably
possible, provide School with at least eight (8) hours notice prior to the applicable
event. Such notice shall be by telephone to the School Athletic Director or School
coach for such School Athletic Event.
Supervision by a Certified Athletic Trainer or Physical Therapist of any Student
(c)
Athletic Trainer assigned to School for the performance of services described in
paragraphs 1(a) and (b) above; provided, however, such supervision shall be
limited to reviewing and evaluating any written reports prepared by a Student
Athletic Trainer as well as being available via telephone to consult with a Student
Athletic Trainer, and will not include the personal presence of a Certified Athletic
Trainer at a School Athletic Event.
(d)
Upon written request by School, provide recommendations to School regarding
appropriate equipment for student athletes for use in School Athletic Events as
well as other injury prevention measures, including, without limitation,
recommended parameters of weather conditions for student athletes' participation
in School Athletic Events.
(e)
Preparation and submission to School's athletic director of quarterly status reports
summarizing the student athletes' injuries, subject, however, to any confidentiality
obligations as described in paragraph 11 below.
Upon written request by School, an oral presentation to the coaches employed by
(f)
School on first aid care, injury protocols and emergency health care procedures.
Such presentation, if requested, shall be made at the beginning of the School's
school year.
All services rendered by a Certified Athletic Trainer, Physical Therapist or Student
Athletic Trainer under this Agreement shall be within the scope of services generally
provided by certified athletic trainers or licensed physical therapists, as applicable.
McFarland and any Certified Athletic Trainer, Physical Therapist, Physical Therapist, or
Student Athletic Trainer will not be required to render any medical care to student athletes
that are required to be rendered by a licensed physician. Any Certified Athletic Trainer,
Physical Therapist or Student Athletic Trainer performing services hereunder shall
perform such services in accordance with the professional ethics and practice as may from
time to time be applicable. Any Certified Athletic Trainer performing services under this
Agreement shall at all times be certified by NATA to perform athletic trainer services and,
if required by applicable law, licensed as an athletic trainer; provided, however, it is
expressly understood that Student Athletic Trainers providing services hereunder shall not
be required to have such certification or license. Any Physical Therapist performing
services under this Agreement shall at all times be licensed to practice physical therapy in
the State of Iowa.
2.
Facilities and Equipment. School shall provide, at its expense, all necessary space and
equipment to enable McFarland to perform services under this Agreement, including,
without limitation:
(a)
Athletic training room(s) and training room equipment, including, without
limitation, a training table and storage space.
(b)
Training supplies including, without limitation, adequate tape (one inch (I") and
two inch (2") width rolls); pre-wraps; Ace wraps (four inch (4") and six inch (6")
width rolls); band aids (one inch (1") and three inch (3") width and knuckle); and
tuf skin spray; as well as any other supplies mutually agreed upon by the parties.
Emergency equipment including, without limitation, one (1) stretcher (conventional
(c)
or scoop) or full length backboard, two (2) air splints, and one (1) cervical collar.
3.
Emergency Medical Transport Service. School shall provide at its own expense an
emergency medical transport ("EMT Service") for purposes of rendering medical care to
student athletes at each School Athletic Event involving the sport of football where a
Certified Athletic Trainer, Physical Therapist or Student Athletic Trainer is rendering
services pursuant to the terms of this Agreement.
4.
Requirements Relating to Student Athletes. As a condition to rendering services under
this Agreement to School student athletes, School shall provide to McFarland written
documentation showing that all student athletes participating in School Athletic Events
have completed physical examinations conducted by a licensed physician, and that such
student athletes have been deemed by such physician physically and otherwise able to
participate in such events. In addition, School shall provide in writing to McFarland in
advance of any School Athletic Event for each School student athlete participating in
such event, the following information: (a) name of student athlete; (b) student athlete's
home telephone number; (c) name of parents/legal guardian(s); and (d) parents'/legal
guardians' telephone number,
5.
Student Athletic Trainers. McFarland shall be solely responsible for the selection and
supervision of any Student Athletic Trainers providing athletic trainer services under this
Agreement. Student Athletic Trainers shall report to a Certified Athletic Trainer, it being
the intent of the parties that a Student Athletic Trainer shall not be directed in the services
rendered pursuant to the terms of this Agreement by School or any School employee,
agent, student or parent/legal guardian of student.
Transportation. School shall not be responsible for transportation of Certified Athletic
6.
Trainer, Physical Therapist, or Student Athletic Trainer for travel to and from School
Athletic Events; provided, however, School shall reimburse McFarland for mileage for
travel to and from Student Athletic Events not held at School's sites. In addition, under
no circumstances will a Certified Athletic Trainer, Physical Therapist or Student Athletic
Trainer provide transportation to any School employee, agent or student athlete.
7.
Payment to McFarland. In consideration of the services to be provided by McFarland to
School through a Certified Athletic Trainer, Physical Therapist or Student Athletic
Trainer under this Agreement, School shall pay McFarland in accordance with the Fee
Schedules set forth in Schedule 1 of this Agreement, as applicable. School shall pay
McFarland for services rendered under this Agreement on a monthly basis no later than
fourteen (14) days after the date of the invoice for services rendered.
No Additional Professional Services Required. Nothing contained in this Agreement
8.
shall be construed to require student athletes of School to use the professional services of
McFarland beyond the services provided hereunder, nor to require McFarland to provide
professional services to any School student athlete beyond the services provided
hereunder, such decisions in each case being the independent and personal decisions of
each student athlete, his or her parents/legal guardian, his/her physician, and McFarland.
9.
School agrees, without charge, to identify McFarland as the provider of
Publicity.
athletic trainer services in each of its programs and other School publications utilized for
School Athletic Events. In addition, School agrees to allow McFarland to post a sign at
such events identifying McFarland as the provider of athletic trainer services to the
School.
10.
Term and Termination of Agreement. This agreement may be terminated by mutual
agreement of the College and McFarland. In the absence of mutual agreement, either the
College or McFarland may terminate this agreement effective at the end of any fiscal year
(June 30) by giving sixty (60) days written notice to the other party prior to the end of the
fiscal year. Notice of termination shall be sent be by certified mail to the Secretary of the
Board of the College or the CEO/Medical Director of McFarland at the address listed
below. This Agreement shall commence effective as of the date hereof and shall
terminate one year from the date of this Agreement, and shall be automatically renewable
for successive one-year terms thereafter. Upon termination of this Agreement, School
shall pay all amounts due to McFarland pursuant to the terms of this Agreement through
the date of termination.
11.
Insurance.
(a)
McFarland or its subcontractor shall at all times maintain professional liability
insurance in the amount of no less than One Million Dollars ($1,000,000) per
occurrence (with such deductibles as shall be determined by McFarland), such
insurance to provide coverage in the amount required hereunder for claims made
at any time (whether during or after the term of this Agreement) on account of an
incident, act or omission of a Certified Athletic Trainer, Physical Therapist or
Student Athletic Trainer occurring during the term of this Agreement. McFarland
or its subcontractor, as applicable, will provide evidence of insurance coverage
and premium payment to School from time to time as requested by School.
McFarland or its subcontractor, as applicable, will immediately notify School in
the event it receives notice of any proposed cancellation, actual cancellation or
change in coverage of its professional liability insurance. McFarland expressly
acknowledges that its agreement pursuant to this paragraph shall survive the
termination of this Agreement.
School shall at all times maintain general comprehensive liability insurance in the
(b)
amount of no less than One Million Dollars ($1,000,000) per occurrence, such
insurance to provide coverage in the amount required hereunder for claims made
at any time (whether during or after the term of this Agreement) on account of an
incident, act or omission occurring during the term of this Agreement. School
will provide evidence of insurance coverage and premium payment to McFarland
from time to time as requested by McFarland. School will immediately notify
McFarland in the event it receives notice of any proposed cancellation, actual
cancellation or change in coverage of its comprehensive liability insurance.
School expressly acknowledges that its agreement pursuant to this paragraph shall
survive the termination of this Agreement.
School shall ensure that EMT Service shall at all times maintain professional
(c)
liability insurance in the amount of no less than One Million Dollars ($1,000,000)
per occurrence, such insurance to provide coverage in the amount required
hereunder for claims made at any time (whether during or after the term of this
Agreement) on account of an incident, act or omission occurring during the term

School will immediately notify McFarland in the event it receives notice of any

Agreement.
Indemnification. McFarland shall indemnify and hold School harmless from and against
12.
any and all liabilities, losses, damages, costs or expenses, including, but not limited to,
reasonable attorneys' fees and legal expenses, incurred by School as a result of a breach of
this Agreement by McFarland or any tortious, unlawful or unauthorized acts or omissions

Payment for Services
For the Fiscal Year ending June 30, 2006: The College shall pay fifty percent (50%) of the
salary and insurance benefits of the McFarland employee who serves as the instructor for the
athletic trainer courses. This payment shall not exceed Twenty-Two Thousand Five Hundred
Dollars ($22,500.00) for ten (10) months of service, and a payment of one-tenth of the agreed-
upon amount shall be made by the College to McFarland on a monthly basis.
For the Fiscal year ending June 30, 2007: If the Agreement is not terminated according to the
terms of Section 9, the College shall pay fifty percent (50%) of the salary and insurance benefits
of the McFarland employee who serves as the instructor for the athletic trainer courses. This
payment shall not exceed Twenty-Three Thousand Four Hundred Dollars ($23,400.00) for ten
(10) months of service, and a payment of one-tenth of the agreed-upon amount shall be made by
the College to McFarland on a monthly basis.
Additional terms: The College and McFarland will mutually agree to payment for any additional
terms after the Fiscal year ending June 30, 2007. If mutual agreement cannot be reached, either
party may give 60-days written notice to terminate the Agreement.
