LAW ENFORCEMENT AGREEMENT
PURSUANT TO CHAPTER 28E CODE OF IOWA
The undersigned County of Floyd and City of Floyd do hereby agree as follows:
l. Purpose.
The purpose of this agreement is for the provision of law enforcement services by Floyd
County to the City of Floyd on the terms and conditions set forth hercin.
2. Parties. The parties to this agreement are the County of Floyd (hercinafter "County") and the City of
Floyd (hercinafter "City"). Both parties are political subdivisions of the State of Iowa duly authorized by the
Code of Iowa
3. Effective Date. This agreement shall become effective on the First (1") day of July, 2011.
This agreement shall be effective for a period of time extending from the First (16) day of
4. Duration.
July, 2011 up to and including the Thirtieth (30th) day of June, 2012.
The County agrees to provide law enforcement services to the City of Floyd
5. Service Provided.
during the duration of this agreement. The law enforcement services shall be performed by the Floyd County
Sheriff and the Sheriff's Deputies and employees.
6. Services Specifically Excluded. The County, the Sheriff, and/or the Sheriff's Deputies and
employees shall not provide any type of service relating to the regulation, control, or abatement of any animals
within the City. The County, the Sheriff, and/or the Sheriff's Deputies will not enforce any violation of the City's
ordinances. This paragraph is not intended to be a complete list of services the County will not provide, but is
intended to be an express exclusion under this agreement.
7. Consideration. In consideration for the services provided by the County, the City shall pay to the
Floyd County Sheriff an amount equal to four dollars ($4.00) per capita of the population of the City. This
amount shall be due and payable on the Effective Date of this agreement.
8. Insurance. The County will maintain liability insurance coverage for the activities of the Floyd
County Sheriff and Sheriff's Deputies and employees while providing law enforcement services to the City.
9. Indemnification. The County shall hold the City harmless and shall indemnify the City for any
claims or causes of action for damages to persons or property resulting solely from the negligent acts of the
County in providing law enforcement services to the City.
10. Amendments. This agreement shall only be amended by the consent and action of both the County
and the City.
11. Early Termination. The County may terminate this agreement at any time by passage of a Motion
by the Board of Supervisors. If terminated between the effective dates of this agreement, a proportional amount
of the Consideration paid to the County shall be returned to the City. This shall be calculated by multiplying the
percentage of time between the effective dates services are not provided to the City by the Consideration paid to
the County, with the resulting sum paid by the County to the City. The City may terminate this agreement at any
time, but shall not be entitled to any return of any portion of Consideration,
12. Continuation and Negotiation. The County, by and through the Board of Supervisors, and the City,
by and through the Mayor, shall meet on Monday, November 7, 2011. The purpose of that meeting shall be to
enter into negotiations regarding a possible extension of this agreement and/or negotiating a different agreement
pertaining to law enforcement services to the City. This paragraph is not intended to create any presumption or
intent, by cither party, to extend or continue this agreement past the Effective Date of this agreement.
13. Advisory Board. This agreement shall not, under any circumstances, create a separate legal entity.
There shall be, however, an advisory board created consisting of the Floyd County Sheriff and City Mayor. This
advisory board shall meet at the request of either party to discuss performance of this agreement. This paragraph
is intended to supersede Iowa Code 28E.6(1)(a).
,14 .. Property. Any and all real and personal property used in performance of this agreement shall be
acquired] held, maintained, and retained by the County.

COUNTY, IOWA
WHEREAS, Johnson County and the City both provide services requiring routine as well as
emergency radio communications to City residents; and
WHEREAS, it is mutually beneficial to both parties to have access to public safety facilities, as
well as to routine communications facilities which serve both parties and the public; and
WHEREAS, it is mutually beneficial for the City and County to cooperate and to work closely
together in the area of radio communications; and
WHEREAS, Chapter 28E, Code of Iowa, (2007), permits state and local governments to make
efficient use of their resources and powers in order to provide joint services through the use of a
duly recorded agreement; and
WHEREAS, the City and Johnson County, lowa have a 28E Agreement for radio communications
which, by its terms, expires on August 1, 2007, and the parties desire to renew said agreement on 
substantially the same terms.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF IOWA
CITY, IOWA, THAT:

interests of the citizens of lowa City, lowa.

the Agreement attached in the Secretary of State's office for the State of Iowa, and also in
the Johnson County Recorder's Office, as required by Chapter 28E, Code of lowa (2007).

CHAPTER 28E AGREEMENT
FOR RADIO COMMUNICATIONS
BETWEEN THE CITY OF IOWA CITY, IOWA
AND JOHNSON COUNTY, IOWA
This Agreement is made and entered into by and between the City of lowa City, lowa, a municipal
corporation ("City"), and Johnson County, Iowa, ("County"), both governmental entities,
sometimes collectively referred to as "Parties." 
WHEREAS, Johnson County and the City both provide services requiring routine as well as
emergency radio communications to City residents; and
WHEREAS, it is mutually beneficial to both parties to have access to public safety facilities, as
well as to routine communications facilities which serve both Parties and the public; and
WHEREAS, it is mutually beneficial for both the City and the County to cooperate, and to work
closely with one another in the area of radio communications; and
WHEREAS, it is in the best interest of both Parties to share communications systems whenever
possible, for the mutual benefit of the citizens of the City of lowa City, and Johnson County, and
WHEREAS, Chapter 28E, Code of Iowa (2007) permits state and Iocal governmental entities to
make efficient use of their resources and powers, in order to provide joint services by way of a
duly recorded agreement.
-2-
NOW, THEREFORE, in consideration of their mutual promises herein, Johnson County and the
City of Iowa City agree as follows:
No Separate Legal Entity is created by this Agreement / Administrator
1.
Johnson County acknowledges the City purchased an eight hundred (800 MHz) radio trunking 
system ("System"), with sufficient capacity to allow the Johnson County Ambulance Service
("JCAS"), a department of Johnson County, lowa, to participate in the use of the system.  No
separate legal entity is created by this Agreement.  Each party will act as administrator of their
own duties.  The lowa City Fire Chief is assigned to be the Agreement administrator.
Purpose:  The purpose of this Agreement is the provision of radio communication
2.
services.  To that end, the City and the County agree more specifically as follows:
a) 
The City shall allow the JCAS to use a number of talk groups (a line of
communications shared by a distinct group of radio units) as agreed to by 
both Parties for use by the JCAS.
b)
The County will purchase all equipment needed by the JCAS, and the
JCAS agrees to maintain any and all equipment so purchased by the JCAS
pursuant to this Agreement.
The City agrees to maintain the 800 MHz trunking radio equipment system
c) 
which is the subject of this Agreement, and to do so adequately and 
responsibly.  Upon future capital investment, upgrade to or replacement of 
the City's radio system, a capital contribution will be required from all
parties involved. Such capital contribution shall be addressed in a separate
agreement between the parties.
- 3 -
d)
Parties agree that the JCAS's cost for use of the 800 MHz trunking radio
equipment system will be determined in September of each fiscal year, for
implementation, billing and payment during said fiscal year, and City
agrees to submit a "user fee" billing to JCAS, to be paid within sixty (60)
calendar days of the date of the billing.
Manner of Financing: The County agrees to pay to City a user fee of
e)
$138 per radio unit per year, to be billed by City on or after September 1 of
each year.  Said billing shall be paid within sixty (60) calendar days of the
date of said billing.  JCAS also agrees to pay the proper amounts billed for
any additional radio units added to the trunking system for JCAS during a 
fiscal year, which shall be paid on a monthly pro-rated basis, with payment
also due within sixty (60) calendar days of billing on or after September 1 of
each year.
The annual user fee noted above may be increased, but not decreased,
during the extended term (i.e. each year after fiscal 2007) by an amount
not to exceed the percentage increase in the United States Bureau of 
Labor Statistics Consumer Price Index for All Items and Mean Groups
Figures for All Urban Consumers July 2007, over the figures for the month
of July 2006.  For each successive year of the automatic renewal term, the
annual user fee may be increased by the percentage increase in the CPI
from the previous fiscal year as outlined above.
- 4 -
Duration and Termination: Parties agree this Agreement shall be for a
f)
period of eleven (11) months from August 1, 2007, and that this Agreement
shall be automatically renewed for additional periods of one (1) year each,
on the same terms and conditions outlined herein, unless either party gives
the other party written notice to terminate the agreement sixty (60) calendar
days prior to August 1 of each successive year.  However, this Agreement
shall not extend beyond July 1, 2012, without review and re-execution of a
new agreement, together with re-recording of said updated agreement.
g)
Parties agree this Agreement is not assignable.
h)
Notices under this agreement shall be sent by regular mail to the City
Clerk of Iowa City and to the Johnson County Board of Supervisors at
their regular mailing addresses and shall be deemed delivered upon the
date of mailing.  Further, all amendments or addenda shall be in writing
and duly executed by proper authority of each municipal corporation
named herein.
3.
Parties hereto acknowledge that this Agreement shall conform to the requirements
of Chapter 28E, Code of Iowa (2007); and that this agreement, as such, be in force and effect
only after execution by the City Council of the City of Iowa City and the Johnson County Board of
Supervisors, upon filing with the Secretary of State of the State of lowa, and upon this Agreement
being duly recorded with the Johnson County Recorder's Office, Johnson County, Iowa.

AGREEMENT
BETWEEN THE CITY OF MAURICE, IOWA AND SIOUX COUNTY, IOWA
RELATING TO THE PROVISION OF LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES
THIS AGREEMENT, consisting of two (2) pages, is made between the City of
Maurice, Iowa, a municipality of the State of Iowa (hereinafter "Maurice") and Sioux
County, Iowa (hereinafter "County").
WHEREAS, Maurice wishes to contract with County for law enforcement services
within the corporate limits of Maurice; and
WHEREAS such Agreements are authorized in Iowa Code §28E;
NOW THEREFORE, Maurice and County agree as follows:
l ) County agrees, through the Sioux County Sheriff ("Sheriff") to provide law
enforcement services within the corporate limits of Maurice, including but not
limited to the following:
a) Patrol, traffic enforcement and control, response to complaints or calls,
investigations, emergency service, service of civil documents, and other tasks
typically performed by a law enforcement agency.
b) Sheriff shall be responsible for administrative duties associated with the function
of said law enforcement services.
2) County shall furnish the necessary equipment and personnel to carry out the services
provided for in this agreement.
l
3) Maurice agrees to pay County for the law enforcement services provided by Sheriff.
The payment shall be in an amount to be determined by the Sheriff and the Board of
Supervisors of Sioux County as is necessary to carry out the law enforcement
functions stated in this agreement. Such payments shall be made to the Sheriff's
Office on a quarterly basis, payable as follows: July 1, 2012; October 1, 2012;
January 1, 2013; April 1, 2013. The total amount for this contract period has been
set at: $17,138.
4) This Agreement shall be irrevocable for the duration of the contract period.
Thereafter either party may discontinue participation by providing written notice to
the other no later than May 1st of the current year.
5) This agreement shall be effective on the 1st day of July, 2012 and shall run to the 18t
day of July 2013. Thereafter, at the option of the Maurice City Council, and the
Sioux County Board of Supervisors, with the consent of the Sheriff of Sioux County,
this agreement may be renewable for successive periods not to exceed one (1) year.
APPROVED by the Maurice, Iowa City Council.

THIS AGREEMENT is made this 2 day of
fire
. 200 S
by and between Jasper County, Iowa, doing business under its "Jasper County
Elderly Nutrition Program" and acting by and through its Board of Supervisors
(hereinafter referred to as "Contractor") and Skiff Medical Center, Newton, Iowa,
(hereinafter referred to as the "Sub-Contractor"), and PROVIDES AS FOLLOWS:
NATURE AND DURATION OF AGREEMENT:
1>
ISt day of
This agreement creates no new entity and shall be effective from the
, 200 5, to the 33 day of fire
200 (s. Sub-
Contractor and all employees and agents of Sub-Contractor are wholly independent
of Contractor, and nothing contained within this Agreement is intended to cause
Sub-Contractor or any of its employees or agents to become employees or agents of
Contractor for any purpose.
LICENSING REQUIREMENTS, MEAL PREPARATION AND
2>
DELIVERY:
The Sub-Contractor shall be licensed by the Iowa Department of Inspections and
Appeals, and shall comply with state restaurant license laws and regulations
pertaining to food handling and preparation.
The Sub-Contractor will prepare meals for the Home Delivered Meals aspects of the
program each Saturday and Sunday. Exceptions include holidays designated below
by the Contractor, and other dates specified below by the Sub-Contractor:
CONTRACTOR
SUB-CONTRACTOR
New Year's Day
Independence Day
Veteran's Day
Christmas
The Sub-Contractor shall provide the Contractor with monthly or cycle menus of
meals prepared for the home delivered meals program. Meals prepared shall be
subject to approval of the program director and shall comply with the food pattern
listed below:
Meat or meat alternative - 3 oz. of cooked edible portions of beef, pork,
1.
fish, fowl, luncheon meats, eggs or cheese.
Two Vegetables and 1 Fruit group - two ½ cup servings, (dessert should
2.
not be counted toward this).
Three servings of bread or bread alternative.
3.
Butter or Margarine.
4.
5.
One Milk/Alternative.
Dessert group - one 1/2 cup serving of simple desserts such as fruit,
Q.
pudding, etc.
Modified diets may be provided by the Sub-Contractor upon request by the
Contractor and standard meals shall be modified if required by any changes of any
state of federal agency rule or grant funding requirement. The Contractor shall be
responsible for delivery of meals via its "Elderly Nutrition Program" endeavors.
3>
ACCESS:
Employees of the Contractor, and other qualified representatives shall have access to
the facility at such time as is needed to perform their job responsibilities and to
ensure full compliance with this Agreement by the Sub-Contractor.
CLIENT CERTIFICATION AND RECORDS:
4>
The Contractor, through its Elderly Nutrition Program Director, shall be responsible
for certification of eligible recipients of Home Delivered Meals and delivery of said
meals. Requests for service shall be referred to the Contractor. The Contractor will
notify the Sub-Contractor, in advance, of additions or deletions to the number of
meals to be prepared. Information necessary for the successful operation of the
program shall be exchanged by both parties. The Sub-Contractor shall maintain a
monthly record of meals served to each recipient and submit such records to the
Contractor, c/o Jasper County Elderly Nutrition Program, 115 N. 2nd Avenue E.,
Newton, Iowa 50208, no later than the 5th day of the following month. The
Contractor may provide the Sub-Contractor with any forms needed by Contractor
record keeping and, if so, Sub-Contractor agrees to promptly and accurately
complete and return such forms concurrent with any billing for Sub-Contractor's
services provided hereunder.
BILLING:

The Sub-Contractor shall submit monthly statements for payment, detailing the
number of meals served and cost per meal.  Any additional charges shall be itemized
in the statement. Statements shall be submitted to the Contractor no later than the
last day of each month.
The Sub-Contractor shall provide suitable meals at the rate of $ 5.00 each.
6>
LIABILITY:
The Contractor shall carry primary insurance for personal injury and personal
liability and secondary insurance for product liability. The Sub-Contractor, and its
employees and representatives, shall be held harmless from claims and actions
against the nutrition program for personal injury and personal liability caused by any
employee or representative of Contractor acting within the scope of his or her
employment. The Sub-Contractor shall indemnify through insurance policies and
hold harmless the Contractor, and its employees and representatives, from any act or
omission on the part of the Sub-Contractor, or its employees or representatives,
causing harm or injury to any third person in relation to any matters involved under
this Agreement. The Sub-Contractor shall cooperate to promptly supply the
Contractor's program director with copies of the required policy or policies of
insurance.
NON-DISCRIMINATION:

All parties to this agreement shall comply with the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (P.L.
880352) and all requirements imposed by or pursuant thereto, the Rehabilitation Act

shall be discriminated against, excluded from participation, be denied benefits, or be

may be made in whole or part without the written consent of the Contractor
following public hearing and passage of appropriate resolution.

9>
No variation or modification of this agreement, and no waiver of its provisions, shall
be valid unless in writing and signed by duly authorized officers of both Contractor
and Sub-Contractor. Both parties may, at any time during the life of this agreement
or any extension thereof, terminate this agreement upon thirty (30) days written
notice of intention to do so, except that Contractor may terminate this agreement

this agreement or any violation of applicable laws, rules or regulations on the part of

LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES CONTRACT
9
_ day of February_, 2015, the City of Zearing and Story
On this
County, lowa, enter into the following agreement:
l .
The Story County Sheriff's Office will provide the City of Zearing, Iowa, with
law enforcement services. These services will include but not be limited to:
A.
Radar operations to control speed.
B.
Issuing violations under city ordinances (excluding animal control
ordinances) upon request.
C.
Housing inmates who have been incarcerated under a city ordinance.
D.
Service of abatement notices on request.
E.
Periodically checking commercial buildings for unlocked doors and
trespassers.
F.
Investigation of traffic accidents and complaints.
G.
Dispatch of city fire departments and first responders.
Staffing a 24 hour E911 dispatch center.
H.
l.
Providing a detective division to investigate crimes and conduct
on-going investigations.
J.
Investigation of drug-related offenses.
K.
Supplying schools or community clubs with officers and materials
for special programs and talks upon request.
L.
Routine patrols and special patrols upon request.
M.
Supply fully equipped patrol cars with radio, lights, siren and all
related equipment, gasoline and oil, tires and maintenance, uniforms and
all other personal equipment.
2.
In consideration for the law enforcement services above described. the City of
Zearing, Iowa will pay a per capita rate of $55.17 (based on the 2010 census of
554) to Story County, lowa, which amounts to the annual sum of $30.564.18.
This shall be paid in equal quarterly installments to the Story County Sheriff on
July 1. October 1, January 1 and April 1. Any per capita increase in contract
cost for the following year shall be negotiated by December for the next fiscal
year. For the purposes of this contract, fiscal year shall be from July 1. through
June 30, of the following year.
AGREEMENT
Page 2
3.
The Sheriff shall be the administrator of this Agreement. Law Enforcement
policy. regulations and matters pertaining to the employment of the Sherifl's
personnel shall be determined solely by the Sheriff. The time, place and manner
in which these services are implemented shall be in the sole discretion of the
Sheriff. The Mayor, Mayor Pro Tem and the City Administrator shall be
authorized to make requests to the Sheriff for performance of specific law
enforcement services as specified in this Agreement.
4.
The initial term of the Agreement shall be automatically extended for successive
one-year periods upon the same terms and conditions provided by this
Agreement for the initial term, unless this Agreement is terminated or modified
by the express election of either city or county as hereinafter provided.
Modification of this contract may be made by mutual consent of both parties.
5.
In accordance with Chapter 28E, Code of lowa. a copy of this agreement shall
be filed with the Secretary of State and recorded with the Story County Recorder.
Signatures will include the Mayor of Zearing, the City Clerk of Zearing.
the Chairperson of the Story County Board of Supervisors. the Story County
Auditor and the Story County Sheriff. The city seal shall be affixed to the
contract before returning to the county for filing.
The city shall fund the consideration for this Agreement from general revenues
6.
under the City's annual general budget. There shall be no joint property
acquired pursuant to this agreement.
This contract may be terminated by either party.  Termination is effective at
the end of the current quarterly billing cycle and must be preceded with a
30 day written notice to either party.  Notice shall be accomplished by
certified mail or personal service.

CHAPTER 28E LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES CONTRACT BETWEEN
CHICKASAW COUNTY AND IONIA
This Agreement is entered into this
by and between Chickasaw County, through its Board of Supervisors, and the Chickasaw
County Sheriff, (collectively County), and the City of Ionia, through its City Council, for
the law enforcement services identified hereunder.
1. STATEMENT OF AGREEMENT
1 A. The City of Ionia (hereinafter City), in lieu of providing police protection services as
required by lowa Code, hereby elects to contract with the County for the provision of law
enforcement services on behalf of the City and its residents.
I B. The County agrees to provide law enforcement services to the City, through the
County's Sheriff and Sheriff's personnel, in response to requests made by the City, its
officers, employees, and agents and upon request, call or dispatch through Sheriff's E911
personnel to any residents or persons within the City.
2. LEGAL BASIS
2A. This Agreement is authorized by the provisions of Code of lowa, Chapter 28E. The
purpose of this agreement is to provide law enforcement services for the City and to
discharge the City's obligation to provide law enforcement services for their citizens in
accordance with Chapter 372.4(2) of the Code of Iowa as interpreted by the lowa
Supreme Court in Johnson v. Allen, 569 N.W. 2d 143 (Iowa 1997), referencing Code of
Iowa Chapter 368
3. GENERAL LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES DEFINED
3A. Law enforcement services consists of routine, irregular, random, intermittent and
unpredictable patrol in the City or "as needed" patrol and investigation and all auxiliary
and technical service now provided by the Sheriff in support of patrol and investigation.
All references to law enforcement services contained in this Agreement are references
only to services that shall be delivered under the terms of this Agreement
4. DELIVERY OF SERVICES
4A. Service area. The Sheriff shall provide law enforcement services within the
corporate limits of the City.
14 March 14 / 19-1
1/4
Todd W. Miller, Chickasaw County Sheriff, 116 N. Chestnut Avenue, New Hampton, IA
Prepared by:
50659 641 394 3121 (24 hours)
4B. Enforcement Responsibilities. It is agreed that the law enforcement services
performed will encompass only violations made criminal under the law defined by the
Code of Iowa. Ordinances established by Chickasaw County will be enforced. No
enforcement will be undertaken for violations of City Ordinances.
4C. Delivery of Service. The delivery of law enforcement services to be provided by the
Sheriff will consist of routine, irregular, random, intermittent and unpredictable patrol in
the City so as to afford the maximum possible law enforcement to the City at those times
and in those places where crime is determined by the Sheriff most likely to occur, except
that upon special request of the City to the Sheriff, specially focused law enforcement
services may be requested upon particularized and identified need.
4D. Service Management. It is understood and agreed that the law enforcement officers
providing services to the City under this Agreement are County employees, and not
employees of the City. The Sherift's Deputies are solely subject to control, supervision,
and discipline of the Sheriff and under the Sheriff's law enforcement policies and
regulations, and employment rules and policies
4E. Responsiveness. The County's Sheriff and his Deputies will answer and
appropriately respond to calls for service made requesting law enforcement services and
provide immediate response to all E911 calls in which an emergency is claimed
threatening the lives, safety, and property of residents of the City or persons in the City.
1.
City agrees "calls for service" from their community will be prioritized
based on established rational law enforcement practices and based on
availability of Sheriff's personnel working any particular duty shift.
4F. Coordination. Pursuant to Iowa Code Section 28E.6 (1) (a), this Agreement does not
establish any separate legal entity. The administrators for this Agreement are the Sheriff
and Mayor of the City, a signatory to it.
4G. Resources. In consideration for the per capita rate charges described below, the
County and Sheriff agree that the law enforcement services to be provided include the
County's provision of fully equipped patrol cars with emergency lights, sirens, and radios
and other standard electronic telemetry; of law enforcement officers and deputies
appropriately selected and employed under County civil service, appropriately trained
and certified by the lowa Law Enforcement Academy; of uniforms and all other personal
equipment necessary for the provision of law enforcement services; and for the
telephone, E911 and radio communications services made necessary under this
Agreement.
5. LIABLITY
5A. No agreement has been reached between the County and City concerning which
party is required to defend and indemnify the other party for claim or suit arising from
law enforcement services provided under this contract. That question is expressly
reserved for decision by the courts on an appropriate occasion.
14 March 14 / 19-1
2/4
Prepared by:
Todd W. Miller, Chickasaw County Sheriff, 116 N. Chestnut Avenue, New Hampton, IA
50659 641 394 3121 (24 hours)
6. PERSONNEL
6B. Employee Payment. The City shall not be liable for the direct payment of salaries.
wages, or other compensation to the County officers or employees providing law
enforcement services to the City.
7. FEES
7A. Total sum. The City shall pay to the County an annual sum for law enforcement
services delivered during the term of this Agreement. Said payment shall be made
semiannually on or before the 15th day of October and the 15th day of April of the
contract year. Said payment shall be made to the Auditor of Chickasaw County.
7B. Payment Plan. The City payment plan is attached in Section 11 of this Agreement.
7C. Adjustment. The County may adjust the total sum in accordance with changes in
costs of providing law enforcement services. The County shall notify the City in writing
of each adjustment. Any adjustment will be done on an annual basis.
8. TERMS
8A. This Agreement will take effect on the 1st day of July, 20 1 4 and shall continue
through the 30th day of June 20 15 and this Agreement may be renegotiated within
three (3) months prior to March 15th of any year as to any terms or particulars upon
request by any party.
8B. Unless terminated or renegotiated, this Agreement shall be renewed automatically for
successive terms of one (1) year. The Agreement may be terminated by cither party by
giving the other party notice of its intention to withdraw, said notice being delivered to
the other party no later than one hundred eighty (180) days prior to the renewal of the 30th
day of June.
9. SPECIAL EVENTS
9A. In the event that the City, or an organization within the City, plans a "special" or
major event in the City, it shall notify the Sheriff at least three weeks, or twenty one (21)
days prior to the event. It is the City's burden, responsibility and expense to determine
the need for extra security personnel and employ the needed security personnel to be
present at a "special" or major event. The City shall be liable for all actions of the extra
security personnel and shall hold harmless, defend and indemnify the County for all acts
of the extra security personnel so employed by the City.
A "special" or major event is defined as an event whether indoors or
1.
outdoors, that is held on public property or streets, non-profit organization
property, or non-residential private property that can reasonably be expected
to cause a public gathering that is not part of the normal course of business or
pedestrian traffic at the location.
10. FILING WITH SECRETARY OF STATE
10A. This Agreement or any amendment, modification, or notice of termination shall be
filed with the Iowa Secretary of State in a manner specified in Iowa Code Section 28E.8.

Law Enforcement Services Contract
On this 23rd day of February, 2015, the City of Bonaparte, Iowa: hereinafter “The City” and
Van Buren County, Iowa, hereinafter "The County" agrees as follows:
APPLICABLE LAW: This agreement is made and entered into by the parties
1.
pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 28E of the Code of Iowa. In any dispute
arising under this agreement, the applicable laws of the State of Iowa shall
govern
2.
DURATION: The law enforcement services provided herein shall commence on
the first day of July, 2015, and shall be perpetual, unless sooner terminated
pursuant to the provisions hereof, or modified by the mutual consent of the parties
hereto.
3.
DUTIES OF THE COUNTY acting through its duly elected, qualified and acting
Sheriff, together with his or her Sheriff's department, shall provide The City
general law enforcement assistance, including but not limited to regular
intermittent patrol, crime detection, crime prevention, crime scene identification
work, witness interview, and such other functions as are necessary and
appropriate to provide law enforcement protection to the citizens and property of
said City. The Sheriff's Office shall make determination of which law
enforcement situations require an officer's immediate presence. Any call that does
not require an officer's immediate presence will have a reasonable response time.
In fulfilling any duties under this Agreement, the Sheriff, or his deputy, shall have
the right to call upon other persons or law enforcement agencies for assistance
including but not limited to, the Iowa Division of Criminal Investigation.
The Sheriff's Office will not enforce any City Ordinances but will assist any
a.
City Official with the enforcement of any City Ordinance if the acting City
Official feels it is necessary to have a member of the Sheriff's Office present
with them for safety reasons. The Sheriff or his designee shall accompany the
City Official in their enforcement of the City Ordinance.
The Sheriff's Office shall be on call to provide service twenty-four (24) hours
b.
per day, every day of the year, but shall not be required to spend any specific
number of hours per week in the City.
4.
FINANCING:
a. The City shall remit to The County to defray the costs of providing services
under this Agreement billable sums on a quarterly basis. Amounts per capita
effective for the 2016FY shall be calculated as follows:
b. City financing for Law Enforcement services within the incorporated cities of
Van Buren County, Iowa, is set by calculating a per capita rate, using the
latest federal census, by dividing the total cost to The County of one deputy
sheriff (including, but not limited to, average salary of one deputy, associated
IPERS/SS, insurances, education/training, uniforms, vehicle and associated
vehicle costs) by the total population of all incorporated cities within The
County. The parties acknowledge that periodic increases in the fee for
services to be paid by the City are to be expected, but any such increase shall
be limited to the demonstrable increase in costs incurred by the County or
Sheriff in fulfilling the terms of this Agreement. In any event, annual
increases beginning with the 2017FY shall not exceed 5% in any one fiscal
year, except with the approval of the City.
c. The first quarterly payment shall be due on the 15th day of July,
The second quarterly payment shall be due on the 15th day of October.
The third quarterly payment shall be due on the 15th day of January,
The fourth quarterly payment shall be due on the 15th day of April.
d. Such payments shall be due as herein stated and shall be timely paid without
demand required.
5.
ANNUAL REVIEW: In December of each year, or at such time as is otherwise
mutually agreed by the parties, the Sheriff, a designee of the Board of
Supervisors, the Mayor and a designee of the city council shall meet and confer to
discuss all aspects of this Agreement and any necessary or appropriate
amendments or adjustments to this Agreement to become effective the following
fiscal year.
6.
PROPERTY OWNERSHIP: Property held and used by The County in carrying
out the provisions of this Agreement shall be owned by The County.
7.
TERMINATION OF AGREEMENT: As stated above, this Agreement is
perpetual and shall continue from year to year unless sooner terminated by the
parties or modified by their mutual agreement. In order to facilitate the
preparation of a budget, each party shall make reasonable effort to give written
notice to the other party prior to December 181 of the current year of any tentative
intent to request modification or termination of the Agreement.
In any event, each party shall have the right to terminate this Agreement for
a. 
the upcoming fiscal year if they provide written notice of said termination to
the other party before February 15th of the current year, and such termination
shall be effective the following June 30th. The County shall notify The City as
soon as possible each year and in any event no later than February 5th
regarding the anticipated costs for the following fiscal year.
b. In the event either The County or the The City fails to perform its obligation
under this Agreement, the other party shall give to the non-performing or
breaching party written notice of the claimed non-performance or breach. If
the non-performance or breach is not cured within thirty (30) days of the
receipt of the notice, the party claiming a breach or non-performance may
terminate this Agreement by written notice to the other party.
8.
SALARY/LIABILITY/WORKERS' COMPENSATION. The County shall be
responsible for the payment of salary, wages, and/or any other compensation or 
benefits to the County employees providing services under this Agreement. The
City shall not be responsible for providing liability or workers' compensation
insurance and shall not be liable for compensation to any County employee for a
workers' compensation claim for injury or sicknesses occurring as a result of, or
while, the County employee undertakes duties in fulfillment of this Agreement.
The County is responsible for all workers' compensation and liability insurance to
cover its employees and the actions of its employees.
9.
LIABILITIES:
The City shall not be called upon to assume any liability for the direct
a. 
payment of any salaries, wages, or other compensation for any County
personnel performing services hereunder for said City. The City shall not be
liable for compensation or indemnity to any County employee for injury or
sickness arising out of his or her employment, and the County hereby agrees
to hold the City harmless against any such claim.
b. The County, its officers and employees, shall not be deemed to assume any
liability for intentional or negligent acts of The City, The City's officials or
employees. Further The City shall hold The County and The County's
officers and employees harmless there from, and shall defend The County and
The County's officers and employers against any claim for damages resulting
there from.
c. The City, its officers and employees, shall not be deemed to assume any
liability for intentional or negligent acts of The County, The County's officials
or employees. Further The County shall hold The City and The City's officers
and employees harmless there from, and shall defend The City and The City's
officers and employers against any claim for damages resulting there from.
SEVERABILTY CLAUSE. If any portion of this Agreement shall be held
10.
unconstitutional or invalid for any reason, this decision shall not affect the
remaining portions of this Ordinance not so declared unconstitutional or invalid.
REPEALER. All previous Law Enforcement Agreements by and between The
11.
County and The City are hereby repealed effective June 30, 2015.
FILING OF AGREEMENT. In accordance with Chapter 28E, Code of Iowa,
12.
2013, as amended, a copy of this agreement shall be filed with the Secretary of
State and recorded with the Van Buren County Revorder.
IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the parties have executed this Agreement on the date and year
written opposite their respective signatures below.

day of Decem
2012 and ending on June 30, 2013, by and between the lowa Workforce Development (IWD)
and North Iowa Area Community College (NIACC).  The parties agree as follows:
Section 1.
Purpose.  The purpose of this Agreement is to establish roles and
responsibilities for district leadership staff in Regions 2, 3&4, and 5, and to
provide for the employment and terms of employment of the District Manager.
Section 1.1
Identity of the Parties: Iowa Workforce Development (IWD), which is a duly
created state department, is authorized, among other things, to provide and fund
workforce development programs. IWD's state administrative address is 1000
East Grand Avenue, Des Moines, lowa 50319. North Iowa Area Community
College (NIACC) is authorized among other things, to provide and fund workforce
development programs. NIACC's address is 500 College Drive, Mason City, IA
50401. This Agreement does not create any separate legal or administrative
entities.
Section 2.
Responsibilities of Parties.
2.1
NIACC shall provide administration/management services for IWD employees
located at the Mason City Workforce Development Center in Region 2, and
oversight of agency operations in Regions 3&4 (Spencer) and 5 (Fort Dodge).
These services will be provided by the District Manager, who shall be employed
by NIACC. The District Manager shall provide all administrative/management
services in accordance with all applicable federal, state, local laws and
regulations, merit system rules, and collective bargaining agreement rules and
practices. (See attachment A for complete list of documents currently included in
all Regional and PROMISE JOBS Master Agreements.)
Policy guidelines for Workforce Development Center operations in Mason City 
2.2.
will be jointly agreed upon by appropriate NIACC and IWD representatives and
will comply with applicable personnel and labor relations policies of both entities.
In the absence of the District Manager, and appropriate IWD Regional Managers,
2.3
personnel issues involving IWD employees which require the involvement of IWD
administration will be the responsibility of the Division Administrator for the
Workforce Services Division or their Designee.
2.4
NIACC shall permit the District Manager to participate in staff development,
training, and management meetings required by IWD.
NIACC shall be responsible for the payment of the District Manager's salary and
2.5
personnel benefits according to its existing policies. NIACC shall be solely
responsible for the payment of all applicable federal and state withholding taxes
and social security taxes.  Additionally, NIACC shall carry a policy of workers
compensation, and at its sole expense, employer's liability insurance for the
Page 1 of 12
Region 2 28e District Manager November 2012
District Manager to the extent and in the amounts required by law.  NIACC, at its
sole expense, shall pay all unemployment compensation taxes for the District
Manager to the extent and in the amounts required by law.  All fringe benefits
provided the District Manager will be in accordance with NIACC policy.
2.6
Selection, annual evaluation and termination of the District Manager will be within
the joint discretion of NIACC and IWD. IWD shall provide NIACC with its
comments concerning potential candidates for the District Manager's position
and shall annually provide NIACC with its comments concerning the performance
of the District Manager in order to assist NIACC with its annual evaluation.
NIACC will notify IWD when the annual evaluation is being developed, a deadline
for IWD comment submission, and a signed copy of the completed evaluation for
IWD records.
2.7
IWD shall provide staff development and training services to ensure the District
Manager is knowledgeable of IWD practices, procedures, and policies.
2.8
IWD will pay NIACC for the services provided in this Agreement as set forth in
Section 4.
The Workforce Development Center District Manager.
Section 3.
3.1
The District Manager shall, at all times, be considered the employee of NIACC and
not an employee of IWD. (See attachment B for District Manager job description:)
3.2
The District Manager shall consult with the Workforce Services Division
Administrator or their Designee and the Department of Administrative Services
(DAS) personnel officer assigned to IWD before taking any disciplinary action
against any IWD employee.  Joint review by both the District Manager and the
Workforce Services Division Administrator or their Designee will precede any
performance appraisal and related action for any IWD employee.
3.3
When notifying NIACC of any annual or sick leave requests, the District Manager
shall also inform the Workforce Services Division Administrator or their Designee.
The District Manager shall attend all regularly scheduled meetings of the IWD
3.4
district managers, as well as any other required meeting called by the Workforce
Services Administrator or their Designee. The District Manager will inform the
Workforce Services Administrator or their Designee of conflicts that may prohibit
attendance.
Section 4.
Compensation.
IWD will pay NIACC the lesser of:
54% of the District Manager's "salary expense," or
(a)
54% of the highest step of a Public Service Executive 4 classification plus
(b)
54% of any additional items included in the definition of salary expense below
which are not included as part of the Public Service Executive 4 classification.
 Region 2 28e District Manager November 2012
Page 2 of 12
"Salary expense" includes base salary, payroli taxes, unemployment insurance and
worker's compensation insurance premiums, fringe benefits, travel, and per diem
but does not include bonuses that may be received by the District Manager for
work at NIACC.
For the purposes of this agreement, IWD will reimburse travel and per diem
expenses at only the rate which is used by the employer of record, in this case
NIACC.
IWD will pay NIACC on a monthly basis in, arrears.  "Salary expense" shall be that
actually paid or incurred by NIACC. NIACC will provide a monthly invoice of the
District Manager's salary expense to the WDCA Division Administrator or their
Designee for approval prior to payment. IWD will provide said approval to NIACC
within 15 days of receipt.
Any percentage increase in the base salary in excess of the percentage increase
for a Public Service Executive 4 classification shall be as agreed between NIACC
and IWD.
All out-of-state travel to be reimbursed by IWD must have prior approval by the
Workforce Services Division Administrator or their Designee, and the Director,
using the "Request for Travel Authority-Out of State Travel" form.
NIACC shall maintain books, records and documents which sufficiently and 
properly document and calculate all charges billed to IWD throughout the term of
this Agreement for a period of at least five (5) years following the date of final 
payment or completion of any required audit, whichever is later.
NIACC shall permit the Auditor of the State of Iowa or any authorized
representative of the State or Department; and where federal funds are involved, 
the Comptroller General of the United States or any other authorized
representative of the United States government; to access and examine, audit,
excerpt and transcribe any directly pertinent books, documents, papers, electronic
or optically stored and created records or other records of NIACC relating to
orders, invoices, or payments or any other documentation or materials pertaining to 
this Agreement. NIACC shall not impose a charge for audit or examination of the
books and records.

Termination.  This Agreement may be terminated in any of the following
circumstances:
a)   At IWD or NIACC discretion, without cause, after sixty (60) days written
notice to the other party by FAX with hard copy to follow by overnight 
deliverv.
b) As a result of default under this Agreement.

Section 8.
Authorization.  Each party to this Agreement represents and warrants to the other
that (1) it has the right, power, and authority to enter into and perform its
obligations under this Agreement; and (2) it has taken all requisite action
(corporate, statutory, or otherwise) to approve execution, deliver, and performance

The President of North lowa Area Community College, or their Designee, and the
IWD Administrator of the Division of Workforce Services will be responsible for 
administration of this Agreement.
Section 9.
Default.
9.1
The occurrence of any one or more of the following events shall constitute cause
for IWD or NIACC to declare the other party in default of its obligations under this
Agreement:
a)  Non-performance of this Agreement.
b) A failure of either party to make substantial and timely progress toward
performance of the Agreement.
c) A failure of either party's work product and services to conform with any
specifications noted herein.
d) A repeated exhibition of defects in the services delivered by either party,
causing serious disruption of use or downtime over a six month period.
e)  A breach of provisions related to intellectual property.
f) A failure to make payments required under section 4.
g) A breach of any term of this Agreement.
9.2
NIACC or IWD shall not be considered to be in default under this
Agreement if its performance is delayed or made impossible by an Act of God,
floods, fires, strikes, a freight embargo or similar events; but in each such case, the
delay or impossibility must go beyond the reasonable control and without the fault
of NIACC or IWD. In event of such delay, the scheduled date of delivery
shall be extended on a day-to-day basis until delivery of performance is possible
and feasible.
9.3
NIACC shall not be liable for indirect, special, or consequential damages
resulting from a breach of this Agreement.

ATTACHMENT B
NORTH IOWA AREA COMMUNITY COLLEGE
JOB DESCRIPTION
 District Manager
TITLE:
CATEGORY/LEVEL:
DIVISION:  Workforce Development
PSS/4
BASIC FUNCTION:    The Director is the chief administrative officer and responsible for the overall
operation and outreach efforts for Region 2 Workforce Development Partnership, and
will provide administrative oversight and leadership for IWD managers in Regions
3&4, and 5.
QUALIFICATIONS:
Bachelor of Arts or Bachelor of Science Degree required. Master's degree preferred.
Minimum of three years of acceptable related work experience, including a minimum
of one year supervising professional staff. Experience should include successful
management skills, grant writing, program planning and budgeting, government 
program or grant implementation and monitoring, contracting for services, and
working with a volunteer board. Preference for previous experience in Human
Services agency-type of organization. Excellent written and oral communication skills
required.
SUPERVISOR:
President, North Iowa Area Community College
RESPONSIBILITIES AND DUTIES:
1. · Provide direct supervision for WIA staff, PJ team leader, Career Center Director, Economic
Developer, and IWD managers/supervisors.
Provide leadership in the development, delivery, and evaluation of programs and services as
2.
outlined in WIA and PROMISE JOBS legislation, the Local Customer Service Plan and other
contracted services with the lowa Department of Workforce Development.
3.
Supervise the preparation and delivery of the Local Customer Service Plan.
4.
Provide administration/management services for IWD employees located at the Workforce
Development Center and any satellite centers in Region 2.
5. Provide all administrative/management services in accordance with all applicable federal, state,
local laws and regulations, merit system rules, and collective bargaining agreement rules and
practices.
6.
 Prepare and monitor budgets; supervise financial and Management information System procedures
and reports
7.
Perform employer and client outreach by developing and maintaining linkages with area economic
development groups, businesses, and potential users of the Workforce Development Partnership
Services.
8.
Serve as Executive Director of the Regional Workforce Investment Board (RWIB) and the Chief
Elected Officials (CEO).
9. Organize, direct, and demonstrate, as needed, appropriate methods for serving WIA applicants,
clients, employers, and vendors.
10. Maintain outreach efforts with prospective employers and clients, and other human service
agencies.
11.  Coordinate and implement advertising and public relations program for outreach to, and recruitment
of, potential clients and employers.
Page 11 of 12
Region 2 28e District Manager November 2012
12. Promote cooperation among internal units of the College and external agencies and organizations
of Regions 2, 3&4, 5 and the State of lowa.
13.  Provide advice and counsel to staff members on college policies and regulations and applicable
state and federal regulations and enforce compliance as required.
14. Make recommendations on staff selection, development and retention, or termination, and
supervise and evaluate assigned personnel.
15. Participate in professional organizations and maintain professional growth.
16. Advise NIACC president on activities within assigned areas.
17. Perform in a manner which strengthens the coordination and cooperation of all organizational
components of the College and One-Stop Workforce Development System and member
organizations,

AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE CITY OF GRIMES AND
BRAVO GREATER DES MOINES, INC.
This Agreement is made and entered into on this Qlo day of Jelruary
2013, (the "Execution Date") by and between the City of Grimes and Bravo Greater Bes
Moines, Inc. ("Bravo") an Iowa not-for-profit corporation, pursuant to the provisions of
Chapter 28E, Code of Iowa. The Agreement shall be effective with respect to
Commitments beginning & & & , 2013 (the "Effective Date").
That inasmuch as Bravo is organized for the purpose of assisting the cultural community
of Polk County and contiguous counties (the "Greater Des Moines Area") in
providing an enriched quality of life by increasing cultural awareness, advocacy, and
funding, as well as by fostering collaboration among cultural organizations.
That the City of Grimes has as a goal the unification and coordination of monies for the
use and benefit of the cultural community and specifically the cultural organizations
eligible for funding by Bravo. The City of Grimes is committed to the reasonable
stewardship of monies for arts and cultural purposes.
That the City of Grimes and Bravo agree as follows:
I. DEFINITIONS
(1)
"Hotel/Motel Tax" means a tax imposed in accordance with Chapter 423A of the
Code of Iowa, or similar successor provisions.
"Hotel/Motel Tax Revenues" means the funds remitted to the City of Grimes by
(2)
the Treasurer of the State of Iowa from the local Transient Guest Tax Fund in
accordance with provisions of Chapter 423A of the Code of Iowa, and the rules
promulgated by the Director of the Iowa Department of Revenue thereunder, or
similar successor provisions, representing the proceeds collected by the State of
Iowa from the Hotel/Motel Tax imposed by the City of Grimes.
II. PRE-CONDITIONS TO OBLIGATIONS OF THE CITY OF GRIMES.  The
parties understand and intend that the City of Grimes obligation to make the
payments hereunder shall be limited to the amounts set forth in Section III(1) of this
Agreement and shall not constitute a legal indebtedness of the City of Grimes within
the meaning of any applicable constitutional or statutory debt limitation. In the event
that any of the provisions of this Agreement are determined by a court of competent
jurisdiction to create, or result in the creation of, such a legal indebtedness of the
City of Grimes, the enforcement of the payment provisions of this Agreement shall
be suspended and the Agreement shall at all times be construed and applied in such a
manner as will preserve the foregoing intent of the parties.
 I
III. COVENANT FROM CITY OF GRIMES
(1) The City of Grimes does hereby agree to pay Bravo for the promotion of arts and
cultural activities in the Greater Des Moines Area (a) for fiscal years 2014-2017
the amounts shown in the chart below and (b) for fiscal year 2018 and all
subsequent fiscal years for the entire term of this Agreement, the City of Grimes
agrees to pay to Bravo 2/7th of its Hotel/Motel Tax Revenues attributable to
periods after June 30, 2017 (the "Commitment") to be distributed and expended by
Bravo in the manner set forth in this Agreement and the bylaws of Bravo.
The
Commitment shall be made according to the following schedule and formula:
Year
Flat Amount (a)
Percentage of

The City of Grimes shall take all action necessary to implement disbursement of
(2)
the Commitment. Payment of the Commitment to Bravo shall be made in
quarterly installments, paid no later than 30 days following the date on which the
City receives the quarterly remittance of Hotel/Motel Tax Revenues for the prior
fiscal quarter, taking into account any reductions for such quarter as provided in
paragraph (1) above.
(3)
If Chapter 423A of the Code of Iowa is amended to permit and the City of Grimes
subsequently imposes a Hotel/Motel Tax in excess of 7%, the Commitment shall
be limited to 2/7th of Hotel/Motel Tax Revenues derived from the initial 7% of
tax.
2
IV. PURPOSE
The purpose of this Agreement is to facilitate and support the cultural community of the
Greater Des Moines Area in providing an enriched quality of life by increasing
cultural awareness, advocacy and funding as well as by fostering collaboration among
cultural organizations and increasing stability of Bravo in carrying out its goals for the
benefit of the Greater Des Moines Area. This Agreement is not intended to establish
a separate legal entity.
V. ACCOUNTING OF BENEFITS
(1)
Bravo shall administer the undertakings between the City of Grimes and Bravo
as described herein, and Bravo shall acquire, hold and disburse its assets,
including the Commitment, in accordance with the purpose and terms stated
herein and the governing documents of Bravo. Upon request, Bravo shall
provide to the City of Grimes copies of the governing documents, including
applicable bylaws and policy guidelines. The City of Grimes hereby appoints
its City Administrator to administer this Agreement with Bravo, and Bravo
hereby appoints its President to administer this Agreement with the City of
Grimes. Bravo shall post on its website notice of the time, location and agenda
for its board meetings and shall provide minutes of action taken via email to the
City Manager or its designee.
The City of Grimes and Bravo acknowledge that the communities within the
(2)
Greater Des Moines Area that make payment commitments to Bravo (Polk
County and the described communities are together the "Participating
Communities") and not-for-profit cultural organizations
within
such
Participating Communities may, as part of a cultural improvements capital
campaign, apply for grant funding. Bravo shall establish a separate fund to
provide matching funds to support the capital campaigns of not-for-profit
cultural organizations within such Participating Communities (the "Fund").
Bravo shall allocate a portion of the aggregate of the Commitment payments by
the City of Grimes and contributions by other Participating Communities so
there is a balance of between $150,000 and $450,000 in the Fund at the
commencement of each fiscal year. In order to increase the amount of funding
available for cultural improvement campaigns, Bravo shall allocate an
additional $150,000 to the Fund each fiscal year provided that the Fund does
not exceed an end of fiscal year balance of $450,000. For a not-for-profit
cultural organization to be eligible to receive a disbursement from the Fund, the
not-for-profit cultural organization must make a presentation regarding its
capital campaign to Bravo before the not-for-profit cultural organization
approaches any of the Participating Communities for a contribution. Bravo, in
its reasonable discretion shall make determinations on Fund disbursements for
proposed cultural capital campaigns within the Participating Communities in
such manner that will enhance the competitiveness of the grant funding
applications and further the purpose of this Agreement. The City of Grimes and
3
Bravo acknowledge that any matching funds provided by Bravo for a not-for-
profit cultural organization's capital campaign shall not be intended or
construed as the sole or exclusive capital funding source to be provided by
Participating Communities for such project.
(3)
Bravo shall present to the City Administrator of the City of Grimes no later
than 30 days after Bravo's Board of Directors approves Bravo's audited
fiscal year financial statements, a full accounting of Bravo's revenues,
disbursements and operations for such year in a form reasonably acceptable
to the City ("Financial Statements"). The Financial Statements will include the
annual salaries paid to officers and employees of Bravo and a summary of the
disbursement awards made by Bravo during the fiscal year, including for each
recipient of an award the amount awarded and a brief description of the approved
uses for the award. Upon request, Bravo shall provide the City of Grimes with
copies of recipient funding agreements. The fiscal year of Bravo ends each June
30.
(4)
The Financial Statements shall be prepared by Bravo and certified by an
independent auditor selected by Bravo.
VI. OPERATIONS AND FINANCES
Bravo shall prepare and submit to the Grimes City Council prior to the commencement of
each of Bravo's fiscal years a distribution plan for the Commitment payments from the
City of Grimes and contributions by the other Participating Communities (the "Plan"). The
Plan for the 2013-14 fiscal year shall be submitted to the Grimes City Council prior to the
Effective Date. All expenditures of public funds by Bravo shall be made pursuant to the
Plan. Notwithstanding anything in this Agreement to the contrary, Bravo may, once each
fiscal year, submit a revised Plan to the Grimes City Council and the governing bodies of
the other Participating Communities to reallocate up to ten percent (10%) of the
Commitment payments from the City of Grimes and contributions by the other
Participating Communities for the fiscal year.
VII. DURATION AND TERMINATION
(1)
This Agreement shall continue in effect from the Effective Date until terminated in
accordance with the terms of this Article VII.
(2)
This Agreement may be terminated by either party as provided in this paragraph.
Any such termination may be accomplished only by delivery of notice to the
other party not later than January 1 of any given year after the year ending
December 31, 2014 and shall be effective on July 1 occurring eighteen (18)
months after the January 1 following the giving of the required notice.
(3)
In the event that another Participating Community submits notice to Bravo to
terminate its payment commitment agreement with Bravo, Bravo shall provide a
4
copy of such notice to the City of Grimes. The City of Grimes may then deliver to
Bravo notice to terminate this Agreement with an effective date that coincides with
the termination date applicable to the terminating Participating Community. Such
notice to terminate shall become invalid if the terminating Participating
Community withdraws or otherwise revokes its termination notice prior to the
effective date.
Notwithstanding paragraphs (2) or (3) above, in the event that any part of the
(4)
Commitment is disbursed or expended by Bravo in violation of the terms of this
Agreement, the City may deliver to Bravo a notice to cure or remedy such default
or breach within sixty (60) days and if such default or breach is not remedied
within such cure period, this Agreement shall promptly terminate.
(5)
This Agreement shall terminate if Chapter 423A of the Code of Iowa is either: (a)
repealed or amended to remove the authority of the City of Grimes to collect the
Hotel/Motel Tax at a rate of at least 7% or (b) so modified that the purpose of the
Agreement can no longer be carried out. If the Agreement terminates pursuant to
the previous sentence, the termination date shall be the June 30 coinciding with
or next following the effective date of the statutory change that causes the
termination.
This Agreement shall terminate if an alternative, reliable funding source is
(5)
secured for Bravo that provides funding to Bravo, in the reasonable determination
of the Bravo board of directors, that is comparable in amount to the annual
funding streams Bravo has secured in the aggregate through 28E agreements with
the cities, counties and municipalities of the Greater Des Moines Area (for
example, if Chapter 423A of the Code of Iowa were amended to increase the
Hotel/Motel tax and to direct a portion of the increase to Bravo in an amount
comparable to the annual funding streams expected from 28E agreements already
in place). If a reliable alternative funding source is secured for Bravo, which
partially replaces the funds provided by the City of Grimes to Bravo, the amount
of annual funding provided to Bravo pursuant to this Agreement shall be reduced
proportionately in such amount as the parties may reasonably determine. If the
Agreement terminates pursuant to this paragraph, the termination date shall be the
June 30 coinciding with or next following the effective date of the alternative
funding source that causes the termination.
(6)
Any notice or demand required or desired to be given hereunder shall be in
writing and deemed given when personally delivered or when deposited in the
United States mail, postage prepaid, sent certified or registered, and addressed
as follows:
5
If to the City of Grimes, to:

VII. AMENDMENT OF AGREEMENT
Any amendment to this Agreement shall be made in writing upon agreement of the City of
Grimes and Bravo and after appropriate discussion and public dialogue, and such
amendment has been approved by resolution of the Grimes City Council.
IX. MISCELLANEOUS
(1)
This Agreement has been made and entered into solely for the benefit of the goals
and objectives of the City of Grimes and Bravo as expressly provided herein and
is not intended to create any rights in any other person.
Notwithstanding anything in this Agreement to the contrary, any liabilities, debts,
(2)
or other obligations experienced by Bravo as a corporation/body or its members
shall not be the responsibility of the City of Grimes.
(3)
While this Agreement is in effect, the City of Grimes shall have the right to
designate one person to serve on the Board of Directors of Bravo.
(4)
It is the intention and expectation of Bravo and the City of Grimes that no
organization that receives funding from Bravo during the term of this Agreement
6
will approach the City of Grimes for additional operational funding during the
term of this Agreement. This expectation does not apply to: (1) any member of
Bravo that is owned, managed or operated by the City of Grimes or a political
subdivision of the City; or (2) capital campaigns.
Each of the City of Grimes and Bravo shall pay its own costs incurred to
(5)
negotiate, amend, abide by or terminate this Agreement.
(6)
After execution by the parties, this Agreement shall be filed with the Iowa
Secretary of State in an electronic format in accordance with the provisions of
Iowa Code § 28E.8.
(7)
As of the Effective Date, this Agreement is intended to replace the prior
agreements referred to in paragraph four of the preamble to this document.

AGREEMENT FOR GENERAL LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES
BETWEEN THE JONES COUNTY SHERIFF'S OFFICE
MARTELLE, IOWA
Prepared by Sheriff Greg A Graver
500 West Main Street
Anamosa, IA 52205-0167
This agreement is entered into this | Y n day of MMY 2013 and
between Jones County, Hereinafter referred to as the County: The County
Sheriff, hereinafter referred to as the Sheriff: and the City of MARTELLE
hereinafter to as the City.
I
STATEMENT OF AGREEMENT. The County and its Sheriff agree to
provide general law enforcement services to the City and the City agrees to
engage the County, through its Sheriff, to provide such service in accordance
with and subject to the terms of this agreement.
II
LEGAL BASIS. This agreement is authorized by the provisions of Chapter
28E of the Code of Iowa.
III
GENERAL LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES DEFINED. General law
enforcement services consist of patrol and investigations and all auxiliary
and technical services now provided by the Sheriffs Office in support of
patrol and Investigations. All references to general law enforcement services
contained in this agreement are references only to services that shall be
delivered under the terms of this agreement.
l
IV
DELIVERY OF SERVICES. Delivery of services shall be provided as
follows:
SERVICE AREA: The Sheriff shall provide general law enforcement
l.
services within the corporate limits of the City.
2.
ENFORCEMENT RESPONSIBILITIES: The Sheriff shall enforce
State statutes, county ordinances and ordinances of the City that are of
the same type and nature as State statutes enforced by the Sheriff. The
Sheriff shall not be required to assume any other law enforcement
duty or function not consistent with those customarily performed by
the Sheriff and under the charter of the county and statutes of the
State.
3.
DELIVERY OF SERVICE: The Sheriff shall deliver various hours of
general law enforcement services each day in addition to law
enforcement services now delivered to the City by the Sheriff as
provided by law.
SERVICE MANAGEMENT: The planning, organization, scheduling,
4.
directions and supervision of the Sheriff's personnel and all other
matters incident to the delivery of general law enforcement services to
the City shall be determined by the Sheriff. The Sheriff shall retain
exclusive authority over the activities of the personnel working in the
cities. However, the Sheriff shall work in conjunction with the Mayor
of MARTELLE to determine the preferred patrol time for Jones
County Deputies.
RESPONSIVENESS: The Sheriff shall give prompt consideration to
5.
all requests of the City regarding the delivery of general law
enforcement services. The Sheriff shall make every effort to comply
with these requests if they are consistent with good law enforcement
practices.
V
RESOURCES. Resources shall be provided as follows:
COUNTY RESPONSIBILITY: Unless specifically agreed to in
l.
another part of this agreement, the County shall furnish all labor,
equipment, facilities, and supplies required to provide general law
enforcement services to the City. The City shall further agree that the
Sheriff may also use these facilities as needed to provide law
enforcement services to the surrounding areas.
2
2.
INDIVIDUAL OWERNERSHIP OF PROPERTY: The County and
City shall retain title to the property each may require to fulfill its
obligations under this agreement. Each party may dispose of its
property as it sees fit.
CITY RESPONSIBILITY: The City shall provide and maintain an
3.
office and parking space suitable for the use of Sheriff's personnel
providing general law enforcement services to the City. The City
further agrees that the Sheriff may also use these facilities as needed
to provide law enforcement services to surrounding areas.
VI
LIABILITY: Liability shall be assumed as follows.
l.
COUNTY: The County shall assume liability for, defend against,
indemnify and hold harmless the City from all costs or damages for
injury to persons or property caused by the County in providing or
failing to provide general law enforcement services to the City,
including attorney fees for defense against such claims.
2.
CITY: The City shall assume liability for, defend against, indemnify
and hold the County from all cost or damages for injury to persons or
property caused by the City, including attorney fees for defense
against such claims.
VII
PERSONNEL:
EMPLOYEE STATUTES: All persons employed by the Sheriff and
1.
providing general law enforcement services to the City shall County
officers or employees, and they shall not have any benefit, statutes or
right of City employment.
PAYMENT: The City shall not be liable for the direct payments of
2.
salaries, wages or other compensation to county officers or employees
providing general law enforcement services to the City.
3.
INDEMNITY: The City shall not be liable for indemnity to any
county officer or employee for injury or sickness arising out of his/her
employment providing general law enforcement services to the City.
MUNICIPAL AGENCY: For the sole purpose of giving official
4.
statutes to their acts in performing municipal functions within the
scope of this agreement, every county officer or employee engaged in
providing general law enforcement services to the City shall be
3
considered deputized by the City. This provision shall be implemented
by an ordinance in the City.
IX
DOG CALLS: The Jones County Sheriff's Office will not respond to
nuisance dog calls of barking dogs and dogs running at large. Citizens
wanting to file complaints about nuisance dog calls shall drop off or
mail written complaints to city hall. Those statements will then be
forwarded to the city attorney for prosecution.
Dog bites are a risk to the safety of the public. The Jones
County Sheriff will respond to a report of a dog bite. The Sheriff will
attempt to identify the owner of the dog, proof of required
immunizations, and if the dog was in violation of the at-large
ordinance. As a result of the investigation, the Sheriff will file the
appropriate charge/charges.
If a dog is found running at large and the dog can be caught, the
Jones County Dog Catcher will respond within the City limits to
transport the dog to the impound. This will take place at no additional
charge to the City.
Any fees due by the Vet Clinic or impound will be the
responsibility of the City for any dogs impounded from within the
City limits.
X
FEES: Fees and payments shall be as follows:
 The total sum the City shall pay the County is $1000.00 for the period
l.
of July 1, 2013 through June 30, 2014 for general law enforcement
services delivered during the term of this agreement.
2.
The County shall receive from the City the entire amount due by the
first day of June 2014. The City may make payments throughout the
term of this contract. Payment shall be made by check payable to the
Jones County Sheriff and mailed to the Sheriff's Office in Anamosa,
Iowa 52205.
3.
DELIQUENCY: If the City does not make full payment to the County
by June 1, 2014 the County may terminate this agreement and the City
shall be liable for general law enforcement services rendered to the
time of termination.
4
XI
TERM: This agreement shall take effect on July 1, 2013 and shall continue
through June 30, 2014, unless the Sheriff, County Board of Supervisors, or
the City, acting through its Mayor, terminates this contract by giving the
other parties written notice of their intention to terminate this agreement and
the date of such termination is to take effect. Said termination notice must be
given before January 1, 2014. However, the parties may agree to renegotiate
such matters as compensation, patrol hours and other contractual terms
without the necessity of formally terminating this entire agreement.
However, any such modification shall take place prior to January 1, 2014
and be evidenced by written agreement by all parties.
