This Agreement made and entered into this _3
1992, by and between the City of Des Moines, Iowa, hereinafter called the "CITY
whose address for the purpose of this Agreement is Park and Recreation Director,
3226 University, Des Moines, Iowa 50311, and Kiwanis Nature Island, hereinafter
called "KIWANIS", whose address for the purpose of this Agreement is 1111 - 9th
Street, Suite 180, Des Moines. Iowa 50314. NOW WITNESSETH:
WHEREAS, the CITY is the owner of certain real property, shown on Exhibit
"A", known locally as Riverview Park, which is under the control and jurisdiction of
the CITY's Park and Recreation Board; and
WHEREAS, Kiwanis desires to undertake a project to develop and improve
said property for the benefit of the citizens of Des Moines; and
WHEREAS, the Des Moines Park and Recreation Board has determined it is
in the best interest of the CITY to enter into a cooperative agreement with
KIWANIS to develop and improve Riverview Park; and
WHEREAS, Iowa Code (1991) Chapter 28E allows any public agency in Iowa,
including municipalities, to enter into agreements with public or private agencies for
joint or cooperative action with respect to any power, privilege or authority exercised
or capable of being exercised by the public agency; and
WHEREAS, the CITY pursuant to its authority under Chapter 28E, desires
to cooperate with the KIWANIS to develop and improve Riverview Park;
NOW THEREFORE, in consideration of the mutual covenants, promises and
agreements hereinafter set forth, the parties agree as follows:
I.
PARK OWNERSHIP.
Nothing in this Agreement shall be construed to convey to Kiwanis any
ownership rights or interest in and to Riverview Park. Kiwanis shall, by this
Agreement, have a contractual right to development and maintenance of the Park,
on behalf of the City, provided such development and maintenance is in accord with
the Master Plan mutually approved.
l
II.
SITE IMPROVEMENT AND DEVELOPMENT.
A.
Master Plan.
All development, construction, and maintenance activities shall be in accord
with a Master Plan for Riverview Park, which plan shall be prepared by
KIWANIS and presented to and approved by the City. No development shall
be initiated or undertaken by KIWANIS which is not in accord with the
approved Master Plan. The Master Plan may be amended from time to time.
Such amendments, however, shall be in writing and approved by the City.
The City reserves the unilateral right, in the master plan approval, or any
amendment thereto, initiated by the City or by Kiwanis, to incorporate into
such plan a major focal point development initiative for the Park, which
development would form the basis for the Park's Master Plan or any
amendment thereto.
At least sixty (60) days prior to such master plan amendment the City shall
advise the Kiwanis of its plan, and provide to Kiwanis the opportunity to make
suggestions and recommendations regarding implementation of
 such
amendment.
B.
Construction Plans and Specifications.
Prior to construction, KIWANIS shall, at its sole cost, develop detailed
plans and specifications for improvements to be made to the site, except for
those improvements initiated by the City, where the City shall bear the costs
of all design, construction, and inspection of work performed. Where State,
Federal or local laws, or the City's Parks Director, require plans to be certified
or by a professional licensed to practice in the State of Iowa, KIWANIS shall
obtain such certification prior to submittal to the CITY for approval.
No
construction or other work, excepting maintenance described in Section III of
this Agreement, shall begin without the prior written approval of the Park and
Recreation Director. All projects shall be completed in strict adherence to the
plans and specifications as approved by the CITY; any deviations from the
plans and specifications or substitutions of materials, construction methods,
or equipment shall be permitted only with the prior written approval of the
CITY.
2
Construction of Improvements.
1.
In the undertaking of the project, the responsibilities of the KIWANIS
shall include but not be limited to:
Preparation of construction plans and specifications
a)
b)
The taking of all bids and quotations, except for projects
initiated and paid for with public funds where the City shall
assume responsibility as set forth in II(B).
The scheduling and supervision of all work
c)
The payment of all fees, costs, charges and expenses
d)
associated with this work
appropriate boards and
Receiving approval
of all
e)
commissions.
f)
Preparing applications for all required State, Federal, and
local permits and licenses, and submitting the same to the
City for approval and transmittal.
Acceptance of Improvements.
2.
The CITY agrees to accept ownership of all improvements to Riverview
Park constructed under this Agreement. Acceptance of ownership of
these improvements shall be subject to verification by the CITY that the
improvements have been completed in compliance with the Master Plan,
and in accord with approved plans and specifications. Acceptance shall
be made by resolution of the Park and Recreation Board.
C.
Site Safety Restoration
KIWANIS shall perform all work to restore Riverview Park to a condition safe
for public use, as determined by the CITY. Said work shall include, but not
necessarily be limited to:
Removal of debris from the site, except hazardous material or
1.
construction debris which may be illegally dumped in the park.
Removal of all vegetative growth from paved areas in the park
2.
3.
Restoring existing paved surfaces through the application of
sealants and resurfacing as needed.
The need for resurfacing
shall be as determined by the CITY.
4.
Removal of building foundations (except those salvageable for
future use), pipe, and remnants of previously used facilities.
Removal of trees identified by the CITY as being a safety hazard.
5.
3
6.
Delineate trails on existing paved surfaces.
7.
Provide paved access to the site by extending the existing paved
levy hiker-biker path (along the river) onto the site.
D.
Site Improvements.
KIWANIS shall make improvements to Riverview Park to improve access
These
within the site and provide limited nature interpretive areas.
improvements shall include, but not necessarily be limited to the following:
Construct walkways over and/or through wetlands areas of the
1.
park.
Develop interpretive areas within the park. This development
2.
shall include the construction and installation of birdhouses and
bird feeding stations, the use of selected debris from the site to
form small mammal and bird habitat related shelters and covers
and the construction of sitting areas for viewing wetlands, lagoon
or island habitats.
E.
Pedestrian Access to Site.
The KIWANIS shall construct a pedestrian bridge, from McHenry Park on the
north, to provide access to the site, subject to and conditioned upon the City
acquiring the necessary right-of-way from the Chicago and Northwestern
Railroad. The pedestrian bridge shall adhere to the requirements of Section
II.
F.
Licenses and Permits.
The KIWANIS shall abide by all applicable federal, state and local laws,
ordinances, rules and regulations, and all licenses and permits obtained for
construction of site improvements.  Nothing herein shall preclude Kiwanis from
asking issuing authorities for waivers of permits, licenses, and fees where
waivers.
statutes or ordinances provide for such
4
G.
Installation of Improvements.
KIWANIS shail coordinate the installation of individual improvements with the
CITY's Park and Recreation Director, to obtain approval for access to the
installation site, and to minimize interference with and damage to surrounding 
Park areas and grounds.
1.
Trees.
No trees or shrubs within the surrounding Park areas shall be removed,
trimmed or otherwise altered by the KIWANIS to provide access to the
site, or for any other reason, without the prior approval of the Park and
Recreation Director or his designee.
2.
Site Restoration.
KIWANIS shall promptly repair any damage caused by Kiwanis to the
site or the grounds of surrounding Park areas, and/or plant materials
resulting from the installation of improvements.  Any site restoration
shall be completed promptly after the occurrence at the sole expense of
the KIWANIS, and shall return the area to its condition prior to the
damage, provided that an improvement installed in accordance with the
plans and specifications approved by the CITY shall not be construed as
creating damage to the grounds.
3.
Supervision.
KIWANIS shall supervise the construction and installation of each
improvement in such a manner to insure that the improvement shall be
installed in a workmanlike and prudent manner, and in accordance with
all applicable codes and ordinances.
III.
PARK MAINTENANCE.
A.
Maintenance Responsibilities.
KIWANIS shall provide all maintenance to the site beyond that which was
being performed by the CITY prior to the execution of this Agreement. That
maintenance shall include but not necessarily be limited to the following tasks:
5
Dailv. Weekly and Seasonal Work Plans.
1.
Mowing and trimming of turf areas to a level comparable
a)
to other park areas maintained by the CITY.
Trash pick up on the site to include depositing said trash
b)
in receptacle at a location determined by the CITY.
Frequency of trash pick up to be sufficient to ensure the
area is reasonably clear of litter.
KIWANIS shall submit a schedule of general maintenance
c)
activities to be performed on a weekly, monthly, and
seasonal basis. Reports shall be submitted on a quarterly
basis, for the periods commingling July 1, October 1,
January 1, and April 1 of each calendar year. Reports shall
be submitted to the Park and Recreation Director not less
than fifteen (15) days prior to the start of each quarter.
2.
Seasonal Tasks.
Seasonal tasks to be performed by Kiwanis shall include, but not
be limited to:
Repair, painting and replacement of site furniture and
a)
fixtures including but not limited to benches, tables,
boardwalks and docks.
Surface and crack repair for all paved paths and surfaces.
b)
c)
Pruning and trimming of trees and shrubs including the
removal of any hazards.
Trimming of trees and shrubs
shall be coordinated with, and approved by the Park and
Recreation Director.
B.
Damage or Destruction of Premises.
KIWANIS shall restore, rehabilitate, or remove, with the permission of the
CITY, any improvement damaged or destroyed by any casualty whatsoever,
including but not limited to damage caused by fire, storms or vandalism.
KIWANIS shall have a reasonable time from the date of notice by the CITY to
correct any damage to improvements on the site. Any unsafe condition shall
be made safe by corrective action taken within a reasonable time thereafter.
All notices shall be as provided in Section VIII (A) of this Agreement.
6
As used in this Agreement, a reasonable time shall mean fifteen (15) days for
damages less than $500, and not more than thirty (30) days for damages
between $501 and $1,500 dollars. For damagers above $1,501 in value, the
City and Kiwanis shall mutually agree on the appropriate time to be allowed,
provided that such time shall not extend beyond six months. The City may
grant an extension to the time periods provided herein for weather related
delays, or for reasonable cause as the City shall determine.
IV. RIGHTS RESERVED BY THE CITY.
Public Park.
A.
It is understood and agreed by the parties that Riverview Park is a public park
and recreation facility. It is the intent of the parties to improve the site in a
manner which will enhance its use as a public recreation facility. KIWANIS
will not. by virtue of this Agreement, and except as set forth in Article VI, be
granted considerations for the use of this park beyond those that are available
to other members of the public. It is agreed and understood that the KIWANIS
shall not have the right to limit the public use of the park or improvements
thereto.
B.
Improvements.
At its sole discretion, and after notification to Kiwanis, the CITY may repair,
replace, enlarge or otherwise improve any facilities or improvements now or
subsequently located in Riverview Park.
V.
FACILITY NAME.
In consideration of the contribution contemplated by the KIWANIS towards the
development of Riverview Park, both in maintenance and in the construction of major
facilities as detailed in the approved Master Plan, the CITY agrees to allow Kiwanis
to incorporate the word "Kiwanis" into the renaming of the Park . The name change
to become effective upon the approval of the Master Plan, and be conditioned upon
continued progress by Kiwanis to implement the Master Plan. KIWANIS may erect
park identification signage as permitted by City ordinances, and as set forth in the
Master Plan document.
Kiwanis may erect temporary signs, upon the execution of this Agreement,
identifying the site as Kiwanis Riverview Nature Island, until such time as a Master
~]
Plan is approved. At that time, Kiwanis shall remove the temporary signs, and
incorporate new signs, including a new name for the Park, as determined by the
Master Plan.
VI.
CONCESSIONS.
KIWANIS shall have the non-exelusive right, during the term of this
Agreement, to run concessions in and upon Riverview Park, and to retain the profits
associated with such Kiwanis concession activities for the purpose of generating funds
to improve the Park.
Concession rights shall be exclusive or non-exclusive as
determined by the Master Plan. Such concessions may include, but are not limited
to paddle boats, canoes, food and beverage stands, bait and tackle shops, bicycle
rental shops, and other concessions of a similar character or nature. All funds
generated from Kiwanis operated concessions in the Park shall be used exclusively
for maintaining, improving and enhancing Riverview Park.
Kiwanis shall keep and maintain true and accurate books and records of all
receipts from concessions at Riverview Park, including all food and beverage
concessions, equipment rentals, and any and all activities from which revenue is
received. 
The City shall have access to all books, banking records, cash register
tapes, and other financial records and receipts used in conjunction with the operation
of Kiwanis at Riverview. Books and records shall be made available to the City at
reasonable hours and upon reasonable notice for inspection and audit by the CITY.
VII.
INSURANCE AND HOLD HARMLESS.
A.
Hold Harmless.
As part of the consideration for this Agreement, the KIWANIS agrees to
indemnify, defend and save harmless the CITY, its officers, employees, and
agents, hereinafter referred to as the "Indemnities", from any and all loss or
damage (including, without limiting the generality of the foregoing, all legal
fees and disbursements paid or incurred by the CITY , including the value of
services rendered by the CITY's Legal Department to enforce this provision)
which may be imposed upon, incurred by, or asserted against the Indemnities
by reason of negligent or tortious act, error, or omission resulting in personal
injury, bodily injury, sickness, disease, or death to persons; or damage to, loss
of, or destruction of tangible or intangible property, including the loss of use
thereof, arising out of the design, construction, installation, maintenance or
presence of improvements pursuant to the terms of this Agreement.
8
B.
Insurance.
KIWANIS covenants and agrees that at all times during the term of this
Agreement, it will at its own expense procure and maintain commercial general
liability insurance, on an occurrence basis, in a responsible company or
companies authorized to do business in the State of iowa, in amounts not less
than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000) combined single limit, or such
increased amount as the CITY may, from time to time, reasonably deem
necessary to protect its interests. Certificates of Insurance naming the CITY
and providing for mandatory notice to the CITY at least thirty (30) days before
cancellation of the policy shall be delivered to the CITY on or before the date
of the beginning of the term of this Agreement and each renewal of the
insurance policy thereafter.
VIII. NOTICES AND COMPLAINTS.
A.
Notices.
Notices as provided for in this Agreement shall be given in writing to the
parties hereto at the respective addresses designated on page one of this
Agreement unless either party notifies the other, in writing, of a different
address. Without prejudice to any other method of notifying a party or making
a demand or other communication, any notice shall be considered given under
the terms of this Agreement when deposited in a United States mailbox,
addressed as above designated, certified mail, return receipt requested, postage
prepaid.
B.
Complaints,
Any complaints by the CITY with regard to improvements or maintenance of
Riverview Park shall be made by the CITY's Park and Recreation Director or
such other person as the Director may designate and shall identify the date
and nature of the complaint, and actions required to correct the problem. Any
complaints by the KIWANIS directed to the CITY shall be in writing to the
CITY's Park and Recreation Director under the signature of an authorized
representative of the KIWANIS, and shall identify the date that the occurrence
complained of occurred.
9
IX.
RIGHTS. PROVISIONS. LANGUAGE.
A.
Successors.
Each and every covenant and Agreement herein contained shall extend to and
be binding upon the successors and assigns of the parties hereto.
B.
Modification.
No covenants, provisions, terms or conditions of this Agreement to be observed
or performed by the CITY or the KIWANIS shall be in any manner modified,
waived or abandoned, except by a written instrument duly signed by the
parties and delivered to the CITY and the KIWANIS. This Agreement contains
the whole agreement of the parties with respect to the restoration and
development of Riverview Park.
C.
Rights.
The various rights, powers, options, elections and remedies of either party
provided in this Agreement shall be construed as cumulative and no one item
is exclusive of any rights, remedies or priorities allowed either party by law,
and shall in no way affect or impair the right of either party to pursue any
other equitable or legal remedy in any way unremedied, unsatisfied or
undischarged.
D.
Language and Captions.
Words and phrases herein, including acknowledgement hereof, shall be
construed as in the singular or plural number, and as masculine, feminine or
neuter gender according to the context. The captions in this Agreement are for
convenience only and shall not constitute a limitation on any terms therein.
E.
Severance.
In the event any term or provision of this Agreement is declared unlawful by
a court of competent jurisdiction, that provision shall be null and void and the
remaining terms shall remain in force and effect and shall be the agreement
between the parties while the parties negotiate in good faith to replace any
such unlawful provision. If the arrangement called for in this Agreement
cannot be continued without the unlawful term of provision, and if the parties
are unable for any reason to negotiate a mutually agreeable and lawful
replacement provision within thirty days after the court decree becomes final,
this Agreement shall terminate.
10
x
ASSIGNMENT OR TRANSFER.
A.
Rights Under Agreement.
The KIWANIS shall not assign or transfer any of its rights under this
Agreement at any time to anyone without the prior approval of the CITY.
B.
Mechanics Lien.
Neither the KIWANIS nor anyone claiming by, through, or under the
KIWANIS, shall have the right to file or place any mechanic's lien or other lien
of any kind or character whatsoever upon the property described in Exhibit
"A", or upon any building or improvement thereon, or upon the interest of the
KIWANIS therein, and notice is hereby given that no contractor, subcontractor,
or anyone else who may furnish any material, service or labor for any
sculpture, building, improvement, alteration, repair or any part thereof, shall
at any time be or become entitled to any lien thereof, and for the further
security of the CITY, the KIWANIS covenants and agrees to file actual notice
thereof, in advance, to any and all contractors and subcontractors who may
furnish material, service or labor.
xi.
DISCRIMINATION.
The KIWANIS agrees that, during the term of this Agreement it will not
exclude any qualified person from participating in any programs or activities operated
by the KIWANIS in Riverview Park and shall not separately or together with anyone
else deny anyone the benefits of such programs or activities, or otherwise subject
anyone to discrimination on the grounds of age, race, religion, creed, sex, color,
national origin, ancestry or disability.
XII.
TERMINATION.
In the event a party violates or fails to carry out any of the provisions of this
Agreement, the other party shall give the violating party sixty (60) days' written
notice of said violation or failure; and in the event the violating party does not correct
such violation or failure within sixty (60) days (or such longer period if the same is
not reasonably curable in sixty days), or if a party habitually violates such provisions,
then the other party may cancel this Agreement.
Il
XIII.
TERM OF AGREEMENT
This Agreement shall be in force and effect from and after its execution and
recording with the Secretary of State for the State of Iowa, and the Recorder's Office
for Polk County, and shall run for a term of five (5) years, with an automatic renewal
of five (5) years unless either party submits its intention to terminate the Agreement
not less than thirty (30) days prior to the end of initial period.
The above not
withstanding, this Agreement's term may be terminated or modified upon mutual
consent of the parties.
XIV. RELATIONSHIP AND ADMINISTRATION
A.
The parties undertake this Agreement pursuant to Iowa Code (1991)
Chapter 28E.
The parties are not creating any separate legal or
administrative entity, and will not have a separate budget; each party
being responsible, as provided herein, for its own expenses.
B.
For purposes of Iowa Code, Section 28E.6 (1), the Park and Recreation
Director of the City shall be the administrator of this cooperative
undertaking.
12
IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the parties have caused this Agreement to be
executed by their duly-authorized officers as of the date first above written.

AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE CITY OF WINDSOR HEIGHTS AND BRAVO
GREATER DES MOINES, INC.
This Agreement is made and entered into on this
day of Apr /
, 2008.
(the "Execution Date") by and between the City of Windsor Heights, Iowa, and Bravo Greater
Des Moines, Inc. ("Bravo") an Iowa not-for-profit corporation, pursuant to the provisions of
Chapter 28E, Code of Iowa. The Agreement shall be effective with respect to Commitments
beginning July 1, 2008 (the "Effective Date").
That inasmuch as Bravo is organized for the purpose of assisting the cultural community of Polk
County and contiguous counties (the "Greater Des Moines Area") in providing an enriched
quality of life by increasing cultural awareness, advocacy, and funding, as well as by fostering
collaboration among cultural organizations.
That the City of Windsor Heights has as a goal the unification and coordination of monies for the
use and benefit of the cultural community and specifically the cultural organizations which are
members of Bravo. The City of Windsor Heights is committed to the reasonable stewardship of
monies for arts and cultural purposes.
That the City of Windsor Heights and Bravo agree as follows:
I. DEFINITIONS
"Hotel/Motel Tax" means a tax imposed in accordance with Chapter 423A of the Code of
(1)
Iowa, 2007, or similar successor provisions.
"Hotel/Motel Tax Revenues" means the funds remitted to the City of Windsor Heights by
(2)
the Treasurer of the State of Iowa from the local Transient Guest Tax Fund in accordance
with provisions of Chapter 423A of the Code of Iowa, 2007, and the rules promulgated by
the Director of the Iowa Department of Revenue thereunder, or similar successor
provisions, representing the proceeds collected by the State of Iowa from the
Hotel//Motel Tax imposed by the City of Windsor Height.
II. PRE-CONDITIONS TO OBLIGATIONS OF THE CITY OF WINDSOR HEIGHTS
The obligation of the City of Windsor Heights hereunder shall be subject to the fulfillment of the
adoption of an appropriate resolution by the City Council of the City of Des Moines approving a
substantially similar Agreement.
III. COVENANT FROM CITY OF WINDSOR HEIGHTS
(1)
The City of Windsor Heights does hereby irrevocably pledge and commit to the
promotion of arts and cultural activities in the Greater Des Moines Area for the entire
term of this Agreement and all extensions thereof, 2/7 of its Hotel/Motel Tax Revenues
(the "Commitment") to be distributed and expended by Bravo in the manner set forth in
this Agreement. Each year the Commitment shall be reduced, but not below zero by the
following amounts
The City of Windsor Heights shall take all action necessary to implement disbursement of
(2)
the Commitment. Payment of the Commitment to Bravo shall be made in quarterly
installments, paid no later than 30 days following the date on which the City receives the
quarterly remittance of Hotel/Motel Tax Revenues for the prior fiscal quarter, taking into
account any reductions for such quarter as provided in paragraph (1) above.
(3)
If Chapter 423A of the Code of Iowa is amended to permit and the City of Windsor
Heights subsequently imposes a Hotel/Motel Tax in excess of 7%, the Commitment shall
be limited to 2/7 of Hotel/Motel Tax Revenues derived from the initial 7% of tax.
IV. PURPOSE
The purpose of this Agreement is to facilitate and support the cultural community of the Greater
Des Moines Area in providing an enriched quality of life by increasing cultural awareness,
advocacy and funding as well as by fostering collaboration among cultural organizations and
increasing stability of Bravo in carrying out its goals for the benefit of the Greater Des Moines
Area. This Agreement is not intended to establish a separate legal entity.
V. ACCOUNTING OF BENEFITS
(1) Bravo shall administer the undertakings between the City of Windsor Heights and Bravo
as described herein, and Bravo shall acquire, hold and disburse its assets, including the
Commitment, in accordance with the purpose and terms stated herein and the governing
documents of Bravo. The City of Windsor Heights hereby appoints its City Administrator to
administer this Agreement with Bravo, and Bravo hereby appoints its President to administer
this Agreement with the City of Windsor Heights.
(2) The City of Windsor Heights and Bravo acknowledge that the communities within the
Greater Des Moines Area that make payment commitments to Bravo ("Participating
Communities") and not-for-profit organizations within such Participating Communities may,
as part of a capital campaign, apply for grant funding. Bravo shall establish a separate fund to
provide matching funds to the Participating Communities and the not-for-profit organizations
within such Participating Communities (the "Fund"). Bravo shall allocate a portion of the
Commitment payments from all Participating Communities to create a minimum required
balance of $150,000 ("Minimum Required Balance") in the Fund prior to September 1, 2008.
For a not-for-profit organization to be eligible to receive a disbursement from the Fund, the
not-for-profit organization must make a presentation regarding its capital campaign to Bravo
before the not-for-profit organization approaches any of the Participating Communities for a
contribution. Bravo, in its reasonable discretion shall make determinations on Fund
disbursements for proposed capital campaigns within the Participating Communities in such
manner that will enhance the competitiveness of the grant funding applications and further
the purpose of this Agreement. Prior to January 1 of each year during the term of this
Agreement, Bravo shall, if necessary, replenish the Fund to its Minimum Required Balance.
If, as of January 1 of each year during the term of this Agreement, the funds in the Fund
exceed the Minimum Required Balance, Bravo may withdraw such excess funds from the
Fund and may use the withdrawn funds in accordance with the purpose of this Agreement.
The City of Windsor Heights and Bravo acknowledge that any matching funds provided by
Bravo for a not-for-profit organization's capital campaign shall not be intended or construed
as the sole or exclusive capital funding source to be provided by Participating Communities
for such project.
Bravo shall present to the City Administrator of the City of Windsor Heights no later than
(3)
30 days after Bravo's Board of Directors approves Bravo's audited fiscal year financial
statements, a full accounting of Bravo's revenues, disbursements and operations for such
year in a form reasonably acceptable to the City ("Financial Statements"). The Financial
Statements will include a summary of the disbursement awards made by Bravo during the
fiscal year, including for each recipient of an award the amount awarded and a brief
description of the approved uses for the award. The fiscal year of Bravo ends each June
30.
(4)
The Financial Statements shall be prepared by Bravo and reviewed by a certified public
accountant selected by Bravo.
VI. OPERATIONS AND FINANCES
Bravo shall prepare and submit to the Windsor Heights' City Council prior to the
commencement of each of Bravo's fiscal years beginning during the term of this Agreement a
distribution plan for public funds (the "Plan"). The Plan for the 2008 fiscal year previously
submitted to the Windsor Heights' City Council, as amended, shall serve as the Plan for the
remainder of the 2008 fiscal year. All expenditures of public funds by Bravo shall be made
pursuant to the Plan.
VII. DURATION AND TERMINATION
(1)
The initial term of this Agreement shall begin on the Effective Date and expire on June
30, 2011.
(2)
Upon the expiration of such initial term and any extension thereof, this Agreement may
be extended for an additional term of 3 years if such extension is affirmed in writing by
both parties.
This Agreement shall terminate if Chapter 423A of the Code of Iowa is either: (a)
(3)
repealed or amended to remove the authority of the City of Windsor Heights to collect the
Hotel/Motel Tax at a rate of at least 7% or (b) so modified that the purpose of the
Agreement can no longer be carried out. If the Agreement terminates pursuant to the
previous sentence, the termination date shall be the June 30 coinciding with or next
following the effective date of the statutory change that causes the termination.
(4)
This Agreement shall terminate if an alternative, reliable funding source is secured for
Bravo that provides funding to Bravo, in the reasonable determination of the Bravo board
of directors, that is comparable in amount to the annual funding streams Bravo has
secured in the aggregate through 28E agreements with the cities, counties and
municipalities of the Greater Des Moines Area (for example, if Chapter 423A of the Code
of Iowa were amended to increase the Hotel/Motel tax and to direct a portion of the
increase to Bravo in an amount comparable to the annual funding streams expected from
28E agreements already in place). If a reliable alternative funding source is secured for
Bravo, which partially replaces the funds provided by the City of Windsor Heights to
Bravo, the amount of annual funding provided to Bravo pursuant to this Agreement shall
be reduced proportionately in such amount as the parties may reasonably determine. If the
Agreement terminates pursuant to this paragraph, the termination date shall be the June
30 coinciding with or next following the effective date of the alternative funding source
that causes the termination.
(5)
Any notice or demand required or desired to be given hereunder shall be in writing and
deemed given when personally delivered or when deposited in the United States mail,
postage prepaid, sent certified or registered, and addressed as follows:
If to the City of Windsor Heights, to:
City of Windsor Heights
1133 66@ Street
Windsor Heights, IA 50311
Attention: Marketa Oliver, City Administrator
If to Bravo, to:
Bravo Greater Des Moines, Inc.
Kathleen K. Law
Nyemaster Goode Law Firm
700 Walnut Street, Suite 1600
Des Moines, Iowa 50309
With a copy to:
Bravo Greater Des Moines, Inc.
1915 Grand Avenue
Des Moines, IA 50309
or to such other address or person as hereafter shall be designated in writing by the applicable
party.
VIII. AMENDMENT OF AGREEMENT
Any amendment to this Agreement shall be made in writing upon agreement of the City of
Windsor Heights and Bravo and after appropriate discussion and public dialogue, and such
amendment has been approved by resolution of the City of Windsor Heights City Council.
IX. MISCELLANEOUS
(1)
This Agreement has been made and entered into solely for the benefit of the goals and
objectives of the City of Windsor Heights and Bravo as expressly provided herein and is
not intended to create any rights in any other person.
(2)
Notwithstanding anything in this Agreement to the contrary, any liabilities, debts, or other
obligations experienced by Bravo as a corporation/body or its members shall not be the
responsibility of the City of Windsor Heights.
(3) While this Agreement is in effect, the City of Windsor Heights shall have the right to
designate one person to serve on the Board of Directors of Bravo.
(4) It is the intention and expectation of Bravo and the City of Windsor Heights that no
organization that receives funding from Bravo during the term of this Agreement will
approach the City of Windsor Heights for additional operational funding during the term of
this Agreement. This expectation does not apply to: (1) any member of Bravo that is owned,
managed or operated by the City of or a political subdivision of the City; or (2) capital
campaigns.
(5) Each of the City of Windsor Heights and Bravo shall pay its own costs incurred to
negotiate, amend, abide by or terminate this Agreement.
(6) After execution by the parties, this Agreement shall be filed with the Iowa Secretary of
State in accordance with the provisions of Iowa Code § 28E.8. The Agreement shall then be
recorded in the office of the Polk County Recorder in accordance with Iowa Code § 28E.8.
(7) As of the Effective Date, this Agreement is intended to replace the prior agreement
referred to in paragraph four of the preamble to this document.

AGREEMENT BETWEEN ADAMS TOWNSHIP AND THE PANTHER CREEK CEMETARY ASSOCIATION FOR THE
MAINTENANCE OF THE PANTHER CREEK CEMETERY
PURSUANT TO CHAPTER 28E OF THE IOWA CODE
This agreement is between the Adams Township, Dallas County, Iowa (Township) as duly represented by the Board of Trustees thereof,
and the Panther Creek Cemetery Association, Inc. (PCCA) respecting Township support for the maintenance of the Panther Creek
Cemetery located within Adams Township, Dallas County, Iowa, pursuant to Chapter 28E of the Code of Iowa.
Whereas PCCA, Inc is a private not-for-profit entity incorporated under the laws of the State of Iowa, and therewith maintains the
Panther Creek Cemetery, a private cemetery in Adams Township, Dallas County, Iowa, and
Whereas Adams Township has the limited ability to levy for the maintenance of cemeteries within the township, including for the
maintenance of private cemeteries within the township at a limited amount allowed within the limits of the law per each fiscal year, and
Whereas Panther Creek Cemetery receives for burial, residents of the Adams Township without cost to said residents,
Therefore Adams Township and PCCA enter into this agreement for the Adams Township to provide mowing maintenance support for
Panther Creek Cemetery
Scope of the agreement. Township agrees to provide funds, up to the allowable legal limit, to assist PCCA in paying for a mowing
l.
contractor of PCCA's choosing, for mowing maintenance only, for Panther Creek Cemetery in Adams Township. In return, PCCA will
abide by its bylaws and be in compliance with all current state and local laws. PCCA will request funds from the Township each year by
obtaining and sending, via U.S. Mail, the mowing contractor's bid they have chosen to mow Panther Creek Cemetery for said given year,
to Adams Township Clerk prior to January 31st of each given year (2010's deadline March 15, 20/0); to thus allow Trustees to prepare
each fiscal year's budget. PCCA will then send, via U.S. Mail, mowing contractor's original monthly invoices, within the first five days
of each mowing season month (-April through November) for previous month's work for reimbursement. Each invoice must include
the following information:
•
Contractor's name, address, phone
•
Detailed monthly billing: name of cemetery mowed, dates work completed, detailed explanation of work completed,
i.e. mowed, trimmed, sprayed for weeds, etc.
•
Total charged per hour per each occurrence mowed/trimmed/sprayed/etc.
•
Totaled amounts per days charged per month and final month's total
•
(Example attached)
2.
Duration. This agreement is of perpetual duration unless written noticed is received by January 31 of any year. This agreement
shall terminate at the end of the fiscal year in which notice is timely given (June 30).
The Adams Township Board of Trustees is administrator of this agreement. No separate organization is contemplated.
3.
4.
Financial. Adams Township agrees to provide limited funds for the cost of mowing operations for Panther Creek Cemetery.
Therewith, Adams Township will levy a tax within the provisions of Iowa Code for Township maintenance of private cemeteries within
the township, and annually budget such levied ansount for the maintenance of Panther Creek Cemetery and such other private cemeteries
within the township as deemed appropriate by the Adams Township Board of Trustees. PCCA understands there is a limit to the amount
that is allowable by law to be levied for privately owned cemeteries, that this amount cannot be amended or changed if already at the
maximum amount per fiscal year and that such funds are also available to other privately owned cemeteries that may at present, or in the
future, request financial assistance from Adams Township. PCCA will be responsible for all other costs of maintenance of the Panther
Creek Cemetery. This agreement does not provide PCCA the ability to control the funds levied by the township. Such funds shall be
budgeted by the township trustees, and may therewith be specially allocated as contemplated herein, with the Township Trustees
providing specified maintenance services. It is at the sole discretion of the Adams Township Board of Trustees to decide how funds may
be allocated to private cemetery association(s) such as PCCA, i.e. in block grants or monthly reimbursements, whichever is deemed
most beneficial and cost effective. Adams Township reserves the right to refuse to provide funding for failure of private cemeteries to
provide timely and detailed information as requested above.
5.
This agreement is effective on filing and recording upon approval of the statutory officers of the affected departments and as
authorized by the governing bodies of the respective entities, and upon recording with the Dallas County Recorder.

employed, shall remain in the County.

3.
not hold Tama County responsible for providing exclusive continuous

COOPERATION.
To facilitate the performance of said function,
it is hereby agreed that the County shall have full cooperation and
assistance from the Municipality, its officers, agents and employees.
The Municipality agrees to the county using the car, equipment, radio
and officers equipment during the period of this agreement after which
time same shall revert back to the Municipality.  The County agrees to
accept the operating and maintenance costs of this equipment for the
period of the contract.
LIABILITIES.
5. 
The Municipality shall not be called upon to assume any
(a)
liability for the direct payment of any salaries, wages or any other
compensation to any County personnel performing services hereunder for
said Municipality or any liability other that provide for in the
contract.
The Municipality shall not be liable for compensation of
indemnity to any County employee for injury or sickness arising out of
the employee's employment, and the Count hereby agrees to hold harmless
the Municipality against any such claims.
(b)
Tama County, its officers and employees, shall not be deemed
assume any liability for intentional or negligent acts of said
to 
Municipality or officers or employees thereof, and said Municipality
shall hold such County and its officers and employees harmless from and
shall defend said County and its officers and employees against any

The Municipality shall not be responsible for any act, injury
(c)
or damage arising out of the performance of this contract by the County
of Tama, and in any case claim is made by any third party, the County
shall defend indemnify and hold harmless the Municipality.
6.
PAYMENT.
The Municipality agrees to pay the hourly rate of
$42.18 for all calls responded to within the city limit, subject to an
increase or decrease as the parties may mutually agree, if the services
contracted for in paragraph 1 hereof are materially changed.
It is
contemplated that this contract shall be effective July 1, 2012, and
shall run for a period of 12 months thereafter.
DURATION OF CONTRACT. At the option of the governing body of
7.
the Municipality, with the consent of the Board of County Supervisors of
Tama County, this contract shall be renewable for successive periods not
to exceed 12 months. In the event the Municipality desires to renew
this 
contract for any succeeding period, the governing body of the
Municipality shall notify the Sheriff of Tama County and the Tama County
Board of Supervisors, in writing, that it wishes to renew the same,
whereupon the Board of Supervisors shall notify in writing the governing
body of the Municipality of its willingness to accept the renewal for no
more
2
than 12 additional months, or such other terms as agreed to. Otherwise,
the contract shall finally terminate at the end of such initial or
renewal period.
(a) Notwithstanding the provision of the paragraph set forth,
either party may terminate this contract as of the first day of any
month, upon notice in writing to the other party prior to the date of
termination.

ACCESS TO RECORDS.

access to records, documents and papers to auditors representing the

no

10.
monthly with a designated represented of the Municipality to review the

Any
complaints, requests or discretionary police matters shall be directed
to the Sheriff.
DISPUTES, APPEALS AND REMEDIES. Except as otherwise provided
11.
in this agreement, any dispute concerning a question of fact arising
under this agreement which is not disposed of by agreement shall be
decided by the County which shall reduce such decision to writing and
furnish a copy to the Municipality. Such decisions shall be final and
conclusive unless within (30) days from the receipt therefor the
Municipality notifies the County in writing the nature and extent that
the Municipality disagrees with the decision. The cause (s) of the
disagreement shall then be submitted to a mutually agreed upon third
party arbitrator for decision. Either party, if still dissatisfied, may
then appeal the decision of the arbitrator in the procedure followed in
a court of contempt jurisdiction. The parties agree that this agreement
shall be governed by the laws of the State of Iowa.

RESOLUTION NO. 09 - 168
A RESOLUTION APPROVING AND AUTHORIZING AN AMEND-
MENT TO A 28E AGREEMENT WITH THE MASON CITY CHAM-
BER OF COMMERCE FOR THE OPERATION AND MANAGEMENT
OF MASON CITY CONVENTION AND VISITORS BUREAU
WHEREAS, the City of Mason City, Iowa, and the Mason City Chamber of
Commerce entered into an amended agreement, (Resolution 98-12), for the management and op-
eration of the Mason City Convention and Visitors Bureau in Mason City, Iowa, on the 6th day
of January, 1998, and
WHEREAS, The City of Mason City, Iowa, on the 15th day of May, 2001, in
Resolution No. 01-106, amended the Section, 6. Finances and Operations, to increase the amount
that the City would allocate to pay to BUREAU from fifty percent (50%) to sixty percent (60%)
with the three year period ending June 30, 2004, and
WHEREAS, the City of Mason City, Iowa on the 4th day of May, 2004, in Reso-
lution No. 04-100 amended Section 6, Finances and operation to increase the amount that the
City would allocate to pay to BUREAU from (50%) to (60%) making the allocation on a con-
tinuous basis.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED by the City Council of the City of Ma-
son City, Iowa:
Section 1: That the allocation amended in Section 6, Finances and Operations of
the agreement, dated January 6, 1998, an amended May 15, 2001 and amended May 4, 2004 al-
locating 60% of the Hotel/Motel Tax to the Bureau will hereby terminate on June 30, 2010.
k . * *
r
Section 2 That the City will hereby amend the agreement, dated January 6, 1998
and amended May 15, 2001, and amended May 4, 2004, should be and the same is hereby
amended as follows:
6. Finances and Operations
The CITY will allocate to pay the BUREAU an amount
equal to at least 45 percent (45%) of the hotel/motel tax an-
nually collected by the Iowa Department of Revenue from
within the City limits of Mason City, Iowa, and received by
the CITY, payable in equal installments as received from
the Department of Revenue. This amount shall constitute
complete compensation from the CITY for all of the ser-
vices to be rendered including personnel costs, travel, print-
ing and publication of all other expenses.
That said allocation decreasing the amount that the City
would allocate to pay to BUREAU from 60% to 45% on a
continuous basis shall become effective July 1, 2010
Section 3: That the Mayor and City Clerk should be and are hereby authorized
and directed to execute said amended agreement, which said agreement is attached hereto, and
by this reference made a part hereof, on behalf of the City of Mason City, Iowa.
Section 4: That the Finance Director is hereby authorized and directed to make
quarterly payments to the Mason City Chamber of Commerce which shall constitute at least 45%
of all hotel/motel tax revenues received from the State of Iowa.
PASSED AND APPROVED this 2nd day of June, 2009.
/s/Brent Trout
Brent Trout, Mayor

LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICE CONTRACT
Article One
Parties
This agreement is made and entered into by and between the COUNTY OF GREENE
and the CITY OF SCRANTON.
Article Two
Purpose
It is the purpose of this agreement to establish the terms and conditions for the GREENE
County Sheriff to provide law enforcement services to the CITY OF SCRANTON,
Article Three
Terms and Conditions
Pursuant to the Provisions of Chapter 28E, Code of Iowa, it is hereby agreed by the
parties as follows:
3.1 Greene County agrees that the Greene County Sheriff's Office shall provide
normal law enforcement services within the corporate limits of the City of
Scranton, including:
a. employing radar operations to control speeding;
b. issuing citations for violations under Municipal Ordinances when applicable;
handling animal calls and bite reports;
c. 
d. serving notices on request without fees;
e. providing on-duty deputies for special events;
periodically checking commercial buildings for unlocked doors and trespassers;
ei
responding to all other reasonable requests from the Mayor or Council for law
g.
enforcement related services.
3.2 Greene County agrees that the Greene County Sheriff's Office will patrol an
average of two (2) times daily, seven (7) days per week within the incorporated
limits of the City of Scranton. The Mayor or Council may request that the patrol
take place during hours designated by them.
3.3 Greene County agrees that the Greene County Sheriff's Office shall provide
monthly reports to the City of Scranton, including a summary of the law
enforcement activities occurring in the City.
3.4 The City of Scranton agrees that its officers, agents and employees shall
cooperate fully with the Greene County Sheriff's Office in the performance of
their official duties.
3.5 Assignment of duties, discipline of county employees and matters incident to the
performance of the duties of county employees shall remain the responsibility of
Greene County and its officers, employees and commissions. The City of
Scranton shall provide requested information and reports to facilitate the Greene
County Sheriff's assignment and supervision of personnel.
3.6 Greene County shall be responsible for the payment of salary, wages, and/or any
other compensation or benefits to any County employee providing services under
this agreement unless otherwise expressly agreed upon by the parties.
3.7 Except as otherwise specified herein, the City of Scranton shall not be liable for
compensation or indemnity to any county employee for injury or sickness arising
out of his/her employment, and Greene County hereby agrees to hold the City of
Scranton harmless against any such claims.
3.8 This contract does not authorize, and the Greene County Attorney is not required
to prosecute any civil or criminal municipal infraction promulgated pursuant to
Section 364.22 of the Code of Iowa or any simple misdemeanor motor vehicle
violations.
Article 4
Limitation of Liability
4.1 While the Greene County Attorney may from time to time give advice to the
Greene County Sheriff's Office which is necessary for the investigation of a
criminal case, the Greene County Attorney is not the legal advisor to the City of
Scranton. Nothing in this contract is to be construed to make the Greene County
Attorney the legal advisor to the City of Scranton or any other officer or employee
of the City of Scranton.
4.2 Greene County shall be responsible and liable for the actions of the Greene
County Sheriff's Office when in the performance of their duties of law
enforcement within the boundaries of the City of Scranton. Greene County shall
hold the City of Scranton harmless and shall indemnify the City of Scranton for
any lawsuits or damages arising out of the actions of the Greene County Sheriff's
Office within the boundaries of the City of Scranton. The Greene County Sheriff
shall have no other civil liability to the City of Scranton for his actions pursuant to
this contract.
4.3 The City of Scranton shall be responsible and liable for the actions of the City of
Scranton, and all its officials or employees. The City of Scranton shall hold
Greene County harmless and shall defend and indemnify Greene County for any
lawsuits or damages arising out of any official's or employee's action on behalf of
the city pursuant to this contract.
Article Five
Financial Terms
5.1
In consideration of services provided herein the City of Scranton will pay
to the Greene County Sheriff's Office effective February 1, 2011 the
annual sum of $28,960.00; payment to be made monthly at the rate of
$2,413.34.
Article Six
Period of Agreement
6.1
This contract shall become effective upon signing by both parties and shall
remain in effect unless terminated by either party by giving the other one
(1) month written notice. It may be modified at any time by joint
agreement of both parties, by written addendums, executed in the same
manner as this agreement.
6.2
This said contract may be reviewed annually in January at the request of
either party, including the amount of consideration.
6.2
This contract shall be governed by the laws of the State of Iowa. If any
part of this contract shall be judicially or legislatively voided, the
remainder of the contract shall, remain in effect until amended or
terminated

4.2 Greene County shall be responsible and liable for the actions of the Greene

any lawsuits or damages arising out of the actions of the Greene County Sheriff's

shall have no other civil liability to the City of Scranton for his actions pursuant to
this contract.
4.3 The City of Scranton shall be responsible and liable for the actions of the City of
Scranton, and all its officials or employees. The City of Scranton shall hold
Greene County harmiess and shall defend and indemnify Greene County for any
lawsuits or damages arising out of any official's or employee action of the city
pursuant to this contract.
Article Five
Financial Terms
5.1
In consideration of services provided herein the City of Scranton will pay.
to the Greene County Sheriff's Office the sum of $60.00 (sixty dollars) for
each investigation of a municipal ordinance violation, other than what is
covered by the Law Enforcement Service Comment payment to be made
monthly

 6.2

28E AGREEMENT AND CONTRACT
FOR EMS COVERAGE
This Agreement and Contract is made between the City of Redfield, Dallas County, Iowa,
hereinafter referred to as "Redfield" and the City of Linden, Dallas County, Iowa, hereinafter referred to
as "Linden".
WHEREAS, Redfield has an EMS in operation which is funded by the City and operated by
volunteers; and
WHEREAS, Linden does not have any EMS services immediately available to them and the
Redfield EMS has frequently been dispatched to Linden to assist its citizens; and
WHEREAS, the cost of providing transportation for EMS has increased substantially, and
Redfield has requested that Linden contribute to said costs, and
WHEREAS, the City of Linden has agreed to a payment of $20.00 per call, commencing October
1, 2013, for any EMS calls made within the city limits of Linden and Redfield shall bill Linden on a
monthly basis for any EMS calls made within the city limits of Linden.
NOW, THEREFORE, the parties hereto agree to enter into this Agreement and Contract for the
purpose of providing emergency medical services to Linden, as follows:
1. Redfield EMS shall respond to the calls within the city limits of the City of Linden.
2. The City of Linden shall pay $20.00 per call to the City of Redfield for each call by the
Redfield EMS within the city limits of Linden, commencing October 1, 2013.
3. The City of Redfield shall bill the City of Linden each month for all calls by the Redfield EMS
within the city limits of the City of Linden, and said amount shall be remitted within 45 days from
submission of the bill.
4. It is further agreed that Redfield will own, maintain, house and man the equipment required to
be used under this Agreement and Contract. Redfield will assume all costs and liability for this EMS
coverage.
5. The City of Redfield represents that the Redfield EMS is a service run by volunteers only.
2013 Page 17121
6. This Agreement may be modified or amended by the parties hereto by giving notice of same
by regular mail to the other community no later than February 1 of each year and said modification or
amendment shall be in writing and signed by the mayor and city clerk of each city.
7. No separate legal or administrative entity is created under this Agreement and Contract.
8. The City Clerk of Redfield shall cause this Agreement and Contract to be filed with the
Secretary of State and recorded in the office of the County Recorder after execution by all parties and it
shall provide the City of Linden a copy of the recorded Agreement and Contract.

AGREEMENT
BETWEEN THE CITY OF BOYDEN, IOWA AND SIOUX COUNTY, IOWA
RELATING TO THE PROVISION OF LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES
THIS AGREEMENT, consisting of two (2) pages, is made between the City of Boyden,
Iowa, a municipality of the State of Iowa (hereinafter "Boyden") and Sioux County,
Iowa (hereinafter "County").
WHEREAS, Boyden wishes to contract with County for law enforcement services
within the corporate limits of Boyden; and
WHEREAS such Agreements are authorized in Iowa Code §28E;
NOW THEREFORE, Boyden and County agree as follows:
1) County agrees, through the Sioux County Sheriff ("Sheriff") to provide law
enforcement services within the corporate limits of Boyden, including but not limited
to the following:
a) Patrol, traffic enforcement and control, response to complaints or calls,
investigations, emergency service, service of civil documents, and other tasks
typically performed by a law enforcement agency.
b) Sheriff shall be responsible for administrative duties associated with the function
of said law enforcement services.
2) County shall furnish the necessary equipment and personnel to carry out the services
provided for in this agreement.
 l
3) Boyden agrees to pay County for the law enforcement services provided by Sheriff.
The payment shall be in an amount to be determined by the Sheriff and the Board of
Supervisors of Sioux County as is necessary to carry out the law enforcement
functions stated in this agreement. Such payments shall be made to the Sheriff's
Office on a quarterly basis, payable as follows: July 1, 2010; October 1, 2010;
January 1, 2011; April 1, 2011. The total amount for this contract period has been
set at: $70,038.
4) This Agreement shall be irrevocable for the duration of the contract period.
Thereafter either party may discontinue participation by providing written notice to
the other no later than May 1st of the current year.
5) This agreement shall be effective on the 1st day of July, 2010 and shall run to the 1st
day of July, 2011. Thereafter, at the option of the Boyden City Council, and the
Sioux County Board of Supervisors, with the consent of the Sheriff of Sioux County,
this agreement may be renewable for successive periods not to exceed one (1) year.
APPROVED by the Boyden, Iowa City Council.

NEIGHBORHOOD DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION
THIS 28E AGREEMENT (“Agreement”) is made and entered into as of the _[]" Hay of
, 2007 by and between the City of Des Moines, Iowa, a municipal
lecember
corporation (hereinafter referred to as "City") and Neighborhood Development Corporation
(hereinafter referred to as "NDC") under and in accordance with Chapter 28E, Code of Iowa,
2007.
WHEREAS, the City of Des Moines ("City") is a municipal corporation established
under the laws of the State of Iowa; and
WHEREAS, Neighborhood Development Corporation is a non-profit corporation
established under the Iowa Non-Profit Corporation Act, Chapter 504A of the Iowa Code; and
WHEREAS, the NDC was incorporated on February 17, 1999 to plan, coordinate and
implement public and private redevelopment efforts within low and moderate income census
tracts in the City of Des Moines, Iowa, and elsewhere in Polk County, Iowa; and
WHEREAS, this Agreement shall supersede and replace a 28E Agreement executed on
December 16, 2002 by the parties; and
WHEREAS, no legal or administrative entity is being created by this Agreement.
NOW, THEREFORE, the parties hereto in consideration of the mutual covenants herein,
agree as follows:
1.
The City shall contribute $1,000,000.00 annually for the five-year term of this
Agreement exclusively for the actual project costs of redevelopment efforts within
areas designated by the United States Department of Housing and Urban
Development Guidelines as low and moderate income census areas within Des
Moines.
NDC specifically agrees that a minimum of 80% of all annual Government source
funding must be obligated pursuant to valid contracts, before additional
Government source funds may be contributed.
NDC may expend from the City's annual contribution an amount not to exceed
2.
$100,000 for NDC operating expenses.
3.
During the term of this Agreement NDC may expend an amount not to exceed
$250,000 from the City's contribution to pay consultants for studies and plans
which will advance NDC's efforts to redevelop property in low and moderate
income areas of Des Moines.
l
NDC covenants that it will use its best efforts to take no action to cause any
4.
general obligation bonds issued by the City for the purpose of funding the NDC's
activities to be classified as Private Activity Bonds under Section 141 of the
Internal Revenue Code and regulations issued thereunder.
5.
NDC further covenants as follows:
If the City determines to contribute proceeds of tax exempt bonds to NDC,
a.
NDC shall determine if the appropriate Tax Exemption Certificate is not
such as to impair NDC's ability to support the programs referred in
paragraph 6 herein. If the NDC accepts the contribution of bond proceeds,
it will conform its operations and policies with respect to government
source monies to the use limitations contained in the Tax Exemption
Certificate issued with respect to such bonds for so long as any of the
bonds remain outstanding.
b.
It will also abide by any advice of Amendment to the City Tax Exemption
Certificate as communicated from time to time by the City Attorney of the
City with respect to the City, as may be necessary to maintain the tax
exempt status of the bonds.
It will maintain accurate records of the monies received from the City
c.
including the types, amounts and yields of all investments of unexpended
government source monies and earnings thereon in order to permit the
City, if necessary, to confirm ultimate use and to calculate the yields and
earnings thereon.
It will permit access to all investment information required or requested by
d.
the City.
NDC shall place all government source monies contributed by the City to the
6.
NDC in segregated accounts. The NDC further agrees that all of the NDC's
investments of government source monies shall be consistent with the NDC's
Investment Policy. Any further amendments to the current NDC Investment
Policy must be communicated by the NDC to the City and County.
7.
NDC agrees to implement redevelopment projects designed to assist in the
creation of housing, small business and employment opportunities in low to
moderate income census tract areas. Such activities may include, without
limitation, the following:
The acquisition of commercial and residential properties for future
a.
development consistent with government-approved development plans.
b.
The purchasing, leasing or selling of real property located in low to
moderate income census tracts in the City of Des Moines, Iowa.
2
Participating in or sponsoring real estate development projects.
c.
Entering into lawful contracts and agreements for the redevelopment of
d.
commercial and residential properties.
Entering into other cooperative efforts with public and private entities to
e.
support governmental unit revitalization and redevelopment efforts.
f.
It is anticipated that NDC will obtain other financing to support the above
efforts, above and beyond those government source monies contributed by
the City for its operating budget, including without limitation the
following sources:
Commercial banks.
Equity funds.
County funds.
Other City funds.
Revenue bonds.
Polk County Housing Trust Fund.
Private funds.
Neighborhood Finance Corporation loan funds.
State grants.
Tax increment financing.
Income generated from commercial property.
The City agrees that NDC may use both the principal and interest earned on the
8.
government source monics contributed to the NDC by the City pursuant to this
Agreement to fund redevelopment programs only developed by the NDC.
NDC agrees that all actions taken by the NDC related in any way to the
9.
government source monies contributed by the City to NDC shall be consistent
with the NDC's Procurement Policy in order to ensure that no NDC employee,
volunteer, officer, director, Board Member (or any of their family members)
receives any improper personal gain or benefit with respect to any agreement or
activity funded in whole or in part with government source monies contributed by
the City to the NDC. Any amendments to the current NDC Procurement Policy
must be communicated by the NDC to the City.
10.
NDC will submit NDC's annual budget, as well as all amendments thereto, to the
City within 30 days after adoption by the NDC's Board of Directors.
11.
NDC will submit NDC's annual audited financial report, which will include an
audit in accordance with OMB Circular A-133 when applicable, along with any
additional audit communications addressed to NDC's management or NDC's
Board of Directors, to the City within thirty (30) days after its issuance by the
NDC's auditing firm.
3
NDC will submit to the City quarterly reports of the NDC's programs and
12.

provide for the recruitment of retail, commercial and professional businesses in the City
in accordance with a marketing plan and the implementation of the Downtown
Development Guide.

board or council. The resolution shall authorize the execution of this Agreement. The

CHAPTER 28E LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES CONTRACT BETWEEN
CHICKASAW COUNTY AND NORTH WASHINGTON
___
This Agreement is entered into this G day of _
April
and between Chickasaw County, through its Board of Supervisors, and the Chickasaw
County Sheriff, (collectively County), and the City of North Washington, through its
City Council, for the law enforcement services identified hereunder.
1. STATEMENT OF AGREEMENT
l A. The City of North Washington (hercinafter City), in lieu of providing police
protection services as required by Iowa Code, hereby elects to contract with the County
for the provision of law enforcement services on behalf of the City and its residents.
1B. The County agrees to provide law enforcement services to the City, through the
County's Sheriff and Sheriff's personnel, in response to requests made by the City, its
officers, employees, and agents and upon request, call or dispatch through Sheriff's E911
personnel to any residents or persons within the City.
2. LEGAL BASIS
2A. This Agreement is authorized by the provisions of Code of Iowa, Chapter 28E. The
purpose of this agreement is to provide law enforcement services for the City and to
discharge the City's obligation to provide law enforcement services for their citizens in
accordance with Chapter 372.4(2) of the Code of lowa as interpreted by the Iowa
Supreme Court in Johnson v. Allen, 569 N.W. 2d 143 (Iowa 1997), referencing Code of
Iowa Chapter 368
3. GENERAL LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES DEFINED
3A. Law enforcement services consists of routine, irregular, random, intermittent and
unpredictable patrol in the City or "as needed" patrol and investigation and all auxiliary
and technical service now provided by the Sheriff in support of patrol and investigation.
All references to law enforcement services contained in this Agreement are references
only to services that shall be delivered under the terms of this Agreement
4. DELIVERY OF SERVICES
4A. Service area. The Sheriff shall provide law enforcement services within the
corporate limits of the City.
1/4
Todd W. Miller, Chickasaw County Sheriff, I 16 N. Chestnut Avenue, New Hampton, IA
Prepared by:
50659 641 394 3121 (24 hours)
4B. Enforcement Responsibilities. It is agreed that the law enforcement services
performed will encompass only violations made criminal under the law defined by the
Code of Iowa. Ordinances established by Chickasaw County will be enforced. No
enforcement will be undertaken for violations of City Ordinances.
4C. Delivery of Service. The delivery of law enforcement services to be provided by the
Sheriff will consist of routine, irregular, random, intermittent and unpredictable patrol in
the City so as to afford the maximum possible law enforcement to the City at those times 
and in those places where crime is determined by the Sheriff most likely to occur; except
that upon special request of the City to the Sheriff, specially focused law enforcement
services may be requested upon particularized and identified need.
4D. Service Management. It is understood and agreed that the law enforcement officers
providing services to the City under this Agreement are County employees, and not
employees of the City. The Sheriff's Deputies are solely subject to control, supervision,
and discipline of the Sheriff and under the Sheriff's law enforcement policies and
regulations, and employment rules and policies
4E. Responsiveness. The County's Sheriff and his Deputies will answer and
appropriately respond to calls for service made requesting law enforcement services and
provide immediate response to all E911 calls in which an emergency is claimed
threatening the lives, safety, and property of residents of the City or persons in the City.
City agrees "calls for service" from their community will be prioritized
1.
based on established rational law enforcement practices and based on
availability of Sheriff's personnel working any particular duty shift.
4F. Coordination. Pursuant to lowa Code Section 28E.6 (1) (a), this Agreement does not
establish any separate legal entity. The administrators for this Agreement are the Sheriff
and Mayor of the City, a signatory to it.
4G. Resources. In consideration for the per capita rate charges described below, the
County and Sheriff agree that the law enforcement services to be provided include the
County's provision of fully equipped patrol cars with emergency lights, sirens, and radios 
and other standard electronic telemetry; of law enforcement officers and deputies
appropriately selected and employed under County civil service, appropriately trained
and certified by the Iowa Law Enforcement Academy; of uniforms and all other personal
equipment necessary for the provision of law enforcement services; and for the
telephone, E911 and radio communications services made necessary under this
Agreement.
5. LIABLITY
5A. The City agrees to hold harmless, defend, and indemnify the County, Sheriff, and
any Law Enforcement personnel performing services under this Agreement to the City, as
fully as though the Sheriff and such law enforcement personnel were officers, employees,
and agents of the City, from any claim, demand, or litigation arising from, out of, or
related to, the provision of services under this Agreement, whether groundless or
otherwise, arising from an alleged act or omission, including claims, demands, and
litigations arising under 42 U.S.C. Section 1983. This duty to hold harmless, defend, and 
indemnify does not apply if, in an action commenced by the City against the County,
Sheriff, and law enforcement personnel involved in the situation giving rise to any such
2/4
Todd W. Miller, Chickasaw County Sheriff, 116 N. Chestnut Avenue, New Hampton, IA
Prepared by:
50659 641 394 3121 (24 hours)
claim, demand, or litigation, it is determined that the conduct of the officer or employee
constituted a willful and wanton act or omission under the same standards established by
Iowa Code Section 670.8(1). For purposes of subparagraph (5A), the Sheriff, deputies
and any other County law enforcement personnel shall be deemed to be "performing
services under this Agreement to the City" when (1) on routine patrol and within the
corporate boundaries of the City at the time when the act or omission occurred giving rise
to any such claim, demand, or litigation; (2) any emergency communication is received
through E911 or otherwise and a law enforcement officer is dispatched to the City, from
the time such dispatch is made and the officer responds through the time that the officer
reports he or she is back in service after such emergency situation has ended.
6. PERSONNEL
6B. Employee Payment. The City shall not be liable for the direct payment of salaries,
wages, or other compensation to the County officers or employees providing law
enforcement services to the City.
7. FEES
7A. Total sum.  The City shall pay to the County an annual sum for law enforcement
services delivered during the term of this Agreement. Said payment shall be made
semiannually on or before the 15th day of October and the 15th day of April of the
contract year. Said payment shall be made to the Auditor of Chickasaw County.
7B. Payment Plan. The City payment plan is attached in Section 11 of this Agreement.
7C. Adjustment. The County may adjust the total sum in accordance with changes in
costs of providing law enforcement services.  The County shall notify the City in writing
of each adjustment.
8. TERMS
8A. This Agreement will take effect on the 1st day of July, 2013 and shall continue
through the 30th day of June 2014 and this Agreement may be renegotiated within three
(3) months prior to March 15th of any year as to any terms or particulars upon request by
any party.
8B. Uniess terminated or renegotiated, this Agreement shall be renewed automatically for
successive terms of one (1) year. The Agreement may be terminated by either party by
giving the other party notice of its intention to withdraw, said notice being delivered to
the other party no later than one hundred eighty (180) days prior to the renewal of the 30th
day of June.
9. SPECIAL EVENTS
9A. In the event that the City, or an organization within the City, plans a “special” or
major event in the City, it shall notify the Sheriff at least three weeks, or twenty one (21)
days prior to the event. It is the City's burden, responsibility and expense to determine
the need for extra security personnel and employ the needed security personnel to be
present at a "special" or major event. The City shall be liable for all actions of the extra
3/4
Todd W. Miller, Chickasaw County Sheriff, 116 N. Chestnut Avenue, New Hampton, IA
Prepared by:
50659 641 394 3121 (24 hours)
security personnel and shall hold harmless, defend and indemnify the County for all acts
of the extra security personnel so employed by the City.
A "special" or major event is defined as an event whether indoors or
1.
outdoors, that is held on public property or streets, non-profit organization
property, or non-residential private property that can reasonably be expected
to cause a public gathering that is not part of the normal course of business or
pedestrian traffic at the location.
10. FILING WITH SECRETARY OF STATE
10A. This Agreement or any amendment, modification, or notice of termination shall be
filed with the lowa Secretary of State in a manner specified in Iowa Code Section 28E.8.
1.
Any amendment, modification, or notice of termination of this Agreement
shall be filed within thirty days of the effective date of the amendment,
modification, or termination, in a manner specified by the Iowa Secretary
of State.
10B. Additionally, upon execution of this Agreement, both the County and City shall
separately file with the Iowa Secretary of State that initial report required by Iowa Code
Section 28E.8(2)(a) and shall file, pursuant to Section 28E.8(2)(b), that biennial report so
required.

28E AGREEMENT
FOR THE ADMINISTRATION/MANAGEMENT
of workforce development in Region 13
This 28E Agreement (Agreement) is made and entered into this 14 day of October, 2010, and
ending on June 30, 2011, by and between the lowa Workforce Development (IWD) and Iowa
Western Community College (IWCC).  The parties agree as follows:
Purpose.  The purpose of this Agreement is to establish a procedure for hiring
Section 1.
the Regional lowaWORKS Director in Region 13 and to provide for the
employment and terms of employment of the Regional lowaWORKS Director.
Identity of the Parties: Iowa Workforce Development (IWD), which is a duly
Section 1.1
created state department, is authorized, among other things, to provide and fund
workforce development programs. IWD's state administrative address is 1000
East Grand Avenue, Des Moines, Iowa 50319. Iowa Western Community College
is authorized among other things, to provide and fund workforce development
programs. IWCC's address is 2700 College Road, Council Bluffs, IA 51503-1057
This Agreement does not create any separate legal or administrative parties or
entities.
Responsibilities of Parties.
Section 2.
2.1
IWCC and IWD will cooperate in development and management of an integrated
workforce delivery system in the Council Bluffs Workforce Development Center
and any satellite centers in Region 13. These services will be overseen by the
Regional IowaWORKS Director, who shall be employed by IWCC. The Regional
lowaWORKS Director shall provide all administrative/management services in
accordance with all applicable federal, state, local laws and regulations, merit
system rules, and collective bargaining agreement rules and practices. (See
attachment A for complete list of documents currently included in all Regional
and PROMISE JOBS Master Agreements.)
Policy guidelines for Workforce Development Center operations will be jointly
2.2.
agreed upon by appropriate IWCC and IWD representatives and will comply with
applicable personnel and labor relations policies of both entities.
In the absence of the Regional IowaWORKS Director, personnel issues involving
2.3
IWD employees which require the involvement of IWD Administration will be the
responsibility of the IWD Division Administrator for the Workforce Development
Center Administration (WDCA) or their Designee. In the absence of the Regional
lowaWORKS Director, personnel issues involving IWCC employees will be the
responsibility of the Executive Director of Economic and Workforce Development
or their Designee.
2.4
IWCC shall permit the Regional lowaWORKS Director to participate in staff
development, training, and management meetings required by IWD.
IWCC shall be responsible for the payment of the Regional IowaWORKS
2.5
Directors' salary and personnel benefits according to its existing policies. IWCC
Page 1 of 11
Region 13 Regional IowaWORKS Director 28e October 2010
shall be responsible for the payment of all applicable federal and state
withholding taxes and social security taxes for its Regional lowaWORKS
Directors. Additionally, IWCC shall carry a policy of workers compensation, and
at its sole expense, employer's liability insurance for its Regional lowaWORKS
Director to the extent and in the amounts required by law. IWCC, at its sole
expense, shall pay all unemployment compensation taxes for the Regional
lowaWORKS Director to the extent and in the amounts required by law. All
fringe benefits provided the Regional IowaWORKS Director will be in accordance
with IWCC policy.
2.6
Selection, evaluation and termination of the Regional IowaWORKS Director will
within the joint discretion of IWCC and IWD. Upon request, the parties shall
provide each other with comments concerning potential candidates for the
Regional lowaWORKS Director position and shall periodically provide each other
with comments concerning the performance of the Regional IowaWORKS
Director in order to assist with program development and monitoring.
2.7
IWD shall provide staff development and training services to ensure the Regional
lowaWORKS Director is knowledgeable of IWD practices, procedures, and
policies.
2.8
Reserved for future use.
Section 3. 
The Workforce Development Center Regional IowaWORKS Director.
3.1
The Regional IowaWORKS Director shall, at all times, be considered the employee
of IWCC and not an employee of IWD. (See attachment B for Regional
lowaWORKS Director job description.)
3.2
The Regional IowaWORKS Director shall advise the WDCA Division Administrator
or their designee of complaints and/or concerns regarding IWD agency personnel.
Any disciplinary action of personnel will be sole responsibility of the employer of
record for individual employees. Although the Regional lowaWORKS Director will 
provide input and comments regarding performance appraisals for integrated
center staff, performance appraisals remain the sole responsibility of the employer
of record for individual employees.
