AGREEMENT FOR GENERAL LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES
BETWEEN THE JONES COUNTY SHERIFF'S OFFICE
OXFORD JUNCTION, IOWA
Prepared by Sheriff Greg A Graver
500 West Main Street
Anamosa, IA 52205-0167
This agreement is entered into this jy day of January _2014 and
between Jones County, Hereinafter referred to as the County. The County
Sheriff, hereinafter referred to as the Sheriff: and the City of OXFORD
JUNCTION hereinafter to as the City.
I
STATEMENT OF AGREEMENT. The County and its Sheriff agree to
provide general law enforcement and dispatch services to the City and the
City agrees to engage the County, through its Sheriff, to provide such
service in accordance with and subject to the terms of this agreement.
II
LEGAL BASIS. This agreement is authorized by the provisions of Chapter
28E of the Code of Iowa.
III
GENERAL LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES DEFINED. General law
enforcement services consist of patrol and investigations and all auxiliary
and technical services now provided by the Sheriffs Office in support of
patrol and Investigations. All references to general law enforcement services
contained in this agreement are references only to services that shall be
delivered under the terms of this agreement.
l
IV
DELIVERY OF SERVICES. Delivery of services shall be provided as
follows:
SERVICE AREA: The Sheriff shall provide general law enforcement
1. 
services within the corporate limits of the City.
2.
ENFORCEMENT RESPONSIBILITIES: The Sheriff shall enforce
State statutes, county ordinances and ordinances of the City that are of
the same type and nature as State statutes enforced by the Sheriff. The
Sheriff shall not be required to assume any other law enforcement
duty or function not consistent with those customarily performed by
the Sheriff and under the charter of the county and statutes of the
State.
DELIVERY OF SERVICE: The Sheriff shall deliver various hours of
3.
general law enforcement services each day in addition to law
enforcement services now delivered to the City by the Sheriff as
provided by law.
SERVICE MANAGEMENT: The planning, organization, scheduling,
4.
directions and supervision of the Sheriff's personnel and all other
matters incident to the delivery of general law enforcement services to
the City shall be determined by the Sheriff. The Sheriff shall retain
exclusive authority over the activities of the personnel working in the
cities. However, the Sheriff shall work in conjunction with the Mayor
of OXFORD JUNCTION to determine the preferred patrol time for
Jones County Deputies.
5.
RESPONSIVENESS: The Sheriff shall give prompt consideration to
all requests of the City regarding the delivery of general law
enforcement services. The Sheriff shall make every effort to comply
with these requests if they are consistent with good law enforcement
practices.
V
RESOURCES. Resources shall be provided as follows:
COUNTY RESPONSIBILITY: Unless specifically agreed to in
1.
another part of this agreement, the County shall furnish all labor,
equipment, facilities, and supplies required to provide general law
enforcement services to the City. The City shall further agree that the
Sheriff may also use these facilities as needed to provide law
enforcement services to the surrounding areas.
2
INDIVIDUAL OWERNERSHIP OF PROPERTY: The County and
2.
City shall retain title to the property each may require to fulfill its
obligations under this agreement. Each party may dispose of its
property as it sees fit.
3.
CITY RESPONSIBILITY: The City shall provide and maintain an
office and parking space suitable for the use of Sheriff's personnel
providing general law enforcement services to the City. The City
further agrees that the Sheriff may also use these facilities as needed
to provide law enforcement services to surrounding areas.
VI
LIABILITY: Liability shall be assumed as follows.
1. 
COUNTY: The County shall assume liability for, defend against,
indemnify and hold harmless the City from all costs or damages for
injury to persons or property caused by the County in providing or
failing to provide general law enforcement services to the City,
including attorney fees for defense against such claims.
2.
CITY: The City shall assume liability for, defend against, indemnify
and hold the County from all cost or damages for injury to persons or
property caused by the City, including attorney fees for defense
against such claims.
VII
PERSONNEL:
EMPLOYEE STATUTES: All persons employed by the Sheriff and
l.
providing general law enforcement services to the City shall County
officers or employees, and they shall not have any benefit, statutes or
right of City employment.
2.
PAYMENT: The City shall not be liable for the direct payments of
salaries, wages or other compensation to county officers or employees
providing general law enforcement services to the City.
3.
INDEMNITY: The City shall not be liable for indemnity to any
county officer or employee for injury or sickness arising out of his/her
employment providing general law enforcement services to the City.
MUNICIPAL AGENCY: For the sole purpose of giving official
4.
statutes to their acts in performing municipal functions within the
scope of this agreement, every county officer or employee engaged in
providing general law enforcement services to the City shall be
3
considered deputized by the City. This provision shall be implemented
by an ordinance in the City.
XIII
DOG CALLS: The Jones County Sheriff's Office will not respond to
nuisance dog calls of barking dogs and dogs running at large. Citizens
wanting to file complaints about nuisance dog calls shall drop off or
mail written complaints to city hall. Those statements will then be
forwarded to the city attorney for prosecution.
Dog bites are a risk to the safety of the public. The Jones
County Sheriff will respond to a report of a dog bite. The Sheriff will
attempt to identify the owner of the dog, proof of required
immunizations, and if the dog was in violation of the at-large
ordinance. As a result of the investigation, the Sheriff will file the
appropriate charge/charges.
If a dog is found running at large and the dog can be caught, the
Jones County Dog Catcher will respond within the City limits to
transport the dog to the impound. This will take place at no additional
charge to the City.
Any fees due by the Vet Clinic or impound will be the
responsibility of the City for any dogs impounded from within the
City limits.
IX
METHAMPHETAMINE LAB RELATED CLEAN-UP: The Federal
Government has money allocated for Meth. Lab clean-up and
disposal. In 2013 the Federal funding for this service was in question.
In the event Federal or State money is not available for this service,
the City is responsible for any associated cost for the clean-up and
disposal of Meth. Lab materials and chemicals, that occurs in the
City of Oxford Junction.
4
X
FEES: Fees and payments shall be as follows:
The total sum the City shall pay the County is $24,784.00 for the
1.
period of July 1, 2014 through June 30, 2015 for general law
enforcement services delivered during the term of this agreement.
2.
The County shall receive from the City the entire amount due by the
first day of June 2015. The City may make payments throughout the
term of this contract. Payment shall be made by check payable to the
Jones County Sheriff and mailed to the Sheriff's Office in Anamosa,
Iowa 52205.
3.
DELIQUENCY: If the City does not make full payment to the County
by June 1, 2015 the County may terminate this agreement and the City
shall be liable for general law enforcement services rendered to the
time of termination.
XI
TERM: This agreement shall take effect on July 1, 2014 and shall continue
through June 30, 2015, unless the Sheriff, County Board of Supervisors, or
the City, acting through its Mayor, terminates this contract by giving the

IOWA DEPARTMENT OF HUMAN SERVICES
CONTRACT NO: REF-01-039
Clarke College
· 1.0
IDENTITY OF PARTIES.
A. The State of Iowa, Department of Human Services, Bureau of Refugee
Services (referred to in this document as "the Department) is the issuing
agency for this Agreement. The Department's address is: 1200 University
Avenue, Suite D. Des Moines, lowa 50314.
B. Clarke College (referred to in this document as "Contractor") is the
contracting entity, and is entering into this Agreement to provide the products
and or services defined in Section 4.0. The address of the Contractor.
1550 Clarke Drive, Dubuque, lowa 52001.
2.0
DURATION OF AGREEMENT.
The term of this Agreement shall be February 1, 2001 through September 30%
unless terminated earlier in accordance with the Termination section of this Agreement.
3.0
PURPOSE.
The parties have entered into this Agreement for the purpose of retaining the Contractor
to: organize and teach English as a Second Language (ESL) instruction that will
emphasize skills to ensure employment, culture and functioning of a workplace.
4.0
SCOPE OF SERVICES.
The Contractor shall provide the following services in accordance with the defined
performance expectations as set forth below.
A. The Contractor will organize and teach hourly instruction, which shall include up to 6
separate classes of ESL instruction.
B.  The Contractor will provide ESL instruction with emphasis on the following:
Understanding and use of English;
Understanding and exchanging ideas on cultures;
Identifying and using information in job descriptions and help wanted ads;
Applying for employment including filling out job applications;
Hands on experience via field trips to local employers;
Using reference materials such as dictionaries, encyclopedias, and newspapers;
Using the internet as a resource for job search, resume and cover letter writing;
Interpreting and translation of work related vocabulary; and
Understanding and responding to typical job interview questions.
C. The Contractor shall market program availability in the local area.
D. The courses offered by the Contractor shall be limited in participants to a maximum
of 20 participants.
E. The Contractor shall issue written and oral tests at the initial class session and again
at a six-week period to measure and report growth and progress of participants.
F. The Contractor shall provide field trip activities for participants that shall allow for
actual on the site usage and learning for participants.
G. The Contractor shall also provide direct facilities and materials for provision of
necessary services incurred during the "Dubuque-Everyone's Neighborhood"
conference.
H.  At the conclusion of each session, the Contractor shall provide along with the
necessary requirements indicated in section 6.0 "Compensation", a detailed
report of statistical progress information including Initial and 6 week
measurements of session participants. The Department will work with the
Contract in the format of this report information.
5.0
COMPENSATION.
The Contractor will be paid for the services described in Section 4 a fee not to exceed
$10,918.00 for the Agreement period. See attachment A, "ESL Budget", for complete
detailment of line item figures.
A. The Contractor shall submit detailed line item invoice within 30 days of each session
rendered. The invoice shall be submitted to the Department with appropriate
documentation as necessary to support all charges included on the invoice. This
billing will include dates of the sessions; the names of the attendees; the
number of hours attended by each attendee; and the names of course
instructors.
B. The Contract Number ref-01-039 must be placed on all claims for payment. Claims
must be submitted to:
David Jones
Department of Human Services
1200 University Avenue, Suite D
Des Moines, Iowa 50314
B. The invoice will be reviewed by the Department for accuracy and adequacy of
documentation before it is approved and submitted to Pavments and Receipts for
processing. The State shall pay all approved invoices in arrears and in conformance
with lowa Code Section 421.40 and 701 IAC 201.1(2). The State may pay in less
than 60 days, as provided in fowa Code Section 421.40. However, an election to
pay in less than sixty days shall not act as an implied waiver of lowa Code Section
421.40.
6.0
DEFAULT AND TERMINATION.
A. Termination for Cause by the Department
The occurrence of any one or more of the following events shall constitute cause
a. 
for the Department to declare the Contractor in default of its obligations under
this Agreement:
.
Failure to observe any condition or perform any obligation created by the
Agreement: or
.
Failure to make substantial and timely progress toward performance of the
Agreement; or
•
Failure of the Contractor's work product and services to conform with any
specifications noted herein, or in the bid proposal, or RFP, if incorporated by
reference.

Contractor, the Department shall provide written notice to the Contractor
requesting that the breach or noncompliance be remedied immediately.  If the 
breach or noncompliance continues to be evidenced 7days beyond the date of
the written notice, the Department may do one or more of the following:
Immediately terminate the Agreement without additional written notice; or,
.
Enforce the terms and conditions of the Agreement and seek any legal or
.
equitable remedies.
.
In addition to either of the above, the Department may seek damages and
payment of reasonable attorney fees and costs as a result of the Contractor's
breach or failure to comply with the terms of this Agreement.
B.  Termination upon Notice
Either party may terminate this Agreement, without penalty or incurring of further
obligation, upon 30 days written notice. The Contractor shall be entitled to
compensation for services or goods provided prior to and including the termination
date.
C. Termination Due to Lack of Funds or Change in Law by the Department
a. The Department shall have the right to terminate this Agreement without penalty
by giving 30 days written notice to the Contractor as a result of any of the
following:
.
Adequate funds are not appropriated by the legislature to allow the
Department to operate as required and to fulfill its obligations under this
Agreement; or
.
Funds are de appropriated, not allocated, or if funds needed by the
Department, at the Department's sole discretion, are insufficient for any
reason: or
.
The Department's authorization to conduct business is withdrawn or there is
a material alteration in the programs the Department administers; or
The Department's duties are substantially modified.
.
b.  The Department will make reasonable efforts to secure funding in an effort to
pay the Contractor under the terms of this Agreement. If any appropriation to
cover the costs of this Agreement becomes available within 30 days subsequent
to termination under this clause, the Department agrees to re-enter the
Agreement with the Contractor under the same terms as the original Agreement,
provided the Contractor is still available to provide the services.
c.   Remedies of the Contractor In the event of non-appropriation: In the event of
termination of this Agreement due to lack of funds or change in law, the sole 
remedy of the Contractor shall be payment for services completed prior to
termination.

28E AGREEMENT
FOR THE ADMINISTRATION/MANAGEMENT
OF WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT IN REGION 11
This 28E Agreement (Agreement) is made and entered into this ___th day of September,
2010, and ending on June 30, 2011, by and between the lowa Workforce Development (IWD)
and Des Moines Area Community College (DMACC).  The parties agree as follows:
Section 1.
Purpose.  The purpose of this Agreement is to establish a procedure for hiring
an Executive Director, Iowa Employment Solutions at DMACC, in Region 11 (the
"Executive Director") and to provide for the employment and terms of
employment of the Executive Director.
Section 1.1
Identity of the Parties: Iowa Workforce Development (IWD), which is a duly
created state department, is authorized, among other things, to provide and fund
workforce development programs. IWD's state administrative address is 1000
East Grand Avenue, Des Moines, Iowa 50319. Des Moines Area Community
College (DMACC) is authorized among other things, to provide and fund
workforce development programs. DMACC's address is 2006 South Ankeny
Boulevard, Ankeny IA 50023-3993. This Agreement does not create any
separate legal or administrative parties or entities.
Section 2.
Responsibilities of Parties.
DMACC shall provide administration/management services for IWD employees
2.1
located at the Des Moines Workforce Development Center and any satellite
centers in Region 11. These services will be provided by the Executive Director,
who shall be employed by DMACC. The Executive Director shall provide all
administrative/management services in accordance with all applicable federal,
state, local laws and regulations, merit system rules, and collective bargaining
agreement rules and practices. (See attachment A for complete list of documents
currently included in all Regional and PROMISE JOBS Master Agreements.)
2.2.
Policy guidelines for Workforce Development Center operations will be jointly
agreed upon by appropriate DMACC and IWD representatives and will comply
with applicable personnel and labor relations policies of both entities.
2.3
In the absence of the Executive Director, personnel issues involving IWD
employees which require the involvement of IWD administration will be the
responsibility of the Division Administrator for the Workforce Development Center

Section 4.
IWD will pay DMACC the lesser of:
50% of the Executive Director's "salary expense," or
(a) 
50% of the highest step of a Public Service Executive 3 classification (110%)
(b) 
plus 50% of any additional items included in the definition of salary expense

below which are not included as part of the Public Service Executive 3
classification.
"Salary expense" includes base salary, payroll taxes, unemployment insurance and 
worker's compensation insurance premiums, fringe benefits, travel, and per diem
but does not include bonuses that may be received by the Executive Director for
work at DMACC.
For the purposes of this agreement, IWD will reimburse travel and per diem 
expenses at only the rate which is used by the employer of record, in this case
DMACC.
IWD will pay DMACC on a monthly basis in, arrears.  "Salary expense" shall be
that actually paid or incurred by DMACC. DMACC will provide a monthly invoice of
the Executive Director's salary expense to the WDCA Division Administrator or
their Designee for approval prior to payment. IWD will provide said approval to
DMACC within 15 days of receipt.
Any percentage increase in the base salary in excess of the percentage increase
for a Public Service Executive 3 classification shall be as agreed between DMACC
and IWD.
All out-of-state travel to be reimbursed by IWD must have prior approval by the
WDCA Division Administrator or their Designee, and the Director, using the
"Request for Travel Authority-Out of State Travel" form.

performance of the Agreement.
c)   A failure of either party's work product and services to conform with any
specifications noted herein.
d)   A repeated exhibition of defects in the services delivered by either party,
causing serious disruption of use or downtime over a six month period.
e)   A breach of provisions related to intellectual property.
f) A failure to make payments required under section 4.
g)  A breach of any term of this Agreement.
9.2
DMACC or IWD shall not be considered to be in default under this
Agreement if its performance is delayed or made impossible by an Act of God,
floods, fires, strikes, a freight embargo or similar events; but in each such case, the
delay or impossibility must go beyond the reasonable control and without the fault
of DMACC or IWD. In event of such delay, the scheduled date of delivery
shall be extended on a day-to-day basis until delivery of performance is possible
and feasible.

28E AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE CITY OF DES MOINES
AND THE CORPORATION FOR ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT IN DES MOINES
day of Sextern Der , 2002, between
THIS AGREEMENT entered into this _
the City of Des Moines, a municipal corporation (hereinafter referred to as "City") and The
Corporation for Economic Development in Des Moines (hereinafter referred to as
“Corporation”), a nonprofit corporation under and in accordance with Chapter 28E, Code of
Iowa (2001).
WHEREAS, the City of Des Moines is a municipal corporation established under the
laws of the State of Iowa; and
WHEREAS, The Corporation for Economic Development in Des Moines is a nonprofit
corporation established under Iowa Nonprofit Corporation Act, Chapter 504A for the purpose of
the growth and development of business concerns, particularly promoting and assisting in small
businesses, and is a Certified Development Corporation under the U.S. Small Business
Administration 504 Loan Program.
WHEREAS, on November 19, 2001, by Roll Call Number 01-3461, the City Council of
the City of Des Moines approved the Economic Development Financing Assistance Program
("EDFA") as part of the City's 2002 Consolidated Plan; and
WHEREAS, the PY 2002 Economic Development Financing Assistance Program
involves joint and cooperative action between the City and the Corporation in that the
Corporation will be acting as agent of the City in a Loan Injection Program with the SBA 504
Program, Microloan Program, and a Revolving Loan Fund Program, as more fully described in
the Economic Development Financing Assistance Program to which this 28E Agreement is
attached and by this reference made a part thereof; and
WHEREAS, as agent of the City, the Corporation shall have sole and final decision
making authority in the approval of projects funded through the aforementioned loan programs;
and
WHEREAS, the City of Des Moines shall provide staff from the Office of Economic
Development to act as the sole staff for the Corporation, and all references to "staff" in this
agreement are to staff employed by the City and supplied for the benefit of the Corporation; and
WHEREAS, the Corporation's "investment account" is the sole and exclusive property of
the Corporation and shall not be used for any payments to the City; and
WHEREAS, no new administrative agency is being created by this Agreement.
1
NOW, THEREFORE BE IT AGREED by the parties as follows:
That this Agreement shall be in effect for the term commencing,
1.
, 2002 and continuing until December 31, 2003 and will be automatically renewed for
consecutive terms of one calendar year unless notice is given by one party to the other to
terminate at Jeast sixty (60) days prior to the end of the then current year.
2. = That this Agreement is solely for the purpose of cooperative action by and
between The Corporation for Economic Development in Des Moines and City of Des Moines for
the promotion of the growth of business concerns, particularly that of small businesses as more
fully described in the project design "PY 2002 Economic Development Financing Assistance
Program" attached hereto or in the project design for each subsequent Program Year ("PY")
3. = That the parameters of the cooperative action between the City and the
Corporation are governed by the applicable project design and the Corporation cannot exercise
any more powers of the City than set forth therein.
4. - That the City of Des Moines shall provide staff from the City Manager's Office of
Economic Development (OED) to the Corporation consisting of the assistance of one Economic
Development Coordinator supported by other City staff. It is recognized and agreed that the
Corporation shall have no other staff, and that all normal and necessary staff functions of the
Corporation will be performed by the staff provided by the City. The staff goals will include:
a. · Marketing and originating applications under the Small Business Administration
504 Loan Program, Loan Injection Program, Revolving Loan Fund, and Microloan
Program and provide other assistance to the Corporation consistent with the goal of
encouraging economic development and job creation in the City; and
b . .. Providing the Corporation with a monthly financial statement that shall show any
and all receipts and disbursements for the preceding calendar month. The format of this
statement shall be subject to approval by the City.
5. That any and all monies within the Revolving Loan Fund account and all receipts
from loans paid or to be paid inclusive of interest thereon, for the Loan Injection Program, the
Revolving Loan Fund and the Microloan Program, shall be and remain at all times the property
of the City. In order to preserve the City's rights, upon termination of this Agreement, the
Corporation will assign all monies in said accounts and the right to all future receipts on
outstanding loans whether principal or interest, to the City
6. That as to all loans granted under the SBA 504 Program, the City will provide
administrative, clerical, and supervisory staff to the Corporation for the purpose of marketing,
origination, processing, packaging, and servicing loans in accordance with the rules and
regulations promulgated by the Small Business Administration for such loans. It is understood
that the SBA 504 Program is based on a Fiscal Year ("FY").
2
That as to all loans granted under the Revolving Loan Fund Program, the
7. " ...
Microloan Program and the Loan Injection Program, the City will provide administrative,
clerical, and supervisory staff for the purpose of marketing, origination, processing, packaging,
and servicing of loans in accordance with the Revolving Loan Fund Program, the Microloan
Program, and the Loan Injection Program guidelines and in accordance with HUD Rules and
Regulations applying to the use of Community Development Block Grant funds.  It is understood
that the programs funded by the Revolving Loan Fund account are based on a Program Year
(“PY”).
8. - The revenues derived from the SBA 504 Program, which include one-time fees
equal to 1.5% of the debenture and net ongoing servicing fees equal to .5% annually of the
outstanding debenture balance, and interest on the 504 Escrow Account, and such other fees that
may from time to time be derived from the SBA 504 Program, shall be disbursed one hundred
percent (100%) to the City of Des Moines effective October 1, 2000.  The City Manager and the
Corporation may agree in writing to modify the fee structure described in this paragraph so long
as the structure remains within SBA guidelines. There shall be no payment to the City from the
Corporation other than the foregoing. The City and the Corporation recognize and agree that all
dividends, interest and capital gains on the “investment account” shall be the sole and exclusive
property of the Corporation.
The City shall submit to the Corporation an annual report outlining past activity,
9.
program goals, and annual objectives. The Corporation shall review the annual report and make
recommendation to the City Manager on the following categories:
a. ... The projected number SBA 504 Loans to be originated and the projected revenues
from SBA 504 Loan origination, servicing, and 504 Escrow accounts.
b. Activities and expenditures related to marketing the SBA 504 Loan Program and
~Economic Development Financial Assistance Programs to be undertaken during the
FY and PY.
c. - Other program activities and expenditures that may impact the effectiveness of the
program.
10. - 'The annual budget for the Corporation shall be approved by the City Council.
Staff will present to the President of the Corporation the proposed annual budget for review and
comment at least 60 days before the City Manager submits the City budget recommendation to
the City Council. The final budget shall contain a provision for Directors' and Officers' liability
insurance in an amount and on such terms as shall be reasonably acceptable to the directors and
officers of the Corporation.
The City shall receive, at the end of each month, the revenues of the Corporation
11 ..
from servicing and closing fees generated from the 504 Loan Program during the previous
month, including interest earned on those accounts prior to transferral to the City. All other
Corporation assets and interest earned thereon shall not be included in revenues transferred to the
City.
3
The Corporation has no responsibility to pay ongoing expenses of the programs.
12.
The City shall indemnify and hold the Corporation, its directors, and its officers,
13. . 
harmless for any damages or penalties arising from action of staff which constitutes a violation
of the rules, regulations, policies or procedures of any of such programs. The "hold harmless"
provisions of this section shall be deemed to include reasonable attorney fees and the cost of
defense of any action or proceeding.
It is the intent of the parties that funds be made available for PY 2002 and in each
14 · ·
subsequent PY for use in the Economic Development Financing Assistance Program, as deemed
appropriate by the City. Loan repayments received from Revolving Loan Fund and Loan
Injection loans and Microloans shall be deposited into the CDBG Repayment Account with the
City of Des Moines.
15. -
The selection, supervision, training and performance review of the Economic
Development Coordinator, as well as all other staff duties assigned to the Corporation by the 
City, are the responsibility of the City Manager or his designee. The City Manager or his
designee shall meet with the President of the Corporation at least once a year to discuss the
services provided by the City to the Corporation.
16. In the event that the Corporation is, at any time, or from time to time, dissatisfied
with the performance of the individuals assigned to it by the City, the President of the
Corporation shall as soon as practicable, specify the nature of such dissatisfaction, and the issues
raised shall be promptly addressed in accordance with normal City procedures.
Use of the Loan Injection Program (direct loan in combination with SBA 504
17. -
Program where the business is locating in certain designated areas) is to be determined by the
Corporation's Loan Review Committee based on its sole determination of the needs of the
applicant business.
The City of Des Moines, Office of Economic Development may be used as the
18. . .
registered office for the Corporation.
. . .
19 ... .
The Corporation’s Board of Directors shall review and concur on the role of the
Corporation's participation in the Economic Development Financing Assistance Program Project
Design for each PY.
This is the entire Agreement of the parties herein. No modification of said
20. -
Agreement is permitted except by written notification mutually entered into.

28E AGREEMENT CONCERNING PUBLIC SAFETY EMERGENCY
COMMUNICATION SERVICES IN DES MOINES COUNTY, IOWA
This Agreement is made and entered into by and between the City of Burlington, Iowa,
hereinafter "Burlington", and Des Moines County, Iowa, the City of West Burlington, Iowa, the
City of Mediapolis, Iowa, and the City of Danville, Iowa, hereinafter, the "Entities", effective on
the adoption of this Agreement by all affected public Entities.
NO ENTITY CREATED
No independent or separate entity is created by this Agreement.
DURATION
This Agreement shall continue for a period of five (5) years from the date of enactment
by all affected Entities or until otherwise modified or amended as hereinafter provided.
PURPOSE
The purpose of this Agreement is to provide emergency communication services to all
incorporated and unincorporated areas within Des Moines County, Iowa. Burlington possesses
all necessary licenses from the Federal Communications Commission to operate a public safety
emergency communication systems from its Police Department building. Burlington has within
its possession and control all necessary licenses, personnel, facilities, and equipment to provide
essential emergency communication services, hereinafter "Services" to all areas in Des Moines
County. Burlington is willing to provide the desired Services to the Entities.
This Agreement is intended to allow Burlington and the Entities to use the Services as a
cost effective means of serving its residents pursuant to Chapter 28E of the Code of Iowa.
AGREEMENT
Burlington and the Entities agree that Burlington shall be compensated for its
1)
Services based on each Entity's population derived from the 2010 Federal Census. Burlington's
percentage for the duration of this Agreement is 63.64%; West Burlington's percentage is 7.36%;
Danville’s percentage is 2.32%; Mediapolis’s percentage is 3.87%; and Des Moines County’s
percentage is 22.81%. Each Entity will compensate Burlington according to its percentage
starting in fiscal year 2014. The Entities will compensate Burlington in an amount calculated by
multiplying its percentage by each succeeding year's fiscal year budget. West Burlington will
compensate Burlington in monthly installments which are 1/12th of the annual amount so
calculated. Danville and Des Moines County will compensate Burlington annually by cach
paying one-half of the amount so calculated. Mediapolis and Des Moines County will
compensate Burlington annually by each paying one-half of the amount so calculated. Des
Moines County, in addition to one-half of the Danville and Mediapolis amounts, will
compensate Burlington in monthly installments which are 1/12th of the annual amount so
calculated.
Upon Burlington's determination of the cost of service for each succeeding year and
adoption of its annual budget, the Administrator or his designee will notify the Entities of that
year's reimbursement amount and each Entity agrees to promptly compensate Burlington
accordingly.
Burlington has or will acquire then operate and maintain all equipment necessary
2)
to carry out the purposes of this Agreement and secure and maintain all proper licenses,
necessary personnel, and facilities necessary to deliver the Services, all at its cost.
3)
The Entities agree that each has or will inform Burlington of all communication
equipment operated by it, including replacement equipment, in order to insure its compatibility
with Burlington's licensing requirements and its operating equipment in order to insure the
proper delivery of the Services. Burlington must be informed of and approve all replacement
equipment employed by the Entities before it is put into use. This is in order to insure that any
such equipment is compatible with Burlington equipment. Burlington will have complete control
over the operation of the equipment, but the equipment will remain the property of the Entities.
The Entities are solely responsible for notifying Burlington of any new or replacement equipment
and securing its approval before it is put into use. Burlington will promptly approve said
equipment upon notification. Final determination of the suitability and compatibility of said
equipment shall be at the sole discretion of Burlington. The Entities shall be solely responsible
for keeping all said equipment in good working order.
4)
Burlington agrees to relay all messages from and to Burlington and the Entities'
emergency vehicles at all times during the term of this Agreement according to emergency
communication standards established by Burlington by and through its Police Department.
5)
This Agreement shall take effect upon its approval by each party's governing
authority and execution of this Agreement by the authorized person of Burlington and each of the
Entities.
ADMINISTRATOR
Burlington's Chief of Police or his designee shall act as Administrator of this Agreement.
The Administrator shall be responsible for filing this Agreement with the Secretary of State of
the State of lowa along with any additional filings required pursuant to Section 28E.8 of the
Code of Iowa. The Administrator and a representative of Burlington, Des Moines County, West
Burlington, Mediapolis, and Danville, agree to meet at least annually in October of cach year at a
time and place designated by the Administrator in order to facilitate administration of this
Agreement and compliance with Chapter 28E, including the publication requirement of Section
28E.6(3)(a) or 28E.6(3)(b).
APPLICABLE LAW
This Agreement is entered into under the provisions of Chapter 28E of the 2009 Code of
Iowa, and is subject to the powers and limitations contained therein.
DIVISION OF ASSETS
There shall be no division of assets upon termination of this Agreement.
AMENDMENTS
Amendments or modifications to this Agreement may be made from time to time. Any
such amendments, modifications, or notice of termination must be in writing, approved by all
parties to this Agreement, and filed with the Secretary of State in conformance with Section
28E.8(1)(b) of the Code of Iowa.
This Agreement may be terminated by any Entity upon written notice to all other Entities
at least six (6) months prior to a specified termination date.
SIGNATURES
Each of the undersigned declares and certifies that they have been authorized by
Burlington, Des Moines County, West Burlington, Mediapolis, and Danville to execute this
Agreement on behalf of the parties to this Agreement, that prior to the execution of this
Agreement the City of Burlington by and through its City Council, Des Moines County by and
through its Board of Supervisors, the City of West Burlington by and through its City Council;
the City of Mediapolis by and through its City Council, and the City of Danville by and through
its City Council have passed resolutions approving this Agreement and authorizing the persons
executing this Agreement below to sign same, and that upon execution this Agreement shall
become effective and binding upon Burlington, Mediapolis, West Burlington, Danville, and Des
Moines County.

28E AGREEMENT
FOR THE ADMINISTRATION/MANAGEMENT
OF WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT IN REGION 5
This 28E Agreement (Agreement) is made and entered into this 1st day of December, 2
and between the lowa Workforce Development (IWD) and lowa Central Community College
(lowa Central). The parties agree as follows:
Section 1.
Purpose. The purpose of this Agreement is to jointly select a Regional Manager
for Workforce Development in Region 5.
Section 2.
Responsibilities of Parties.
2.1
IWD and lowa Central shall share administration/management services for lowa
Central employees located at the Fort Dodge Workforce Development Center
and any satellite centers in Region 5. These services will be provided by a
Workforce Development Regional Manager employed by IWD. IWD shall
provide all administrative/management services in accordance with all applicable
federal, state, local laws and regulations, merit system rules, and collective
bargaining agreement rules and practices.
2.2.
Policy guidelines for Workforce Development Center operations will be jointly
agreed upon by appropriate lowa Central and IWD representatives and will
comply with applicable personnel and labor relations policies of both entities.
2.3
in the absence of the Regional Manager, personnel issues involving lowa Central
employees which require the involvement of lowa Central administration will be
the responsibility of lowa Central or designee.
2.4
IWD shall permit the Regional Manager to participate in staff development,
training, and management meetings required by lowa Central.
2.5
IWD shail be responsible for the payment of the Regional Manager's salary and
personnel benefits according to its existing policies. IWD shall be solely
responsible for the payment of all applicable federal and state withholding taxes
and social security taxes. Additionally, IWD, at sole expense, shall carry a policy
of workers compensation and employer's liability insurance for the Regional
Manager to the extent and in the amounts required by law. IWD, at its sole
expense, shall pay all unemployment compensation taxes for the Regional
Manager to the extent and in the amounts required by law. All fringe benefits
provided the Regional Manager will be in accordance with IWD policy.
2.6
Selection, annual evaluation and termination of the Regional Manager will be
jointly determined by lowa Central and IWD.
2.7
lowa Central shall provide staff development and training services to ensure the
Regional Manager is knowledgeable of lowa Central practices, procedures, and
polices.
1
2.8
lowa Central will pay IWD for the services provided in this Agreement as set forth
in Section 4.
Section 3.
The Workforce Development Center Regional Manager.
3.1
The Regional Manager shall, at all times, be considered the employee of IWD and
not an employee of lowa Central.
3.2
The Regional Manager shall consuit with the lowa Central Dean of Continuing
Education, before taking any disciplinary action against any lowa Central
employee. Joint review by both the Regional Manager and the lowa Central Dean
of Continuing Education will precede any performance appraisal and related action
for any lowa Central employee.
3.3
The Regional Manager will be responsible for the delivery of high quality programs
of IWD and lowa Central and shall submit program progress reports as requested
by either IWD or lowa Central.
Section 4.
Compensation.
Effective February 1, 2001, lowa Central will pay IWD the lesser of:
Thirty Percent (30%) of the Regional Manager's "salary expense," or
(a)
(b)
Thirty Percent (30%) of the highest step of a Public Service Executive 3
classification.
"Salary expense" includes base salary, payroll taxes, unemployment insurance and
worker's compensation insurance premiums, fringe benefits, travel, and per diem.
ICCC will pay IWD on a monthly basis in, arrears. "Salary expense" shall be that
actually paid or incurred by IWD.
Any percentage increase in the base salary in excess of the percentage increase
for a Public Service Executive 3 classification shall be as agreed between ICCC
and IWD.
Section 5.
Effective Date of Agreement. This Agreement shall be effective when the
following conditions are completed:
5.1
The Agreement is signed by IWD and lowa Central.
5.2
The Agreement or a recordable form of this Agreement is recorded by the Polk and
Webster County Recorders . .
5.3
The Agreement is filed with lowa Secretary of State.
Section 6.
Term of Agreement. The initial term of this Agreement shall be from its effective
date in Section 5 until it is terminated in accordance with the terms of this
Agreement. This Agreement may be terminated at any time, by either party, for
2
any reason upon at least ninety (90) days written notice in advance of the specified
termination date.
Section 7.
Nonappropriation. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this Agreement, if
funds anticipated for the continued fulfillment of this Agreement are at any time not
forthcoming or insufficient, either through the failure of the State of lowa to
appropriate funds or the discontinuance or material alteration of the program under
which funds were provided, then IWD shall have the right to terminate this
Agreement, or a portion of this Agreement, without penaity by giving not less than
sixty (60) days written notice. If an appropriation to cover the costs of the
Agreement becomes available within sixty (60) days subsequent to termination
under this section, IWD agrees to reenter this Agreement on the same provisions,
terms, and conditions.
Section 8.
Authorization. Each party to this Agreement represents and warrants to the other
that (1) it has the right, power, and authority to enter into and perform its
obligations under this Agreement; and (2) it has taken all requisite action
(corporate, statutory, or otherwise) to approve execution, deliver, and performance
of this Agreement, and this Agreement constitutes a legal, valid, and binding
obligation upon itself in accordance with its terms.
The President of lowa Central and the WD Administrator of the Division of
Workforce Center Administration will be responsible for administration of this
Agreement.
Section 9.
Default.
9.1
Any of the following events shall constitute cause for IWD to declare lowa Central
In default of its obligations under this Agreement:
(a)
Continued failure of lowa Central to perform the terms of this Agreement for a
period of sixty (60) days following delivery of written notice by IWD to lowa
Central specifying the item or items of non-performance.
9.2
In the event of default under Section 9.1; IWD may at its option, either:
Exercise any remedy provided by law; or
(a)
(b)
Terminate this Agreement.
9.3
lowa Central shall not be considered to be in default under this Agreement if its
performance is delayed or made Impossible by an Act of God, floods, fires, strikes,
a freight embargo or similar events; but in each such case, the delay or
impossibility must go beyond the reasonable control and without the fault or
negligence of lowa Central. In event of such delay, the scheduled date of lowa
Central delivery or performance shall be extended on a day-to-day basis until
delivery of performance is possible and feasible.
9.4
lowa Central shall not be liable for indirect, special, or consequential damages
resulting from a breach of this Agreement.
3
9.5
Any of the following events shall constitute cause for lowa Central to declare IWD
in default of its obligations under this Agreement:
(a)
Failure to make the payments required under Section 4; or
(b)
Any other non-performance of this Agreement not cured within sixty (60) days
of delivery of written notice by lowa Central to IWD specifying the item or
items of non-performance.
8.6
in the event of default by IWD hereunder, lowa Central may, at its option, either:
(a)
Terminate this Agreement; or
(b)
Exercise any remedy provide by law.
Section 10.
Waiver. Except as specifically provided for in a waiver signed by duly authorized
representatives of IWD and lowa Central, failure by either party at anytime to
require performance by the other party or to claim a breach of any provision of the
Agreement shall not be construed as affecting any subsequent breach or the right
to require performance with respect thereto or claim a breach with respect thereto.
Section 11.
Notices. Notices under this Agreement shall be in writing and delivered to the
representative of the party to receive notice (identified below) at the address of the
party stated below:
If to IWD:
lowa Workforce Development
Attention: Director
1000 East Grand Avenue
Des Moines, IA 50319
If to Iowa Central:
lowa Central Community College
Attention: President
330 Ave. M
Fort Dodge, IA 50501
The effective date for any notice under this Agreement shall be the date of the
delivery of such notice:
(a)
By personal delivery; or
By certified U.S. Mail, return receipt requested, with postage paid thereon
(b)
(and not the date of mailing). Failure to "receipt" shall constitute delivery; or
(c)
By recognized overnight delivery service, such as Federal Express or UPS,
Section 12.
Indemnification.
Consistent with Article VII, Section 1 of the lowa Constitution and lowa Code Chapter
669, lowa Workforce Development agrees to defend and indemnify lowa Central and
hold it harmless against any and all losses, costs, damages, expenses, claims,
4
demands, causes of action, judgements and settlements arising out of IWD's
negligence or wrongful acts or omissions in the performance of this Contract.
lowa Central shall be responsible for all damages to persons or property but only to
the extent the same are caused by lowa Central's fault, negligence, gross negligence,
bad faith, fraud or other wrongful acts in the performance of this Contract and as they
are related to or arising from:
(a) Any violation of this agreement by lowa Central; or
(b) Any negligent acts or ornissions of lowa Central; or
(c) Any failure by lowa Central to comply with all local, state and federal laws and
regulations as they pertain to this agreement; or
(d) Any failure by lowa Central to make all reports, payments and withholdings
required by federal and state law with respect to social security, employee income
and other taxes, fees or costs required by lowa Central to conduct business in the
State of lowa; or
(e) Any infringement of any copyright, trademark, patent, or other intellectual property
right
Any indemnification shall be subject to the prior approval of an appropriation of funds
by the General Assembly and Governor of the State of lowa and the allotment of
funds by the lowa Department of Management as may be required by law, and lowa
Central shall furnish the State with a detailed estimate of any expected claim, loss,
liability, damage and/or expense for the State's use in obtaining such approval and
appropriation or allotment. Indemnification is further conditioned on the following:
(a)  lowa Central and the State or IWD shall cooperate to provide prompt written.
notice of any expected, threatened or actual claim, loss, liability, damage or
expenses.
(b)  lowa Central and the State or IWD shail at all times cooperate both in 
document production and personnel time.
Section 13.
No Indemnification. The State of lowa shall not be responsible for action taken
by lowa Central, its employees, officers, elected or appointed officials, or its agents
in knowing violation of any federal, state or municipal law or in knowing violation of
a law of a foreign country.
Section 14.
Obligations Beyond Agreement Term. This Agreement shall remain in full force
and effect to the end of the specified term or until terminated or cancelled pursuant
to this Agreement. All obligations of IWD and lowa Central incurred or existing
under the Agreement as of the date of expiration, termination, or cancellation will
survive the termination on conclusion of this Agreement.
Section 15.
Third Party Beneficiarles. There are no third party beneficiaries to this
Agreement. This Agreement is intended only to benefit IWD and lowa Central.
5
Section 16.
Assignment and Delegation. This Agreement may not be assigned, transferred,
or conveyed in whole or in part without the prior written consent of the other party.
Section 17. 
Choice of Law and Forum. The terms and provisions of this Agreement shall be
construed in accordance with the laws of the State of lowa.  Any and all litligation or
actions commenced in connection with this Agreement shall be brought in Des
Moines, Iowa, in the lowa District Court for Polk County.  This provision shall not
be construed as waiving any immunity to suit or liability which may be available to
the State.
Entire Agreement.  This Agreement represents the entire agreement between the
Section 18.
parties and neither party is relying on any representation which may have been
made which is not included in this Agreement. This Agreement may be amended
or modified only in writing signed by all parties.
Section 19.
Headings or Captions.  The paragraph headings or captions are for identification
purposes only and do not limit or construe the contents of the paragraphs.
Section 20.
Not a Joint Venture.  Nothing in this Agreement shall be construed as creating or
constituting the relationship of a partnership, joint venture, or other association of
any kind or agent/principal relationship between the parties. Each party shall be
deemed to be an independent contractor contracting for services and acting toward 
the mutual benefits expected to be derived from the Agreement. No party, unless
otherwise specifically provided for in the Agreement, has the authority to enter into
any contract or create an obligation or liability o behalf of, in the name of, or
binding upon another party to this Agreement.
Cumulative Rights.  The various rights, powers, options, elections, and remedies
Section 21.
of either party, provided in this Agreement, shall be construed as cumulative and
no one of them is exclusive of any rights, remedies or priorities allowed either party
by law, and shall in now way affect or impair the right of either party to pursue any
other equitable or legal remedy to which either party may be entitled as long as any
default remains in any unremedied, unsatisfied, or undischarged.
Section 22.
Severability. If a provision of this Agreement is determined by a court of
competent jurisdiction to be invalid or unenforceable, such determination all not
affect the validity of enforceability of any other part or provision of this Agreement,
unless such invalid or unenforceable provision goes to the very essence of the
Agreement.
Section 23.
Time is of the Essence. Time is of the essence with respect to the performance
of the terms of this Agreement.
Section 24.
Binding Effect. All the terms, provisions, and conditions of the Agreement shail
be binding upon and inure to the benefit of the parties hereto and their respective
successors, assigns and legal representatives.
Counterparts. The parties agree that this Agreement has been or may be
Section 25.
executed in several counterparts, each of which shall be deemed an original and
all such counterparts shall together constitute one and the same instrument.
6
Section 26.
Additional Provisions.  The parties agree that if an Addendum, Rider or Exhibit is 
attached hereto by the parties, and referred to herein, then the same shall be
deemed incorporated herein by reference.
Section 27. 
Further Assurances and Corrective Instruments.  The parties agree that they
will, from time to time, execute, acknowledge and deliver, or cause to be executed,
acknowledged and delivered, such supplements hereto and such further
instruments as may reasonably be required to carry out the express intentions of
this Agreement.
Administration/Additional Property.  No separate legal or administrative entity is 
Section 28.
necessary to carry out the arrangement contemplated by this Agreement.  It is not
contemplated that any additional real or personal property be acquired by either
lowa Central or IWD in order to carry out the objectives in this Agreement.

LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES CONTRACT
On this |} day of March , 2013, the City of Zearing and Story
County, Iowa, enter into the following agreement:
The Story County Sheriff's Office will provide the City of Zearing, Iowa, with
1.
law enforcement services. These services will include but not be limited to:
A
Radar operations to control speed.
Issuing violations under city ordinances (excluding animal control
B.
ordinances) upon request.
C.
Housing inmates who have been incarcerated under a city ordinance.
Service of abatement notices on request.
D.
E.
Periodically checking commercial buildings for unlocked doors and
trespassers.
Investigation of traffic accidents and complaints.
F.
Dispatch of city fire departments and first responders.
G.
H.
Staffing a 24 hour E911 dispatch center.
I.
Providing a detective division to investigate crimes and conduct
on-going investigations.
J.
Investigation of drug-related offenses.
K.
Supplying schools or community clubs with officers and materials
for special programs and talks upon request.
L.
Routine patrols and special patrols upon request.
M.
Supply fully equipped patrol cars with radio, lights, siren and all
related equipment, gasoline and oil, tires and maintenance, uniforms and
all other personal equipment.
2.
In consideration for the law enforcement services above described, the City of
Zearing, IA. will pay a per capita rate of $52.00 (based on the 2010 census of
554) to Story County, Iowa, which amounts to the annual sum of $28,808.00.
This shall be paid in equal quarterly installments to the Story County Sheriff on
July 1, October 1, January 1 and April 1. Any per capita increase in contract
cost for the following year shall be negotiated by December for the next fiscal
year. For the purposes of this contract, fiscal year shall be from July 1, through
June 30, of the following year.
AGREEMENT
Page 2
The Sheriff shall be the administrator of this Agreement. Law Enforcement
3.
policy, regulations and matters pertaining to the employment of the Sheriff's
personnel shall be determined solely by the Sheriff. The time, place and manner
in which these services are implemented shall be in the sole discretion of the
Sheriff. The Mayor, Mayor Pro Tem and the City Administrator shall be
authorized to make requests to the Sheriff for performance of specific law
enforcement services as specified in this Agreement.
4.
The initial term of the Agreement shall be automatically extended for successive
one-year periods upon the same terms and conditions provided by this
Agreement for the initial term, unless this Agreement is terminated or modified
by the express election of either city or county as hereinafter provided.
Modification of this contract may be made by mutual consent of both parties.
5.
In accordance with Chapter 28E, Code of Iowa, a copy of this agreement shall
be filed with the Secretary of State and recorded with the Story County Recorder.
Signatures will include the Mayor of Zearing, the City Clerk of Zearing,
the Chairperson of the Story County Board of Supervisors, the Story County
Auditor and the Story County Sheriff. The city seal shall be affixed to the
contract before returning to the county for filing.
The city shall fund the consideration for this Agreement from general revenues
6.
under the City's annual general budget. There shall be no joint property
acquired pursuant to this agreement.
This contract may be terminated by either party. Termination is effective at
the end of the current quarterly billing cycle and must be preceded with a
30 day written notice to either party. Notice shall be accomplished by
certified mail or personal service.

28E AGREEMENT FOR LAW ENFORCEMENT AND EMERGENCY
SERVICE AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE COUNTY OF
HUMBOLDT, IOWA AND THE CITY OF DAKOTA CITY, IOWA
This Agreement is made pursuant to Chapter 28E of the lowa Code between Humboldt County, lowa
and the City of Dakota City, lowa.
SECTION1.  AUTHORITY.  Humboldt County, Iowa, acting through its Sheriff and Board of
Supervisors and the City of Dakota City, lowa, acting through its city council, enters into this Agreement
by virtue of the powers granted to them by Chapter 28E of the lowa Code, the relevant provisions of
which are hereby incorporated by reference.
SECTION 2.  PURPOSE.  The purpose of this Agreement is to provide law enforcement and
emergency services conducted by the Humboldt County Sheriff's Department within the corporate city
limits of the City of Dakota City, lowa, as designated in this agreement.
SECTION 3.  SERVICE AREA.  The service area of this Agreement is within the corporate city limits
of the City of Dakota City, lowa.
SECTION 4.  TERM.  The term of this Agreement shall begin on July 1, 2016 and continue through
June 30, 2018.
SECTION 5. COMPENSATION.  The City of Dakota City, lowa, agrees to pay Humboldt County,
lowa, for the service rendered under this Agreement, the amount of $8,430.00, which is $10.00 per
capita based on the 2010 census figures, to be paid in quarterly payments of $2,107.50 payable on July
1, October 1, January 1 and April 16, payments to be made at the Humboldt County Courthouse to the
Humboldt County Treasurer at 203 Main Street in Dakota City, lowa.  For each of the remaining two
years of the Agreement, the amount to be paid will increase by 5% per year.  This amount will be paid in
quarterly payments on the same date and month of each remaining term of this Agreement.
SECTION 6. TERMS AND CONDITIONS.
1.  The Humboldt County Sheriff's Department will provide all requested police services and
have jurisdiction and enforcement authority to provide same, to the City of Dakota City,
lowa.  These services include but are not limited to, emergency and non-emergency calls for
service, alarm response, criminal investigations, traffic enforcement, and enforcement of
laws detailed within the Federal Code, and the lowa Code.
2.  The Humboldt County Sheriff's Department will be directed by its Sheriff who will be the
chief law enforcement officer during the time this agreement is in effect.
3.  The Humboldt County Sheriff's Department agrees to provide non-emergency dispatch
services to its officers.  9-1-1 Emergency Dispatch services will be dispatched by the
Humbold! County Communications Center.  This will Include the dispatching of Fire and
Medical Services.
4.  The City of Dakota City, Iowa agrees to investigate and prosecute at their expense those
violations charged under the City Code of Dakota City, lowa.
5.  Any property seized by the Humboldt County Sheriff’s Department within the City of
Dakota City, lowa will be retained by the Humboldt County Sheriff's Department pursuant to
restrictions provided in the lowa Code.
6. This agreement will be evaluated prior to July 1, 2018 by both entities.
7 .  The City of Dakota City, lowa agrees to hold harmless Humboldt County and its entities for 
Any actions or inactions on the part of Humboldt County in the performance of said services
and Humboldt County agrees to hold harmless the City of Dakota City, lowa for any actions
or inactions on the part of the City of Dakota City, lowa in the performance of said services.
8.  The City of Dakota City, lowa will not be required to provide police liability insurance,
however, it is agreed that in the event Humboldt County is required to defend any claim as a
result of providing these services, the City of Dakota City, lowa will reimburse Humboldt
County for its deductible amount under the insurance policy carried by Humboldt County.
SECTION 7.  TERMINATION.  Either party to this agreement may terminate this agreement by
giving written notice to the other at least ninety (90) days in advance of the date of termination.  In the
event that termination is other than the end of the fiscal year (June 30), the payment paid or due shall
be prorated to the effective date of such termination.

This Agreement is made and entered into on this 5
day of &
(the "Execution Date") by and between the City of Ankeny, Polk County, 1
Ankeny"), and Bravo Greater Des Moines, Inc. ("Bravo") an Iowa not-for-profit corporation,
pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 28E, Code of Iowa. The Agreement shall be effective with
respect to Commitments beginning July 1, 2006 (the "Effective Date").
That inasmuch as Bravo is organized for the purpose of assisting the cultural community of the
Greater Des Moines area in providing an enriched quality of life by increasing cultural
awareness, advocacy, and funding, as well as by fostering collaboration among cultural
organizations, and
That the City of Ankeny has as a goal the unification and coordination of monies for the use and
benefit of the cultural community and specifically the cultural organizations which are
members of Bravo.  The City of Ankeny is committed to the reasonable stewardship of monies
for arts and cultural purposes.
That the City of Ankeny and Bravo agree as follows:
I. DEFINITIONS
"Hotel/Motel Tax" means a tax imposed in accordance with Chapter 422A of the Code of
(1)
Iowa, 2005, or similar successor provisions.
"Hotel/Motel Tax Revenues" means the funds remitted to the City of Ankeny by the
(2)
Treasurer of the State of Iowa from the local Transient Guest Tax Fund in accordance with
provisions of Chapter 422A of the Code of Iowa, 2005, and the rules promulgated by the
Director of the Iowa Department of Revenue thereunder, or similar successor provisions,
representing the proceeds collected by the State of Iowa from the Hotel/Motel Tax
imposed by the City of Ankeny.
II. PRE-CONDITIONS TO OBLIGATIONS OF THE CITY OF ANKENY
The obligation of the City of Ankeny hereunder shall be subject to the fulfillment of the adoption
of an appropriate resolution by the City Council of the City of Ankeny approving this Agreement.
III. COVENANT FROM CITY OF ANKENY
(1)
The City of Ankeny does hereby irrevocably pledge and commit to the promotion of arts
and cultural activities in the Greater Des Moines, Iowa metropolitan area for the
entire term of this Agreement and all extensions thereof, not less than 2/7 of its
Hotel/Motel Tax Revenues (the "Commitment") to be distributed and expended by Bravo
in the manner set forth in this Agreement.
Each year the Commitment shall be reduced, but not below zero, by the amount the City

of Ankeny is contractually obligated to contribute during the year to the lowa Events

The City of Ankeny shall take all action necessary to implement disbursement of the
(2)
Commitment on an annual basis.
Payment of the Commitment to Bravo shall be made in quarterly installments, no later than
(3)
30 days following the end of each fiscal quarter of the City, based upon receipts of the
Hotel/Motel Tax Revenues for the prior fiscal quarter, taking into account the reductions
for such quarter as provided in paragraph (1) above.
IV. PURPOSE
The purpose of this Agreement is to facilitate and support the cultural community of the Greater
Des Moines area in providing an enriched quality of life by increasing cultural awareness,
advocacy and funding as well as by fostering collaboration arnong cultural organizations and
increasing stability of Bravo in carrying out its goals for the benefit of the Greater Des
Moines area. This Agreement is not intended to establish a separate legal entity.
V. ACCOUNTING OF BENEFITS
(I)
Bravo shall administer the undertakings between the City of Ankeny and Bravo as
described herein, and Bravo shall acquire, hold and disperse its assets, including the
Commitment, in accordance with the purpose stated herein and the governing
documents of Bravo. The City of Ankeny hereby appoints its City Administrator to
administer this Agreement with Bravo, and Bravo hereby appoints its President to
administer this Agreement with the City of Ankeny.
Bravo shall present to the City Administrator of the City of Ankeny no later than 45
(2)
days after the close of each fiscal year that ends within the term of this
Agreement a full accounting of Bravo's revenues, disbursements and operations
for such year in a form reasonably acceptable to the City ("Financial Statements"). The
fiscal year of Bravo cnds each December 31.
The Financial Statements shall be prepared by Bravo and reviewed by a certified public
(3)
accountant.
VI. OPERATIONS AND FINANCES
That Bravo shall prepare and submit to the  Ankeny City Council prior to the commencement of
each fiscal year beginning during the term of this Agreement a distribution plan for public funds
(the "Plan"). All expenditures of public funds shall be made pursuant to the Plan.

AGREEMENT FOR PROVISION OF FOOD SERVICES BETWEEN
JASPER COUNTY, IOWA AND SKIFF MEDICAL CENTER
THIS AGREEMENT is made this Q day of Septem 200
, 2007, by and between Jasper
County, Iowa, doing business under its "Jasper County Elderly Nutrition Program" and
acting by and through its Board of Supervisors (hereinafter referred to as "Contractor")
and Skiff Medical Center, Newton, Iowa, {hereinafter referred to as the "Sub-
Contractor"), and PROVIDES AS FOLLOWS:
1.
NATURE AND DURATION OF AGREEMENT:
This agreement creates no new entity and shall be effective from the 13 day of
2002 to the 30th day of June
JUIV
20 08. Sub-
Contractor and all employees and agents of Sub-Contractor are wholly independent of
Contractor, and nothing contained within this Agreement is intended to cause Sub-
Contractor or any of its employees or agents to become employees or agents of
Contractor for any purpose.
2.
LICENSING REQUIREMENTS, MEAL PREPARATION AND DELIVER Y:
The Sub-Contractor shall be licensed by the Iowa Department of Inspections and
Appeals, and shall comply with state restaurant license laws and regulations pertaining to
food handling and preparation.
The Sub-Contractor will prepare meals for the Home Delivered Meals aspects of the
program each Saturday and Sunday and on the holidays of Thanksgiving Day and
Christmas Day.
The Sub-Contractor shall provide the Contractor with monthly or cycle menus of meals
prepared for the home delivered meals program. Meals program shall be subject to
approval of the program director and shall comply with the food pattern listed below:
Meat or meat alternative - 3 oz. of cooked edible portions of beef, pork,
fish, fowl, luncheon meats, eggs or cheese
Two Vegetables and One Fruit group  – two 1/2 cup servings (dessert ·
should not be counted toward this).
Three servings of bread or bread alternative.
Butter or Margarine
One Milk / Alternative
Dessert -- one 1/2 cup serving of simple dessert such as fruit, pudding, etc.
Page 1 of 3
Modified diets may be provided by the Sub-Contractor upon request by the Contractor
and standard meals shall be modified if required by any changes of any state or federal
agency rule or grant funding requirement. The Contractor shall be responsible for
delivery of meals via its "Elderly Nutrition Program" endeavors.
3.
ACCESS:
Employees of the Contractor, and other qualified representatives shall have access to the
facility at such time as is needed to perform their job responsibilities and to ensure full
compliance with this Agreement by the Sub-Contractor.
4.
CLIENT CERTIFICATION AND RECORDS:
The Contractor, through its Elderly Nutrition Program Director, shall be responsible for
certification of eligible recipients of Home Delivered Meals and delivery of said meals.
Requests for service shall be referred to the Contractor. The Contractor will notify the
Sub-Contractor, in advance, of additions or deletions to the number of meals to be
Information necessary for the successful operation of the program shall be
prepared. 
exchanged by both parties. The Sub-Contractor shall maintain a monthly record of meals
served to each recipient and submit such records to the Contractor, c/o Jasper County
Elderly Nutrition Program, 2401 First Avenue East, Newton, Iowa, 50208, no later than
the 5d day of the following month. The Contractor may provide the Sub-Contractor with
any forms needed by Contractor record keeping and, if so, Sub-Contractor agrees to
promptly and accurately complete and return such forms concurrent with any billing for
Sub-Contractor's services provided hereunder.
5.
BILLING:
The Sub-Contractor shall submit monthly statements for payment, detailing the number
of meals served and cost per meal. Any additional charges shall be itemized in the
statement. Statements shall be submitted to the Contractor no later than the last day of
the month.
The Sub-Contractor shall provide suitable meals at the rate of $6.00 each for Saturdays
and Sundays, EXCEPT that the rate of $4.00 per meal shall apply for those meals
prepared on Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day (even if Christmas Day were to fall on
a Saturday or Sunday).
6.
LIABILITY:
The Contractor shall carry primary insurance for personal injury and personal liability
and secondary insurance for product liability. The Sub-Contractor, and its employees
and representatives, shall be held harmless from claims and actions against the nutrition
program for personal injury and personal liability caused by any employee or
representative of Contractor acting within the scope of his or her employment. The Sub-
Contractor shall indemnify through insurance policies and hold harmless Contractor, and
Page 2 of 3
its employees and representatives, from any act or omission on the part of the Sub-
Contractor, or its employees or representatives, causing harm or injury to any third
person in relation to any matters involved under this Agreement. The Sub-Contractor
shail cooperate to promptly supply the Contractor's program director with copies of the
required policy or policies of insurance.
7.
NON-DISCRIMINATION:
All parties to this agreement shall comply with the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (P.L.
880352) and all requirements imposed by or pursuant thereto, the Rehabilitation Act of
1965, Section 504, and all other applicable Federal, State and local laws, rules and
regulations. In accordance therewith, no person shall be discriminated against, excluded
from participation, be denied benefits, or be otherwise subjected to discrimination on the
grounds of race, creed, color, sex, age, national origin, or handicap.
8.
ASSIGNMENT
OF
DUTIES
AND
RESPONSIBILITIES BY
SUB-
CONTRACTOR:
No assignment or transfer of this agreement or any of the duties imposed hereunder may
be made in whole or part without the written consent of the Contractor following public
hearing and passage of appropriate resolution.
9.
MODIFICATIONS, TERMINATION FOR CONVENIENCE:
No variation or modification of this agreement, and no waiver of its provisions, shall be
valid unless in writing and signed by duly authorized officers of both Contractor and Sub-
Contractor. Both parties may, at any time during the life of this agreement or any
extension thereof, terminate this agreement upon thirty (30) days written notice of
intention to do so, except that Contractor may terminate this agreement immediately and
without recourse if based upon probable cause of any breach of this agreement or any
violation of applicable laws, rules or regulations on the part of the Sub-Contractor.
IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the parties have hercto caused this agreement to be signed by
their duly authorized officers/representatives.

LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES CONTRACT
On this 1* day of July, 2015, the incorporated City of Underwood, Iowa, hercinafter referred to
as "City", and Pottawattamie County, Iowa, hereinafter referred to as "County", enter into the
following agreement:
1.
The County will provide the City with law enforcement services through the
Pottawattamie County Sheriff's Office. These services will include but not be limited to:
A.
Radar operations to control speed.
B.
Issuing violations under city ordinances (excluding animal control ordinances) at
request.
C.
Housing inmates who have been incarcerated under a city ordinance without
charge to the city.
D.
Service of abatement notices on request.
E.
Periodically checking commercial building for unlocked doors and trespassers.
k
Investigation of traffic accidents and complaints.
G
Providing a detective division to investigate crimes and conduct on-going
investigations.
H.
Providing services by the Pottawattamie County Drug Task Force.
Supplying schools or community clubs with officers and materials for special
I.
programs and talks upon request.
J.
Routine patrols and special patrols upon request by the mayor or members of the
city council.
K.
Supply fully equipped patrol cars with radio, lights, siren, and all related
equipment, gasoline and oil, tires, and maintenance, uniforms, and all other
personal equipment for sheriff's deputies.
In consideration for the law enforcement services above described, City will pay a per
2.
capita rate of $17.50 (based on the 2010 census figures of 917) to County, which amounts to the
annual sum of $16,047.50. This shall be billed by the Pottawattamie County Sheriff's Office and
paid in equal quarterly installments to the Pottawattamie County Sheriff's Office on July 1,
October 1, January 1, and April 1.
(PARAGRAPH 3 IS OPTIONAL:  STRIKE IF CITY DOES NOT INTEND TO CONTRACT
FOR ADDITIONAL COVERAGE)

3.
City. In consideration for this extra coverage, County is guaranteeing_
hours of
patrol / coverage per day within the City limits of City. The cost of this additional coverage is
$8,760.00 for an hour of additional coverage for 365 days during the year. This amount shall be
paid in equal quarterly installments as set forth in Paragraph 2.
Law enforcement policy, regulations and other matters pertaining to the employment of
4.
Pottawattamie County Deputy Sheriffs are to be determined solely by the Pottawattamie County
Sheriff. The Pottawattamie County Sheriff's Office will provide law enforcement services 24
hours a day in such a manner as to afford the maximum possible law enforcement to all the
citizens of the county to whom the sheriff owes a statutory or contractual obligation for such
services. The time, place, and manner in which these services are implemented shall be in the
sole discretion of the Pottawattamic County Sheriff's Office.
This contractual agreement shall commence on the 1st day of July, 2015, and shall
5.
continue for one year ending on the 30th day of June, 2016. The contract shall be reviewed
annually in December of the contract year. This Agreement is renewable on an annual basis
upon mutual agreement of the parties herein. If agreement is not reached by the end of
December in the given contract year, this contract shall automatically terminate on June 30 of the
following year.
In accordance with Chapter 28E, Code of Iowa, a copy of this agreement shall be filed
6.
with the Secretary of State and recorded with the Pottawattamie County Recorder. Signatures
will include the Mayor of Underwood, Iowa, the City Clerk of Underwood, Iowa, the

of Supervisors. The city seal shall be affixed to the contract before returning to the county for
filing.
