COORDINATING SERVICE PROVIDER 28E AGREEMENT
Region 5
This Agreement, made and entered into effective July 1, 1998, by and among Iowa
Workforce Development, Iowa Central Community College, JTPA Grantee, and certain
Participating Providers. The parties agree as follows:
SECTION 1. IDENTITY OF THE PARTIES.
Iowa Workforce Development ("IWD"), which is a duly created state department, is
1.1
authorized, among other things, to provide and fund workforce development programs. IWD's
address is 1000 East Grand Avenue, Des Moines, Iowa, 50319.
1.2 Iowa Central Community College ("JTPA Grantee") is authorized among other things, to
provide and fund workforce development programs.  JTPA Grantee's address is 330 Avenue M,
Fort Dodge, Iowa, 50501.
1.3 Also parties to this Agreement are those entities listed on Schedule A (collectively referred
to as "Participating Providers") who satisfy the eligibility requirements and who agree to be
bound by the terms of this Agreement.
SECTION 2. PURPOSE The purpose of this Agreement is to establish a Coordinating Service
Provider for IWD Region 5 and for that entity to coordinate the delivery of workforce
development services and to implement an integrated delivery system for those services in IWD
Region 5. IWD Region 5 consists of the following counties: Webster, Hamilton, Wright,
Humbolt, Pocahontas Sac, Calhoun, Greene, and Buena Vista.
SECTION 3. TERM. The term of this Agreement shall be for five years from July 1, 1998 to
Jume 30, 2003, unless earlier terminated in accordance with this Agreement. By mutual
agreement, this Agreement may be renewed for one additional five-year term.
SECTION 4. EFFECTIVE DATE OF AGREEMENT. This Agreement shall be effective
when the following conditions are completed:
4.1 The Agreement is signed by Iowa Workforce Development, the JTPA Grantee, and
the Participating Providers listed on Schedule A.
4.2 The Agreement or a recordable form of this Agreement is recorded by the Webster
and Polk County Recorders.
4.3 The Agreement is filed with the lowa Secretary of State.
SECTION 5. COORDINATING SERVICE PROVIDER. A separate administrative entity
called the Coordinating Service Provider for Region 5 ("CSP") is created by this Agreement.
I
SECTION 6.  COORDINATING SERVICE PROVIDER GOVERNANCE.
6.1 At the time of the execution of this Agreement, each Member Organization shall designate,
in writing, its official representative to serve until the expiration of this Agreement, its
withdrawal from the Agreement, or the designation of a substitute representative.
6.1.1 For purposes of this Agreement, the term "Member Organization" means any party
to this Agreement.
6.2 The CSP will be operated by the Member Organizations in accordance with the terms of this
Agreement.
6.3 All CSP decisions will be decided by majority vote of the Member Organizations, unless
IWD, determines that the decision or proposed decision is contrary to applicable law, policies,
and procedures, in which case the decision or proposed decision is void upon notice from Iowa
Workforce Development to the CSP.
6.4 Each Member Organization shall have one (1) vote.
6.5 Regional Management Structure - The Region 5 organizational structure is described in
the local Management Plan.
SECTION 7. POWERS AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE COORDINATING
SERVICE PROVIDER.
7.1 Subject to the limitations imposed by this Agreement and limitations imposed by applicable
law, the CSP shall have all powers necessary to carry out this Agreement including the power to
develop a budget and approve the expenditure of funds received by the Fiscal Agent on behalf of
the CSP.
7.2 The CSP is responsible for the coordination of the delivery of workforce development
services, the design and implementation of integrated products and services, and the management
of the workforce development center system subject to guidelines issued by IWD.
7.3 The CSP shall use the Iowa Integrated Customer Service system subject to guidelines issued
by IWD.
7.4 The CSP shall market and maintain the identity of the Regional Workforce Development
Center System subject to guidelines issued by IWD.
The CSP shall develop and implement a Regional Workforce Development Customer
7.5
Service Plan based upon the results of the Regional Assessment and Analysis, product and
2
7.6 The CSP shall also have the power to decide how best to deliver its products and services,
allocate available funds for the delivery of products and services subject to all applicable laws
and restrictions.
7.7
The CSP shall have the authority to enter into contracts necessary to carry out this
Agreement subject to all applicable laws and restrictions. Any such contracts must be in a form
satisfactory to counsel for IWD. The CSP shall also have authority to purchase personal property
subject to applicable law and guidelines issued by IWD.
7.8 The CSP shall also select vendors in a manner consistent with applicable law and subject to
guidelines issued by Iowa Workforce Development.
7.9 The IWD, the Iowa Workforce Development Board, and the Regional Advisory Board shall
establish from time to time performance outcome goals and customer satisfaction requirements
that shall be met by the CSP.
7.10 The CSP will provide reports to IWD, the Workforce Development Board, the Regional
Advisory Board, Local Elected Officials, and to Private Industry Council as required.
SECTION 8. PROPERTY ACQUIRED. Any personal property acquired by the CSP with
funds under this agreement during the term of this Agreement shall become the property of IWD
upon the expiration of this Agreement. The CSP shall not acquire any real property.
SECTION 9. FISCAL MANAGEMENT. Fiscal management issues for Region 5 shall be
governed by a separate agreement with a Fiscal Agent and all of the terms and conditions
contained therein.
SECTION 10. CONTROL OF STAFF.
10.1 The staff of each Member Organization will at all times be under the direct control and
supervision of that Member Organization's staff even while the staff is performing work under
this Agreement.
10.2 No Employee Sharing. Under this Agreement, Member Organizations may not enter into
any arrangement for the sharing of employees or supervisors. Any such arrangement must be
created by separate agreement.
10.3 Member Organizations shall be solely responsible for the selection, hiring, disciplining,
firing, and compensating their staff. Each Member Organization shall not have any authority to
discipline or reassign the other Member Organization's staff.
10.4 Insurance, Benefits and Compensation. JTPA Grantee and the Participating Providers
will provide for and pay all employment costs of their staff including, but not limited to, worker's
compensation, unemployment insurance, health insurance, and other benefits and compensation,
3
and will make and remit all payroll withholdings with respect to the staff, all as required by law.
IWD shall have no liability whatsoever for all such employment costs to or for the benefit of the
staff. Evidence of payment of such benefits shall be provided to IWD upon request.
10.5 Independent Contractor. The status of JTPA Grantee and the Participating Providers
shall be that of an independent contractor. IWD shall not provide JTPA Grantee or the
Participating Providers with office space, support staff, equipment or tools, or supervision
beyond the terms of this Agreement or other agreement entered into between the parties. JTPA
Grantee and the Participating Providers and their staff are ineligible for any State of Iowa
employee benefits, including but not limited to, retirement benefits, insurance coverage or the
like unless otherwise eligible by virtue of employment. Neither JTPA Grantee or the
Participating Providers nor any of their staff shall be considered an employee of the State of Iowa
or IWD for federal or state tax purposes. IWD shall not withhold taxes on behalf of JTPA
Grantee or the Participating Providers (unless required by law). JTPA Grantee and the
Participating Providers shall be responsible for payment of all taxes in connection with any
income earned from performing this Agreement.
SECTION 11.
ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS TO BE A PARTICIPATING
PROVIDER. In order to become a member of the CSP, each Participating Provider warrants
and represents that it satisfies the eligibility requirements set forth in this Section.
11.1 Authority to Conduct Business in State of Iowa. Each Participating Provider is a
corporation duly organized, validly existing and in good standing under the laws of the State of
Iowa or another state and has full power and authority to carry on its business in Iowa as now
conducted.
11.2
Financial Requirements.
Each Participating Provider shall demonstrate, to the
satisfaction of IWD, that it has sufficient funds to participate in the CSP and to satisfy potential
liabilities arising from its participation in this Agreement.
11.3 Programmatic Requirements. Each Participating Provider agrees to:
11.3.1 Integrate those products and services agreed to be offered through the Region's
workforce development system;
11.3.2 Use and share customer information through the Integrated Customer Service
System:
11.3.3 Accept financial responsibility and liability for its actions related to financial and
audit matters, personal injury, property damage, performance outcomes, employment
matters, and all other matters arising out of its respective performance in this Agreement;
and
11.3.4 Actively participate in the management of the delivery of workforce development
services.
4
SECTION 12. DUTIES OF IWD AND JTPA GRANTEE. In addition to the duties imposed
elsewhere in this Agreement, IWD and JTPA Grantee agree to:
12.1 Integrate those products and services agreed to be offered through the Region's
workforce development system;
12.2 Use and share customer information through the Integrated Information System;
12.3 Accept financial responsibility and liability for their respective actions related to
financial and audit matters, personal injury, property damage, performance outcomes,
employment matters, and all other matters arising out of its participation in this
Agreement; and
12.4 Actively participate in the management of the delivery of workforce development
services.
SECTION 13. DATA PRIVACY.
13.1 Participating Providers' employees and agents may have access to private or confidential
data maintained by IWD and JTPA Grantee to the extent permitted under federal or state law and
as necessary to carry out their responsibilities under the Agreement. Each Participating Provider
shall designate one individual who shall remain the responsible authority in charge of all data
collected, used, or disseminated by the Participating Provider in connection with the performance
of the Agreement. Each Participating Provider shall accept responsibility for providing adequate
supervision and training to its agents and employees to ensure compliance with the terms of this
Agreement. The private or confidential data shall remain the property of IWD or JTPA Grantee
at all times.
13.2 No private or confidential data collected, maintained, or used in the course of performance
of the Agreement shall be disseminated except as authorized by statute, either during the
period of the Agreement or thereafter. Any data supplied to the Participating Providers
shall be considered the property of IWD or JTPA Grantee. Each Participating Provider
must agree to return any and all data furnished by IWD or JTPA Grantee promptly at the
request of IWD or the Department in whatever form it is maintained by the Participating
Providers. Upon the termination or completion of the Agreement, Participating Providers
shall not use any of such data or any material derived from the data for any purpose unless
the use is pursuant to the license granted by IWD or JTPA Grantee. Otherwise, upon the
request of IWD or JTPA Grantee, Participating Providers will destroy the data and make it
unreadable.
Participating Providers shall indemnify IWD and JTPA Grantee in
conformance with Section 15 for violations of this section. Participating Providers shall
notify IWD and the Department prior to the destruction of these materials and shall provide
IWD and the Department with the opportunity to confirm the proper destruction of these
materials.
5
SECTION 14. TERMINATION.
14.1 Termination For Convenience. Following ninety (90) days written notice, any party may
terminate this Agreement in whole or in part for convenience without the payment of any penalty
or incurring any further obligation to the non-terminating party. Terminations for convenience
shall become effective at the end of the fiscal year unless the party terminating for convenience
can demonstrate hardship or good cause for an earlier termination date. Following termination
for convenience, the non-terminating party(les) shall be entitled to compensation, upon
submission of invoices and proper proof of claim, for services provided under this Agreement to
the terminating party up to and including the date of termination.
14.2 Termination For Cause. IWD, in its sole discretion, can terminate this Agreement, in
whole or in part, if the JTPA Grantee or Participating Providers are in default of the Agreement.
If default exists, IWD shall terminate this Agreement, in whole or in part, in accordance with the
terms set out below. In determining whether default exists, IWD, in its discretion, may consult
with the Regional Advisory Boards or the IWD Board.
14.3 Notice of Default. If there is a default event, IWD shall provide written notice to the
defaulting party requesting that the breach or noncompliance be immediately remedied. Written
notice shall also be provided to the Regional Advisory Board and the IWD Board. In the event
that the breach or noncompliance continues to be evidenced thirty (30) days beyond the date of
the written notice, IWD may:
14.3.1 Immediately terminate the Agreement, in whole or in part, without additional
written notice; or
14.3.2
Enforce the terms and conditions of the Agreement and seek any legal or
equitable remedies.
In either event, the non-defaulting party(ies) may seek damages as a result of the breach
or failure to comply with the terms of the Agreement.
14.4 Termination Due to Lack of Funds or Change in Law. Notwithstanding anything in this
Agreement to the contrary, and subject to the limitations, conditions, and procedures set forth
below, IWD shall have the right to terminate this Agreement without penalty by giving sixty (60)
days written notice to Member Organizations as a result of any of the following:
14.4.1 The legislature or governor fail to appropriate funds sufficient to allow IWD to
operate as required and to fulfill its obligations under this Agreement;
14.4.2 If funds are de-appropriated or not allocated;
6
14.4.3 If IWD's authorization to operate is withdrawn or there is a material alteration in
the programs administered by IWD;
14.4.4 If IWD's duties are substantially modified.
IWD agrees to make reasonable requests for the necessary funds. If any appropriation to cover
the costs of this Agreement becomes available within sixty (60) days subsequent to termination
under this clause, IWD agrees to re-enter the Agreement with JTPA Grantee and the Participating
Providers under the same provisions, terms and conditions as the original Agreement.
14.5
Remedies Of JTPA Grantee and Participating Providers In Event Of Non-
Appropriation. In the event of termination of this Agreement due to non-appropriation, the
exclusive, sole and complete remedy of JTPA Grantee and Participating Providers shall be
payment for services completed prior to termination if any.
SECTION 15. INDEMNIFICATION.
15.1 By JTPA Grantee. The JTPA Grantee agrees to defend, indemnify and hold the State of
Iowa and IWD harmless from any and all liabilities, damages, settlements, judgments, costs and
expenses, including reasonable attomey's fees of the Attorney General's Office, and the costs
and expenses and attorney fees of other counsel required to defend the State of Iowa and IWD
related to or arising from:
15.1.1 Any violation of this Agreement by the JTPA Grantee; or
15.1.2 Any negligent acts or omissions of JTPA Grantee; or
15.1.3 JTPA Grantee's performance or attempted performance of this Agreement; or
15.1.4 Any failure by JTPA Grantee to comply with all local, state and federal laws and
regulations; or
15.1.5 Any failure by JTPA Grantee to make all reports, payments and withholdings
required by Federal and State law with respect to social security, employee income and
other taxes, fees or costs required by JTPA Grantee to conduct business in the State of
Iowa; or
Any infringement of any copyright, trademark, patent, or other intellectual
15.1.6
property right.
15.2 By Participating Providers. Each Participating Provider agrees to defend, indemnify and
hold the State of Iowa and IWD harmless from any and all liabilities, damages, settlements,
judgments, costs and expenses, including reasonable attorney's fees of the Attorney General's
Office, and the costs and expenses and attorney fees of other counsel required to defend the State
of Iowa and IWD related to or arising from:
7
15.2.1 Any violation of this Agreement; or
15.2.2 Any negligent acts or omissions of the Participating Provider; or
15.2.3
The Participating Provider's performance or attempted performance of this
Agreement; or
15.2.4 Any failure by the Participating Provider to comply with all local, state and
federal laws and regulations; or
15.2.5 Any failure by the Participating Provider to make all reports, payments and
withholdings required by Federal and State law with respect to social security, employee
income and other taxes, fees or costs required by the Participating Provider to conduct
business in the State of Iowa; or
15.2.6
Any infringement of any copyright, trademark, patent, or other intellectual
property right.
15.3 By IWD. To the extent allowed by applicable constitutional and statutory law (including
without limitation lowa Code Chapter 669), IWD shall indemnify JTPA Grantee and the
Participating Providers under this Agreement, and their directors, officers, elected and appointed
officials and employees for any claim, loss, liability, damage or expense (including reasonable
attorneys fees) which may be asserted against it or them by a third-party, by reason of any action
taken or not taken by JTPA Grantee in accordance with the Agreement, and which does not arise
from the breach of this Agreement, negligence, fraud, or willful misconduct by JTPA Grantee
and the Participating Providers, their employees, officers or agents or elected or appointed
officials.
15.3.1 Conditions. Any indemnification hereunder shall be subject to the prior
approval of an appropriation of funds by the General Assembly and Governor of
the State of Iowa and the allotment of funds by the Iowa Department of
Management as may be required by law, and JTPA Grantee and Participating
Providers shall furnish the State with a detailed estimate of any expected claim,
loss, liability, damage and/or expense for the State's use in obtaining such
approval and appropriation or allotment. Indemnification is further conditioned
on the following:
(i)
JTPA Grantee and Participating Providers shall give the State
prompt written notice (by overnight mail) of any expected,
threatened or actual claim, loss, liability, damage or expenses.
(ii)
JTPA Grantee and Participating Providers, and the above-
mentioned indemnified, shall at all times cooperate with the State,
both in document production and personnel time.
8
To the extent that JTPA Grantee and Participating Providers are
(iii)
indemnified under this section, the State shall have the right to hire
and direct counsel in the defense of JTPA Grantee and
Participating Providers.
To the extent that JTPA Grantee and Participating Providers are
(iv)
indemnified under this section, the State shall, after consultation
with JTPA Grantee and Participating Providers, make all decisions
regarding any claim, threatened litigation, litigation, or settlement
in connection with any claim, loss, liability, damage or expense
which may be asserted against JTPA Grantee, Participating
Providers, and/or the above-referenced indemnified.
The indemnification provisions contained herein, in no way limits
(v)
the State from asserting a sovereign immunity defense as allowed
by applicable state or federal law to any claim made in
conformance with this section.
SECTION 16. CONTRACT ADMINISTRATION.
16.1 Amendments. This Agreement may be amended in writing as needed by mutual consent
of the parties. All amendments to this Agreement must be fully executed by all parties.
16.2 Third Party Beneficiaries. There are no third party beneficiaries to this Agreement. This
Agreement is intended only to benefit IWD, JTPA Grantee, and the Participating Providers.
16.3
Choice of Law and Forum. The terms and provisions of this Agreement shall be
construed in accordance with the laws of the State of Iowa. Any and all litigation or actions
commenced in connection with this Agreement shall be brought in Des Moines, Iowa, in Polk
County District Court for the State of lowa. If, however, jurisdiction is not proper in the Polk
County District Court, the action shall only be brought in the United States District Court for the
Southern District of Iowa, Central Division, provided that jurisdiction is proper in that forum.
This provision shall not be construed as waiving any immunity to suit or liability which may be
available to the State of Iowa or IWD.
Assignment and Delegation.
This Agreement may not be assigned, transferred or
16.4
conveyed in whole or in part without the prior written consent of the other parties.
16.5 Integration. This Agreement represents the entire Agreement between the parties and
neither party is relying on any representation that may have been made which is not included in
this Agreement.
16.6 Headings or Captions. The paragraph headings or captions are for identification purposes
only and do not limit or construe the contents of the paragraphs.
9
Not a Joint Venture. Nothing in this Agreement shall be construed as creating or
16.7
constituting the relationship of a partnership, joint venture, (or other association of any kind or
agent and principal relationship) between the parties hereto. Each party shall be deemed to be an
independent contractor contracting for services and acting toward the mutual benefits expected to
be derived herefrom. No party, unless otherwise specifically provided for herein, has the
authority to enter into any contract or create an obligation or liability on behalf of, in the name
of, or binding upon another party to this Agreement.
Supersedes Former Agreements. This Agreement supersedes all prior Agreements
16.8
between IWD and JTPA Grantee or the Participating Providers for the services provided in
connection with this Agreement but does not void or impair existing agreements for services not
covered by this Agreement.
16.9
Waiver. Except as specifically provided for in a waiver signed by duly authorized
representatives of IWD and JTPA Grantee or the Participating Providers, failure by either party
at any time to require performance by the other party or to claim a breach of any provision of
the Agreement shall not be construed as affecting any subsequent breach or the right to require
performance with respect thereto or to claim a breach with respect thereto.
16.10
Notices.
Notices under this Agreement shall be in writing and delivered to the
representative of the party to receive notice (identified below) at the address of the party to
receive notice as it appears below or as otherwise provided for by proper notice here under. The
effective date for any notice under this Agreement shall be the date of delivery of such notice
(not the date of mailing) which may be effected by certified U.S. Mail return receipt requested
with postage prepaid thereon or by recognized overnight delivery service, such as Federal
Express or UPS. Failure to "receipt" shall constitute delivery.

16.11 Cumulative Rights. The various rights, powers, options, elections and remedies of any
party provided in this Agreement, shall be construed as cumulative and not one of them is
exclusive of the others or exclusive of any rights, remedies or priorities allowed either party by
law, and shall in no way affect or impair the right of any party to pursue any other equitable or
legal remedy to which either party may be entitled as long as any default remains in any way
unremedied, unsatisfied, or undischarged.
16.12 Severability. If any provision of this Agreement is determined by a court of competent
jurisdiction to be invalid or unenforceable, such determination shall not affect the validity or
enforceability of any other part or provision of this Agreement.
16.13 Time is of the Essence. Time is of the essence with respect to the performance of the
terms of this Agreement.
16.14 Authorization. Each party to this Agreement represents and warrants to the others that:
16.14.1 It has the right, power and authority to enter into and perform its obligations
under this Agreement.
11
16.14.2 It has taken all requisite action (corporate, statutory, or otherwise) to approve
execution, delivery and performance of this Agreement, and this Agreement constitutes a
legal, valid and binding obligation upon itself in accordance with its terms.
16.15 Successors in Interest. All the terms, provisions, and conditions of the Agreement shall
be binding upon and inure to the benefit of the parties hereto and their respective successors,
assigns, and legal representatives.
16.16 Record Retention And Access. JTPA Grantee and Participating Providers shall maintain
books, records, and documents which sufficiently and properly document and calculate all
charges billed to IWD throughout the term of this Agreement for a period of at least three (3)
years following the date of final payment or completion of any required audit, whichever is later.
JTPA Grantee and the Participating Providers shall permit the Auditor of the State of Iowa or any
authorized representative of the State and where federal funds are involved, the Comptroller
General of the United States or any other authorized representative of the United States
government, to access and examine, audit, excerpt and transcribe any directly pertinent books,
documents, papers, electronic or optically stored and created records or other records of JTPA
Grantee and the Participating Providers relating to orders, invoices, or payments or any other
documentation or materials pertaining to this Agreement. JTPA Grantee and the Participating
Providers shall not impose a charge for audit or examination of the books and records.
16.17 Counterparts. The parties agree that this Agreement has been or may be executed in
several counterparts, each of which shall be deemed an original and all such counterparts shall
together constitute one and the same instrument.
16.18 Additional Provisions. The parties agree that if an Addendum, Rider or Exhibit is
attached hereto by the parties, and referred to herein, then the same shall be deemed incorporated
herein by reference.
16.19 Further Assurances and Corrective Instruments. The parties agree that they will, from
time to time, execute, acknowledge and deliver, or cause to be executed, acknowledged
and delivered, such supplements hereto and such further instruments as may reasonably be
required for carrying out the expressed intention of this Agreement.

This Agreement is made this _
_, 19_ 92
between the Cerro Gordo County Farm Bureau (hereinafter Farm Bureau) at _
4050 4th Street S.W., Mason City, IA and the North Iowa Fair Association.
RECITALS
A.
The North Iowa Fair Association is engaged in the promotion of agriculture
and agricultural interests.
B.
The North Iowa Fair Association desires to annually sponsor a livestock barn
for children at the North Iowa Fair.
Ü
The North Iowa Fair Association is engaged in the supervising and making
arrangements for the activities of the North Iowa Fair, which is held on the North Iowa
Fairgrounds located north of Highway 18 west of Mason City, Iowa.
D.
The North Iowa Fair Association is responsible for making decisions
concerning the use and development of the North Iowa Fairgrounds.
Farm Bureau wishes to erect a building for the purpose of a livestock barn
E.
for children (hereinafter "building") on the North Iowa Fairgrounds.
9505726
In consideration of the mutual promises contained herein, and of the mutual benefit
to be derived hereunder, the parties agree as follows:
Farm Bureau agrees to construct a building on the North Iowa Fairgrounds
1.
suitable for use as a livestock barn for children.
The general plans for this building shall be mutually agreed upon by Farm
2.
Bureau and the North Iowa Fair Association prior to construction of this building.
3.
The location of this building shall be mutually agreed upon by Farm Bureau
and the North Iowa Fair Association prior to the construction of the building.
4.
Once the construction of this building is completed, Farm Bureau shall turn
the ownership of the building over to the North Iowa Fair Association, provided that the
following conditions are met:
a.
Farm Bureau will be allowed the right of first refusal to use the
building as a livestock barn for children during the North Iowa Fair.
This right of use shall cover each day of fair activities as well as one
day prior to and after the fair.
b.
The upkeep and maintenance of the building and premises shall be
the responsibility of the North Iowa Fair Association.
The North Iowa Fair Association will insure the building and premises.
c.
Liability and casualty insurance shall be provided.
Proof of this
insurance shall be provided to Farm Bureau prior to turning the
building over to the North Iowa Fair Association and thereafter will
be provided upon request of Farm Bureau.  The amount of liability
and casualty insurance coverage provided on the building shall be
approved by Farm Bureau. This approval shall not be unreasonably
withhcld.
d.
Farm Bureau will erect a sign that recognizes Farm Bureau's
contribution of the building on the building. The content and
placement of the sign will be mutually agreed upon by the parties.
Any modification to the building, excluding normal and routine
e.
maintenance and upkeep, shall be approved by the both parties to this
agreement.
f.
Farm Bureau shall not be required to pay rent for the use of this
building during the North Iowa Fair.
5.
Insurance during the construction of this building shall be the responsibility
of North Central Farm Service.
6.
The North Iowa Fair Association is free to utilize this building for other
purposes at times other than the North Iowa Fair, as defined in paragraph 4(a).  This use
shall not interfere with or harm the use of the building as a livestock barn for children.
7.
The North Iowa Fair Association warrants that they have the authority to
execute this agreement and that their execution of this agreement is binding upon the 
North Iowa Fair Association and Cerro Gordo County.  Any approval necessary from the
Cerro Gordo County Board of Supervisors, or any other county or city agency or official,
has been obtained prior to the execution of this agreement. This agreement is entered
into with any such governmental body's knowledge and approval.
8.
This agreement, and the promises herein, shall be effective for twenty (20)
years from the date of execution, or as long as the fair is held at this location, whichever
is longer, and the condition of the building remains satisfactory to both parties.
o
This agreement shall only be modified in writing signed by both parties.
10.
This agreement shall survive any future changes in the name or format of
the fair that is now known as the North Iowa Fair, and shall apply with equal force to
any such fair.  Further, any changes in the composition or existence of the North Iowa
Fair Association will not affect this agreement.

28E AGREEMENT BETWEEN WOODBURY COUNTY, IOWA AND THE CITY OF _
IOWA FOR THE PROVISION OF LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES
_ 2013, by and between the County of Woodbury
This Contract is made and entered into this UNA 4
hereinafter referred to as "County" and the City of _
lowa, hereinafter referred to as "Municipality."
The Municipality desires to contract for Law Enforcement Services with the County. The County is
agreeable to rendering such services on terms and conditions hereinafter set forth. 
In consideration of the mutual promises contained herein, it is agreed as follows:
The County agrees through the Sheriff of the County to provide police protection within the corporate
limits of the Municipality, which services shall encompass the duties and functions of the type customarily
rendered by professional law enforcement officers including the enforcement of State Statues and Municipal
Ordinances, all criminal investigations and patrol coverage of the Municipality at intermittent intervals. The
Sheriff's Office will attempt to supply XXX hours of law enforcement services per month.
It is agreed that the Municipality will share the services of the Woodbury County Sheriff's Office with
other Municipalities in Woodbury County. Deputies shall, when applicable, file charges under Municipal
Ordinances, but if the town has no ordinance, then the deputy may file a under the applicable State Statue. When
a charge is filed under a Municipal Ordinance, the deputy will appear to testify as a witness at the hourly rate
agreed to in this contract and the Municipality will provide legal counsel for prosecution of Municipal Ordinances.
The Municipality agrees to pay and all incidental fees, such as but not limited to, towing bills and dog
transportation and kenneling charges, incurred in the normal course of law enforcement activities. It is understood
that the Sheriff does not have means by which to hold or transport animals
The Sheriff or his designee shall meet monthly with designated representatives of the Municipality to
review the logs and work of Sheriff’s Deputies in the Municipality. The Sheriff's Office shall make monthly reports
to the designated representative of the council which reports shall include a summary of the enforcement activity 
conducted by the Sheriff's Office within the Municipality, summary of the reported criminal activity within the 
Municipality and the interim reports on other matters not considered routine criminal activities. Any complaints,
requests, questions about or discretionary police matters shall be directed to the Sheriff.  Services provided shall
be administered and supervised by the Woodbury County Sheriff.
The number of hours may be increased or decreased, with adjustments being made for the cost of said
service by mutual agreement of the parties.
The discipline of deputies, matters of performance of services and of personnel so employed shall remain
with the Sheriff.
To facilitate the performance of said functions it is hereby agreed that the County shall have full
cooperation and assistance from the municipality, its officers, agents and employees. The County agrees to supply
a car, equipment, radio and deputy's equipment during the period of this agreement.  During the course of this
agreement and upon termination of this agreement, all equipment, cars, radios and deputy equipment shall
remain property of the Woodbury County Sheriff.
The Municipality shall not be called upon to assume any liability for the direct payment of any salaries,
wages, or other compensation for any County personnel performing services herein for said Municipality or any
liability other than provided for under the contract. County personnel performing the services rendered pursuant
to this agreement shall remain the employees of the County and shall not be considered employees of the
Municipality.  The County shall maintain workers compensation insurance as required by law.
Woodbury County, its officers and employees, shall not be deemed to assume any liability for intentional
or negligent acts of said Municipality or officers or employees, thereof, and said Municipality shall defend, 
indemnify and hold harmless Woodbury County and its officers and employees against any claim for damages 
resulting there from.
The Municipality shall not be responsible for any act, injury or damage arising out of the performance of
this contract by Woodbury County and in case claim is made by any third party, the County shall defend, indemnify
and hold harmless the Municipality.
Payment for hours of service described in said contract: the Municipality agrees to pay the County on 
quarterly basis the sum of $35.00 per hour for the hours of service performed up to a maximum of XX hours per 
month. All checks shall be made payable to Woodbury County, lowa, and delivered to the Woodbury County 
Sheriff.
It is contemplated that this contract shall become effective on
un 4
_ 2013 and shall run a period
of 12 months with the option of being renewable for successive periods not to exceed twelve months. The
Municipality shall notify the Woodbury County Sheriff sixty days prior to the expiration of said contract in writing
that it wishes to renew the same contract, make changes to the contract or discontinue said contract. County may
also discontinue or request changes to the contract at the end of a contract term by giving written notice to
Municipality sixty days prior to the end of a contract term.  If either party gives notice of proposed changes to this
agreement as provided above, this agreement will not be renewed unless the parties reach a mutual agreement
concerning the proposed changes. This contract shall be construed in accordance with the laws of the state of 
lowa.

LAW ENFORCEMENT AGREEMENT
PURSUANT TO CHAPTER 28E CODE OF IOWA
The undersigned County of Floyd and City of Colwell do hereby agree as follows:
1. Purpose.
The purpose of this agreement is for the provision of law enforcement services by Floyd
County to the City of Colwell on the terms and conditions set forth herein.
2. Parties. The parties to this agreement are the County of Floyd (hereinafter “County”) and the City of
Colwell (hereinafter "City").  Both parties are political subdivisions of the State of Iowa duly authorized by the
Code of Iowa.
3. Effective Date. This agreement shall become effective on the First (1") day of July, 2012.
This agreement shall be effective for a period of time extending from the First (1ª) day of
4. Duration.
July, 2012 up to and including the Thirtieth (30th) day of June, 2013.
5. Service Provided.
The County agrees to provide law enforcement services to the City of Colwell
during the duration of this agreement. The law enforcement services shall be performed by the Floyd County
Sheriff and the Sheriff's Deputies and employees.
6. Services Specifically Excluded. The County, the Sheriff, and/or the Sheriff's Deputies and
employees shall not provide any type of service relating to the regulation, control, or abatement of any animals
within the City. The County, the Sheriff, and/or the Sherift's Deputies will not enforce any violation of the City's
ordinances. This paragraph is not intended to be a complete list of services the County will not provide, but is
intended to be an express exclusion under this agreement.
7. Consideration. In consideration for the services provided by the County, the City shall pay to the
Floyd County Sheriff an amount equal to four dollars ($4.00) per capita of the population of the City.  This
amount shall be due and payable on the Effective Date of this agreement.
8. Insurance. The County will maintain liability insurance coverage for the activities of the Floyd
County Sheriff and Sheriff's Deputies and employees while providing law enforcement services to the City.
9. Indemnification. The County shall hold the City harmless and shall indemnify the City for any
claims or causes of action for damages to persons or property resulting solely from the negligent acts of the
County in providing law enforcement services to the City.
10. Amendments. This agreement shall only be amended by the consent and action of both the County
and the City.
11. Early Termination. The County may terminate this agreement at any time by passage of a Motion
by the Board of Supervisors. If terminated between the effective dates of this agreement, a proportional amount
of the Consideration paid to the County shall be returned to the City.  This shall be calculated by multiplying the
percentage of time between the effective dates services are not provided to the City by the Consideration paid to
the County, with the resulting sum paid by the County to the City. The City may terminate this agreement at any
time, but shall not be entitled to any return of any portion of Consideration.
12. Continuation and Negotiation. The County, by and through the Board of Supervisors, and the City,
by and through the Mayor, shall meet on November 5, 2012. The purpose of that meeting shall be to enter into
negotiations regarding a possible extension of this agreement and/or negotiating a different agreement pertaining
to law enforcement services to the City. This paragraph is not intended to create any presumption or intent, by
either party, to extend or continue this agreement past the Effective Date of this agreement.
13. Advisory Board. This agreement shall not, under any circumstances, create a separate legal entity.
There shall be, however, an advisory board created consisting of the Floyd County Sheriff and City Mayor.  This
advisory board shall meet at the request of either party to discuss performance of this agreement.  This paragraph
is intended to supersede Iowa Code 28E.6(1)(a).
14. Property. Any and all real and personal property used in performance of this agreement shall be
acquired, held, maintained, and retained by the County.

28E AGREEMENT
This Agreement, entered into by and between the Town of Beacon, Iowa, a municipal
corporation, hereinafter called “the Town”, and Mahaska County, lowa, a political subdivision,
hereinafter called “the County”, is duly authorized by Chapter 28E of the Code of lowa.

Sheriff, has the manpower and equipment necessary to provide said services.
Therefore, the said Town and County, is a spirit of cooperation between these public agencies,
agree with each other under the following terms and conditions as follows:
 The County shall provide, through the Office of the Sheriff, law enforcement services and all
1.
men and equipment necessary therefore to said Town.
2.
The said law enforcement services shall consist of patrol and traffic enforcement which
shall be provided to said Town for a minimum of six hours per week.
3.   The Town shall pay the County the sum of $3,400.00 per year as reimbursement for
expenses in relation to carrying out this Agreement.
4.
 The major portion of payment for said service shall be through the Town purchasing
equipment for the office of the Sheriff and receiving credit for the cost thereof.  The said
equipment shall be selected and approved in advance by the Sheriff.  Any balance shall be
paid to the General Fund of the County.

without the express written permission of the other party.

 This Agreement shall be supervised by the Mayor and Council of the Town and Sheriff of 
7.
the County.

any of the parties hereto of any obligation or responsibility imposed upon it or them by law,
except that to the extent of actual and timely performance thereof by any contracting party
hereto, said performance may be offered in satisfaction of the obligation or responsibility.

LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES CONTRACT
On this and day of March , 2017, the City of Collins and Story
County, Iowa, enter into the following agreement:
The Story County Sheriff's Office will provide the City of Collins, Iowa, with
1.
law enforcement services. These services will include but not be limited to:
Radar operations to control speed.
A.
Issuing violations under city ordinances (excluding animal control
B.
ordinances) upon request.
C.
Housing inmates who have been incarcerated under a city ordinance.
Service of abatement notices on request.
D.
Periodically checking commercial buildings for unlocked doors and
E.
trespassers.
F.
Investigation of traffic accidents and complaints.
G.
Dispatch of city fire departments and first responders.
H.
Staffing a 24 hour E911 dispatch center.
Providing a detective division to investigate crimes and conduct
I.
on-going investigations.
Investigation of drug-related offenses.
J.
K.
Supplying schools or community clubs with officers and materials
for special programs and talks upon request.
Routine patrols and special patrols upon request.
L.
Supply fully equipped patrol cars with radio, lights, siren and all
M.
related equipment, gasoline and oil, tires, and maintenance, uniforms and
all other personal equipment.
In consideration for the law enforcement services above described, the City of
2.
Collins, Iowa will pay a per capita rate of $58.11 (based on the 2010 census of
495) to Story County, Iowa, which amounts to the annual sum of $28,764.45.
This shall be paid in equal quarterly installments to the Story County Sheriff on
July 1, October 1, January 1 and April 1. Any per capita increase in contract
cost for the following year shall be negotiated by December for the next fiscal
year. For the purposes of this contract, fiscal year shall be from July 1, through
June 30, of the following year.
AGREEMENT
Page 2
The Sheriff shall be the administrator of this Agreement. Law Enforcement
3.
policy, regulations and matters pertaining to the employment of the Sheriff's
personnel shall be determined solely by the Sheriff. The time, place and manner
in which these services are implemented shall be in the sole discretion of the
Sheriff. The Mayor, Mayor Pro Tem and the City Administrator shall be
authorized to make requests to the Sheriff for performance of specific law
enforcement services as specified in this Agreement.
The initial term of the Agreement shall be automatically extended for successive
4.
one-year periods upon the same terms and conditions provided by this
Agreement for the initial term, unless this Agreement is terminated or modified
by the express election of either City or County as hereinafter provided.
Modification to this contract may be made by mutual consent of both parties.
In accordance with Chapter 28E, Code of Iowa, a copy of this Agreement shall
5.
be filed with the Secretary of State and recorded with the Story County Recorder.
Signatures will include the Mayor of Collins, the City Clerk of Collins, the
Chairperson of the Story County Board of Supervisors, the Story County
Auditor and the Story County Sheriff. The city seal shall be affixed to the
contract before returning to the county for filing.
6.
City shall fund the consideration for this Agreement from general revenues
under the City's annual general budget. There shall be no joint property
acquired pursuant to this Agreement.
7.
This contract may be terminated by either party. Termination is effective at
the end of the current quarterly billing cycle and must be preceded with a
30 day written notice to either party. Notice shall be accomplished by
certified mail or personal service.

CHAPTER 28E LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES CONTRACT BETWEEN
CHICKASAW COUNTY AND ALTA VISTA
This Agreement is entered into this 7 th day of April
. 20 2014
by and between Chickasaw County, through its Board of Supervisors, and the Chickasaw
County Sheriff, (collectively County), and the City of Alta Vista, through its City
Council, for the law enforcement services identified hereunder.
1. STATEMENT OF AGREEMENT
l A. The City of Alta Vista (hereinafter City), in lieu of providing police protection
services as required by Iowa Code, hereby elects to contract with the County for the
provision of law enforcement services on behalf of the City and its residents.
IB. The County agrees to provide law enforcement services to the City, through the
County's Sheriff and Sheriff's personnel, in response to requests made by the City, its
officers, employees, and agents and upon request, call or dispatch through Sheriff's F911
personnel to any residents or persons within the City.
2. LEGAL BASIS
2A. This Agreement is authorized by the provisions of Code of Iowa, Chapter 28E. The
purpose of this agreement is to provide law enforcement services for the City and to
discharge the City's obligation to provide law enforcement services for their citizens in
accordance with Chapter 372.4(2) of the Code of lowa as interpreted by the lowa
Supreme Court in Johnson v. Allen, 569 N.W. 2d 143 (Iowa 1997), referencing Code of
Iowa Chapter 368
3. GENERAL LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES DEFINED
3 A. Law enforcement services consists of routine, irregular, random, intermittent and
unpredictable patrol in the City or "as needed" patrol and investigation and all auxiliary
and technical service now provided by the Sheriff in support of patrol and investigation.
All references to law enforcement services contained in this Agreement are references
only to services that shall be delivered under the terms of this Agreement
4. DELIVERY OF SERVICES
4A. Service area. The Sheriff shall provide law enforcement services within the
corporate limits of the City.
14 March 2014 / 19-1
1/4
Todd W. Miller, Chickasaw County Sheriff, 116 N. Chestnut Avenue, New Hampton, IA
Prepared by:
50659 641 394 3121 (24 hours)
4B. Enforcement Responsibilities. It is agreed that the law enforcement services
performed will encompass only violations made criminal under the law defined by the
Code of lowa. Ordinances established by Chickasaw County will be enforced. No
enforcement will be undertaken for violations of City Ordinances.
4C. Delivery of Service. The delivery of law enforcement services to be provided by the
Sheriff will consist of routine, irregular, random, intermittent and unpredictable patrol in
the City so as to afford the maximum possible law enforcement to the City at those times
and in those places where crime is determined by the Sheriff most likely to occur, except
that upon special request of the City to the Sheriff, specially focused law enforcement
services may be requested upon particularized and identified need.
4D. Service Management. It is understood and agreed that the law enforcement officers
providing services to the City under this Agreement are County employees, and not
employees of the City. The Sherift's Deputies are solely subject to control, supervision,
and discipline of the Sheriff and under the Sheriff's law enforcement policies and
regulations, and employment rules and policies
4E. Responsiveness. The County's Sheriff and his Deputies will answer and
appropriately respond to calls for service made requesting law enforcement services and
provide immediate response to all E911 calls in which an emergency is claimed
threatening the lives, safety, and property of residents of the City or persons in the City.
1.
City agrees "calls for service" from their community will be prioritized
based on established rational law enforcement practices and based on
availability of Sheriff's personnel working any particular duty shift.
4F. Coordination. Pursuant to Iowa Code Section 28E.6 (1) (a), this Agreement does not
establish any separate legal entity. The administrators for this Agreement are the Sheriff
and Mayor of the City, a signatory to it.
4G. Resources. In consideration for the per capita rate charges described below, the
County and Sheriff agree that the law enforcement services to be provided include the
County's provision of fully equipped patrol cars with emergency lights, sirens, and radios
and other standard electronic telemetry; of law enforcement officers and deputies
appropriately selected and employed under County civil service, appropriately trained
and certified by the Iowa Law Enforcement Academy; of uniforms and all other personal
equipment necessary for the provision of law enforcement services; and for the
telephone, E911 and radio communications services made necessary under this
Agreement.
5. LIABLITY
5A. No agreement has been reached between the County and City concerning which
party is required to defend and indemnify the other party for claim or suit arising from
law enforcement services provided under this contract. That question is expressly
reserved for decision by the courts on an appropriate occasion.
14 March 2014 / 19-1
2/4
Prepared by:
Todd W. Miller, Chickasaw County Sheriff, 116 N. Chestnut Avenue, New Hampton, IA
50659 641 394 3121 (24 hours)
6. PERSONNEL
6B. Employee Payment. The City shall not be liable for the direct payment of salaries,
wages, or other compensation to the County officers or employees providing law
enforcement services to the City.
7. FEES
7A. Total sum. The City shall pay to the County an annual sum for law enforcement
services delivered during the term of this Agreement. Said payment shall be made
semiannually on or before the 15th day of October and the 15th day of April of the
contract year. Said payment shall be made to the Auditor of Chickasaw County.
7B. Payment Plan. The City payment plan is attached in Section 11 of this Agreement.
7C. Adjustment. The County may adjust the total sum in accordance with changes in
costs of providing law enforcement services. The County shall notify the City in writing
of each adjustment. Any adjustment will be done on an annual basis.
8. TERMS
8A. This Agreement will take effect on the 1st day of July, 20 /4 and shall continue
through the 30th day of June 20 15 and this Agreement may be renegotiated within
three (3) months prior to March 15th of any year as to any terms or particulars upon
request by any party.
8B. Unless terminated or renegotiated, this Agreement shall be renewed automatically for
successive terms of one (1) year. The Agreement may be terminated by either party by
giving the other party notice of its intention to withdraw, said notice being delivered to
the other party no later than one hundred eighty (180) days prior to the renewal of the 30th
day of June.
9. SPECIAL EVENTS
9A. In the event that the City, or an organization within the City, plans a "special" or
major event in the City, it shall notify the Sheriff at least three weeks, or twenty one (21)
days prior to the event. It is the City's burden, responsibility and expense to determine
the need for extra security personnel and employ the needed security personnel to be
present at a "special" or major event. The City shall be liable for all actions of the extra
security personnel and shall hold harmless, defend and indemnify the County for all acts
of the extra security personnel so employed by the City.
1.
A "special" or major event is defined as an event whether indoors or
outdoors, that is held on public property or streets, non-profit organization
property, or non-residential private property that can reasonably be expected
to cause a public gathering that is not part of the normal course of business or
pedestrian traffic at the location.

1.

shall be filed within thirty days of the effective date of the amendment,

10B. Additionally, upon execution of this Agreement, both the County and City shall

RESOLUTION APPROVING AN AGREEMENT WITH THE CLINTON
COMMUNITY SCHOOL DISTRICT FOR SCHOOL RESOURCE OFFICERS
WHEREAS, the City of Clinton and the Clinton Community School District have
maintained a contractual relationship for more than twenty years regarding School
Resource Officers; and
WHEREAS, the current agreement expires July 31, 2016, and both parties wish to
renew the agreement; and
WHEREAS, the Clinton Community School District has agreed to amend the cost
distribution from the current split of fifty percent to each party to fifty-five percent to be
paid by the School District and forty-five percent to be paid by the City for a term of five
years to commence on August 1, 2016 and end on July 31, 2021;

and City Clerk are directed to execute said Agreement.

AGREEMENT FOR
SCHOOL RESOURCE OFFICER PROGRAM
This Agreement is made between the Clinton Community School District ("the District") and the
City of Clinton, Iowa ("the City").
ARTICLE I: AUTHORITY
This Agreement to create a School Resource Officer ("SRO") program is executed pursuant to
Chapter 28E of the Code of Iowa.
This Agreement is between two public agencies.  No separate entity for administration
of this Agreement will be created.
This Agreement will be filed in the Office of the Secretary of State.
ARTICLE II: PURPOSE
Section I. Purpose. The purpose of this Agreement is to establish a working relationship
between the District and the City whereby the Clinton Police Department will provide to the District
two (2) uniformed sworn peace officers to work as SROs in the schools. These SROs will handle all
necessary law enforcement matters in the schools, including investigation of crime, arrests, truancy,
delinquency, school rule violations and similar issues. This Agreement will enhance communication
and cooperation between school administrators and teachers, law enforcement officers, students,
parents, service providers, and the community.
ARTICLE III: ADMINISTRATION
Section 1, Collaborative Administration. The Superintendent of Schools or designee
and the Chief of Police or designee will collaborate to administer and implement this
Agreement.
Section 2. Finance/Budget. Budgeting will continue in the same collaborative manner
as historically followed by the parties. Funding for the SRO program will be shared by the
District and the City. Grant funding obtained by either party will first be applied to the total cost of
the program.
The remaining budgeted amount will be funded 55% by the District and 45% by the
A.
City.
The District will reimburse the City monthly for the District's share of the SRO
B.
Program expenses, including pay and benefits of the SROs and other documented
reasonable costs associated with the program, including but not limited to vehicle
costs and maintenance. Said monthly expenses will be funded 55% by the District
and 45% by the City.
Section 3. Duration.
Term. This Agreement will commence on August 1, 2016 and will, unless sooner
A.
terminated by the terms of this Agreement, end on July 31, 2021.
B.
Renewal. This Agreement may be renewed only by written extension executed by
the parties. The District and the City agree to meet and confer regarding extension of
this Agreement by November 1, 2020, in order to allow sufficient time to complete
grant applications and the budget process prior to an anticipated extension.
C.
Termination. This Agreement will be terminated:
(1) Upon expiration of the stated term or any extension thereof; or
2
(2) Upon material breach of the terms of this Agreement by either
party; provided, however, that before any such termination, the party
alleging material breach will provide 120 days' written notice of intent
to terminate the agreement and specifying the factual matters which
constitute grounds for termination. The Agreement may then be
terminated upon failure of the defaulting party to remedy the default
within 120 days after receipt of such notice.
Section 4. Selection of School Resource Officers.
Two full-time SROs will be selected and assigned.
A.
B.
All SROs will be sworn Clinton police officers certified by the Iowa
Law
Enforcement Academy and:
have a minimum of three years' law enforcement experience;
(i)
have working knowledge of child welfare and the juvenile
(ii)
justice system; and
have working knowledge of community human services.
(iii)
A bachelor’s degree in a related field is desirable.
C.
D.
The Chief of Police or designee will select proposed police officers for
SRO assignment in consultation with and subject to the approval of the
Superintendent of Schools or the Superintendent's designee. The
Superintendent or designee will participate in applicant interviews and
other phases of the selection process.
E.
SRO will be assigned for a minimum of three years, unless
reassigned as provided in this Agreement. Parties agree that a
minimum period of SRO assignment is desirable to maximize the
benefits of the program by recouping the investment in training,
experience and established relationships.
During the first year any new SRO is assigned, the officer will
F.
successfully complete the National Association of School Resource
Officers Training Program.
3
Section 5. Reassignment of SROs.
During the first ninety (90) days of an SRO's assignment to the SRO
A.
program, the District, the City, or the SRO may request reassignment. Under
this circumstance, the Chief of Police will immediately assign a replacement
SRO, subject to paragraph III, 4., D above.
B.
In the event the District believes an SRO is not effectively performing his or
her duties and responsibilities, the Superintendent or designee and Chief of
Police or designee will consult and take appropriate actions to resolve
identified performance deficiencies. If the matter is not resolved by informal
action, the Superintendent or designee may approach the School Board to
formally request removal of the SRO. If the Board approves, a written
request stating the reasons for the requested removal will be provided to the
City pursuant to Article V, Section 5. In the event of such a request, the
Superintendent and District representatives will meet with the Chief of Police,
the SRO, and other City representatives in an effort to mediate or resolve the
issue. If, within a reasonable time after commencing such mediation, the issue
is not resolved, the SRO will be removed from the program and a
replacement will be assigned pursuant to paragraph III., 4., D above.
C.
In the event the City believes an SRO is not effectively performing law
enforcement functions under this Agreement, the Chief of Police or designee
and the Superintendent or designee will informally consult in an effort to
allow the City to resolve the identified law enforcement performance
deficiencies. If the matter is not resolved by informal action, the Chief of
Police may reassign the SRO and replace the SRO pursuant to paragraph III.,
4., D above.
D.
If an SRO is promoted to a higher rank during the course of an assignment, the
Chief of Police, after consultation with the Superintendent, may reassign the
promoted SRO provided the City makes a good faith effort to implement the
reassignment at the completion of the school year in progress at the time of the
promotion. In the event of reassignment of a promoted SRO, a replacement
SRO will be assigned pursuant to paragraph III., 4., D above.
4
In the event of a vacancy in an SRO position or in the case of a long-term
E.
absence, a replacement SRO will be assigned pursuant to paragraph
III., 4., D above.
Section 6. District Evaluation of SROs. The Superintendent or designee
may evaluate each SRO's performance of school-related duties under this
Agreement and provide the Chief of Police with a written evaluation on or before
March 15 of each year of the Agreement. The District's evaluation may be
utilized by the Chief of Police or designee for use in a comprehensive evaluation
of an SRO's performance,
Section 7. City Employees. SROs will, for all legal intents and purposes, be full-
time employees of the City and not the School District. Any terms or conditions of
employment between the City and the SRO will be consistent with the terms of this
Agreement.
Section 8. Job Description. The job description relative to the SRO assignment is
attached to this Agreement as Exhibit "A." It may be modified from time to time by
agreement between the District and the City.
Section 9. Overtime Work and Pay. The Superintendent or designee and Chief of Police
or designee will consult and agree on assignments which result in SROs working overtime.
Overtime compensation will be paid 55% by the District and the 45% by the City. Overtime
hours resulting from law enforcement services unrelated to those provided under this Agreement
will be paid solely by the City. Overtime at school functions outside of regular school hours
which are not stipulated by the parties to be shared will be paid 100% by the District.
Section 10. Assignment of Duties. Hours, and Locations of Work. The
Superintendent or designee and Chief of Police or designee will develop a work
schedule for SROs detailing the locations of work, hours of work at various locations,
and duties to be performed at various locations. Such schedules will account for
school holidays, vacations, and times when school is not in session.
It is preferred that SRO vacation time be taken during school vacations, holidays, or
times when school is not in session. However, the decision to grant SRO vacation time when
school is in session will remain solely in the discretion of the Chief of Police, and the parties
recognize this may be necessary and advisable from time to time. The parties will strive to
minimize the effect of the SRO's absence.
Section 11, Law Enforcement Functions. The District and the City acknowledge and
agree that SROs will from time to time perform duties and responsibilities which under this
Agreement which are strictly law enforcement in nature. In such instances, the SRO and the
City will have sole discretion to determine means and methods of performing and
implementing such law enforcement functions.
Section 12. Confidentiality, The parties acknowledge that SROs will from time to time
acquire confidential information concerning the District, students, and others. It is agreed that
such information or records will be kept confidential by the SROs in accordance with school
policy, Chapter 22 of the Iowa Code, FERPA, and such other federal, state and local laws
which may be applicable.
ARTICLE IV: INSURANCE
Section 1. Worker's Compensation Insurance, The City acknowledges that all services
performed by SROs under this Agreement will be as City employees. The SROs will be swom
police officers who are members of the statewide retirement system for police officers created by
Chapter 411 of the Code of lowa. Coverage for all claims for injury or death to police officers
arising from the performance of SRO services under this Agreement will be provided by the
police retirement system under Chapter 411 and state and federal guidelines for line of duty
death.
Section 2. Liability and Other Insurance. The City agrees to provide liability and all
other appropriate insurance coverage for the City and the City's employees to cover claims for
damage to property or for personal injury, including death, made by any person that may arise
from the performance of SRO duties by the City and its employees under this Agreement. The
City will not provide liability coverage or other insurance coverage for the District and its
employees.
Section 3. Indemnification. The City will indemnify the District against all liability, loss,
or claims or actions based on or arising out of damage or injury, including death, to persons or
property caused solely by the City or its employees in performance of SRO duties under this
Agreement.
The City will also indemnify the District against all liability and loss in connection
with, and will assume full responsibility for, payment of all federal, state, and local taxes or
contributions imposed or required under unemployment insurance, social security, and
income tax laws with respect to the SROs employed by the City to provide SRO services
under this Agreement.
6
ARTICLE V: MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS
Section 1. Entirety of Agreement and Modification. This document and its referenced Exhibit A is the
entire Agreement between the parties. None of the tems and provisions of this Agreement may be modified,
waived, or abandoned except by written agreement of the parties.
Section 2. Governing Law. This Agreement will be construed under the laws of the State
of Iowa.
Section 3. Binding Effect. This Agreent is binding upon the parties and their respective successors
and assigns.
Section 4. Rights Cumulative. The rights, powers, options, elections, and remedies of either party
provided in this Agreement will be construed as curnulative and not as exclusive of the others, or exclusive of any
rights, remedies or priorities allowed either party by law. Further, this Agreement in no way affects or impairs
the ability of either party to pursue any other equitable or legal remedy to which either party may be entitled, so
long as any default remains in any manner unremedied, unsatisfied, or undischarged.
Section 5, Notice and Demands. Notices under this Agreement will be provided to the parties at:
Clinton Community School District:
Superintendent of Schools
Clinton Community School District
1401 12ª Avenue North Clinton, IA 52732
City of Clinton, Iowa:
Chief of Police
Clinton Police Department 113 641 Avenue
South

notifying a party in writing or making a demand or other communication, notice will be deemed given under the
terms of this Agreement when sent by certified mail, return receipt requested. Mailed notice will be deemed
given upon proper mailing. In addition, notice may be given by the manner of serving original notices,

any provision of this Agreement will not be construed as affecting any subsequent breach or the right to
require performance with respect thereto or to claim a breach with respect thereto.
Section 7. Severability. If any provision of this Agreement is determined by a court of competent
jurisdiction to be invalid or unenforceable, such determination will not affect the validity or enforceability
of any other part or provision of this Agreement.
Section 8. Authorization. The parties represent and warrant to the other that they have the authority to

JOB DESCRIPTION FOR SCHOOL RESOURCE OFFICER
PURSUANT TO AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE CLINTON COMMUNITY
SCHOOL DISTRICT AND THE CITY OF CLINTON, IOWA
PERFORMANCE RESPONSIBILITIES:
1.
Act as liaison between the law enforcement community and
School administration
Parents
Teachers
Juvenile Court Services
Department of Human Services
Area Education Association
County Attorney
Women's Health Services
Lutheran Social Services
Mental Health Center
New Directions
Court System
Other Intervention, Counseling and Health Care Services
2.
Member of the prevention/intervention strategies team.
3.
Inform appropriate school officials and staff of current police involvement with
students and/or students' families.
4.
Investigate all cases involving students as victims or suspects in criminal activity
except cases normally handled by a specialized unit.
5.
Perform preventive patrol for students en route to or from school.
Take appropriate action for on-sight occurrences including but not limited to:
6.
Fights
Disorderly Conduct
Vandalism
Narcotics Offenses
Theft
Weapons Violations
Motor Vehicle Accidents
Unauthorized Persons on School Property
Traffic Violations
Other Occurences as Appropriate
7.
Serve as truancy officer to assist in the prevention and processing of truants.
8.
Interact with Operations, Services, and Criminal Investigations Divisions on
matters of mutual concern including but not limited to:
EXHIBIT "A"
Sex Offenses
Indecent Exposures
Suspicious Persons
Gang Activity
Traffic Hazards
Other matters as appropriate
9.
Attend school staff meetings and training as appropriate.
10.
Act as resource person to school staff and students and provide short-term
programs on law enforcement or public safety related topics.
11.
Attend school-sponsored extra-curricular activities such as:
Sporting Events
Dances
Assemblies
Concerts
Field Trips
Others
12.
Interact with students to promote and reinforce basic life skills, self control, and
accountability in areas of:
Resolving conflict without violence
Problem solving
Peer pressure
Interpersonal skills
Have working knowledge of School Board policies, Administrative Regulations,
13.
and Student Handbook.
14.
Other:
Hours and workdays will be determined by building schedule and extra-
A.
curricular activities.
School administrators shall be involved in selection of SROs.
B.
15.
Perform such other duties as are from time to time assigned by the School District
and the Police Department.
16.
Be familiar with police case information pertaining to schools, students, and the
neighborhood surrounding school campuses.
The SRO will encourage individual and group discussions about law enforcement
17.
related matters with students, faculty, and parents.
18.
Whenever possible and within budgetary constraints, the SRO will attend
mectings of the District's parent and faculty groups to solicit their support and
understanding of the SRO program and to promote awareness of law enforcement
functions. The SRO will attend meetings of the District's Board of Directors
when requested to do so.
19.
The SRO shall not utilize his/her position for personal advancement or preference
and shall conduct himself?herself in such a manner to bring credit to the Clinton
Police Department and District.
The SRO and school personnel shall confer when appropriate to develop plans and
20.
strategies to provide for counseling of at risk students and those students who
present a problem.
21.
The SRO shall assist school personnel in developing plans and strategies to
prevent and/or minimize dangerous situations which may occur on campus or
during school sponsored events.
22.
The SRO shall take law enforcement action as required. As soon as practicable,
the SRO shall make the District aware of such action. At the Superintendent or
designee's request, the SRO shall take appropriate law enforcement action against
intruders and unwanted guests who may appear at the school and school-related
functions, to the extent that the SRO may do so under the authority of law.
Whenever practicable, the SRO should advise the District before requesting
additional police assistance on campus.
23.
The SRO will be available for conferences with students, parents, and faculty
members in order to assist them with problems with law enforcement or in matters
of crime prevention.
24.
Information obtained during SRO activities shall be kept confidential in
accordance with federal, state, and local laws.
25.
When necessary, the SRO shall give assistance to other police officers in matters
regarding his/her school assignment. However, the SRO will not be available to
conduct investigations extraneous to his/her assigned SRO responsibilities or those
of school activities when the SRO's presence is needed elsewhere for the sake of
convenience or expediency without prior approval from the Superintendent or
designee.
By mutual agreement between the Superintendent or designee and the Chief of
26.
Police or designee, the SRO will, in accordance with established overtime
procedures, as limited by the overtime budget, participate in and/or attend school
functions.
The SRO will become familiar with community agencies that offer assistance to
27.
youth and their families such as, mental health clinics, drug treatment centers and
protective shelters. However, the SRO will make no referrals to such agencies
without previous consultation with appropriate school administration.
Generally, the SROs will work in uniform attire and shall carry a regulation
28.
sidearm in accordance with Department Guidelines.
29.
The SRO shall perform other duties as mutually agreed upon by the
Superintendent or designee and the Chief of Police or designee so long as the
performance of such duties is reasonably related to the SRO program.
END OF JOB DESCRIPTION
