Law Enforcement Contract Between
Tama County and Garwin, Iowa
This contract is made and entered into this 18 day of July, 2013 by and between
the County of Tama and the Town of Garwin, lowa, hereinafter referred to as the
"Municipality". The Municipality desires to contract for Law Enforcement services
with Tama County Law Enforcement.  The County is agreeable to rendering such
services on terms and conditions hereinafter set forth.  Such contracts are
authorized and provided for by the provisions of the Code of lowa, Chapter 28E.
1.  Obligation of County
.
The County agrees through the Sheriff of Tama County to provide
police protection within the corporate limits of the Municipality.
which services shall encompass the duties and functions of the type
customarily rendered by professional law enforcement officers
including the enforcement of State Statutes, and Municipal
Ordinances.
•
The Sheriff's Office will attempt to provide a minimum of 60 hours
per month of law enforcement coverage.  The Sheriff's Office will
provide a car and officer for all other police assistance requested
in the Town of Garwin if the officers assigned to the Garwin area
are not otherwise available.
The Sheriff's Office shall make monthly reports to the Mayor.
.
Reports shall include a summary of the enforcement activity
conducted by the Sheriff's Department within the Municipality, and
interim reports on other matters not considered routine criminal
matters.
Either the number of hours or units (car-patrolman) may be
.
increased or decreased, with adjustments being made for the cost
of said service by mutual agreement of the parties. It is anticipated
by the parties that emergencies may arise in the County, which
may necessitate the withdrawal of the unit or units from the Town
of Garwin.
.
It is agreed the Municipality will share the service of the Tama
County Sheriff's Office with other towns in surrounding areas of the
County only in the case of emergency. Officers shall, where
applicable, file charges under municipal ordinances, but if the
town has no ordinance, the charge may be filed under the
applicable state statute.  The Officers will appear to testify in
those cases in which they are witnesses, without requiring
subpoenas and the city will provide legal counseling and
prosecution of ordinances as request by the officer.
2. Control of Deputy
The discipline of Officers, matters incident to performance of
.
enforcement services, and control of personnel so employed, shall
remain in the County.
3. 24 Hour Coverage
The Municipality agrees that it shall not hold Tama County
•
responsible for providing exclusive continuous surveillance for any
24-hour period unless the threat of crime so dictates.
4. Cooperation
To facilitate the performance of said functions, it is hereby agreed
.
that the County shall have full cooperation and assistance from the
Municipality, it's officers, agent and employees.
The County agrees to accept the operating and maintenance costs
•
of equipment for the period of the contract.
5. Liabilities
.
The Municipality shall not be called upon to assume any liability for the
personnel performing services hereunder for said Municipality of any
liability other than provides for in the contract. The Municipality shall not
be liable for compensation or indemnity to any County employee for injury
or sickness arising out of his employment and the County hereby agrees to
hold harmless the Municipality against such claim.
.
Tama County, it's officers and employees, shall not be deemed to assume
any liability for intentional or negligent acts of said Municipality or it's
officers or employees thereof, said Municipality shall hold such County and
it's officers and employees harmless from and shall defend said County and
it's officers end employees against any claim for damages resulting
therefrom.
The Municipality shall not be responsible for any act, injury or damage
•
arising out of the performance of this contract by the County of Tama, and
in case claim is made by any third party, the County shall defend,
indemnify and hold harmless the Municipality.
6. Payment
The Municipality agrees to pay the County monthly the sum of
•
$1,042.00 per month. Subject to an increase or decrease as the
parties mutually agree, if the services contracted for in Paragraph
.
1 hereof are mutually changed. It is contemplated that this
contract shall be effective July 1,2013 and shall run for a period of
12 months thereafter.
7. Duration of Contract
At the option of the governing body of the Municipality, with the
•
consent of the Board of County Supervisors of Tama County this
contract shall be renewable for successive periods not to exceed 12
months. In the event the Municipality desires not to renew this
contract for any succeeding period, the governing body of the
Municipality, not later than 60 days before the expiration date of
this contract shall notify the Board of County Supervisors in writing
that it wished not to renew the same, whereupon the Board of
County Supervisors not later than 30 days shall notify in writing the
governing body of the Municipality of it's willingness to accept the
termination. Otherwise, the contract shall automatically renew.
•
Notwithstanding the provision of the paragraph set forth, either
party may terminate this contract as of the first day of any month,
upon notice in writing to the other party not less than 60 days prior
to the date of termination.
•
It is agreed that in the event the Municipality terminates this
agreement, the Municipality shall provide continuing employment 
to the Deputy employed by the Sheriff's Department as a result of
this agreement.
8. Access to Records
Both parties mutually agree to allow access to records, documents.
.
and papers to auditors representing the lowa Crime Commission,
the LEAA or the Comptroller's Office.
9. Non-Discrimination
Both parties mutually agree that if the contract price exceeds $10,
•
000.00, then the parties assure that an affirmative action plan
declaring no discrimination on the basis or race, religion, creed,
national origin, sex or age will be implemented.
10. Review and Complaint
The Sheriff of Tama County or his designee agrees to meet, from
•
time to time, with the Mayor of Garwin to review logs and works of
the Sheriff's Department in the Municipality.  Any complaints,
requests of discretionary police matters shall be directed to the
Sheriff.
11. Police Telephone
The Municipality shall list as the local police telephone number the
.
number of the County Sheriff's Office in Toledo.
12. Disputes, Appeals and Remedies
Except as otherwise provided in this agreement, any dispute
.
concerning a question of fact arising under this agreement which is
not disposed of by agreement shall be decided by the County which
shall reduce such decision to writing and furnish a copy to the
Municipality. Such decision shall be final and conclusive unless
within thirty (30) days from the receipt the Municipality notifies
the County in writing the nature and extent that the Municipality
disagrees with the decision. The cause(s) of disagreement shall
then be submitted to a mutually agreed upon third party arbitrator
for decision.  Either party, if still dissatisfied, may then appeal the
decision of the arbitrator in the procedure appeal followed in a
court of competent jurisdiction. The parties agree that this
agreement shall be governed by the laws of the State of lowa.
This contract is hereby entered into by the following
authorized agents of the parties.
Mayor City of)Garwin
Sheriff Dennis P. Kucera
Tama County Supervisor

AGREEMENT
BETWEEN THE CITY OF BOYDEN, IOWA AND SIOUX COUNTY, IOWA
RELATING TO THE PROVISION OF LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES
THIS AGREEMENT, consisting of two (2) pages, is made between the City of Boyden,
Iowa, a municipality of the State of Iowa (hereinafter "Boyden") and Sioux County,
Iowa (hereinafter "County").
WHEREAS, Boyden wishes to contract with County for law enforcement services
within the corporate limits of Boyden; and
WHEREAS such Agreements are authorized in Iowa Code §28E;
NOW THEREFORE, Boyden and County agree as follows:
1) County agrees, through the Sioux County Sheriff ("Sheriff") to provide law
enforcement services within the corporate limits of Boyden, including but not limited
to the following:
a) Patrol, traffic enforcement and control, response to complaints or calls,
investigations, emergency service, service of civil documents, and other tasks
typically performed by a law enforcement agency.
b) Sheriff shall be responsible for administrative duties associated with the function
of said law enforcement services.
2) County shall furnish the necessary equipment and personnel to carry out the services
provided for in this agreement.
l
3) Boyden agrees to pay County for the law enforcement services provided by Sheriff.
The payment shall be in an amount to be determined by the Sheriff and the Board of
Supervisors of Sioux County as is necessary to carry out the law enforcement
functions stated in this agreement. Such payments shall be made to the Sheriff's
Office on a quarterly basis, payable as follows: July 1, 2009; October 1, 2009;
January 1, 2010; April 1, 2010. The total amount for this contract period has been
set at: $65,791.
4) This Agreement shall be irrevocable for the duration of the contract period.
Thereafter either party may discontinue participation by providing written notice to
the other no later than May 18t of the current year.
5) This agreement shall be effective on the 1st day of July, 2009 and shall run to the 18t
day of July 2010. Thereafter, at the option of the Boyden City Council, and the
Sioux County Board of Supervisors, with the consent of the Sheriff of Sioux County,
this agreement may be renewable for successive periods not to exceed one (1) year.
APPROVED by the Boyden, Iowa City Council.

28E AGREEMENT
FOR THE ADMINISTRATION/MANAGEMENT
OF WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT IN REGIONS 2, 3&4, 5
This 28E Agreement (Agreement) is made and entered into this 1st day of July, 2013, and 
ending on July 31, 2013, by and between the lowa Workforce Development (IWD) and North 
lowa Area Community College (NIACC). The parties agree as follows:
Section 1.
Purpose. The purpose of this Agreement is to establish roles and
responsibilities for district leadership staff in Regions 2, 3&4, and 5, and to 
provide for the employment and terms of employment of the District Manager.
Section 1.1
Identity of the Parties: Iowa Workforce Development (IWD), which is a duly
created state department, is authorized, among other things, to provide and fund
workforce development programs. IWD's state administrative address is 1000
East Grand Avenue, Des Moines, lowa 50319. North lowa Area Community
College (NIACC) is authorized among other things, to provide and fund workforce
development programs. NIACC's address is 500 College Drive, Mason City, IA
50401. This Agreement does not create any separate legal or administrative
entities.
Section 2.
Responsibilities of Parties.
2.1
NIACC shall provide administration/management services for IWD employees
located at the Mason City Workforce Development Center in Region 2, and
oversight of agency operations in Regions 3&4 (Spencer) and 5 (Fort Dodge).
These services will be provided by the District Manager, who shall be employed
by NIACC. The District Manager shall provide all administrative/management
services in accordance with all applicable federal, state, local laws and
regulations, merit system rules, and collective bargaining agreement rules and
practices. (See attachment A for complete list of documents currently included in 
all Regional and PROMISE JOBS Master Agreements.)
2.2.
Policy guidelines for Workforce Development Center operations in Mason City 
will be jointly agreed upon by appropriate NIACC and IWD representatives and 
will comply with applicable personnel and labor relations policies of both entities.
2.3
In the absence of the District Manager, and appropriate IWD Regional Managers,
personnel issues involving IWD employees which require the involvement of IWD
administration will be the responsibility of the Division Administrator for the
Workforce Services Division or their Designee.
2.4
NIACC shall permit the District Manager to participate in staff development,
training, and management meetings required by IWD.
2.5
NIACC shall be responsible for the payment of the District Manager's salary and
personnel benefits according to its existing policies. NIACC shall be solely
responsible for the payment of all applicable federal and state withholding taxes
and social security taxes.  Additionally, NIACC shall carry a policy of workers
compensation, and at its sole expense, employer's liability insurance for the
Region 2 28e District Manager July 2013
Page 1 of 12
District Manager to the extent and in the amounts required by law.  NIACC, at its
sole expense, shall pay all unemployment compensation taxes for the District
Manager to the extent and in the amounts required by law.  All fringe benefits
provided the District Manager will be in accordance with NIACC policy.
2.6
Selection, annual evaluation and termination of the District Manager will be within
the joint discretion of NIACC and IWD. IWD shall provide NIACC with its
comments concerning potential candidates for the District Manager's position
and shall annually provide NIACC with its comments concerning the performance
of the District Manager in order to assist NIACC with its annual evaluation.
NIACC will notify IWD when the annual evaluation is being developed, a deadline
for IWD comment submission, and a signed copy of the completed evaluation for 
IWD records.
2.7
IWD shall provide staff development and training services to ensure the District 
Manager is knowledgeable of IWD practices, procedures, and policies.
2.8
IWD will pay NIACC for the services provided in this Agreement as set forth in
Section 4.
Section 3.
The Workforce Development Center District Manager.
3.1
The District Manager shall, at all times, be considered the employee of NIACC and 
not an employee of IWD. (See attachment B for District Manager job description.)
3.2
The District Manager shall consult with the Workforce Services Division
Administrator or their Designee and the Department of Administrative Services
(DAS) personnel officer assigned to IWD before taking any disciplinary action 
against any IWD employee.  Joint review by both the District Manager and the
Workforce Services Division Administrator or their Designee will precede any
performance appraisal and related action for any IWD employee.
When notifying NIACC of any annual or sick leave requests, the District Manager
3.3
shall also inform the Workforce Services Division Administrator or their Designee.
3.4
The District Manager shall attend all regularly scheduled meetings of the IWD
district managers, as well as any other required meeting called by the Workforce
Services Administrator or their Designee. The District Manager will inform the
Workforce Services Administrator or their Designee of conflicts that may prohibit
attendance.
Section 4.
Compensation.
IWD will pay NIACC the lesser of:
(a) 
54% of the District Manager's "salary expense," or
(b) 
54% of the highest step of a Public Service Executive 4 classification plus
54% of any additional items included in the definition of salary expense below
which are not included as part of the Public Service Executive 4 classification.
Region 2 28e District Manager July 2013
Page 2 of 12
"Salary expense" includes base salary, payroll taxes, unemployment insurance and
worker's compensation insurance premiums, fringe benefits, travel, and per diem 
but does not include bonuses that may be received by the District Manager for
work at NIACC.
For the purposes of this agreement, IWD will reimburse travel and per diem 
expenses at only the rate which is used by the employer of record, in this case
NIACC.
IWD will pay NIACC on a monthly basis in, arrears.  "Salary expense" shall be that
actually paid or incurred by NIACC. NIACC will provide a monthly invoice of the
District Manager’s salary expense to the WDCA Division Administrator or their
Designee for approval prior to payment. IWD will provide said approval to NIACC
within 15 days of receipt.
Any percentage increase in the base salary in excess of the percentage increase
for a Public Service Executive 4 classification shall be as agreed between NIACC
and IWD.
All out-of-state travel to be reimbursed by IWD must have prior approval by the
Workforce Services Division Administrator or their Designee, and the Director,
using the "Request for Travel Authority-Out of State Travel" form.
NIACC shall maintain books, records and documents which sufficiently and
properly document and calculate all charges billed to IWD throughout the term of
this Agreement for a period of at least five (5) years following the date of final
payment or completion of any required audit, whichever is later.
NIACC shall permit the Auditor of the State of lowa or any authorized
representative of the State or Department; and where federal funds are involved.
the Comptroller General of the United States or any other authorized
representative of the United States government; to access and examine, audit,
excerpt and transcribe any directly pertinent books, documents, papers, electronic
or optically stored and created records or other records of NIACC relating to
orders, invoices, or payments or any other documentation or materials pertaining to 
this Agreement. NIACC shall not impose a charge for audit or examination of the
books and records.
Effective Date of Agreement.  This Agreement shall be effective when the
Section 5.
following conditions are completed:
5.1
The Agreement is signed by IWD and NIACC.
5.2
The Agreement or a recordable form of this Agreement is recorded by the Polk and
Cerro Gordo County Recorders.
5.3
The Agreement is filed with lowa Secretary of State.
 Region 2 28e District Manager July 2013
Page 3 of 12
Section 6.
Term of Agreement.  This Agreement shall be in effect beginning July 1, 2013,
and ending July 31, 2013. This Agreement may be terminated at any time, by
either party, and for any reason.
Section 7.
Termination.  This Agreement may be terminated in any of the following
circumstances:
a)  At IWD or NIACC discretion, without cause, by either party, for any reason
or no reason.
b) As a result of default under this Agreement.
c)  As a result of the termination or reduction of funding to IWD.
d)  Due to bankruptcy, insolvency, or receivership.
Section 8.
Authorization.  Each party to this Agreement represents and warrants to the other
that (1) it has the right, power, and authority to enter into and perform its
obligations under this Agreement; and (2) it has taken all requisite action
(corporate, statutory, or otherwise) to approve execution, deliver, and performance
of this Agreement, and this Agreement constitutes a legal, valid, and binding
obligation upon itself in accordance with its terms.
The President of North Iowa Area Community College, or their Designee, and the 
IWD Administrator of the Division of Workforce Services will be responsible for
administration of this Agreement.
Section 9.
Default.
9.1
The occurrence of any one or more of the following events shall constitute cause 
for IWD or NIACC to declare the other party in default of its obligations under this
Agreement:
a) Non-performance of this Agreement.
b) A failure of either party to make substantial and timely progress toward
performance of the Agreement.
c) A failure of either party's work product and services to conform with any
specifications noted herein.
d)  A repeated exhibition of defects in the services delivered by either party,
causing serious disruption of use or downtime over a six month period.
e) A breach of provisions related to intellectual property.
f) A failure to make payments required under section 4.
g) A breach of any term of this Agreement.
9.2
NIACC or IWD shall not be considered to be in default under this
Agreement if its performance is delayed or made impossible by an Act of God,
floods, fires, strikes, a freight embargo or similar events; but in each such case, the
delay or impossibility must go beyond the reasonable control and without the fault
of NIACC or IWD. In event of such delay, the scheduled date of delivery
shall be extended on a day-to-day basis until delivery of performance is possible
and feasible.
9.3
NIACC shall not be liable for indirect, special, or consequential damages
resulting from a breach of this Agreement.
Region 2 28e District Manager July 2013
Page 4 of 12
9.4
Notice of Default. IWD or NIACC shall issue a written notice of default
providing therein a sixty (60) day period in which the other party shall have an
opportunity to cure, provided that cure is possible and feasible. If, after opportunity
to cure, the default remains, IWD or NIACC may do one of the following:
a) Exercise any remedy provided by law.
b) Terminate this Agreement as set forth in Section 7 of this Agreement.
Section 10.
Waiver. Except as specifically provided for in a waiver signed by duly authorized
representatives of IWD and NIACC, failure by either party at anytime to require
performance by the other party or to claim a breach of any provision of the
Agreement shall not be construed as affecting any subsequent breach or the right
to require performance with respect thereto or claim a breach with respect thereto.
Section 11.
Notices.  Notices under this Agreement shall be in writing and delivered to the
representative of the party to receive notice (identified below) at the address of the
party stated below:
If to IWD:
lowa Workforce Development
Attention: Director Teresa Wahlert
1000 East Grand Avenue
Des Moines, IA 50319
If to NIACC:
North Iowa Area Community College
Attention: Interim President Dr. David Buettner
500 College Drive
Mason City, IA 50401
The effective date for any notice under this Agreement shall be the date of the
delivery of such notice:
(a)
By personal delivery; or
By certified U.S. Mail, return receipt requested, with postage paid thereon
(b) 
(and not the date of mailing).  Failure to "receipt" shall constitute delivery; or
By recognized overnight delivery service, such as Federal Express or UPS.
(c)
Section 12.
Indemnification.
12.1
Indemnification of IWD.  To the extent allowed by applicable constitutional and
statutory law (including without limitation lowa Code Chapter 670), NIACC agrees
to indemnify and hold IWD harmless from any and all liabilities, damages,
settlements, judgments, costs and expenses, including reasonable attorney's fees
of the lowa Attorney General's office, and the costs and expenses and reasonable
attorney's fees of other counsel IWD may retain, related to or arising from:
(a) 
Property damage, personal injury, death, loss costs, expense or other harm
arising out of, resulting from, relating to, or connected with, any act or
omission by NIACC, its divisions, subsidiaries, employees, agents, elected or
appointed officials, officers, and directors in fulfilling this Agreement; or
Region 2 28e District Manager July 2013

(b) 
Claims for infringement of patents, trademarks, trade secrets, or copyrights
arising from this Agreement.
Provided that NIACC accepts responsibility for Indemnification under this Section
12, NIACC, at its sole expense, shall be entitled to control the prosecution, defense
and settlement of, any proceeding, litigation or claim incident to any of the
foregoing with counsel of its own choosing and IWD will cooperate in connection 
with any such proceeding.
12.2
Indemnification of NIACC.  To the extent allowed by applicable constitutional and 
statutory law (including without limitation lowa Code Chapter 669), the State of
lowa shall indemnify NIACC under this Agreement, and its directors, officers,
elected and appointed officials, and employees for any claim, loss, liability, damage
or expense (including reasonable attorney's fees) which may be asserted against it
or them by a third party, by reason of any action taken or not taken by IWD in
connection with the Agreement, and which does not arise from the breach of this

(a) 
Conditions.  Any indemnification hereunder shall be subject to the prior

NIACC and the above-mentioned indemnified, shall at all times cooperate

(iii)
To the extent that NIACC is indemnified under this section, the State
shall have the right to hire and direct counsel in the defense of NIACC.
To the extent that NIACC is indemnified under this section, the State

shall, after consultation with NIACC, make all decisions regarding any

ATTACHMENT B
NORTH IOWA AREA COMMUNITY COLLEGE
JOB DESCRIPTION
TITLE:
District Manager
DIVISION: Workforce Development
CATEGORY/LEVEL:
PSS/4
BASIC FUNCTION: The Director is the chief administrative officer and responsible for the overall
operation and outreach efforts for Region 2 Workforce Development Partnership, and
will provide administrative oversight and leadership for IWD managers in Regions
3&4, and 5.
QUALIFICATIONS:
Bachelor of Arts or Bachelor of Science Degree required. Master's degree preferred.
Minimum of three years of acceptable related work experience, including a minimum
of one vear supervising professional staff. Experience should include successful
management skills, grant writing, program planning and budgeting, government
program or grant implementation and monitoring, contracting for services, and
working with a volunteer board. Preference for previous experience in Human
Services agency-type of organization. Excellent written and oral communication skills
required.
SUPERVISOR:
President, North Iowa Area Community College
RESPONSIBILITIES AND DUTIES:
1. Provide direct supervision for WIA staff, PJ team leader, Career Center Director, Economic
Developer, and IWD managers/supervisors.
2. Provide leadership in the development, delivery, and evaluation of programs and services as
outlined in WIA and PROMISE JOBS legislation, the Local Customer Service Plan and other
contracted services with the lowa Department of Workforce Development.
3. 
Supervise the preparation and delivery of the Local Customer Service Plan.
Provide administration/management services for IWD employees located at the Workforce
4.
Development Center and any satellite centers in Region 2.
6. 
Provide all administrative/management services in accordance with all applicable federal, state,
local laws and regulations, merit system rules, and collective bargaining agreement rules and
practices.
6. Prepare and monitor budgets; supervise financial and Management information System procedures
and reports.
7. Perform employer and client outreach by developing and maintaining linkages with area economic
development groups, businesses, and potential users of the Workforce Development Partnership
Services.
8. 
 Serve as Executive Director of the Regional Workforce Investment Board (RWIB) and the Chief
Elected Officials (CEO).
Organize, direct, and demonstrate, as needed, appropriate methods for serving WIA applicants,
9.
clients, employers, and vendors.
10. Maintain outreach efforts with prospective employers and clients, and other human service
agencies.
11. Coordinate and implement advertising and public relations program for outreach to, and recuilment
of, potential clients and employers.
Region 2 28e District Manager July 2013
Page 11 of 12
12. Promote cooperation among internal units of the College and external agencies and organizations
of Regions 2, 3&4, 5 and the State of Iowa
13. Provide advice and counsel to staff members on college policies and regulations and applicable
state and federal regulations and enforce compliance as required.
14. Make recommendations on staff selection, development and retention, or termination, and
supervise and evaluate assigned personnel.
15. Participate in professional organizations and maintain professional growth.
16. Advise NIACC president on activities within assigned areas.
17. Perform in a manner which strengthens the coordination and cooperation of all organizational
components of the College and One-Stop Workforce Development System and member
organizations.
 Region 2 28e District Manager July 2013

This 28E Agreement (Agreement) is made and entered into this 7th day of March,
2001, by and between the lowa Workforce Development (IWD) and Northeast lowa
Community College (NICC). The parties agree as follows:
Purpose. The purpose of this Agreement is to jointly select and find a
Section 1.
Regional Director for Workforce Development in Region One.
Responsibilities of Parties.
Section 2.
2.1
NICC shall provide administration/management services for IWD
employees located at the one Workforce Development Center and any
satellite centers in Region One. These services will be provided by a
Workforce Development Regional Director employed by NICC. NICC
shall provide all administrative/management services in accordance with
all applicable federal, state, local laws and regulations, merit system rules,
and collactive bargaining agreement rules and practices.
2.2
Policy guidelines for Workforce Development Center operations will be
jointly agreed upon by appropriate NICC representatives and IWD
representatives and will comply with applicable personnel and labor
relations policies of both entities.
2.3
In the absence of the Regional Director, personnel issues involving IWD
employees which require the involvement of IWD administration will be the
responsibility of the IWD State Employment and Training Coordinator.
2.4
NICC shall permit the Regional Director to participate in staff
development, training, and management meetings required by IWD.
2.5
NICC shall be responsible for the payment of the Regional Director's
salary and personnel benefits according to its existing policies. NICC
shall be solely responsible for the payment of all applicable federal and
state withholding taxes and social security taxes. Additionally, NICC, at
sole expense, shall carry a policy of workers compensation and
employer's liability insurance for the Regional Director to the extent and in
the amounts required by law. NICC, at its sole expense, shall pay all
unemployment compensation required by law. All fringe benefits provided
the Regional Director will be in accordance with NICC policy.
2.6
Selection, annual evaluation and termination of the Regional Director w
be jointly determined by NICC and IWD.
.
2.7
IWD shail provide staff development and training services to ensure the
Regional Director is knowledgeable of IWD practices, procedures, and
policies.
2.8
IWD will pay NICC for the services provided in this Agreement as set forth
in Section 4.
The Workforce Development Center Regional Director.
Section 3.
3.1
The Regional Director shall, at all times, be considered the employee of
NICC and not an employee of IWD.
3.2
The Regional Director shall consult with the State Employment and
Training Coordinator and the Administrator of Employee Services Bureau
of IWD before taking any disciplinary action against any IWD employee.
Joint review by both the Regional Director and the IWD Employment and
Training Coordinator will precede any performance appraisal and related
action for any IWD employee.
Compensation.
Section 4.
IWD will pay NICC the lesser of:
(a) One-half of the Regional Director's "salary expense," or
(b) One-half of the highest step of a Public Service Executive 2
classification.
*Salary expense" includes base salary, payroll taxes, unemployment
insurance and worker's compensation insurance premiums, fringe
benefits, travel, and per diem but does not include bonuses that may be
received by the Regional Director for work at NICC.
IWD will pay NICC on a monthly basis in arrears. "Salary expense" shall
be that actually paid or incurred by NICC.
Any percentage increase in the base salary in excess of the percentage
increase for a Public Service Executive 2 classification shall be as agreed
between NICC and IWD.
Section 5.
Effective Date of Agreement. This Agreement shall be effective when
the following conditions are completed:
5.1
The Agreement is signed by IWD and NICC.
The Agreement or a recordable form of this Agreement is recorded by the
5.2
Polk and Winneshiek County Recorders.

The Agreement is filed with lowa Secretary of State.

effective date in Section 5 until its terminated in accordance with the terms
of this Agreement. This Agreement may be terminated at any time, by
either party, for any reason upon at least ninety (90) days written notice in
advance of the specified termination date.

written notice. If an appropriation to cover the costs of the Agreement
becomes available within sixty (60) days subsequent to termination under
this section, IWD agrees to reenter this Agreement on the same
provisions, terms, and conditions.

28E AGREEMENT
FOR THE ADMINISTRATION/MANAGEMENT
OF WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT IN REGION 13
This 28E Agreement (Agreement) is made and entered into this 2 day of December, 2009,
and ending on June 30, 2010, by and between the lowa Workforce Development (IWVD) and 
Iowa Western Community College (IWCC). The parties agree as follows:
Purpose. The purpose of this Agreement is to establish a procedure for hiring
Section 1.
Co-Regional Area Coordinators in Region 13 and to provide for the employment
and terms of employment of the Co-Regional Area Coordinators.
Section 1.1
Identity of the Parties: Iowa Workforce Development (IWD), which is a duly
created state department, is authorized, among other things, to provide and fund
workforce development programs. IWD's state administrative address is 1000
East Grand Avenue, Des Moines, Iowa 50319. Iowa Western Community College
is authorized among other things, to provide and fund workforce development
programs. IWCC's address is 2700 College Road, Council Bluffs, IA 51503-1057
This Agreement does not create any separate legal or administrative parties or
entities.
Responsibilities of Parties.
Section 2.
iWCC and IWD will cooperate in development and management of an integrated
2.1
workforce delivery system in the Council Bluffs Workforce Development Center
and any satellite centers in Region 13. These services will be overseen by Co-
Regional Area Coordinators, who shall be employed by IWCC and IWD,
respectively. The Co-Regional Area Coordinators shall provide all
administrative/management services for their respective employees of record in
accordance with all applicable federal, state, local laws and regulations, merit
system rules, and collective bargaining agreement rules and practices. (See
attachment A for complete list of documents currently included in all Regional
and PROMISE JOBS Master Agreements.)
2.2.
Policy guidelines for Workforce Development Center operations will be jointly
agreed upon by appropriate IWCC and IWD representatives and will comply with
applicable personnel and labor relations policies of both entities.
2.3
In the absence of the IWD Co-Regional Area Coordinator, personnel issues
involving IWD employees will be the responsibility of the IWD Division
Administrator for the Workforce Development Center Administration (WDCA) or
their Designee. In the absence of the IWCC Co-Regional Area Coordinator,
personnel issues involving IWCC employees will be the responsibility of the
Executive Director of Economic and Workforce Development or their Designee.
IWCC shall permit the IWCC Co-Regional Area Coordinator to participate in staff
2.4
development, training, and management meetings required by IWD.
IWCC & IWD shall be responsible for the payment of their respective Co-
2.5
Regional Area Coordinators' salary and personnel benefits according to its
 Page 1 of 11
Region 13 Co-Regional Area Coordinators 28e Dec 2009
existing policies.   IWCC shall be responsible for the payment of all applicable
federal and state withholding taxes and social security taxes for its Co-Regional
Area Coordinators. Additionally, IWCC shall carry a policy of workers
compensation, and at its sole expense, employer's liability insurance for its Co-
Regional Area Coordinator to the extent and in the amounts required by law.
IWCC, at its sole expense, shall pay all unemployment compensation taxes for
its Co-Regional Area Coordinator to the extent and in the amounts required by
law.  All fringe benefits provided the IWCC Co-Regional Area Coordinator will be
in accordance with IWCC policy.
2.6
Selection, evaluation and termination of the Co-Regional Area Coordinators will
remain the sole responsibility of the respective employer of record. Upon request,
the parties shall provide each other with comments concerning potential
candidates for the Co-Regional Area Coordinators' position(s) and shall
periodically provide each other with comments concerning the performance of
the respective Co-Regional Coordinators in order to assist with program
development and monitoring.
2.7
IWD shall provide staff development and training services to ensure the Co-
Regional Area Coordinators are knowledgeable of IWD practices, procedures,
and policies.
2.8
Reserved for future use.
The Workforce Development Center Co-Regional Area Coordinators.
Section 3.
The IWCC Co-Regional Area Coordinator shall, at all times, be considered the
3.1
-
employee of IWCC and not an employee of IWD. The IWD Co-Regional Area
Coordinator shall, at all times, be considered the employee of IWD and not an 
employee of IWCC. (See attachment B for Co-Regional Area Coordinators job
description.)
3.2
The IWCC Co-Regional Coordinator shall advise the IWD Co-Regional Coordinator
of complaints and/or concerns regarding IWD agency personnel. The IWD Co-
Regional Coordinator shall advise the IWCC Co-Regional Coordinator of
complaints and/or concerns regarding IWCC personnel. Any disciplinary action of
personnel will be sole responsibility of the employer of record for individual
employees. Although Co-Regional Coordinators will provide input and comments
regarding performance appraisals for integrated center staff, performance
appraisals remain the sole responsibility of the employer of record for individual
employees.
3.3
When notifying IWCC of any annual or sick leave requests, the Co-Regional Area
Coordinators shall also inform the WDCA Division Administrator or their Designee.
3.4
The Co-Regional Area Coordinators shall attend all regularly scheduled meetings
of the IWD regional managers and joint administrators, as well as any other
required meeting called by the WDCA Administrator or their Designee. The Co-
Regional Area Coordinators will inform the WDCA Administrator or their Designee
of conflicts that may prohibit attendance.

Section 4.
Compensation.
Reserved for future use.
Effective Date of Agreement.  This Agreement shall be effective when the
Section 5.
following conditions are completed:
5.1
The Agreement is signed by IWD and IWCC.
5.2
The Agreement or a recordable form of this Agreement is recorded by the Polk and
Pottawattamie County Recorders.
The Agreement is filed with lowa Secretary of State.
5.3
Term of Agreement. This Agreement shall be in effect beginning July 1, 2009,
Section 6.
and ending June 30, 2010, with the option to renew for two (2) additional one-year
terms. This Agreement may be terminated at any time, by either party, for any
reason upon at least sixty (60) days written notice in advance of the specified
termination date.
Section 7.
Termination.  This Agreement may be terminated in any of the following
circumstances:
a)  At IWD or IWCC discretion, without cause, after sixty (60) days written
notice to the other party by FAX with hard copy to follow by overnight
delivery.
b) As a result of default under this Agreement.
c)   As a result of the termination or reduction of funding to IWD.
d) Due to bankruptcy, insolvency, or receivership.
Authorization. Each party to this Agreement represents and warrants to the other
Section 8.
that (1) it has the right, power, and authority to enter into and perform its
obligations under this Agreement; and (2) it has taken all requisite action
(corporate, statutory, or otherwise) to approve execution, deliver, and performance
of this Agreement, and this Agreement constitutes a legal, valid, and binding
obligation upon itself in accordance with its terms.
The Vice President of Business Services of IWCC and the IWD Administrator of
the Division of Workforce Development Center Administration will be responsible
for administration of this Agreement.
Section 9.
Default.
The occurrence of any one or more of the following events shall constitute cause
9.1
for IWD or IWCC to declare the other party in default of its obligations under this
Agreement:
a)  Non-performance of this Agreement.
b)  A failure of either party to make substantial and timely progress toward
performance of the Agreement.
c) A failure of either party's work product and services to conform with any
specifications noted herein.

Region 13 Co-Regional Area Coordinators 28e August-2009
d) A repeated exhibition of defects in the services delivered by either party,
causing serious disruption of use or downtime over a six month period.
e)  A breach of provisions related to intellectual property.
f) A failure to make payments required under this Agreement.
g) A breach of any term of this Agreement.
9.2
IWCC or IWD shall not be considered to be in default under this
Agreement if its performance is delayed or made impossible by an Act of
God, floods, fires, strikes, a freight embargo or similar events; but in each
such case, the delay or impossibility must go beyond the reasonable control
and without the fault of IWCC or IWD. In event of such delay, the
scheduled date of delivery shall be extended on a day-to-day basis until
delivery of performance is possible and feasible.
9.3
IWCC shall not be liable for indirect, special, or consequential damages
resulting from a breach of this Agreement.
9.4
Notice of Default. IWD or IWCC shall issue a written notice of default
providing therein a sixty (60) day period in which the other party shall have an
opportunity to cure, provided that cure is possible and feasible. If, after opportunity
to cure, the default remains, IWD or IWCC may do one of the following:
a)  Exercise any remedy provided by law,
b)   Terminate this Agreement as set forth in Section 7 of this Agreement.
Section 10.
Walver.  Except as specifically provided for in a waiver signed by duly authorized
representatives of IWD and IWCC, failure by either party at anytime to require
performance by the other party or to claim a breach of any provision of the
Agreement shall not be construed as affecting any subsequent breach or the right
to require performance with respect thereto or claim a breach with respect thereto.

AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE CITY OF SIOUX CITY, IOWA, AND MAIN

BUDGET.
WHEREAS, the City of Sioux City, lowa, (hereinafter "City") has, pursuant to Chapter 386,
Code of lowa, created the Sioux City Main Street Self-supported Municipal Improvement
District; and
WHEREAS, Main Street Sioux City Corporation, an Iowa non-profit corporation, (hereinafter
"Corporation") has been created for the purpose of conducting and administering a main street
project in Sioux City, lowa; and
WHEREAS, City and Corporation desire to enter into an agreement, pursuant to Chapter 28E,
Code of lowa, for the operation and administration of the Sioux City Main Street Self-supported
Municipal Improvement District; and
WHEREAS, the Sioux City Main Street Self-supported Municipal Improvement District
Operation Agreement between the City and the Corporation, attached hereto and by this
reference incorporated herein, should be approved as to form and content; and
WHEREAS, the fiscal year 98/99 budget is attached hereto and by this reference made a part
hereof and should also be approved as to form and content.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF SIOUX
CITY, that the Sioux City Main Street Self-supported Municipal Improvement District Operation
Agreement between the City and the Corporation, referred to in the preamble hereof, be and
the same is hereby approved as to form and content.
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that the Mayor and City Clerk be and they are hereby authorized
and directed to execute said agreement for and on behalf of the City of Sioux City, lowa.
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED that the fiscal year 98/99 budget attached hereto be and the
same is hereby approved.
BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED that the City Clerk be and she is hereby authorized and directed
to file executed copies of said agreement with the lowa Secretary of State and the Recorder of
Woodbury County, lowa.

SIOUX CITY MAIN STREET SELF-SUPPORTED
MUNICIPAL IMPROVEMENT DISTRICT
OPERATION AGREEMENT
WHEREAS, the City of Sioux City, Jowa, (hereinafter "City") has, pursuant to Chapter 386, Code
of lowa, created the Sioux City Main Street Self-supported Municipal Improvement District; and
WHEREAS, Main Street Sioux City Corporation, an Iowa non-profit corporation, {hereinafter
"Corporation") has been created for the purpose of conducting and administering a main street
project in Sioux City, Iowa; and
WHEREAS, City and Corporation desire to enter into an agreement, pursuant to Chapter 28E,
Code of Iowa, for the operation and administration of the Sioux City Main Street Self-supported
Municipal Improvement District.
NOW, THEREFORE, it is agreed by and between the City and Corporation as follows:
1. Duration: The duration of this agreement shall be for a period of five years commencing on
July 1, 1998, unless otherwise terminated by the parties.
2. Organization: The Corporation's board of directors shall administer this agreement and the
City's Sioux City Main Street Self-supported Municipal Improvement District program.
3. Purpose: The purpose of the board of directors acting hereunder shall be:
a. The administration of the Sioux City Main Street Self-supported Municipal Improvement
District, (hereinafter "District").
b. The administration of the Sioux City Main Street Self-supported Municipal Improvement
District Operation Fund, (hereinafter "Operation Fund").
c. To encourage and support the redevelopment of the central business district of the City of
Sioux City, Iowa. Such redevelopment shall include, but not be limited to, reducing the
vacancy rate in office and commercial property in the District and carrying out activities as
will increase the taxable value of property in the District.
4. Duties and responsibilities of board of directors: The duties and responsibilities of the
board of directors acting hereunder shall be:
a. Hiring and employing a central business district development coordinator and such other
administrative employees as shall be necessary to carry out the purposes and functions of
the District.
b. To employ such consultants, engineers, architects and other professionals as are necessary
to carry out the purposes and functions of the District.
c. To incur such expenses, make such purchases and enter into such agreements and
functions of the District all in accordance with the budget hereinafter provided.
d. Immediately upon the execution of this agreement and then on or before the 1st day of
May in each year of the term of this agreement prepare an annual budget for the fiscal
year commencing July 1 and ending June 30. Such budget shall be submitted to the City's
city council for its approval (at least as to such portion of the Corporation's budget as
represented the City's contribution for the District program).
e. Conduct an annual audit and submit a financial report to the City's city council no later
than one hundred twenty days after the close of the fiscal year.
f. Submit to the City's city council an annual performance report which shall update the
City's present Main Street Report indicators. The initial report shall update the Main
Street Report indicators to reflect the status of such indicators as of July 1, 1998 and
succeeding reports shall update such indicators to reflect their status at the end of each
fiscal year. Such performance reporting shall be performed and documented in such a
manner as to determine the effectiveness of the program in meeting the purpose of the
program as defined in Section 3.
g. Administer a revolving loan program for the purpose of achieving the purpose of the
District as defined in Subsection 3.c. hereof.
5. Duties of City:  The City shall pay annually to Corporation at such time as the funds are
collected and received by the City:
a. The proceeds from Operation Fund levy payable in equal monthly installments at the
beginning of each month; and
b. Sales tax revenues (economic development) to be used solely for funding the revolving
loan program referred to in Subsection 4.g. hereof. Such sales tax revenues shall be made
available at the beginning of each fiscal year. The maximum amount that will be made
available at the beginning of each fiscal year shall be $50,000.00 less any uncommitted
funds remaining from the prior year. The maximum amount that will be available during
the term of this agreement shall not exceed $150,000.00;
all in accordance with the Corporation's budget (paragraph 4.d. hereof) as approved by the
City.
6. Termination: Either party may terminate this agreement upon 120 days advance written
notice to the other party.
a.  All obligations currently outstanding and budgeted for in the budget (paragraph 4.d.
hereof) shall be paid from the funds provided for in paragraph 5 hereof. All remaining
funds in Corporation's possession or control shall be immediately paid to City.
b. All personal property purchased by Corporation with the budgeted funds (paragraph 4.d.
hereof) shall be turned over to and delivered to City by Corporation.
. .
7. Reservation of authority:  Nothing herein shall be interpreted or construed so as to limit the
legislative discretion of the City's city council under Iowa Code Chapter 386 with respect to
the expenditure of the Operation Fund levy or the approval of the annual budget of the
Corporation

Contract Law Enforcement Agreement
Hardin County Sheriffs Office & The City of Radcliffe
It is hereby agreed by and between the Hardin County Sheriffs Office and the
Hardin County Board of Supervisors, herein and after refereed to as Hardin County and
the City of Radcliffe, herein referred to as the City, a public agency and political sub-
division of the State as defined in the Iowa Code Chapter 28E.2 that:
1. The Hardin County Sheriffs Office will provide the City with Law Enforcement
services. These services will include, but not limited to:
A. Radar operations to control speed.
B. Issuing violations under city ordinances, excluding animal control
ordinances, at request.
C. Housing inmates who have been incarcerated under a city ordinance
without additions cost to the city.
D. Serve abatement notices upon request.
E. Periodically checking commercial building for unlocked doors and
trespassers.
F. Investigate traffic accidents and complaints.
G. Dispatch of the City Fire Department, Ambulance and First Responders.
H. Staff a twenty-four hour E-911 Dispatch Center
Provide Investigative services to investigate crimes and conduct on-going
I.
investigations.
J. Provide Drug Enforcement services by the Multi-County Drug Task
Force.
K. Supply schools or community clubs & organizations with Officers and
materials for special programs upon request.
L. Routine patrol and special patrol upon request of the City.
M. Supply fully equipped patrol cars with radio, lights, siren and all related
equipment. Gasoline, oil & tires, and other vehicle maintenance.
Uniforms for the Officers and all the necessary personal equipment.
N. Telephone services to answer calls from the City.
O. Regular Office Hours of a minimum of one hour per week at City Hall.
Dates and times to be determined by the Sheriff.
2. In consideration for the Law Enforcement Services above described, the City will
pay a per capita rate of:
Twenty-three dollars ($23.00) based on the 2000 census figure of 607 residents,
which amounts to the sum of $13,961.00 starting July 1, 2009.
Year 2008 Document 3823
2 of 4
Twenty-three dollars and twenty five cents ($23.25) based on the 2000 census
figure of 607 residents which amounts to the sum of $14,112.75 starting July
1,2010
Twenty-three dollars and fifty cents ($23.50) based on the 2000 census figure of
607 residents, which amounts to the sum of $14,264.50 starting July 1, 2011.
Twenty-three dollars and seventy five cents ($23.75) based on the 2000 census
figure of 607 residents, which amounts to $14,416.25 starting July 1, 2012.
The contract shall be paid in equal monthly installments to the Hardin County
Sheriff's Office commencing July 1, 2009.
3. Law Enforcement policy, regulations and other matters relating to the
Employment of the Hardin County Deputy Sheriffs are to be solely determined
By the Hardin County Sheriff. The Hardin County Sheriffs Office will provide
Law enforcement services twenty-four hours a day in such a manner as to afford
Maximum possible law enforcement to all citizens of the county to whom the
Sheriff owes a statutory or contractual obligation for such services. The time,
place and manner in which these services are implemented shall be in the sole
discretion of the Hardin County Sheriffs Office.
4. The period of this agreement shall commence on July 1, 2009 and shall continue
Until June 30, 2013. It is further agreed that this agreement shall be automatically
renewed for one year periods until affirmative action to rescind its provision is
taken by either party not later than ninety (90) days notice prior to it's expiration.
5. In accordance with Chapter 28E, Code of Iowa, a copy of this agreement shall be
Filed with the Secretary of State and recorded with the Hardin County Recorder.
Signatures will include the Mayor & City Clerk, the Hardin County Sheriff, the
Hardin County Auditor and the members of the Hardin County Board of
Supervisors.

28E AGREEMENT
FOR THE ADMINISTRATION/MANAGEMENT
OF WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT IN REGION 7
This 28E Agreement (Agreement) is made and entered into this 1st day of July, 2011, and
ending on June 30, 2012, by and between the lowa Workforce Development (IWD) and
Hawkeye Community College (HCC). The parties agree as follows:
Section 1.
Purpose.  The purpose of this Agreement is to establish a procedure for hiring a
Regional lowa Works Director in Region 7 and to provide for the employment and
terms of employment of the Regional lowa Works Director.
Section 1.1
Identity of the Parties: Iowa Workforce Development (IWD), which is a duly
created state department, is authorized, among other things, to provide and fund
workforce development programs. IWD's state administrative address is 1000
East Grand Avenue, Des Moines, Iowa 50319. Hawkeye Community College is
authorized among other things, to provide and fund workforce development
programs. HCC's address is 1501 East Orange Road, Waterloo IA 50704. This
Agreement does not create any separate legal or administrative parties or
entities.
Section 2.
Responsibilities of Parties.
2.1
IWD shall provide administration/management services for HCC employees
located at the Waterloo Workforce Development Center and any satellite centers
in Region 7. These services will be provided by the Regional lowa Works
Director, who shall be employed by IWD. The Regional lowa Works Director shall
provide all administrative/management services in accordance with all applicable
federal, state, local laws and regulations, merit system rules, and collective
bargaining agreement rules and practices. (See attachment A for complete list of
documents currently included in all Regional and PROMISE JOBS Master
Agreements.)
2.2.
Policy guidelines for Workforce Development Center operations will be jointly
agreed upon by appropriate HCC and IWD representatives and will comply with
applicable personnel and labor relations policies of both entitles.
2.3
In the absence of the Regional lowa Works Director, personnel issues involving
IWD employees which require the involvement of IWD administration will be the
responsibility of the Division Administrator for the Workforce Development Center
Administration (WDCA) or their Designee.
2.4
HCC shall permit the Regional lowa Works Director to participate in staff
development, training, and management meetings required by IWD.
2.5
IWD shall be responsible for the payment of the Regional lowa Works Director's
salary and personnel benefits according to its existing policies. IWD shall be
solely responsible for the payment of all applicable federal and state withholding 
taxes, social security taxes, workers compensation, employer's liability and
Region 7 Regional lowa Works Director 28e May 2011
Page 1 of 11
unemployment compensation taxes. All fringe benefits provided the Regional
lowa Works Director will be in accordance with IWD policy.
2.6
Selection, evaluation and termination of the Regional Iowa Works Director will be
within the joint discretion of HCC and IWD.  HCC shall provide IWD with its
comments concerning potential candidates for the Regional lowa Works
Director's position and shall periodically provide IWD with its comments
concerning the performance of the Regional Iowa Works Director in order to
assist IWD with its evaluation. IWD will notify HCC when the evaluation is being
developed, a deadline for HCC comment submission, and a signed copy of the
completed evaluation for HCC records.
2.7
IWD shall provide staff development and training services to ensure the Regional
lowa Works Director is knowledgeable of IWD practices, procedures, and
policies.
2.8
Reserved for future use.
The Workforce Development Center Regional Iowa Works Director.
Section 3.
3.1
The Regional Iowa Works Director shall, at ail times, be considered the employee
of IWD and not an employee of HCC. (See attachment B for Regional lowa Works
Director job description.)
3.2
The Regional Iowa Works Director shall consult with the WDCA Division
Administrator or their Designee and the Department of Administrative Services
(DAS) personnel officer assigned to IWD before taking any disciplinary action
against any IWD employee.  Joint review by both the Regional lowa Works Director
and the WDCA Division Administrator or their Designee will precede any
performance appraisal and related action for any IWD employee.
3.3
When notifying IWD of any annual or sick leave requests, the Regional lowa Works
Director shall also inform HCC.
The Regional Iowa Works Director shall attend all regularly scheduled meetings of
3.4
the IWD regional managers and joint administrators, as well as any other required
meeting called by the WDCA Administrator or their Designee. The Regional lowa
Works Director will inform the WDCA Administrator or their Designee of conflicts
that may prohibit attendance.
Section 4.
Compensation.
Reserved for future use.
Effective Date of Agreement.  This Agreement shall be effective when the
Section 5.
following conditions are completed:
5.1
The Agreement is signed by IWD and HCC.
5.2
The Agreement or a recordable form of this Agreement is recorded by the Polk and
Black Hawk County Recorders.

5.3
The Agreement is filed with lowa Secretary of State.
Term of Agreement. This Agreement shall be in effect beginning July 1, 2011,
Section 6.
and ending June 30, 2012, with the option to renew for two (2) additional one-year
terms. This Agreement may be terminated at any time, by either party, for any
reason upon at least sixty (60) days written notice in advance of the specified
termination date.
Section 7.
Termination.  This Agreement may be terminated in any of the following
circumstances:
a)  At IWD or HCC discretion, without cause, after sixty (60) days written notice
to the other party by FAX with hard copy to follow by overnight delivery.
b) As a result of default under this Agreement.
c)  As a result of the termination or reduction of funding to IWD.
d)  Due to bankruptcy, insolvency, or receivership.
Authorization.  Each party to this Agreement represents and warrants to the other
Section 8.
that (1) it has the right, power, and authority to enter into and perform its
obligations under this Agreement; and (2) it has taken all requisite action
(corporate, statutory, or otherwise) to approve execution, deliver, and performance
of this Agreement, and this Agreement constitutes a legal, valid, and binding
obligation upon itself in accordance with its terms.
The President of HCC and the IWD Administrator of the Division of Workforce
Development Center Administration will be responsible for administration of this
Agreement.
Section 9.
Default.
9.1
The occurrence of any one or more of the following events shall constitute cause 
for IWD or HCC to declare the other party in default of its obligations under this
Agreement:
a)  Non-performance of this Agreement.
b) A failure of either party to make substantial and timely progress toward
performance of the Agreement.
c) A failure of either party's work product and services to conform with any
specifications noted herein.
d)  A repeated exhibition of defects in the services delivered by either party,
causing serious disruption of use or downtime over a six month period.
e)  A breach of provisions related to intellectual property.
f) A failure to make payments required under this Agreement.
g) A breach of any term of this Agreement.
HCC or IWD shall not be considered to be in default under this
9.2
Agreement if its performance is delayed or made impossible by an Act of
God, floods, fires, strikes, a freight embargo or similar events; but in each 
such case, the delay or impossibility must go beyond the reasonable control 
and without the fault of HCC or IWD. In event of such delay, the
scheduled date of delivery shall be extended on a day-to-day basis until
delivery of performance is possible and feasible.

to cure, the default remains, IWD or HCC may do one of the following:
a) Exercise any remedy provided by law,
b) Terminate this Agreement as set forth in Section 7 of this Agreement.

Section 18.
Entire Agreement.  This Agreement represents the entire agreement between the
parties and neither party is relying on any representation which may have been
made which is not included in this Agreement.
Section 19.
Writing Required. This Agreement may be amended or modified only in writing
signed by all parties.
Section 20.
Headings or Captions.  The section headings or captions are for identification
purposes only and do not limit or construe the contents of the sections.
Section 21.
Not a Joint Venture.  Nothing in this Agreement shall be construed as creating or 
constituting the relationship of a partnership, joint venture, or other association of
any kind or agent/principal relationship between the partles.  Each party shall be
deemed to be an independent contractor contracting for services and acting toward 
the mutual benefits expected to be derived from this Agreement.  No party, unless
otherwise specifically provided for in this Agreement, has the authority to enter into
any contract or create any obligation or liability on behalf of, in the name of, or
binding upon another party to this Agreement.
Section 22. 
Cumulative Rights.  The various rights, powers, options, elections, and remedies
of either party, provided in this Agreement, shall be construed as cumulative and

by law, and shall in no way affect or impair the right of either party to pursue any

Binding Effect.  All the terms, provisions, and conditions of this Agreement shall

LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES CONTRACT
On this 13 day of Manch , 2009, the City of Collins and Story
County, Iowa, enter into the following agreement:
The Story County Sheriff's Office will provide the City of Collins, Iowa with
1.
law enforcement services. These services will include but not be limited to:
A.
Radar operations to control speed.
B.
Issuing violations under city ordinances (excluding animal control
ordinances) upon request.
C.
Housing inmates who have been incarcerated under a city ordinance.
Service of abatement notices on request.
D.
Periodically checking commercial buildings for unlocked doors and
E.
trespassers.
F.
Investigation of traffic accidents and complaints.
G.
Dispatch of city fire departments and first responders.
H.
Staffing a 24 hour E911 dispatch center.
Providing a detective division to investigate crimes and conduct
I.
on-going invest gations.
J.
Investigation of drug-related offenses.
K.
Supplying schools or community clubs with officers and materials
for special programs and talks upon request.
L.
Routine patrols and special patrols upon request.
M.
Supply fully equipped patrol cars with radio, lights, siren, and all
related equipment, gasoline and oil, tires, and maintenance, uniforms, and
all other personal equipment.
2.
In consideration for the law enforcement services above described, the City of
Collins, Ia. will pay a per capita rate of $43.75 (based on the 2000 census of
499) to Story County, Iowa, which amounts to the annual sum of $21,831.25.
This shall be paid in equal quarterly installments to the Story County Sheriff on
July 1, October 1, January 1, and April 1. Any per capita increase in contract
cost for the following year shall be negotiated by December for the next fiscal
year. For the purposes of this contract, fiscal year shall be from July 1, through
June 30, of the following year.
AGREEMENT

The Sheriff shall be the administrator of this Agreement. Law Enforcement
3.
policy, regulations, and matters pertaining to the employment of the Sheriff's
personnel shall be determined solely by the Sheriff. The time, place, and manner
in which these services are implemented shall be in the sole discretion of the
Sheriff. The Mayor, Mayor Pro Tem, and the City Administrator shall be
authorized to make requests to the Sheriff for performance of specific law
enforcement services as specified in this Agreement.
4.
The initial term of the Agreement shall be automatically extended for successive
one-year periods upon the same terms and conditions provided by this
Agreement for the initial term, unless this Agreement is terminated or modified
by the express election of either City or County as hereinafter provided.
Modification to this contract may be made by mutual consent of both parties.
5.

Signatures will include the Mayor of Collins, the City Clerk of Collins, the

28E AGREEMENT
FOR THE SHARING OF STAFF BETWEEN
IOWA WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT AND MATURA ACTION CORPORATION
This 28E Agreement (Agreement) is made and entered into this _25____ day of May, 2015, and
ending on June 30, 2015, by and between the lowa Workforce Development (IWD) and
MATURA Action Corporation (MATURA). The parties agree as follows:
Section 1.
Purpose.  The purpose of this Agreement is to provide for the employment and
terms of employment of the Workforce Management Analyst/WIOA Transition
Planning & Direct Service/Policy Coordinator (Policy Coordinator).
Identity of the Parties: Iowa Workforce Development (IWD), which is a dulv
Section 1.1
created state department, is authorized, among other things, to provide and fund
workforce development programs. IWD's state administrative address is 1000
East Grand Avenue, Des Moines, lowa 50319. MATURA Action Corporation is
authorized among other things, to provide and fund workforce development
programs. MATURA's address is 215 N. Elm Street, Creston IA 50801. This
Agreement does not create any separate legal or administrative parties or
entities.
Section 2.
Responsibilities of Parties.
2.1
MATURA shall provide a staff person for Workforce Innovation and Opportunity
Act (WIOA) transition planning assistance as part of a state level team. These
services will be provided by the Policy Coordinator, who shall be employed by
MATURA. The Policy Coordinator shall provide all administrative/management
services in accordance with all applicable federal, state, local laws and
regulations, merit system rules, and collective bargaining agreement rules and
practices. (See attachment A for complete list of documents currently included in
all Regional Master Agreements.)
2.2.
Policy guidelines for sharing of this staff person will be jointly agreed upon by
appropriate MATURA and IWD representatives and will comply with applicable
personnel and labor relations policies of both entities.
2.3
Reserved for future use.
2.4
MATURA shall permit the Policy Coordinator to participate in staff development,
training, and policy/planning meetings required by IWD.
2.5
MATURA shall be responsible for the payment of the Policy Coordinator's salary
and personnel benefits according to its existing policies. MATURA shall be
solely responsible for the payment of all applicable federal and state withholding
taxes and social security taxes. Additionally, MATURA shall carry a policy of
workers compensation, and at its sole expense, employer's liability insurance for
the Policy Coordinator to the extent and in the amounts required by law.
MATURA, at its sole expense, shall pay all unemployment compensation taxes
for the Policy Coordinator to the extent and in the amounts required by law.  All
28e policy coordinator April 2015 MATURA IWD
 Page 1 of 13
fringe benefits provided the Policy Coordinator will be in accordance with
MATURA policy.
2.6
Selection, evaluation and termination of the Policy Coordinator will be within the
joint discretion of MATURA and IWD. IWD shall provide MATURA with its
comments concerning potential candidates for the Policy Coordinator position
and shall periodically provide MATURA with its comments concerning the
performance of the Policy Coordinator in order to assist MATURA with its
evaluation. MATURA will notify IWD when the evaluation is being developed, a
deadline for IWD comment submission, and a signed copy of the completed
evaluation for IWD records.
2.7
IWD shall provide staff development and training services to ensure the Policy
Coordinator is knowledgeable of IWD practices, procedures, and policies.
2.8
Reserved for future use.
Section 3.
The Workforce Development Center Policy Coordinator.
3.1
The Policy Coordinator shall, at all times, be considered the employee of MATURA
and not an employee of IWD. (See attachment B for Policy Coordinator job
description.)
3.2
Reserved for future use.
3.3
When notifying MATURA of any annual or sick leave requests, the Policy
Coordinator shall also inform the WIOA State Director or their Designee.
3.4
The Policy Coordinator shall attend all regularly scheduled meetings of the IWD
regional managers and joint administrators, as well as any other required meeting
called by the WSD Administrator or their Designee. The Policy Coordinator will
inform the WIOA State Director or their Designee of conflicts that may prohibit
attendance.
Section 4.
Compensation.
IWD will pay MATURA the lesser of:
The Policy Coordinator's "salary expense," or
(a)
{b}
The highest step of a Workforce Program Coordinator classification plus any
additional items included in the definition of salary expense below which are
not included as part of the Workforce Program Coordinator classification.
"Salary expense" includes base salary, payroll taxes, unemployment insurance and
worker's compensation insurance premiums, fringe benefits, travel, the Federally
negotiated indirect rate, and per diem but does not include bonuses that may be
received by the Policy Coordinator for work at MATURA.
Policy Coordinator 28e April 2015
 Page 2 of 13
For the purposes of this agreement, IWD will reimburse travel and per diem 
expenses at only the rate which is used by the employer of record, in this case
MATURA.
IWD will pay MATURA on a monthly basis in, arrears.  "Salary expense" shall be
that actually paid or incurred by MATURA. MATURA will provide a monthly invoice 
of the Policy Coordinator's salary expense to the WIOA State Director or their
Designee for approval prior to payment. IWD will provide said approval to
MATURA within 15 days of receipt.
Any percentage increase in the base salary in excess of the percentage increase
for a Workforce Program Coordinator classification shall be as agreed between
MATURA and IWD.
All out-of-state travel to be reimbursed by IWD must have prior approval by the
Workforce Services Division Administrator or their Designee, and the Director,
using the "Request for Travel Authority-Out of State Travel" form.
MATURA shall maintain books, records and documents which sufficiently and
properly document and calculate all charges billed to IWD throughout the term of
this Agreement for a period of at least five (5) years following the date of final
payment or completion of any required audit, whichever is later.
MATURA shall permit the Auditor of the State of lowa or any authorized
representative of the State or Department; and where federal funds are involved,
the Comptroller General of the United States or any other authorized
representative of the United States government; to access and examine, audit,
excerpt and transcribe any directly pertinent books, documents, papers, electronic
or optically stored and created records or other records of MATURA relating to
orders, invoices, or payments or any other documentation or materials pertaining to
this Agreement. MATURA shall not impose a charge for audit or examination of the
books and records.

Section 9.
Default.
The occurrence of any one or more of the following events shall constitute cause
9.1

performance of the Agreement.

specifications noted herein.

causing serious disruption of use or downtime over a six month period.
e) A breach of provisions related to intellectual property.
f) A failure to make payments required under this Agreement.
g) A breach of any term of this Agreement.
9.2
MATURA or IWD shall not be considered to be in default under this
Agreement if its performance is delayed or made impossible by an Act of
God, floods, fires, strikes, a freight embargo or similar events; but in each
such case, the delay or impossibility must go beyond the reasonable control
and without the fault of MATURA or IWD. In event of such delay, the
scheduled date of delivery shall be extended on a day-to-day basis until
delivery of performance is possible and feasible.
9.3
MATURA shall not be liable for indirect, special, or consequential damages
resulting from a breach of this Agreement.

providing therein a sixty (60) day period in which the other party shall have an
opportunity to cure, provided that cure is possible and feasible. If, after opportunity
to cure, the default remains, IWD or MATURA may do one of the following:
a) Exercise any remedy provided by law,
b)   Terminate this Agreement as set forth in Section 7 of this Agreement.

Conditions. Any indemnification hereunder shall be subject to the prior

of the State of lowa and the allotment of funds by the lowa Department of

with a detailed estimate of any expected claim, loss, liability, damage and/or

allotment. Indemnification is further conditioned on the following:
(i)
MATURA shall promptly give the State of lowa written notice (bv
overnight mail) of any expected, threatened, or actual claim, loss, liability,
damage or expenses.
(ii)
MATURA and the above-mentioned indemnified, shall at all times
cooperate with the State, both in document production and personnel
time.
To the extent that MATURA is indemnified under this section, the State
(iii)
shall have the right to hire and direct counsel in the defense of MATURA.
(iv)   To the extent that MATURA is indemnified under this section, the State
shall, after consultation with MATURA, make all decisions regarding anv
claim, threatened litigation, litigation, or settlement in connection with any
claim, loss, liability, damage or expense which may be asserted against

(v) The indemnification provisions contained herein, in no way limits the

Section 13.
No Indemnification.  The State of lowa shall not be responsible for action taken

Section 14. 
Obligations Beyond Agreement Term.  This Agreement shall remain in full force
and effect to the end of the specified term or until terminated or cancelled pursuant
to this Agreement.  All obligations of IWD and MATURA incurred or existing under
the Agreement as of the date of expiration, termination, or cancellation will survive 
the expiration, termination, or cancellation of this Agreement.
Section 15.
Third Party Beneficiaries.  There are no third party beneficiaries to this
Agreement. This Agreement is intended only to benefit IWD and MATURA.
Section 16.
Assignment and Delegation.  This Agreement may not be assigned, transferred,
or conveyed in whole or in part by either party without the prior written consent of
the other party.
Section 17. 
Choice of Law and Forum.  The terms and provisions of this Agreement shall be
construed in accordance with the laws of the State of Iowa.  Any and all litigation or
actions commenced in connection with this Agreement shall be brought in Creston,
lowa, in the lowa District Court for Union County. This provision shall not be
construed as waiving any immunity to suit or liability which may be available to the
State or to MATURA.
Section 18.
Entire Agreement. This Agreement represents the entire agreement between the
parties and neither party is relying on any representation which may have been
made which is not included in this Agreement.
Section 19.
Writing Required. This Agreement may be amended or modified only in writing
signed by all parties.
Section 20.
Headings or Captions.  The section headings or captions are for identification
purposes only and do not limit or construe the contents of the sections.
Section 21.
Not a Joint Venture. Nothing in this Agreement shall be construed as creating or
constituting the relationship of a partnership, joint venture, or other association of 
any kind or agent/principal relationship between the parties. Each party shall be
deemed to be an independent contractor contracting for services and acting toward 
the mutual benefits expected to be derived from this Agreement.  No party, unless
otherwise specifically provided for in this Agreement, has the authority to enter into
any contract or create any obligation or liability on behalf of, in the name of, or
binding upon another party to this Agreement.
Section 22.
Cumulative Rights.  The various rights, powers, options, elections, and remedies
of either party, provided in this Agreement, shall be construed as cumulative and 
no one of them is exclusive of any rights, remedies or priorities allowed either party
by law, and shall in no way affect or impair the right of either party to pursue any
other equitable or legal remedy to which either party may be entitled as long as any
default remains in any way unremedied, unsatisfied, or undischarged.
Section 23.
Severability. If a provision of this Agreement is determined by a court of
competent jurisdiction to be invalid or unenforceable, such determination shall not 
affect the validity of enforceability of any other part or provision of this Agreement, 
unless such invalid or unenforceable provision goes to the very essence of the
Agreement.

Time is of the Essence. Time is of the essence with respect to the performance
of the terms of this Agreement.
Section 25.
Binding Effect. All the terms, provisions, and conditions of this Agreement shall
be binding upon and inure to the benefit of the parties hereto and their respective
successors, assigns and legal representatives.
