ATTACHMENT B
Job Description
Contract Workforce Management Analyst/WIOA Transition Planning
and Direct Service/Policy Coordinator
Under the supervision of the WIA/WIOA/TAA Work Unit Supervisor, through 28E
agreement/contract, the WIOA Transition Planning and Direct Service/Policy Coordinator is
responsible for working closely with the state Workforce Services Field Operations team advising
and assisting in the transition planning for WIOA.  This analyst will assist in the development and 
drafting the State Workforce Plan, drafting program policies and procedures, maintaining the WIA
Program Handbook, drafting grant proposals and requests for proposal, and coordinating
communication with WIA program service providers and the One-Stop System partners. In
addition, the coordinator will have general research and analysis, strategic planning, project 
development, and coordination of service responsibilities. This temporary contract position will
serve as an advisor and liaison between direct service provision and state staff in the shaping of 
policy throughout the transition to WIOA and will possess a minimum of two years' experience in 
field operations in a local One-Stop. Specific job duties include:
.
Acquires and maintains a comprehensive knowledge base of State and national workforce
trends, issues, and opportunities.
.
Interprets federal or state legislation, regulations and policy to establish state policies and
procedures governing the programs; may draft administrative rule and handbook policies
for this purpose.
.
Analyzes developments in state and federal legislations and regulations to assess the
impact on current state and regional program operations and recommends appropriate
policy/process revisions, or operational strategies in anticipation of such changes.
.
Observes, tracks, and provides input as appropriate to workforce initiatives and, pending 
legislation emanating from the Executive or Legislative branch.
Participates in the development of the State Workforce Plan to include coordinating and
.
gathering input from all related constituencies. Drafts major portions of the plan and
coordinates the overall development, review, and submittal of the document.
Provides assistance, as requested, to the IWD Board, and to other State planning councils
•
or groups.
•
Develops program policies and procedures and disseminates that information through field
memos, technical assistance notices, and similar communication systems.
.
Develops or revises policy and procedures contained in the WIA Handbook and assumes
responsibility for maintaining that document.
•
Drafts language for Administrative Rule revisions in accordance with proposed changes in
State policy or new federal requirements.
Region 14 Shared Position 2015
Page 11 of 13
•
Reviews regional operational policies and procedures to ensure conformity with state and
federal requirements; provides guidance on establishing or revising such policies.
.
Participates in quality improvement projects.
o
Participates in quality assurance reviews.
.
Develops reports on workforce and training programs at both State and sub-state levels.
•
Based on research and analysis of agency goals and opportunities, proposes new projects
or initiatives for consideration by the WIA work unit, WIA service providers or partner
agencies.
•
Develops proposals or offers in response to Requests for Proposal or Solicitations for
Grant Application.
•
Provides input or drafts language for inclusion in project descriptions or proposals that are
being developed by other IWD or partner-agency staff.
.
Performs additional data acquisition or analysis to support proposals and projects being
developed. Prepares technical reports, public information materials, or other
documentation as necessary.
•
Maintains familiarity and connections to other State agencies that are commonly partners
with IWD in projects or initiatives. The Departments of Economic Development,
Education, and Human Services are particularly noted in this responsibility.
•
Delivers training to direct service providers in the transition to WIOA.

CASS COUNTY AND THE CITY OF MASSENA
28E JOINT MUTUAL AID AGREEMENT
THIS JOINT MUTUAL AID AGREEMENT is made pursuant to Chapter 28E of the Iowa
Code. It shall be known as the "Cass County and the City of Massena 28E Joint Mutual Aid
Agreement" and shall be adopted by Cass County and the City of Massena by resolution.
RECITALS
WHEREAS the following law enforcement agencies wish to enter into a cooperative law
enforcement agreement: Cass County Sheriff's Office and City of Massena (hereinafter referred
to as "Agency" or "Agencies").
WHEREAS the Agencies wish to enter into this Agreement for the purpose of engaging in
mutual aid law enforcement support.
WHEREAS the Agencies wish to perform whatever law enforcement services are necessary as
part of the 28E Joint Mutual Aid Agreement to enforce the laws of the State of Iowa.
WHEREAS no new or separate law enforcement entity or agency is created by the Agreement.
WHEREAS this is a contract for law enforcement services between the two Agencies, but does
not create a unified law enforcement district as provided in Iowa Code Sections 28E.21 through
28E.30.
THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED that the Agencies mutually agree as follows:
1. DURATION. The duration of this Agreement shall be ten years from the starting
date of July 1, 2008 and ending June 30, 2018.
2. PURPOSE. The purpose of said Agreement is for Cass County and the Cass County
Sheriff's Office to contract with the City of Massena and to provide law enforcement services to
the City of Massena without creating a unified law enforcement district.
3. AUTHORIZATION. The Cass County Sheriff's Office shall be authorized to
provide full law enforcement aid and services to the City of Massena for purposes of effectuating
this Agreement. For purposes of this Agreement, this shall mean the enforcement of any State of
Iowa code violations including investigation, charging, all necessary paperwork and related
duties to law enforcement and City of Massena code violations, both criminal and municipal.
However, the City of Massena shall be responsible for the preparation of any City of
Massena code violations and municipal infractions to include serving such notices in the manner
included in the City of Massena Code. The Cass County Sheriff's Office will file any charges
arising from such notices. The Cass County Sheriff's Office shall be responsible for serving any
City of Massena code violations to any citizen(s) in the City of Massena.
l
The Cass County Sheriff's Office shall be responsible for any in-court witness
appearances, depositions and testimony for the officer's only for any State of Iowa code
violations. The compensation in paragraph seven (7) of this Agreement shall cover any such
duties. The City of Massena shall be financially responsible for securing and obtaining the
presence of any other witnesses for any of its city code violations.
4.  ORGANIZATION.  No separate legal or administrative entity is created by this
Agreement. The Cass County Sheriff and the City of Massena shall be the joint board
responsible for administering the joint or cooperative undertaking. All personal property shall be
paid for as delineated in this agreement. No real property shall be acquired, held or disposed of
by the Agencies.
5. ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS AND ADMINISTRATION. Because no separate
legal or administrative was created by this Agreement, a Joint Board consisting of the Cass
County Sheriff who shall represent Cass County and the City Mayor who shall represent the City
of Massena shall be responsible for the joint administration of this Agreement.
Further, the Agencies agree that any property, vehicles or equipment purchased by the
Cass County Sheriff's Office acquired or held during this Agreement shall be the property of the
Cass County Sheriff's Office and shall remain the property of said Agency following the
termination of this Agreement. It shall be the responsibility of the Cass County Sheriff's Office
for the maintenance and upkeep of any property, vehicles or equipment purchased by the Cass
County Sheriff's Office as a result of this Agreement.
The parties agree that the City of Massena does not have any law enforcement equipment
or property and that none shall be purchased by the City as a result of this agreement.
All parties agree that this agreement does not provide for any administrative services by
the Cass County Sheriff's Office.
6. MEETINGS. No regular scheduled meetings are anticipated as a result of this
Agreement between the Agencies. However, should any meetings occur for the purpose of
discussing any administration of this Agreement, said meetings shall be held pursuant to Iowa
Code Chapter 21 and held as part of the regularly scheduled monthly city council meetings in the
City of Anita and in accordance with all publication requirements of this Section and chapter 21.
2
7. COMPENSATION. For purposes of this agreement, all parties agree that the
amount that the City of Massena shall pay to the Cass County Sheriff's Office each fiscal year
for law enforcement services shall be as follows:
$0.00
Year 1
Fiscal year 2008-2009
$10.00 per capita
Fiscal year 2009-2010
Year 2
$10.00 per capita
Fiscal year 2010-2011
Year 3
$10.00 per capita
Fiscal year 2011-2012
Year 4
$10.00 per capita
Year 5
Fiscal year 2012-2013
$15.00 per capita
Fiscal year 2013-2014
Year 6
$15.00 per capita
Fiscal year 2014-2015
Year 7
$15.00 per capita
Fiscal year 2015-2016
Year 8
$15.00 per capita
Year 9
Fiscal year 2016-2017
$15.00 per capita
Fiscal year 2017-2018
Year 10
All parties agree that any amounts for compensation as stated herein are based upon the
2000 U.S. Census population for the City and said amounts may need to be adjusted following
the U.S. Census population for the City in 2010.
Said payments shall be used for employee wages, insurance, equipment, training,
benefits, vehicle maintenance and upkeep.
Said payments shall be made in biannual installments.  The first installment is due and
payable on or before October 30th of each year. The second installment is due and payable on or
before April 30th of each year.
If at any time the City of Massena requests an itemized breakdown of any expenditures,
the Cass County Sheriff shall provide same to the City of Massena.
8. LIABILITY. Pursuant to Iowa Code Section 28E.7, nothing in this Agreement shall
relieve cither public agency of any obligation or responsibility imposed upon it by law except as
provided in this section.
9. MODIFICATION, RENEWAL & TERMINATION.
The terms and conditions of this agreement may be modified for good cause and upon the
agreement and approval of the Cass County Sheriff and the City of Massena.
This Agreement shall terminate on June 30, 2018 unless the Agencies named herein
renew said Agreement by said date.
Termination may occur as long as six month written notice is given by the other party, unless
both parties agree to waive the six month termination period.
3
This contract is null and void if either party willfully breaches the terms of this agreement.
Breach may occur by the Cass County Sheriff not providing law enforcement services as agreed
upon. Breach may also occur by the City of Massena by not rendering timely payments for services
rendered.
Should changes in state law eliminate the need for communities to enter into a 28E
agreement to receive law enforcement coverage, this agreement shall terminate immediately unless
both sides agree to continue it.
10.  EFFECTIVE DATE OF AGREEMENT.  This Agreement shall become effective
between the governmental agencies stated herein upon the passage and execution by the
governing body of each governmental agency which is a party to this Agreement. The Clerk or
Auditor of each member shall furnish the other member agencies copies of the resolution
approving the Agreement and authorizing execution and a signed copy of the Agreement shall be
furnished to each party to this Agreement.
11.  OBLIGATIONS NOT EXCUSED.  Nothing in this Agreement made pursuant to
Chapter 28E shall relieve either agency of any obligation or responsibility imposed upon it by
law except any of the agreed upon responsibilities as delineated in the Agreement.
12.  FILING AND REPORTING.  Pursuant to Section 28E.8 of the Iowa Code, before
entry into force, this Agreement made pursuant to Chapter 28E shall be filed with the Secretary
of State of Iowa and shall also comply with all requirements in Iowa Code Section 28E.8.  This
agreement shall also be filed with the Cass County Recorder's Office.  Further the Agencies in
this agreement shall comply with all other reporting requirements in Iowa Code Section 28E.8.
13. CONSTRUCTION. This agreement includes all of the terms, conditions and full
intentions contemplated by all parties whose names are affixed herein.

WHEREAS, the City of Des Moines is a municipal corporation established under the laws of

corporation established under Iowa NonProfit Corporation Act, Chapter 504A for the purpose of

businesses, and is a Certified Development Corporation under the U.S. Small Business
Administration 504 Loan Program.
WHEREAS, by Roll Call No. 96-3445 dated October 7
, 1996
_, the City
Council of the City of Des Moines will consider the Economic Development Financing Incentive
Program as part of the City's 1996 Neighborhood Development Plan; and
WHEREAS, the PY96 Economic Development Financing Incentive Program involves joint
and cooperative action between the City and the Corporation in that the Corporation will be
acting as agent of the City in a Loan Injection Program with the SBA 504 Program and a
Revolving Loan Fund Program, as more fully described in the Economic Development
Financing Incentive Program to which this 28E Agreement is attached and by this reference
made a part thereof; and
WHEREAS, no new administrative agency is being created by this Agreement.
NOW, THEREFORE BE IT AGREED by the parties as follows:
That this Agreement shall be in effect for the PY96 Economic Development
ni
Financing Incentive Program, commencing January 1, 1996 and continuing until
December 31, 1996 or until the completion of the Program Year, if extended.
2.
That this Agreement is solely for the purpose of cooperative action by and
between The Corporation for Economic Development in Des Moines and City
of Des Moines for the promotion of the growth of business concerns,
particularly that of small businesses as more fully described in the project
design "Economic Development Financing Incentive Program" attached hereto.
3.
That the parameters of the cooperative action between the City and the
Corporation are governed by the project design and the Corporation cannot
exercise any more powers of the City than set forth therein.
4.
That the City of Des Moines shall provide staff to the Corporation consisting of
the assistance of two Development Financing Coordinators, supported by other
Office of Economic Development staff. The Corporation staff will market and
package Small Business Administration 504 Loan applications, Loan Injections
and Revolving Loan Fund applications and provide other assistance to the
Corporation consistent with the goal of encouraging economic development and
job creation in the City.
2.
That any and all monies within the accounts and all receipts from loans paid or
to be paid inclusive of interest thereon, for the Loan Injection and the Revolving
Loan Fund shall be and remain at all times the property of the City even though
under the administrative control of the Corporation; that the Corporation upon
the termination date of this Agreement will assign all monies in said accounts
and the right to all future receipts on outstanding loans whether principal or
interest, to the City.
6.
That as to all loans granted under the SBA 504 Program, the City will provide
administrative, clerical, and supervisory staff to the Corporation for the purpose
of processing, packaging, and servicing loans in accordance with the rules and
regulations promulgated by the Smail Business Administration for such loans.
The revenues derived from the SBA 504 Program, which include one-time fees
equal to 1.5% of the debenture and ongoing servicing fees equal to .5% annually
of the oustanding debenture balance, and interest on the 504 Escrow Account,
and such other fees that may from time to time be derived from the SBA 504
Program, shall be disbursed as follows:
Fifty percent (50%) to the City of Des Moines, fifty percent (50%)
to The Corporation for Economic Development in Des Moines.
Earned interest in the SBA 503 account will be allocated on a prorata basis
to the City and the Corporation based on their respective balances in the
SBA 503 account at the time the interest is credited.
7.
That as to all loans granted under the Revolving Loan Fund Program and the
Loan Injection Program, the City will provide administrative, clerical, and
supervisory staff for the purpose of processing, packaging, and servicing of
loans in accordance with the Revolving Loan Fund and the Loan Injection
Program guidelines, which by this reference are made a part hereof as though
fully set forth herein and in accordance with HUD Rules and Regulations as to
Community Development Block Grant funding.
8.
That for PY96, it is the intent of the parties that a combined set aside of
$1 10,000 be available for use in the Revolving Loan Fund, Loan Injection
Program, and Business Technical Assistance as deemed appropriate by the
CEDDM. This set aside will be a combination of Revolving Loan Fund and
Loan Injection Program repayments received in PY96 and previous years. Loan
repayments received in excess of the set aside will be available for use in the
Economic Development Financing Incentive (EDFI) program.
9.
The Corporation will retain private counsel for necessary legal services, except
in those circumstances where the City and the Corporation Board decide that
use of City legal counsel is appropriate. The scope of services and payment for
services shall be determined between the CEDDM and The City on a case-by-
case basis.
-2-
The selection, supervision, training and performance review of the Development
10.
Financing Coordinators, as well as all other staff to the Corporation, is the
responsibility of the City Manager through the Office of Economic
Development and shall be coordinated with the President of the Corporation for
Economic Development in Des Moines. If CEDDM, at its discretion, deems
staff training on the SBA 504 program as appropriate and necessary, it may pay
for such expenses out of non-EDFI funds.
11.
That use of the Loan Injection Program (direct loan in combination with SBA
504 Program where the business is locating in certain designated areas) is to be
determined by the Corporation's Loan Review Committee based on its
determination of the needs of the business.
12.
The Office of Economic Development of the City of Des Moines may be used
as the registered office for the Corporation,
13.
The Corporation's Board of Directors shall review and concur on the Economic
Development Financing Incentive Program Project Design with regard to the
role of The Corporation for Economic Development in Des Moines.
14.
This is the entire Agreement of the parties herein. No modification of said
Agreement is permitted except by written notification mutually entered into.

AGREEMENT
BETWEEN THE CITY OF HOSPERS, IOWA AND SIOUX COUNTY, IOWA
RELATING TO THE PROVISION OF LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES
THIS AGREEMENT, consisting of two (2) pages, is made between the City of Hospers,
Iowa, a municipality of the State of Iowa (hereinafter "Hospers") and Sioux County,
Iowa (hereinafter "County").
WHEREAS, Hospers wishes to contract with County for law enforcement services
within the corporate limits of Hospers; and
WHEREAS such Agreements are authorized in Iowa Code §28E;
NOW THEREFORE, Hospers and County agree as follows:
1) County agrees, through the Sioux County Sheriff ("Sheriff") to provide law
enforcement services within the corporate limits of Hospers, including but not
limited to the following:
a) Patrol, traffic enforcement and control, response to complaints or calls,
investigations, emergency service, service of civil documents, and other tasks
typically performed by a law enforcement agency.
b) Sheriff shall be responsible for administrative duties associated with the function
of said law enforcement services.
2) County shall furnish the necessary equipment and personnel to carry out the services
provided for in this agreement.
1
3) Hospers agrees to pay County for the law enforcement services provided by Sheriff.
The payment shall be in an amount to be determined by the Sheriff and the Board of
Supervisors of Sioux County as is necessary to carry out the law enforcement
functions stated in this agreement. Such payments shall be made to the Sheriff's
Office on a quarterly basis, payable as follows: July 1, 2014; October 1, 2014;
January 1, 2015; April 1, 2015. The total amount for this contract period has been
set at: $77,476.
4) This Agreement shall be irrevocable for the duration of the contract period.
Thereafter either party may discontinue participation by providing written notice to
the other no later than May 1st of the current year.
5) This agreement shall be effective on the 1st day of July, 2014 and shall run to the 1st
day of July 2015. Thereafter, at the option of the Hospers City Council, and the
Sioux County Board of Supervisors, with the consent of the Sheriff of Sioux County,
this agreement may be renewable for successive periods not to exceed one (1) year.
APPROVED by the Hospers, Iowa City Council.

28E AGREEMENT BETWEEN
NORTH POLK COMMUNITY SCHOOL DISTRICT
AND
POLK COUNTY, IOWA
FOR
SCHOOL RESOURCE OFFICER PROGRAM
This Agreement for School Resource Officer Program ("Agreement") made and entered
into this 17 of August, 2017, by and between the NORTH POLK COMMUNITY SCHOOL
DISTRICT, an Iowa school corporation organized and existing under the provisions of lowa
Code Chapter 274, (hereinafter referred to as "District") and POLK COUNTY, IOWA, an lowa
county organized and existing under the provisions of Iowa Code Chapter 331, (hereinafter
referred to as "County").
This Agreement is entered into pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 28E of the Code of
Iowa. This Agreement is between two public agencies for joint or cooperative action. Neither a
separate legal or administrative entity, nor joint board, will be created for administration of this
Agreement. The Polk County Sheriff or designee and the District's Superintendent of Schools or
designee shall be designated as the Administrators of this Agreement for purposes of Iowa Code
Chapter 28E.
After exceution of this Agreement by the District and the City, it shall be filed in the
office of the Iowa Secretary of State as required by law. This Agreement shall be effective when
executed and filed as set forth above and shall continue for an initial period of five (5) years
unless sooner terminated as provided herein.
ARTICLE I
General
The parties share a mutual interest to maintain an atmosphere in the District schools
where school staff and students have a safe learning environment. The School Resource Officer
program presents a cooperative approach towards addressing various collaborative efforts to
maximize student safety, performance, and wellbeing.
School Resource Officer programs are recognized nationally as programs that effectively
cstablish positive working relationships between schools and law enforcement. The School
Resource Officers (SROs) will assist school administrators by taking immediate action when law
enforcement intervention is warranted. Additionally, the SROs will provide guidance and
support in assisting school staff; students and parents with a variety of non-emergency law
enforcement related matters.
Selection
1. The SROs will be certified, non-probationary law enforcement officers,
l
2. The SROs will maintain at least the minimum qualifications required for employment as a
law enforcement officer with the Polk County Sheriff's Office.
3. The SROs will have working knowledge of the child welfare and juvenile justice system, as
well as community human services. The SROs will have exceptional public relations skills
and the ability to work well with all individuals in the District, including administrators,
staff, students, and families.
4. The Polk County Sheriff or designee shall select the officer for assignment as SRO in
consultation with, and subject to the approval of, the District Superintendent or designee.
Supervision
1.
The Polk County Sherriff's Office shall assign a higher ranking deputy to supervise the
officer(s) assigned to the School Resource Officer program.
In addition to providing direction for the SRO, the SRO supervisor will serve as a liaison
2
between the District and County in order to resolve matters of mutual concern,
3.
The SRO supervisor, in consultation with the school principal or designee, will complete
a performance evaluation of the SRO during March of each year.
The District shall provide requested information and reports to the SRO supervisor to
4.
facilitate this evaluation.
Assignment
SROs will be assigned cooperatively by the District and County. At least one (1) SRO
1.
will be assigned to the District primarily for use at the North Polk High School. The
SROs may perform duties at other District schools with the approval of the SRO
supervisor.
The SRO shall be assigned on a full-time basis during those hours that the schools are in
2.
regular session. The SRO shall be on campus from 1/2 hour prior to the start of class until
1/2 hour after classes are dismissed. During their daily tour of duty, the SRO may be off
campus performing such tasks as may be required by the assignment.
3.
Regular working hours may be adjusted on a situational basis with the mutual approval of
the Superintendent or designee, SRO supervisor, and SRO. These adjustments may be to
attend school-rolated events requiring the presence of a law enforcement officer. Such
adjustments will be in accordance with the Fair Labor Staudards Act and any collective
bargaining agreement which may apply to employees of the Polk County Sheriff's
Office.
2
4.
The SRO may be temporarily reassigned by the County during school holidays or
vacations and/or during times of emergencies.
The SRO shall notify the SRO supervisor and Superintendent or designee of planned
5.
vacation days. All reasonable action will be taken to minimize the effect of the SRO's
absence by the County, including provision of a back-up SRO. If the County is not able
to provide an SRO for any reason, the County shall proportionally reduce the amount
charged to the District for each day that an SRO is not available.
ARTICLE II
Duties and Responsibilities of School Resource Officers
İ.
The SRO shall enforce state laws and local ordinances, and coordinate directly with the
school principal or designee to provide security during school hours.
2,
The SRO should be present at the school during times of high activity such as the
beginning and end of the school day and during the lunch period(s). The SRO should
monitor the parking lots during high traffic times.
3.
The SRO should be familiar with all law enforcement case information pertaining to
schools, students and the neighborhood surrounding the campus.
4.
The SRO should facilitate and assist with law enforcement investigations involving
victims, witnesses and suspects associated with the schools.
The SRO shall act as an instructor or facilitate specialized law enforcement or public
5.
safety related short-term programs at the schools when invited to do so by District
officials. The SRO shall coordinate with the school principal or designee to teach the
DARE curriculum and assist with other drug prevention programs as needed.
The SRO shall assist District officials in developing plans and strategies to prevent,
6.
minimize or respond to dangerous situations which may occur on campus or during
school sponsored events.
The SRO will adhere to School Board policy which does not conflict with state or federal
7.
law and the Polk County Sheriff's Office General Order and Policies.
8.
The parties acknowledge that the SRO may from time to time acquire confidential
information concerning the District, students, and others in the course of performing
duties under this Agreement. It is agreed that such non-law enforcement information or
records shall be kept confidential by the SROs in compliance with District policy, and
federal, state, and local law.
3
The SRO shall take law enforcement action as required in accordance with the Polk
9.
County Sheriff's Office policies and directives. As soon as practicable, the SRO shall
make the principal or designee(s) of the school aware of such action. The SRO shall take
appropriate law enforcement action against intruders and unwanted guests who may
appear at the school and school related functions, to the extent that the SRO may do so
under the authority of law. Whenever practicable, the SRO should advise the principal or
designee(s) of the intended action when requesting additional law enforcement assistance
on campus.
The SRO will be available for conferences with students, parents and faculty members in
10.
order to assist them with law enforcement problems or in matters of crime prevention.
The SRO shall coordinate with the Juvenile Court Officer assigned to the District.
Confidential information obtained pursuant to Iowa Code Chapter 232 or in proceedings
relating to juveniles shall not be disclosed except as provided by law or court order.
When necessary, the SRO shall give assistance to other law enforcement officers in
11.
matters regarding his/her school assignment. However, the SRO will not be available to
conduct investigations extraneous to his/her assigned SRO responsibilities for the sake of
convenience or expediency without prior approval from the SRO supervisor.
By mutual agreement between designated District officials and the SRO supervisor, the
12.
SRO will, in accordance with established overtime procedures as limited by the overtime
budget and in accordance with any collective bargaining agreement which may apply to
employees of the Polk County Sheriff's Office, attend school functions such as sporting
events or social events that require the presence of a law enforcement officer.
The SRO will become familiar with community agencies that offer assistance to youth
13.
and their families such as mental health clinics, drug treatment centers, and protective
shelters. The SRO may make referrals to such agencies and will notify school
administration of any such referral as soon as practicable,
The SRO shall not act as a school disciplinarian and shall.not take administrative action
14.
or levy sanctions on behalf of any District employee. However, if the principal or
designee believes an incident is a violation of the law, the principal or designee may
contact the SRO and the SRO shall then determine whether law enforcement action is
appropriate. The SRO is not to be used for lunchroom duties, hall monitors, bus duties,
or other monitoring duties. If there is a problem in one of these areas the SRO may assist
the school until the problem is solved.
15.
The SRO will work in uniform attire. Exceptions may be made with approval of the SRO
supervisor. The SRO shall carry a regulation sidearm and other approved/assigned police
equipment necessary to perform the essential functions of the position in accordance with
sheriff office policy and regulations and applicable law.
4
16.
The parties acknowledge that the SRO is not responsible for providing continuous
surveillance for any twenty-four (24) hour period unless in the opinion of the County the
threat of criminal activity or risk to safety and security warrants such surveillance.
17.
The number of hours of service provided, the number of patrol vehicles, or the number of
SROs may be increased or decreased upon mutual agreement of both parties.
18.
The SRO shall make monthly reports to the Superintendent or designee, including a
summary of the law enforcement activities occurring within the District. The District
agrees that its officers, agents and employees shall cooperate fully with the County in the
performance of the County's duties.
19.
The SRO shall perform other duties as mutually agreed upon by the school principals and
the SRO supervisor so long as the performance of such duties is reasonably related to the
SRO program as described in this Agreement and so long as such duties are consistent
with Polk County Sheriff's Office rules and regulations,
ARTICLE III
Rights and Duties of the District
The District shall provide to the full-time SRO the following materials and facilities
which are deemed necessary to the performance of the SRO's duties:
1. Access to a properly lighted private office equipped with a telephone to be used for general
business purposes;
2. A location for files and records which can be properly locked and secured;
3. A desk with drawers, a chair, worktable, filing cabinet and office supplies;
4. Email and internet access; use of a District device to access student management systems;
5. Secretarial assistance,
6.
A location within the SRO's private office for the County to supply a secured
weapon/evidence storage safe. The District shall facilitate proper mounting of the storage
safe.
ARTICLE IV
Employment Status of School Resource Officer
SROs shall remain employees of the County and shall not be an employee of the District
for any purpose. As the employer of the SROs, the County shall be responsible to recruit, hire,
train, assign, supervise, evaluate, discipline, and/or discharge the SROs, and shall be responsible
5
for payment of all wages and benefits due the SROs. The District and the County acknowledge
that the SROs shall remain responsive to the chain of command of the Polk County Sheriff's
Office.
ARTICLE V
Replacement of School Resource Officer
1. In the event that a principal of a school to which the SRO is assigned believes that the SRO is
not effectively performing his/her duties and responsibilities, the principal shall consult with
the SRO and the SRO supervisor. If the situation is not resolved, the principal shall
recommend to the Superintendent that the SRO be removed from the SRO program and shall
state the reasons therefore in writing. Within a reasonable time after receiving the
recommendation from the principal, tho Superintendent shall advise the Polk County Sheriff
or designee of the principal's request. If the County so desires, the Superintendent and
Sheriff or their designees shall meet with the SRO to mediate or resolve any problems which
may exist. At such meeting, the SRO supervisor and/or specified members of the staff of the
school to which the SRO is assigned may be required to be present. If, within a reasonable
amount of time after commencement of such mediation, the problem cannot be resolved or in
the event mediation is not sought by the Sheriff, then the SRO shall be removed from the
program and replaced.
2. In the event of a vacancy in the position of SRO, or in the case of long-term absence by a
SRO, the Superintendent or designee will work with the Polk County Sheriff or designed to
resolve the vacancy.
ARTICLE VI
Financing of the School Resource Officer Program
The District agrees to pay the County an amount not exceeding the following amounts
over the term of this agreement for the services agreed upon above. The County shall invoice the
District monthly. The District shall make payment to the County within thirty (30) days of
receipt of invoice.
Cost to District Not to Exceed
Fiscal Year
$32,676
2017-2018
$36,069
2018-2019
$39,647
2019-2020
2020-2021
$43,421
2021-2022
$47,401
In the event the County is unable to perform according to the Agreement, the County
shall proportionally reduce the amount charged to the District for each day the County is unable
to perform. Each party shall allow access to all records, documents and papers necessary for the
6
financial auditing of the parties' transactions. Appropriate records, documents and papers
necessary to conduct a financial audit shall be maintained a minimum of three (3) years.
Any cost increase to the County occurring as a result of action taken by the United States
or Iowa Government which increases the cost of wages, insurance for employees or other
benefits shall be borne by the District.
ARTICLE VII
Duration and Termination of Agreement
The term of this Agreement shall be effective upon signing and expire on June 30, 2022.
No extensions to this Agreement will be made. Either party may terminate this Agreement, with
or without cause, by providing written notice with not less than sixty (60) days notice. Upon
termination of this Agreement (a) the District will retain all desks, chairs, tables, filing cabinets,
provided technologies, access cards, building keys and other District property and (b) the County
will retain all motor vehicles, radios, cell phones, computers, cameras, storage safes and other
County property.
ARTICLE VIII
Insurance and Indemnification
l . Liability Insurance. The County and the District shall cach maintain Commercial General
Liability insurance for protection of each, respectively, from any liability arising out of any
accidents or other occurrence causing any injury and/or damage to any person or property
arising from the performance of their obligations under this Agreement due directly or
indirectly to the actions of the insured. Liability policies shall have limits of not less than
Two Million Dollars ($2,000,000) per occurrence,
2. Workers' Compensation/Employer's Liability Insurance. The County shall maintain
Workers' Compensation insurance for the SROs as statutorily required by the State of lowa
and Employer's Liability insurance in amounts not less than $100,000 per accident, per
employee, per disease and $500,000 in the aggregate.
3. Other Insurance Provisions. All required insurance shall be obtained from issuers of
recognized responsibility licensed to do business in the State of Iowa. Each party shall be
furnished with a certificate(s) of insurance required under this Agreement upon request.
Such policies shall not be modified or cancelled except upon at least thirty (30) calendar
days' prior written notice to the other party to this Agreement. It is specifically agreed that
the types and amounts of insurance specified above shall not limit or otherwise affect any
party's obligation to indemnify and hold the other party harmless as provided by the
indemnification provisions of this Agreement. The failure of any party to maintain the
insurance coverage and limits required by this Agreement shall be considered a material
breach of this Agreement. However, the failure of any party to declare another party to be in
7
material breach shall not be deemed a wavier by the other party of the right to claim a
material breach for a subsequent failure to maintain the required coverage or limits.
4. Indemnification by District. To the extent permitted by law, the District agrees to indemnify,
defend, and hold harmless the County, its officers, agents, and employees, against all claims,
suits, actions, debts, damages, costs, charges and expenses, including court costs and
attorney's fees, and against all liability for property damage and personal injury including
death resulting directly or indirectly there from, arising from any acts or omissions of the
District, either active or passive, or those of its agents, employees, assigns, or any other
person acting on its behalf in the performance of its obligations, duties, and responsibilities
imposed under this Agreement.
5. Indemnification by County. To the extent permitted by the Iowa constitution and applicable
law, the County agrees to indemnify, defend, and hold harmless the District, its officers,
agents, and employees, against all claims, suits, actions, debts, damages, costs, charges and
expenses, including court costs and attorney's fees, and against all liability for property
damage and personal injury including death resulting directly or indirectly there from, arising
from any acts or omissions of the County, either active or passive, or those of its agents,
employees, assigns, or any other person acting on its behalf in the performance of its
obligations, duties, and responsibilities imposed under this Agreement. The County, by
having such insurance does not waive the immunities and limitations afforded the County
and its employees by Chapter 670, Iowa Code
6. Waiver of Subrogation Rights. The County and the District each release the other from any
claim for recovery for any loss or damages to any of its property that is insured under valid
and collectible insurance policies to the extent of any recovery collectible under such
insurance. The County and the District shall cach waive and, to the extent allowed by law
cause its insurance underwriter to waive, its rights of subrogation with respect to Workers'
Compensation.
7. Claims. Each party shall notify the other party of any claim or any potential claim for bodily
injury or property damage to another arising out of actions taken under this Agreement as
soon as practical following knowledge of the claim or potential claim.
ARTICLE IX
Miscellaneous
1. Amendment. This Agreement may only be modified by written mutual agreement of the
partics.
2. Binding Effect. This Agreement shall be binding upon, and inure to the benefit of, the
parties and their successors and assigns. However, neither party may assign this Agreement
without the consent of the other party.
8
3. Severability. If any clause, provision or section of this Agreement shall, for any reason, be
held illegal or invalid by any court, the illegality or invalidity of such clause, provision or
section shall not affect any of the remaining clauses, provisions or sections, and this
Agreement shall be construed and enforced as if such illegal or invalid clause, provision or
section had not been contained herein. In case any agreement or obligation contained in this
Agreement is held to be in violation of law, then such agreement or obligation shall be
deemed to be the agreement or obligation of the parties to the full extent permitted by law.
4. Notices. All notices under this Agreement must be in writing and shall be deemed given when
either personally delivered, transmitted by confirmed facsimile or confirmed electronic mail
or when received by certified mail at the address below or at another address as designated by
a party.
North Polk Community School District

5. Supersedes. This Agreement supersedes all prior agreements between the District and the
County purporting to establish and finance a School Resource Officer Program.
6. Execution in Counterparts. This Agreement may be simultaneously executed in several
counterparts, each of which shall be an original and all of which shall constitute but one and
the same instrument.

28E AGREEMENT
FOR THE ADMINISTRATION/MANAGEMENT
of workforce development in Region 16
This 28E Agreement (Agreement) is made and entered into this 1st day of July, 2010, and
ending on June 30, 2011, by and between the lowa Workforce Development (IWD) and
Southeastern Community College (SCC).  The parties agree as follows:
Purpose.  The purpose of this Agreement is to establish a procedure for hiring a
Section 1.
Regional Iowa Works Director in Region 16 and to provide for the employment
and terms of employment of the Regional lowa Works Director.
ldentity of the Parties: Iowa Workforce Development (IWD), which is a duly
Section 1.1
created state department, is authorized, among other things, to provide and fund
workforce development programs. IWD's state administrative address is 1000
East Grand Avenue, Des Moines, Iowa 50319. Southeastern Community College
is authorized among other things, to provide and fund workforce development
programs. SCC's address is 1500 West Agency Road, West Burlington IA 52655.
This Agreement does not create any separate legal or administrative parties or
entities.
Responsibilities of Parties.
Section 2.
2.1
SCC shall provide administration/management services for IWD employees
located at the Burlington Workforce Development Center and any satellite
centers in Region 16. These services will be provided by the Regional lowa
Works Director, who shall be employed by SCC. The Regional lowa Works
Director shall provide all administrative/management services in accordance with
all applicable federal, state, local laws and regulations, merit system rules, and
collective bargaining agreement rules and practices. (See attachment A for
complete list of documents currently included in all Regional and PROMISE 
JOBS Master Agreements.)
2.2.
Policy guidelines for Workforce Development Center operations will be jointly
agreed upon by appropriate SCC and IWD representatives and will comply with
applicable personnel and labor relations policies of both entities.
In the absence of the Regional Iowa Works Director, personnel issues involving
2.3
IWD employees which require the involvement of IWD administration will be the
responsibility of the Division Administrator for the Workforce Development Center
Administration (WDCA) or their Designee.
2.4
SCC shail permit the Regional Iowa Works Director to participate in staff
development, training, and management meetings required by IWD.
2.5
SCC shall be responsible for the payment of the Regional lowa Works Director's
salary and personnel benefits according to its existing policies. SCC shall be
solely responsible for the payment of all applicable federal and state withholding 
taxes and social security taxes.  Additionally, SCC shall carry a policy of workers
compensation, and at its sole expense, employer's liability insurance for the
Page 1 of 11
Region 16 Regional lowa Works Director 28e April 2010
Regional lowa Works Director to the extent and in the amounts required by law.
SCC, at its sole expense, shall pay all unemployment compensation taxes for the
Regional lowa Works Director to the extent and in the amounts required by law.
All fringe benefits provided the Regional lowa Works Director will be in
accordance with SCC policy.
2.6
Selection, evaluation and termination of the Regional Iowa Works Director will be
within the joint discretion of SCC and IWD.  IWD shall provide SCC with its
comments concerning potential candidates for the Regional lowa Works
Director's position and shall periodically provide SCC with its comments
concerning the performance of the Regional Iowa Works Director in order to
assist SCČ with its evaluation. SCC will notify IWD when the evaluation is being 
developed, a deadline for IWD comment submission, and a signed copy of the
completed evaluation for IWD records.
IWD shall provide staff development and training services to ensure the Regional
2.7
Iowa Works Director is knowledgeable of IWD practices, procedures, and
policies.
Reserved for future use.
2.8
The Workforce Development Center Regional lowa Works Director.
Section 3.
The Regional Iowa Works Director shall, at all times, be considered the employee
3.1
of SCC and not an employee of IWD. (See attachment B for Regional lowa Works
Director job description.)
The Regional lowa Works Director shall consult with the WDCA Division
3.2
Administrator or their Designee and the Department of Administrative Services
(DAS) personnel officer assigned to IWD before taking any disciplinary action
against any IWD employee.  Joint review by both the Regional lowa Works Director
and the WDCA Division Administrator or their Designee will precede any
performance appraisal and related action for any IWD employee.
3.3
When notifying SCC of any annual or sick leave requests, the Regional lowa
Works Director shall also inform the WDCA Division Administrator or their
Designee.
3.4
The Regional lowa Works Director shall attend all regularly scheduled meetings of
the IWD regional managers and joint administrators, as well as any other required
meeting called by the WDCA Administrator or their Designee. The Regional Iowa
Works Director will inform the WDCA Administrator or their Designee of conflicts
that may prohibit attendance.
Compensation.
Section 4.
Reserved for future use.
Effective Date of Agreement.  This Agreement shall be effective when the
Section 5.
following conditions are completed:

Region 16 Regional Iowa Works Director 28a April 2010

Des Moines County Recorders.

The Agreement is filed with lowa Secretary of State.
Term of Agreement.  This Agreement shall be in effect beginning July 1, 2010,
Section 6.
and ending June 30, 2011, with the option to renew for two (2) additional one-year
terms. This Agreement may be terminated at any time, by either party, for any
reason upon at least sixty (60) days written notice in advance of the specified
termination date.
Termination.  This Agreement may be terminated in any of the following
Section 7.
circumstances:
a)  At IWD or SCC discretion, without cause, after sixty (60) days written notice
to the other party by FAX with hard copy to follow by overnight delivery.
b) As a result of default under this Agreement.

d)  Due to bankruptcy, insolvency, or receivership.

Development Center Administration will be responsible for administration of this

Section 9.
Default.

The occurrence of any one or more of the following events shall constitute cause

b)   A failure of either party to make substantial and timely progress toward
performance of the Agreement.
c)   A failure of either party's work product and services to conform with any
specifications noted herein.

causing serious disruption of use or downtime over a six month period.
e)   A breach of provisions related to intellectual property.

God, floods, fires, strikes, a freight embargo or similar events; but in each

AGREEMENT AND CONTRACT FOR AMBULANCE SERVICES
Between the
City of Gladbrook, located in Tama County, State of Iowa
And
Spring Creek Township, Tama County, State of Iowa
1. Public Entities
This agreement and contract shall be between the City of Gladbrook, hereafter referred to as "the
City," and Spring Creek Township, hereafter referred to as "the Township."
2. Area Service
Where available, the legal description of the area to be afford ambulance services as by this
Agreement is attached as Exhibit A to this Agreement. A map of the area described in Exhibit A
is attached to this agreement
3.
Equipment
It is further agreed that the City with own, maintain, house and staff the ambulance service under
this Agreement
Tax Levies
4.
It is agreed that the Trustees of the Township will levy enough taxes with the tax limitations
prescribed by the Code of lowa to pay the Township's agreed upon share of the ambulance
service maintenance, replacement and all other necessary expenditures to provide ambulance
service to the signatories.
5. Township Payments
It is agreed that the Township Clerk shall promptly transmit, on or before December first and
June first each year, tax monies received during the six months immediately preceding said dates
resulting from the ambulance service levies. Payments shall be in the amounts to pay costs
agreed to under the Agreement and shall be sent to the City Clerk of the City of Gladbrook. The
township agrees to pay 15 cents per 1,000 assess valuations for fiscal year 2017-2018 then shall
increase to 20.25 cents per 1,000 assess valuations for 2018-2019 and all future fiscal cycles.
6. Mutual Aid Agreements
It is agreed that the City's ambulance service may be used in the ambulance service areas outside
the area covered by this Agreement in accordance with mutual aid agreements between the City
and other cities to assist each other in the event of an extraordinary emergency.
7. Service to Other Areas
If the City wishes to serve a township or part of a township or city or part of a city not party to
this Agreement on an annual basis, it may do so as long as the fee assessed and collected is equal
to what the assessment would be under the formula used for the original entities involved herein,
calculated after considering the new costs and depreciation on inventory.
8. 
Insurance Coverage
The City shall provide and maintain the following insurance coverage from companies and
agents properly licensed and authorized to do business by the State of Iowa.
A. Public Liability: Including coverage for direct operation, independent contractors,
contractual liability and completed operations, with limits not less than:
a. Bodily Injury Liability
i. $1,000,000 each person
ii. $2.000.000 each occurrence
b. 
Property Damage Liability
i. $1.000.000 each occurrence
ii. $2.000.000 aggregate
B. Workers' Compensation: Including employer's liability in accordance with the
Workers' Compensation Laws of the State of Iowa
C. Malpractice Errors and Omissions: Coverage for all the personnel, officers, and
board members for errors and omissions in the performance of duties with a
maximum limit of no less than $1,000.000
9. Liability and Indemnification
The public entities that are parties to this Agreement shall, at all times during the term of this
Agreement and thereafter, indemnify, defend and hold one another harmless against all claims
and expenses, including legal expenses and reasonable attorneys’ fees, arising out of the death or
injury to any person or person or out of any damage to property and against any other claim,
proceeding, demand, expense and liability of any king whatsoever resulting from any action or
inaction related to either entity which is deemed by a court of law or arbitrator not to be an action
or inaction of the other entity.  Notwithstanding the above, each entity at all times reserves the
right to retain counsel of its own to defend its respective interests.
10. Terms of Agreement
The entities agree that this Agreement is the complete agreement of the parties and nothing
further may be utilized to explain, contradict, or nullify the agreement. The parties further agree
that this document is 6 pages and encompasses 16 numbered sections. Each part has had ample
opportunity to seek independent advice with regard to its terms.  If there are to be any changes to
this Agreement, they shall be done in writing and signed by all entities.
11. Jurisdiction, Venue, and Attorney's Fees
In the event there are any disputes that arise between the entities, all entities hereby consent and
agree to the jurisdiction of the State of Iowa and the venue of Tama County, Iowa.  All disputes
shall be decided according to the laws of the State of Iowa and prevailing entity shall be entitled
to reasonable attorney's fees.
12. Article Headings
The article headings contained in this Agreement are for reference purposes only and shall not
affect the meaning or the interpretation thereof.
13. Execution of Documents
The parties agree to timely execute any documents necessary to carry out the terms of this
Agreement. The parties further agree that this document may be executed outside the presence
of the other part and in separate counterparts.
14. Amendments
As required by Section 28E.8, Code of Iowa, this Agreement, before going into effect, must be
filed with the Secretary of State and recorded with the County Recorder of Tama County, Iowa.
The City Clerk of the City shall cause this Agreement to be recorded in the office of the county
recorder and filed with the Secretary of State prior to the effective date of this Agreement which
shall be deemed effective fifteen days subsequent to the last date of approval, below, by the
governing bodies designated. Any amendment, before adoption, must receive unanimous
approval of the governing bodies of the public entities that are signatories to this Agreement.  An
amendment is required to add another public agency as a signatory part to this Agreement.  Any
duly approved amendments to the Agreement shall be filed with the Secretary of State and
recorded in the office of the Tama County Recorder.
15. Term of Agreement
This agreement shall be in effect indefinitely starting July 1, 2017 and may be terminated and/or
amended by all parties by the resolutions of the city council and township trustees made at least
thirty (30) days prior to the first day of February next preceding the above date or any
subsequent February 151 thereafter.
16. Termination
In the event that any public entity that is party to this Agreement shall desire to withdraw or
terminate this Agreement, a written notice of withdrawal shall be completed and delivered to all
other public entities by hand delivery or certified mail by the first day of February.
Said withdrawal or termination shall not become effective until June 3061, and all current and -------
outstanding payments for service have been made by the Townships to the City.

28E CONTRACTUAL AGREEMENT FOR LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES
THIS CONTRACT (hereinafter, the “Agreement”) made and entered into this _28th_day of
November, 2016 by and between the City of Mount Vernon, lowa (hereinafter “Mount
Vernon”) and the City of Lisbon, lowa (hereinafter “Lisbon”). This Contract revokes and replaces
all previous Law Enforcement Assistance Agreements between the Cities of Mount Vernon and
Lisbon. This agreement does not affect the Agreement Establishing Mutual Aid Law
Enforcement Services (the “Mutuai Aid Agreement”) between Mount Vernon and Lisbon
WHEREAS, Lisbon is desirous of contracting law enforcement services with Mount Vernon, and
WHEREAS, Mount Vernon is agreeable to rendering such service on the terms and conditions
hereinafter set forth, and WHEREAS, Mount Vernon is agreeable to furnishing law enforcement
services to Lisbon as hereinafter set forth.
NOW, THEREFORE, pursuant to Chapter 28E of the Code of lowa, 2016, the parties agree as
follows:
1. Duration of Agreement.
The duration of this Agreement is November 28, 2016,
through June 30, 2017.  Thereafter this Agreement will be for a duration of one year,
beginning July 1, and through June 30 of each year, unless terminated by either party
according to this Agreement as defined in section 5 below.
2. No Entity Created.
No separate legal or administrative entity is created by this
Agreement.
3. Purpose of Agreement.    The purpose of this Agreement is to provide supplemented law
enforcment services to Lisbon.
4. Financing.
Lisbon shall finance the operation from general revenue.  Detailed
budgets and costs shall be kept by both parties.  Lisbon agrees to pay Mount Vernon a rate
of  $40.00 per hour for police services, payable quarterly on the 15th day of the first month
of each quarter.
5. Renewal.
The Agreement will automatically extend for an additional one year
period unless three months’ written notice of intent not to extend is given by either party.
6. Services to be provided.
a.   Mount Vernon agrees to provide law enforcement services within the corporate
limits of Lisbon, which services shall include but not be limited to the enforcement
of state statutes, where applicable, municipal ordinances, general patrol activities,
and the duties and functions of the type customarily rendered by professional law
enforcement officers to enforce the ordinances of the munincipal code of Lisbon and 
the statutes of the State of lowa by duly sworn and certified officers of Mount 
Vernon. Law enforcment services do not include civil process, including but not 
limited to the service of legal process or civil ordinance enforcement, or criminal 
investigations beyond those incidental to responding to a request for service.  The 
calculation of hours of law enforcement service is determined by the hours spent 
providing law enforcement services in Lisbon, as well as necessary followup work,
wherever performed, including but not limited to transporting arrestees and
completing paperwork associated with arrests and citations taking place in Lisbon. 
b. Mount Vernon agrees that it shall provide law enforcement services within the
corporate limits of Lisbon for up to 20 hours per week when Lisbon does not have an 
officer on duty. If in a given week Mount Vernon has already provided 20 hours of
law enforcmenet services and an emergency occurs in Lisbon while Lisbon has no
officer on duty, Lisbon agrees to pay Mount Vernon according to the rate set forth in 
paragraph 4 for all law enforcement services provided on an emergency basis. Law
enforcent services provided pursuant to the Mutual Aid Agreement do not count 
toward the up to 20 hours set forth in this paragraph. Lisbon may request, and
Mount Vernon in its sole discretion may agree to provide, additional hours of law
enforcement services pursuant to the terms and conditions of this Agreement at the 
rate set forth in paragraph 4.
c. The parties agree that during peak policing hours Mount Vernon will only provide
Lisbon mutual ald and shall respond to emergencies but will not provide any other
law enforcement services. “Peak policing hours” are defined as 7:00 p.m. Friday to
3:00 a.m., Saturday, and 7:00 p.m. Saturday to 3:00 a.m. Sunday and such other
hours as agreed upon by the Mount Vernon and Lisbon police chiefs
d.   Officers shall attend all law enforcement related court and administrative hearings
upon the request of Lisbon City Attorney or Lisbon City Officials. Lisbon shall pay the 
attorney fees, court costs, and any other expenses associated with the prosecution
of any case initiated by a Mount Vernon officer while providing law enforcement
services to Lisbon under this Agreement. Lisbon shall pay Mount Vernon for any
time spent by a Mount Vernon officer associated with attending any law
enforcement related court and administrative hearings at the rate set forth in
paragraph 4. This time shall not be included in the 20 hours of law enforcement 
services set forth in paragraph 6(b).
e. Officers shall, where possible file charges under City Ordinance of Lisbon, but if
Lisbon has no applicable ordinance, then the charge may be filed under applicable
state statute.
f. 
Mount Vernon shall make monthy reports to the Lisbon Chief of Police and Lisbon
City Administrator. These monthy reports shall include the enforcement activity,
number of calls, and other matters which the parties deem important to be included 
in these reports.
g.   The discipline of all officers in matters incident to performance of their services and
control of all personnel shall remain with Mount Vernon.  Mount Vernon shall also 
be responsible for training, hiring, firing, assignment and other discipline of their
employees.
h.   Mount Vernon shall hold Lisbon harmless for any liability arising out of Mount
Vernon's performance of this contract.  Lisbon shall, however, remain responsible
for any intentional or negligent acts of Lisbon, it officers or employees, that result in 
liability and damages to Mount Vernon or third parties.  Both Mount Vernon and
Lisbon shall provide their liability insurance to cover the operation and performance
of this contract.
7. Responsibility of the Mayor.
The Mayor of Lisbon shall be responsible for setting law
enforcement practices and standards for law enforcement services provided pursuant to 
this agreement, generally.  Said guidelines will be communicated directly to the Mount 
Vernon Police Chief by the Mayor.  Laws are to be enforced equally and without favor.
8. Specialty Personnel.
lf it becomes necessary for Mount Vernon to provide special
investigative, enforcement, photographic, or other services to Lisbon for the investigation 
or prosecution of any crime committed in Lisbon, Mount Vernon shall bill Lisbon on a
monthly basis for police services at the rate set forth in paragraph 4 and for expenses at the 
actual cost to Mount Vernon.  Mount Vernon agrees that the above services shall only be
necessary if the regular patrol officer is unable to perform the needed work due to the lack 
of experience, tranining, or availability.  It is anticipated by the parties that the above
services would only be required of the investigation of major felony matters.  The billing for
specialty services will be done by Mount Vernon.  An itemized statement will be prepared
and sent to Lisbon for the services and payment for the services will be sent to Mount
Vernon and placed in general fund as revenue.  Payments for services under this paragraph
shall be due 30 days from the date of the invoice.
9. Lisbon Non-Liability.
Lisbon shall not assume any liability for direct payment of any
salaries, wages or other compensation to any Mount Vernon personnel peforming services
herunder for Lisbon, or any liability other than provided in the contract.  Lisbon shall not be
liable for compensation or indemnity to any Mount Vernon employee for injury or sickness
arising out of his or her employment and Mount Vernon hereby agrees to hold harmless
Lisbon from any such claim.
10. Liability Insurance.
Each of the parties hereto agrees that they shall maintain the
same liability insurance coverage they now have in force to insure their respective interest
in this contract.  Each party may require proof of insurance and certification of insurance
from the other, and compliance with such a request shall not be unreasonably withheld.
11. Consultation with Lisbon. The Mount Vernon Police Chief shall make him or herself available
during normal working business hours to the City Council or Mayor of Lisbon to discuss law
enforcement services being provided to Lisbon.
12. Access.
All parties mutually agree to allow access to records, documents, and papers to
auditors of Lisbon and of Mount Vernon as allowed by Chapter 692 of the Code of lowa.
Such access shall be allowed until three years after the expiration date of this contract.
13. Third Party Claims,
Lisbon shall not be responsible for any act, injury, or damage
arising out of the performance of this contract due solely to the fault or negligence of
Mount Vernon.  Lisbon shall, however, be responsible for any act including acts of
negligence, that causes claims to be made by or against Mount Vernon or a third party.
Each party to this agreement shall be required to defend any action as their interests
appear.
14. Mount Vernon Non-Liability.
Mount Vernon and its officers and employees shall not be
deemed to assume any liability for intentional or negligent acts of Lisbon, its officers or
employees.  Lisbon shall hold Mount Vernon, its officer and employees harmless from, and
shall defend Mount Vernon, its officers and employees against any claim for damages
resulting therfrom.
15. Entire Agreement.
All parties state that they have obtained the necessary approval
and acceptance from their respective governing bodies to enter into this Agreement and 
that the above provisions constitute the entire and complete agreement between the
parties on this subject matter.
THE ABOVE CONTRACT is hereby entered into by the following authorized agents of the parties.

28E Agreement for Law Enforcement
This agreement made and entered into by and between IOWA COUNTY, IOWA, the
OFFICE OF IOWA COUNTY SHERIFF and the INCORPORATED CITY OF NORTH ENGLISH, IOWA.
Whereas, lowa Code Section 28E.12 provides that the City of North English may contract
for law enforcement services from the lowa County Sheriff.
Whereas, the City of North English desires to contract with the lowa County Sheriff's
Office to provide law enforcement services.
Whereas, it is necessary and desirable that a 28E Agreement be executed for the
duration of said law enforcement services.
Now it is agreed by and between each and all of the undersigned parties to the
following:
The lowa County Sheriff's Office will provide a minimum average of 40 hours of law
enforcement services per week to the incorporated area of North English, lowa. The services
will include, but not limited to patrol, investigative, student and public safety education
services.
The City of North English will pay the lowa County Sheriff's Office $94,859 per year
billed to the city quarterly by the Sheriff.
This agreement will be in force for a period of three (3) years beginning July 1, 2012 and
end at the end of the calendar day June 30, 2015.
Either party may cancel this agreement if notice is made in writing to the other party
within 90 days proceeding the next fiscal year.
Dated this 20 day of July, 2012.

DISPATCHING SERVICES CONTRA
THIS AGREEMENT, is entered into this Into day of Me
200 by and between
Story County, Iowa and the City of Nevada, Iowa and is duly authorized by Chapter 28E of the
Code of Iowa.
The City of Nevada has no office wherein the police department may receive or dispatch
telephone and radio messages on a 24 hour per day basis. Nevada agrees to the following terms
with the Story County Sheriff's Office.
1.
This contractual agreement shall commence on the first day of July, 2009 and shall
continue for one (1) year ending on June 30, 2010. The per capita charge shall
automatically increase by 4 percent or an amount equal to the U.S. Consumer Price
Index for all Urban Consumers (CPI-U) for a 12 month period, to be reviewed each
November, and increased the lesser amount. The new rate will begin on the first
day of each July.
2.
Story County shall be reimbursed by Nevada for its dispatching services at a rate of
$5.21 per capita (based on the 2000 census figure of 6658 the annual fee is
$34,688.18) This fee shall be paid in equal quarterly installments to the Story
County Sheriff's Office on July 1, October 1, January 1, and April 1.
The Sheriff of Story County and his deputies or duly designated representatives
3.
agree to receive in the Sheriff's Office or county jail, such telephone calls, teletype
messages, and radio messages as are directed to the Police Department and the Fire
Department of the City of Nevada, and transmit the same to the officers of the
respective departments.
The Sheriff of Story County and his deputies or duly designated representatives
agree to receive or dispatch telephone, radio and teletype messages on a 24 hour
per day basis in the Sheriff's Office or county jail as are directed to the Nevada
Wastewater Treatment Plant and transmit same to said department.
The Sheriff's Office's telephone number shall be included on the Automatic Dialing
Alarm System for the Water Department and Wastewater treatment Plant.
. Page 2
The Sheriff or Sheriff's Designee will provide the Nevada Police Department with
4.
copies of teletype messages of general and specific interest to all law enforcement
officers and agencies in Story County.
The Sheriff or Sheriff's Designee will provide a printed daily report to the Nevada
5.
Police Chief or the Chief's Designee of all phone calls received in the Dispatch
Center and other such calls for service and activities that are entered into the
Computer Aided Dispatch System for the Nevada Police Department.
6.
The Sheriff agrees to provide and allow the Nevada Police Chief or Chief's
Designee computer terminal access to the records contained in the Computer Aided
Dispatch System that pertain to the activities of the Nevada Police Department and
its officers.
7.
The Story County Sheriff shall keep in the Story County Jail, under his control and
supervision, any and all prisoners who have been committed to its care by the Chief
of Police of the City of Nevada, or his duly authorized agents or police officers, for
violation of the city ordinances of Nevada, Iowa, at no additional charge.
8.
The Sheriff and his deputies or duly designated representatives shall take
fingerprints and forward same of all persons arrested and brought into custody at
the Story County Jail by members of the Nevada Police Department to the Iowa
Division of Criminal Investigation and the Federal Bureau of Investigation as
required by State and Federal law.
The Sheriff agrees to allow the Nevada Police Chief or the Chief's Designee access
9.
to the criminal history and jail record files of all prisoners brought into custody at
the Story County Jail by members of the Nevada Police Department.
10.
The City of Nevada agrees to pay all medical and doctor expenses for injuries to or
sickness of their prisoners held on City of Nevada ordinance violations and all
other extraordinary expenses related to those prisoners which may occur and which
are not due to the negligence of Story County or its employees.
11.
Story County will furnish and maintain the necessary radio equipment to provide
the services named above (The City of Nevada will pay for their telephone service
on the designated police department line installed in the Sheriff's telephone
system.)
12.
In accordance with Section 28E.7 of the Code of Iowa, this agreement shall not
relieve any of the parties hereto of any obligation or responsibility imposed upon it
or them by law, except that to the extent of actual and timely performance thereof
by either of the contracting parties hereto, said performance may be offered in
satisfaction of the obligation or responsibility.
13.
No separate legal or administrative entity or organization shall be created by this
agreement; no separate budget shall be established and no tangible property shall
Page 3
be acquired which would require disposition upon the termination of this agreement.
The duly elected Sheriff of Story County, Iowa, and the duly appointed City
14.
Administrator of Nevada, Iowa, shall be joint co-administrators of this agreement
as provided by Section 28E.6(1) of the Code of Iowa.
15.
As joint co-administrators the duly elected Sheriff of Story County, Iowa, and the
City Administrator, shall develop the necessary procedures to effectively
administer this agreement including but not limited to addressing new situations
not covered by this agreement and conflict resolution.
16.
Story County shall file a copy of this agreement with the Secretary of State and
the County Auditor of Story County, Iowa and record a copy with the Story
County Recorder pursuant to Section 28E.8 of the Code of Iowa.
17.
This contract may be terminated by either party. Termination is effective at the
end of the current quarterly billing cycle and must be preceded with a minimum
30 day written notice to either party. Notice shall be accomplished by certified
mail or personal service.
18.
Any amendments or addendums to this Agreement shall be created and passed in
the same manner and with reference made to this original document.
19.
The initial term of the Agreement shall be automatically extended for successive
one-year periods upon the same terms and conditions provided by this Agreement
for the initial term, unless this Agreement is terminated or modified by the express
election of either City or County as hereinafter provided. Modification to this
Agreement may be made by mutual consent of both parties.

tolution No. 67 (2008/2
RESOLUTION NO. 67 (2008/2009)
A RESOLUTION TO ENTER INTO A 28E AGREEMENT WITH STORY COUNTY FOR
THE PROVISION OF DISPATCH AND JAIL SERVICES FOR FISCAL YEAR
2009/2010
WHEREAS, the City of Nevada has no facilities to house and care for prisoners
committed to jail for violation of City Ordinances, State or Federal Statutes; and
WHEREAS, the City has no office wherein the Police Department may receive or
dispatch telephone and radio messages on a twenty-four hour per day basis; and
WHEREAS, the Story County Sheriff's Department has such facilities; and
WHEREAS, the Story County Sheriff's Department has submitted to the City of Nevada
for its approval a proposed 28E Agreement concerning the matter, a copy of which is attached
to the Resolution and marked Exhibit "A" and incorporated herein as if set out in full; and
WHEREAS, it is in the best interest of the City of Nevada and the citizens thereof to
enter into the proposed 28E Agreement with the Story County Sheriff's Department.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED by the City Council of the City of Nevada,
Story, County, Iowa, that the City of Nevada shall contract with the Story County Sheriff's
Department for jail and dispatch services beginning July 1, 2009 and continuing through June
30, 2010 for the annual tee of $34,688.18. The Mayor and City Administrator are hereby
authorized to execute the agreement on behalf of the City.
AND APPROVED this 23rd day of March, 2009.
Donna K. Mosinski
Deputv City Clerk
